column2: Our foreign files by the City of Baltimore furnish us a few items of interest in addition to those which we published yesterday:

In a report given recently of a meeting held at Carmansville, by residents and others interested in the extension of the Eigth-avenue Railway, it was stated that Alderman BOOLE was opposed to the extension, and had been to a certain extent, faithless to his promises. Last night, at a special meeting of the Board, Alderman BOOLE rose to a question of privilege and said:

At a meeting held at Stamford, Conn., on Tuesday evening last, I said "that propositions for an armistice or peace had been submitted to the President on the 12th December last, which, had they been accepted, would have terminated this war by the first of April, upon a basis satisfactory to the people North and South."
GENERAL ORDERS, No 18.--The following instructions will govern commanding officers in disembarking their troops:

NEW-YORK, Thursday, March 12, 1863--6 P.M. The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 40 bbls, Ashes, 4,973 bbls, Flour, 374 bbls, and 1,233 bags Corn Meal, 1,613 bushels Wheat, 7,815 bushels Corn, 1,935 bushels Rye, 27 bushels Barley, 11,222 bushels Oats, 625 bushels Malt, 6,939 pkgs. Provisions, and 440 bbls. Whisky.

The charges and specifications preferred by Mr. T.C. FIELDS against Speaker CALLICOT being the special order last evening, the galleries and lobbies were filled at an early hour. The attendance by members was also unusually full.

The Canadian screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, Capt. BURGERS, from Liverpool afternoon of the 26th, via Londonderry 27th, arrived at this port at 3:15 this afternoon. The London Globe thinks that if a contradiction between Mr. SEWARD and M. MERCIER exists in fact, one of the two Governments involved will have to demand a substantial apology.

Moses Lowenberg, Plaintiff in Error vs. The ... People Defendants in Error.--This is the case which it was stipulated should dispose of the Jefferds case, so far as it was affected by the points involved; and the judgment of the Court, if it shall be sustained, is of the highest importance in respect to the many murder cases now and to come before the Courts of the State.

Mr. TALMAN rose to a question of privilege. Last evening a resolution was offered to place him on the Committee of Investigation, on the charges against the speaker. He had then asked to be excused from serving, and now renewed the motion. He was tired of the whole thing.

The rebels have offended Neptune--that is clear. They were never thorough sailors. They never even liked water. They regarded it as a useful liquid to irrigate young cotton or tone down bad whisky; but beyond, they had no love for it. How could they expect the divinities of the deep to prosper them?

A telegram from Salt Lake City the other day made the announcement, unexpected by most people, that a collision between the military and the Mormon citizens or Utah was imminent--that the Governor of the Territory had ordered the arrest of the Prophet, and that the Saints were in arms to prevent it. Our correspondence from Utah for some time past, has indicated that there was trouble brewing in that quarter.
We are informed that a dispatch relative to the Affairs of Poland has been forwarded from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to Baron DE TALLEYRAND, Ambassador of France at Berlin.

Advices from Port Royal to the 8th inst., are received by the arrival of the steamship Ericsson at Baltimore, with mails and dispatches for the Government. The movements against Charleston had not yet commenced, but the important preliminary order issued by Gen. HUNTER, which we publish elsewhere, shows that it may be expected soon. The last bombardment of Fort McAllister lasted twenty hours, and neither of the three Monitors engaged was injured.
The attitude of the various governments on the Polish question had undergone no change. At Paris on the 26th, writes the correspondent of the London Times:

The World is quite right in its statement that a notion is very prevalent that a large part of the "Jecker bonds" are in the hands of "high personages about the Imperial Court of France," and that a desire to give value to these bonds was a powerful motive for the Mexican war. A military commission is in session at Norfolk, Virginia, for the trial of ALEXANDER SPENCE (charged with firing buildings,) and others that may be brought forward for trial. It is composed of Lieut.-Col. Z.P. BAYER, One Hundred and Seventy-third Pennsylvania Lieut.-Col.G.M. GUION, One Hundred and Forty-eighth New-York, Maj. J.S. BATES, Ninety-ninth New-York, and JOHN A. BOLLES, Judge-Advocate.
A special from Memphis to the Gazette gives a report of a fight on the Yazoo River, in which 7,000 rebel prisoners were captured and eight transports. No particulars.

The confirmation by the Senate of Mr. CLAY's appointment as Minister to Russia, places us under the painful necessity of appealing to his own good sense to decide whether he ought to accept the place or not. It seems to us, and we think nine-tenths of the public will agree with us, that he ought

The latest cry of the croakers is that we must end the war at all hazards this Spring,-- that if we can whip the rebels by a vigorous effort very well, but if not we must "bow to our destiny and make the best attainable peace." And the reason given for this advice

We have advices from Europe, two days later, by the steamship Australasian, which arrived at this port last evening. She left Liverpool on the 28th ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst. The new Ministry is as follows: President of the Council, Minister of War and the Colonies, DURRO: Foreign Affairs, PASADA HEREERA; Interior, CANOVAS; Finance, SALAVEREIA; Justice, MAYANS; Marine, JUBALA; Public Works, LUHAN.
Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch rejecting the Emperor NAPOLEAN'S last proposition, attracts considerable comment. The following is from the London Times:

A Shecking case of wife-murder in Mott-street was brought to light yesterday by Coroner WILDEY, at the Fourteenth Precinet Station. The name of the husband is PETER GANNON who, with his wife, ANN GANRON, and a son between eight and nine years of age, and one of two other children, resided at No. 319 Mott-street. An act incorporating the Seira Hancock Company was reported favorably.
The funds were steady, and but for a temporary pressure for money, a rise was considered likely. Consols closed on the 27th at 92 3/8 @ .
Ship Pacific, Benson, Philadelphia, W A. Nelson. Larks W.E. Anderson, Reed, Candeans, J.E. Ward Co., Maryflower, Duel, Barbados, H. Trowbridge's Sons; Harkaway, (Br.,) Cundy, London G.F. Bulley.
We have this morning a partial confirmation of the report of a decided success in the Yazoo River, as published yesterday--that is, we have another report, a little more definite. A dispatch

The shooting of SILAS C. GREENLEAF by JOSEPH HOLIADAY has been the chief topic of interest in the city during the past week. Respecting the deed and the provocation, I gave the substantial particulars last week. But I will explain more fully.
The speeches made at the great Union meeting at Cooper Institute ten days ago seem to be very accceptable to the people everywhere, as they were to the audience that listened to them.

As welcome as the cool mountain stream gurgling forth from its pebbly bed to the thirsty traveler on a Summer's day, is an item of interesting news to the unfortunate army correspondent, whom chance or choice has stationed in these parts just at this time.

A letter written on board the U.S.gunboat king,dated Mississipi River, Feb. 10, says: "We are anchored off the town of Donaldsonville, seventy-five miles above New-Orleans. Returned from the latter city about one week ago.
Several hundred Poles, resident in this City and vicinity, met in Steuben Hall, Bowery, last evening, for the purpose of expressing sympathy with the native land in her present struggle.

The Postmaster-General made a valuable addition to the polemics of the rebellion, in the brief letter he addressed to Mayor OPDYKE and others, in answer to their invitation to attend the late Union meeting in this City. We published the letter in Tuesday's TIMES, and
The telegraph has already given us the main facts connected with the capture of the iron-clad Indianola by the rebels--but the following, from the Memphis Argus of the 5th, is of interest:
The following donation has been received in a most opportune period, as the continuous calls upon this institution had depleted its always open coflers.

Americans are indignant because the Press and the publicists of Europe cannot be made to comprehend the nature of the cause which the North is battling to uphold. Why wonder at this perversity in foreigners, when we see a party growing up in out midst who pronounce that cause unjust and detestable, and who are laboring to destroy that unanimity in the Free States, which is indispensable to the triumph of the National Government?

The storm of war which gathers along the coast of South Carolina and Georgia, is manifestly not unnoticed by the rebels. Every account which comes from there speaks of immense preparations on their part to meet

It was evident that there was not a quorum of Senators present to-day, a number having left Washington during the week for their homes. Many nominations to brevet rank for marked military services which, by a recent law, the President was authorized to confer, were not acted upon.
We take the following interesting extract, relating to the foreign invasion of Mexico, from a private letter recently received in this city from Vera Cruz:

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM. Before Justices Ingraham. Peckman and Leonard. Moses Lowernberg, Plaintiff in Error vs. The People,Defendants in Error.--The opinion of the Court, in this case, was given in the TIMES of yesterday. The following is the dissenting opinion of Presiding Justice INGRAHAM:

The pilot-boat Potter, of San Francisco,arrived here on Sunday, Dec.28, from Manzanillo, having recently visited the wreck of the steamship Golden Gate. T. J. L SMILEY, of San Francisco, who was one of the party accompanying the pilot-boat on her expedition to the wrecked steamer, has given us Some interesting particulars of the excursion. Mr. SMILEY says portions of the wreck are still visible.

The " Union League of New-York City" was inaugurated at the Academy of Music last evening by an audience of ladies and gentlemen, larger in numbers, and more enthusiastic in spirit than was probably ever before gathered within the walls of the Academy. This noted case was brought to a close this day, the young man, Maturin, being brought up, in obedience to the new writ of habeas corpus, obtained by Mr. Wm. F. Howe against the Colonel.

The preparation for the naval wedding are going toward with all activity at Windsor, both within the precincts of the Castle and in the town. The arrangements in the interior of the chapel and their itself, are now nearly all completed, as far as regards the accomodation for the visitors. These seats are arranged in blocks, spreading backward into the aisles.

The loyalists of Missouri have just experienced a sensation, in the publication of a letter, addressed by one Col. ALEXANDER M. WOOLFOLK, of the Missouri State Militia, to Maj. A. W. MULLINS, a member of the present
WARNING FROM THE FRENCH CONSUL The French Consul at Galveston has issued the following address " to the French,Spanish and Italian subjects in the Countries of Colorado, Austin and Fayeue:"

An arrival from Port Royal, yesterday, brings intelligence to March 10. Nothing of importance had transpired since the departure of the last steamer; but the following important orders have reached us. GENERAL ORDERS,NO.16.--SOLDIERS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE SOUTH: After long and wearying delays, due to cause over when no one in this Department had control, we have at length the cheering prospect of active and very important service.

FATAL BURNING ACCIDENT.--At about 10 o'clock on Friday night, a fatal burning accident occurred at the house of Mr. ROTHCHILDS, No. 187 Avenue D, whereby a domestic lost her life and an infant was so severely burned that it is thought it cannot recover. It appears that Mr. and Mrs. ROTHCHILDS had gone out to spend the evening, leaving the children in charge

Mr. HORACE GREELEY has taken a position on the war question which makes him for the time being the most prominent politician and statesman in America. Those who understand the temper of the people, and study the current of events, see at a glance that his logic leads to peace.
FRED. DOUGLASS has issued another address to the colored men, urging them to come forward and enlist. He says:

GEN.BUCKNER AFTER THE SPECULATORS. By command of Maj.Gen. BUCKNER, at NewOrleans,Maj. WINTER-MITH IS empowered to impress all subsistence stores and cattle in the hands of specculators and other parties, paying a fair value for the same, and in all cases leaving enough to subsist the families of these from whom the impressment is made. In accordance with the above, Maj.WINTERSMITH issues the following order:
--The will of the late Mrs. Blandina Dudley has been admitted to probate in Albany, R.J. Hilton, E. E. Kendrick and R. 11. Pruvn are the executors. The will was made in December 1859.

By order of the Secretary of War, the following places are designated as rendezvous to which soldiers absent without leave may report themselves to the officers named, on or before the 1st day of April next under the Proclamation of the President of this date.

ADMIRAL:I have the honor to report to you that I left the landing below Vicksburgh, in obediance to your written instructions, on the night of the 10th lost, taking with me the De Soto and coal barge, and proceeded down the river. We passed Warrenton without interruption, and reached Red River on the following evening. I destroyed, as you directed, the skills and flatboats among either shore.

--A letter to the Rochester Democrat gives the following particulars of a disaster to the Eighth New-York Cavalry, a detachment of which was on picket duty near Dumfries. Under date of Stafford Court House, March 7, the writer says:

On the 26th a deputation waited upon Mr. ADAMS, the United States Minister, for the purpose of presenting him with an address signed by more than 13,500 of the inhabitants of Birmingham on the subject of the American crisis. The deputation was intro duced by Mr. BRIGHT, M. P., and consisted of Mr. CHARLES STURGE ,(the ex-Mayor), Mr.HENRY MANTON, Mr. GEORGE EDMONDS, (Clerk of the peace), Mr.JAMES TAYLOR, jun., Mr. WILLIAM MORGAN, and Mr.J.A. PASTRIDGE.
I have just reached this city; an route from Murfreesboro to Franklin, the scene of the disgraceful affair of Thursday.

Hon. THADDEUS STEVENS, late Chairman of the Committee, in the House of Representatives, on Ways and Means, was serenaded at his home in Lancaster, Penn., on Wednesday evening last, and made a speech to his fellow-citizens. After acknowledging the welcome in appropriate terms and referring generally to the conduct of the war, he said, according to the report given by the Lancaster Express:

A correspondent of the Nashville Union waiting from Franklin, Tenn., under date of Marenb. gives the following particulars of the recent battle at Spring Hill:

Capt.CASE of schooner Hanover, of Provincetown captured off the Island of Hayti, by the pirate schooner Retribution, while on the voyage from this port to Aux Cayes, has arrived in this city. He took passage, with his mate and one man from Port au Prince to New-York in the brig Bird of the Wave.

We are for crushing the Secesh; we are also for crushing the Copperhead. To our mind, there is not, essentially, a jot's difference between them. They are simply varieties of the same species. The one moves in the highway, the other in the grass.

The combined advantages of fine weather and public enthusiasm, exercised a desirable influence over Mr. MARETZEK'S fortunes last week. Three evening performances and a matinee were given, the last a brilliant affair on Saturday, that attracted an overflowing representation of our New-York fair ones, and was in all respects eminently successful.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been; 146 bbls. Ashes, 7,666 bbls. The tidings of the destruction of the pirateship Nashville in the Ogeechee River, near Fort McAllister, by the iron-clad Montauk, reached us at Port Royal on Sunday morning--a dispatchboat having been sent up to Admiral DUPONT by Capt. WORDEN.

FROM THE STATE CAPITAL. The House resolutions, raising a Grinding Committee, are well-guarded, and were passed after a full understanding of their scope. The only intention was that the Committee should be a genuine help, and not a machine to grind grists that never should be ground under any circumstances, and would not be, except possibly by a Committee under the control of the owner of the grists.

Mr. GREELEY protested, in sending us the letter, which we gave our readers on Saturday morning, that he did not ask its publication as a favor at our hands. With every disposition to oblige him, we are unable to conceive how the publication of that letter could have been construed into a "favor" to him, even by the most indulgent of his friends. His worst enemy could have done him no worse turn.
The reappearance in public of Mr. ISAAC TOUCEY, after two years of enforced seclusion, is one of those incidents which must convince the most despondent and most unfortunate of the folly of despair.

There seems now to be no doubt that our fleet which made its way through the Yazoo Pass and down the Cold water to the Yazoo River has at least met with its first success.

The Gazette's Vicksburgh dispatch says the Yazoo Pass Expedition has captured twenty-six steamboats, eighteen of which were destroyed. The gunboats have arrived above Hanes' Bluff, and would soon commence the attack.

The long time that necessarily passes between the dispatching of a letter hence, and its publication in New-York, may permit a general allusion to matters that could not perhaps be properly touched upon if shorter time and distance intervened.

The Yazoo Pass movement, we are now positively assured, has proved a complete success. Twenty-six steam boats have been captured in Yazoo River, eighteen of which were destroyed-- the rest bring probably retained for transports.

FIRES--EXPLOSION--A CHILD BURNED TO DEATH.--Last evening absent 6 o'clock, a fire broke out in a small frame shanty at the foot of Henry, street, South Brooklyn, occupied by Mrs. MARY MOORE, a poor woman, who makes her living by going out to do days' work.
Twice since the war began has the public mind approached to perfect unanimity in its favor. The first time was immediately after the bombardment of Fort. Sumter by the rebels. The second is--now.

No "friendly" Celt can this year complain of the way in which St. Patrick and his memory green were treated by the heavens above or the earth and all that are in Gotham. A finer day than yesterday

The British steamship Solent, which left Carthagena on the 4th, arrived at Aspinwall on the 5th instant. The news from the capital is interesting. On the 4th February, the National Convention opened its regular sessions in the city of Rio Negro, in the interior State of Antioquia. There were fifty-on members present, all the States being represented.

With a Grinding Committee, morning sessions commencing at 10 o'clock, and sessions every evening, there is a fair prospect of going ahead. Speaker CALLICOT has consitituted the Grinding Committee, or Committee of Thirteen, with entire fairness.
It was well said by Mr. BRADY in his Brooklyn speech, that "the time will surely come when the men who oppose this war will be deemed more infamous than the Tories of the Revolution."

No official information, relative to affairs at Vicksburgh and vicinity, has been received by the Government up to last evening, although the reports of the captures in the Yazoo River were fully credited. No further Press dispatches had reached us up to a late hour last night.
Steamar State of Maine arrived here last night, from Washington, with 310 political and citizen prisoners and six Surgeons, and left for City Point this forenoon, in charge of Capt. MULPORD.

ITALIAN OPERA.--In consequence of the continued indisposition of Mme. MEDORI, it will be impossible to give "Norma" to-night at the Academy of Music as announced. "Un Ballo in Maschera" will be repeated, with Mme. GUERRABELLA and Signor BELLINI, for the first time, in the two important roles previously sustained by Mme, MEDORI and Signor YPOLITO.

A special meeting of the Commercial Association was held at the Produce Exchange yesterday to hear Mr. CYRUS FIELD discourse upon the prospects of the Atlantic Telegraph. The President of the Assoviation, Mr. J.P. WALLACE, introduced Mr. FIELD to the meeting, which was numerously attended.

Acting Rear-Admiral BAILEY, commanding the Eastern Gulf Blockading Squadron, under date of Key West, March 10, informs the Navy Department of the arrival there of the steamer Huntsville, from a short cruise between Havana and the Tortugas; also, of the return of the Sagamore from as far up the coast as Mosquito Inlet.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Notwithstanding the continued indisposition of Mme. MEDORI, and the change of opera rendered necessary in consequence thereof, the Academy of Music was completely filled last evening, when "Un Ballo is Maschera" was performed. His remarks were substantially the same as those made the day before at the Produce Exchange. He spoke of the manifold advantages, political, social, and financial, that would result from the successful laying of a tele...

A few days since was announced the decease of Mrs. BLANDINA DUDLEY, who died in this City, on the 5th inst., at an advanced age.

This Commission, consisting of the Mayor and Comptroller, and five members of each Board of the Common Council, it will be recollected, met and organized on the 28th of last month.

Sundry petitions were presented for Croton water in Manhattanville. Mr. FARAR made a majority report in favor of holding the New-York Charter Election at the same time as the General Election, Mr. LOW dissenting.

The immense preparations for the coming event which is now attracting the eyes of the whole country--both of patriots and rebels--to this department are almost completed, at least as far as the army is concerned, and the signal from Admiral DUPONT is all that is required to inaugurate a movement.

The telegraphic wire from Fortress Monroe sends over the country this morning a series of shocking magnetic shocks. There are but four brief and jerky paragraphs in the dispatch, yet each one of them thrills the nerves. A battle on the Blackwater in Virginia--an attack on Newbern, in North Carolina--a ...

ALLEGED MURDER.--On Sunday last an Irishman, named JAMES KELLET, was found lying on the Hunterfly Road, beyond the city line, suffering from injuries sustained, as then supposed, by falling with his head upon some sharp stones, while in a state of intoxication.

The steamer Huntsville, Lieut.-Commanding ROGERS, arrived this morning from Havana, with dates of the 2d inst. from New-York, by the steamer British Queen, but no mail. By this arrival we learn that the rebel steamer Antoneke, Capt. COXETER, left Havana with a full cargo, three days since, and went to sea; also, that as an American bark was about to leave the harbor of Martinique, where the rebel ...

We hear to-night that AVERILL'S and PLEASANTON's cavalry commands, with a light battery, had a sharp skirmish at Kelley's Ford yesterday. The rebels attempted to cross infantry over, but were driven back.

The prisoners captured by Capt. MOSBY, of FITZHUGH LEE'S command, arrived by the Central cars on Wednesday night, in charge of Lieut. McCLELLAN. Included in the number (the whole amounting to 29) were E.H. STOUGHTON, Brigadier-General of the Second Brigade, CASEY'S Division; A. HARKER, Captain of Company L, Fifth New-York Cavalry; ROBERT WELLBRIENT, a telegraph operator; R. WARDENER, an Austrian Baron; P. PRATT, a private in Company F, ...

The London Times rejoices because, as it informs its readers, "at last there appears a ray of hope" from this country. Our readers are sufficiently well acquainted with the tendencies, the wishes and hopes of that paper, to feel at once that its joy must be of ill omen for us, its "ray of hope" only the gathering of thicker darkness over our sky.

The gunboat expedition down the Yazoo River was said to have for its chief object the assailment of Haines' Bluff, immediately north of Vicksburgh. Such may have been its primary purpose, for all we know.
There was fighting on the Blackwater yesterday. No particulars have been received. The rebels attacked Newbern last Friday, and were defeated.

FEY, Assistant AdjutantGeneral, U.S.A., be and hereby is detailed as Provost-Marshal-General of the United States, in pursuance of Section 5 of the act approved March 3, 1863, for enrolling and calling out the national forces and ...

In the Senate, yesterday, a majority report was made in favor of holding the New-York Charter Election at the same time as the General Election. The bill incorporating the Medical College for women was ordered to a third reading. A bill to provide arms and equipment for the State Militia was introduced.

This election excites greater interest in view of the fact that it is the first one in a Free State in which the peace issue has been clearly put forth and accepted. In NewYork, and in every other Northern State, the Anti-Administration party made their fight on the ground that the Administration was ...

A curious medley of news--or rather reports-- comes to us from Fortress Monroe. The first report is, that there was fighting on the Blackwater on Tuesday, of which no particulars are received. It is likely enough that another fight has occurred there. The rebels under PRYOR have been constantly threatening our position beyond Norfolk, and a collision has at any time been imminent.

The subject of the Atlantic Telegraph was presented to the Board of Brokers, yesterday, by Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD, and was very favorably received. Resolutions pledging the aid and influence of the Board in favor of the enterprise were adopted, and a Committee to solicit subscriptions is to be appointed to-day.

The waters still rise around us as surely as they did over the world in the days of Noah, and perhaps, judging from all appearances, the aqueous tyranny of another forty days is upon us. There is but little on every side save a waste of waters, through which appears the top of an occasional wagon like ships wrecked in a shallow ...

On the 6th inst. Gen. HENRY PRINCE, with his Division, BELGER'S and RIGGS' Battery, and a portion of the Third New-York Cavalry, started on a reconnoisance to the south of Newbern. It was most successful in its results.
Mr. CORNELL made a unanimous report from the Railroad Committee in favor of a State interest in the Broadway Railroad bill.
The following paragraph, from the Richmond papers of the 16th inst., is the basis of the dispatch from Fortress Monroe published in the TIMES yesterday:

HON. HENRY J. RAYMOND--Sir: On the 25th day of January last, an order from the War Department was published relieving Maj.-Gen. WILLIAM B. FRANKLIN from his command of the Left Grand Division of the Army of the Potomac. It did not appear by the order to have been at his request, but it transpired, when his own order was published, that he had not asked to be relieved.

A special dispatch to the Democrat from Memphis, says, intelligence has been received from the Yazoo expedition up to Saturday last. The fleet consisted of the Chillicothe, Baron de Kalb, five gunboats of the Mosquito fleet and eighteen transports.
One of the most important military offices in the country is that of Provost-Marshal-General, created by the recent act of Congress for enrolling and calling out the militia of the United States.
Capt. JULIEN, of the First Tennessee Cavalry, was killed, yesterday, by guerrillas, near Hillsboro, Tenn.

In the Senate, yesterday, a unanimous report was made by the Railroad Committee in favor of a State interest in the Broadway Railroad bill. A unanimous report was made from the same Committee in favor of the Crosstown Railroad, striking out the streets in which stage lines exist.
Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, has recommended the observance of April 2, by the people of that State, as a day of fasting and prayer, and Gov. BUCKINGHAM, of Connecticut, has named April 3.

As our readers are already aware, the "diffusers of political information," who set about evangelizing the heathen of New-Hampshire and Connecticut some weeks ago, discovered a grand remedy for all the evils of our political condition, which they produced with becoming solemnity.

The English mail steamer Clyde arrived yesterday from Vera Cruz. The news it brings is not of a striking character. We learn that GONZALEZ ORTEGA continues in Puebla at the head of 24,000 men; that the fortifications of that city are finished, and that great enthusiasm prevails among the garrison and inhabitants.

The salt question, which engaged so much of the time of the last, and has been one of so much interest at the present session, has, it is believed, been so thoroughly canvassed as to leave little or no doubt that it would be unjust as well as impolitic to impose an additional tax on the manufacture of salt.

Increasing the salary of Police, Justice and Justices of the Peace in Brooklyn. Increasing the compensation of jurors in certain towns in Kings County.

The thirty-third annual commencement of the College of Pharmacy of the City of New-York, but the first that has been celebrated in public, took place last evening in the large chapel of the New-York University. A large and intelligent audience was present, and the exercises were enlivened by music furnished by DODWORTH. Rev. Dr. FERRIS opened the proceedings with prayer.

The TIMES correspondent on the Rappahannock sends this bureau the following: HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Wednesday, March 18. The first real cavalry battle of the war has been fought, resulting in a decisive victory on the part of the national forces.

The Gazette's Indianapolis special says, on the arrival of the Cincinnati train a party of soldiers seized and destroyed a package of Cincinnati Enquirers. Gen. CARRINGTON arrested the soldiers, and paid the agent for the copies destroyed.

To Dr. Quackenbush, Surgeon-General of the State of New--York: SIR: The attention of the United States Sanitary Commission has just been called to a bill soon to be brought forward in the State Legislature, entitled, "An act to provide additional means of relief for the sick and wounded soldiers of the State of New-York in the United States service."

Among the bills pending in the rebel Senate is one for the confiscation of the lease, interest and stock owned by the American Telegraph Company, and other alien enemies in the lines of telegraph in the Confederate States.

Last night Lieut.-Col. WHIPPLE, of the Nineteenth Wisconsin, captured a small boat attempting to run the blockade on Elizabeth River, near Norfolk. She had about $2,000 worth of contraband goods on board. Three of the men were arrested and taken to Norfolk.

We have dispatches from Memphis to the 18th inst., embodying intelligence from the Yazoo Pass Expedition to Saturday morning last, which does not corroborate, in all respects, the reports which have previously reached us.
The Convention has nominated JOSHUA F. BELL for Governor, and RICHARD T. JACOB for Lieutenant-Governor.

Two State Legislatures have just made their mark, and with a difference. The Legislature of Ohio has resolved "That we will have no dissolution of the Union; that we will have no armistice; that we can fight as long as rebels and traitors can; that the war shall go on until law is restored; and that we will never despair of the Republic."
Quite a sensation was created in the City, yesterday morning, by the following announcement, which appeared in the journals of the day:

Gen. HOOKER reviewed the Twelfth Corps to-day. Our casualties in the cavalry fight of the 17th will number less than forty. All the wounded were brought into camp, except five, who were too seriously hurt to be moved.

St. Patrick's Day was mild and lovely, contrary to expectation--contrary to custom. "Opening Day" was the same. No one day in the whole year's round is of such interest to ladies of fashion, unless it be NewYear's Day, as the l9th day of March, the Milliners' "Opening Day" in the City of New-York.
A bill passed the Senate to-day providing forcalling a new State Convention, to take into consideration the gradual emancipatibn of Slavery in Missouri.

On Sunday, March 1, an expedition left this city for Hyde County, to route and disperse the guerrillas infesting that portion of the State. The expedition consisted of Company F, Third New-York cavalry, Capt. RICHARDSON; one howitzer, under command of Lieut. BURK, and Company G, First regiment ...
Senator Ira Harris and wife, Albany; Col. P. J. Glassen, U.S. Army; Rev. C.T. Berry and lady, Newark; and W.H. Irwin, Philadelphia, are stopping at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

COTTON dull and nominal, but the tone was better at the close. The sales of the three days sum up 9,000 bales, of which 3,000 were to speculators and exporters.

Remonstrances against the Broadway Railroad bill were presented, as were sundry petitions for the regulating of the Staten Island and New-York ferries, also, petitions for the protection of shipowners.

The North American arrived at Londonderry on the morning of the 6th. The Paris correspondent of the Times quotes a letter from Warsaw, stating that the Russian Government fears to send treasure from St. Petersburgh to Warsaw in consequence of frequent insurgent attacks on runway trains, and the Warsaw Treasury was empty.

Notwithstanding the quotations of gold in the Richmond papers, it is known here that from $6 to $6.50 in Confederate notes have been offered within the past two days in Fredericksburgh; and, moreover, $2.25 in Virginia bank notes, and $3.50 in Confederate notes are freely paid for our national currency.

FATAL STABBING AFFRAY IN A GROGGERY-- ARREST OF THE PERPETRATOR.--Thursday night about 10 o'clock, a disturbance occurred in the liquor-shop of GARRETT LAUNDRESS, No.25 Washington-street, between the keeper of the place and John KANE, a seaman, during which LAUNDRESS, as is charged, drew a sharp-pointed sheatn-knife and stabbed KANE in the abdomen, inflicting a mortal wound. It will be remembered that VALLANDIGHAM, recently advertised to deliver an address in Baltimore, received a notification that it could not safely be done, and thereupon, like a prudent man, reserved his sedition for NewYork. He thereby escaped rough handling. An Indiana Copperhead--CRAVENS, Congressman elect--has not been so fortunate.

The latest intelligence from the Black Brigade, which is now marching into Florida, is, that they have taken several important points, with many prisoners, and captured large quantities of munitions and supplies, and are still driving the enemy before them.

Kimball vs. Richard B. Connolly.--The plaintiff sued as Executor of Ellen LeRop to make the defendant liable as County Clerk for an alleged error in a search made of the title of a lot on Twelfthstreet.

Silas Ha Buttrick vs. William Patten and others.--This was an action to recover the value of certain jewelry alleged to have been wrongfully taken from the plaintiff by the defendants at Cleveland, Ohio, in May, 1861, claimed to be worth $2,500.

Sally Ann Howell vs. The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company.--In the year 1853, as appeared in this case, George A. Howell, of this City, as agent for his wife, insured his life for her benefit and the benefit of his children, in the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company, of this City, in the sum of $5.000.

Flag-of-truce boat State of Maine arrived this morning from City Point, having on board all the political prisoners who have been imprisoned at Richmond; also 190 privates and seamen, in charge of Capt. JOHN E. MULFORD.

There was a tremendous assemblage of politicians present at the opening of the Union Convention here this morning, and the greatest interest was fell and expressed in connection with the work to be done.

The steamship Norwegian arrived at Portland yesterday, bringing advices from Europe five days later, including a summary of news brought from Liverpool by the Edinburgh, now due at this port. The majority of the Finance Committee reported in favor of settling the claim of the State against Richmond County, for Quarantine buildings destroyed, at $47,000, instead of $107,000. Mr. BELL dissents from the report.
Burnett Vs. Lichtenstein.--This was an action upon a note made by the defendant, as alleged, upon the request of her husband for his benefit and his surety.

A special dispatch from Columbus, to the Gazette, says a resolution has been offered in the House, expeliing OTTO DRESEL, for offering resolutions disloyal in sentiment and insulting to the country. It is thought action will be taken on the resolution to-day.

The rebellion in Santo Domingo has ended in a "bottle of smoke," or, at least, the Government authorities here say so. On the afternoon of Wednesday, the 11th inst., three days after the news had been brought from Santo Domingo by the Spanish mail steamer, the newspapers of Havana, in their afternoon bulletin, published the following telegraphic message, which had been transmitted to them from the Captain-General's Office to be inserted in their issue:

Maj.-Gen. E.V. SUMNER, United States Army expired at the residence of his son-in-law, Col. W.W. TRALL, in this city, this morning, at fifteen minutes past 1 o'clock, of congestion of the lungs, after an illness of only five days.

We take the following items of news from the New-Mexican of February 21: The Navajoe Indians have been committing depredations in the vicinity of Pesalta. Maj. LEWIS BACA had gone in quest of them, at the head of a party of volunteers.

Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday at the Twenty-seventh Precinct Station-house, upon the body of JOHN KANE, the man who was stabbed in an affray with GARRETT LAUNDRESS, on Thursday night last, at No. 25 Washington-street, an account of which appeared in the TIMES of yesterday.

The blockade at present is not so extensive as it has been, the gunboats Oneida, R.R. Cuyler and Cayuga having been taken off for other duty. The Oneida is cruising for the Alabama; the R.R. Cuyler has not yet returned from pursuing the Oreto, who ran out here on the morning of Jan. 16; the Cayuga has been ordered to the coast of Texas.

Petitions were presented in reference to the Broadway Railroad bill; for the endowment of Hygeia College; to regulate the price of gas in Brooklyn; for increasing the number of savings banks in New-York.

The 4th of March was quite a busy and interesting day among our Public Schools. The day was set apart as one of special visits from the Directors and other gentlemen interested in the cause of education here.

YEATON, President of the Western Sanitary Commission, will be of interest. Under date of St. Louis, March 13, he writes as follows, communicating the result of a visit to the camps:

1. Sales of liquor by Post Commissaries to officers, will be made only upon permits, containing a certificate signed by the officer that this liquor is for his personal use exclusively, and a proved by company and regimental commanders, and by the commanding officer of the post, personally. Permits will not be given to exceed one gatlon per month. A record of such permits will be kept Post Headquarters.

Arrived ships Don Quixote, from New-York; Imperial, from Hong Kong. The markets are dull. Sales of 2,000 tons Anthracite Coal, at $15.50.

PASSION SUNDAY.--To-day, the fifth Sunday in Lent, the Sunday but one before Easter, is called by the Roman Church "Passion Sunday," a title by which the sixth, or "Palm Sunday," is called in the Reformed Church. "To-day," says Dr. COXE, of Calvary, "is called Passion Sunday, because the Services begin to relate the story of our Lord's sufferings and death. The Atonement is preeminently the theme of this day."

We are glad to announce that Mr. MARETZEK'S tribulations, which were heavy to bear last week, are at an end. Mme. MEDORI has recovered from her throat complaint, and Signor MAZZOLINI is reported to be in excellent voice. The interrupted programme of last Monday will be commenced afresh to-night with the performance of "Norms"--a work in which the lady has won some of her greatest Euro-...

Up to this time the Spring season has been one rather of promise than of performance among publishers. Many causes have retarded the issue of books now in various stages of preparation. Principal among these is the enhanced cost, not merely of paper, but of all the other materials (binders' board, muslin, ) that enter into the mechanical construction of a book.

The dispatch of Mr. SEWARD rejected the Commissioner proposition of the French Government, has fallen almost without notice. This general silence, it was supposed, was imposed by an order from the Government. But this, I find, is not the fact; such an order was not needed with the present experience of the French Press.
The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. MUIR, from Liverpool at 10 A. M., of 7th, and Queenstown evening of the 8th, arrived at this port at 11:30 this morning, en route for Boston.
Major-Gen. WOOL issues a final and impressive order to-day, which will command the earnest attention of every enlisted soldier in this Department. The day of hesitation and equivocation is past.

When I arrived here yesterday it was confidently asserted that to-day was to witness the opening of the canal from the river into the lake. The canal had been completed, and all that was necessary to allow the water to rush in was the cutting of one small strip of the levee, a narrow embankment of only six or seven feet in thickness.

The monotony of affairs, in this vicinity, is relieved occasionally by operations whose character is the very reverse of those that usually make up the sum total of stern war. Playing upon the credulity of the watchful rebels at Vicksburgh, horse racing; deer and duck hunting, visits from rare old characters from the plantations around us; are among a few of these events whose lightness serves to dispel the gloom of the shadows around us.

By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Europa yesterday, we received advices from Eu- rope two days later than came to hand by the Norwegian. The news is not specially important. The great topic in England was the entry of Princess ALEXANDRA into London, which event took place on the day the Europa left Liverpool--the 7th inst.

It is now evident that the tribe of orators and journalists who have undertaken the task of dragging the people of the United States down to their own level, have turned their attention to the Conscription act, and are torturing their wits to convert it into an instrument of division and discomfiture.

The World takes exception to the use of the expression "loyal Democrats," "as if," it indignantly exclaims," "as if there were any disloyal Democrats." We think our neighbor must admit, on reflection, that there are some circumstances which justify outsiders in making this classification of Democrats.

A letter from Rear-Admiral PORTER, dated March 14, has been received, in which he speaks of the difficulties of navigating Yazoo Pass with safety to the vessels of the expedition. The natural impediments are represented as similar to those heretofore reported. He says nothing as to any engagement with the enemy, up to that date.
The steamship City of Manchester arrived at this port yesterday, from Liverpool on the 7th, and Queenstown on the 9th inst. The news is one day later, but not important.

GOOD NEWS RECEIVED AND EXPECTED. The news received to-day by the Government from Port Hudson and Vicksburgh is of the most cheering character. Intelligence is hourly expected of the capture of the latter place, and of a speedy opening of the Mississippi River for free navigation. From Charleston, too, good news is hourly expected.
The following correspondence has been submitted for publication by H.H. VAN DYCK, Superintendent of the Banking Department:

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been : 82 bbls. Ashes, 9,785 bbls. Flour, 1,057 bbls. and 1,327 bags Corn Meal, 4,603 bushels Wheat, 109 bushels Corn, 150 bushels Rye, 8,858 bushels Oats, 3,690 bushels Malt, 8,301 pkgs. Provisions, 689 bbls. Whisky.

The more I see of our colored regiments, and the more I converse with our soldiers, the more convinced I am that upon them we must ultimately rely as the principal source of our strength in these latitudes.

ING LAW.--Mr. VAN DYCK, the Bank Superintendent of this State, has given notice that he shall take steps to forbid the circulation of any notes as currency, within this State, which are not issued in strict conformity with the laws of this State.

We give, this morning, a very interesting budget of news from the South. There are glimpses of the inside condition of affairs at all the points of interest--Richmond, Charleston, Vicksburgh, the Yazoo, the Mississippi and Middle Tennessee. The Richmond papers continue to be greatly exercised at the position of the loyal conservatives of the North.
The Tribune has a special dispatch from Lake Providence, dated the 16th inst., which says:
The U.S. mail steamship Geo. Washington, Capt. GAGER, from New-Orleans on the 15th inst., with merchandise and passengers to H.B. CROMWELL Co., arrived yesterday morning.
Gen. BURNSIDE and his Staff will arrive in this city to-morrow morning.

The steamer George Washington, which arrived at this port early yesterday morning, from New-Orleans on the afternoon of the 15th inst., brought dispatches from Baton Rouge, which were put on board at the Southwest Pass. These dispatches contain the first reliable intelligence received regarding Admiral FARRAGUT'S operations at Port Hudson.

Saturn and Mercury are at last in conjunction. The National Intelligencer and the Post both agree that the President should not use the authority given him by the last Congress to issue letters-of-marque. The chance that this may be done disturbs the moral balance of both. This is really a very curious phenomenon.
From the Richmond correspondence (Feb. 22) of the Mobile Advertiser we extract the annexed paragraphs:

It was at one time in the ambition of the South to establish Slavery in all the United States. Massachusetts, it was supposed, would prove most refractory under the proposed discipline of Southern plantations, but ROBERT TOOMBS, of Georgia, did not doubt that he would live to see her subdued, and he boasted that he would "call the roll of his slaves on Bunker Hill."

The United States steam-transport Mississippi, Capt. BAXTER, arrived at this port yesterday from New-Orleans, Ship Island, Key West, She brings a large number of passengers. Among them are a number of officers belonging to the Harriet Lane and Queen of the West, who return as paroled prisoners.

I told you in my last that we were on the eve of action, and I was not mistaken. Finding that things had assumed in New-Orleans a decided appearance of some onward movement, I made up my mind to leave our slug quarters there, and hastened on to this place, arriving in the Sallie Robinson transport on the evening of Thursday, the 12th.
The Confederate steamer Florida, Capt. MAFFITT, came into our harbor yesterday. Her advent created the most intense excitement, for this is essentially a Secesh place.

The Constitution brought from the wreck of the Golden Gate $100,000 in treasure : also, 3,000 bags of coffee from the Isthmus, creating a panic in the market. Rio declined to 27c.; Costa Rica to 25c. Alcohol and Whisky improve. Money easy. Atlantic currency exchange, equivalent to 40@45 premium for gold in New-York, 3@6 premium. Sterling, 48d. Legal-tenders, 63@66, with considerable inquiry for remittance East.
The storm was very severe, in this vicinity, all last night, with a heavy northeast wind.
The death and public services of Major-Gen. SUMNER received a fitting recognition in the House in the preamble and resolutions offered by Mr. DEAN.

The following bills were introduced : Incorporating MURRAY HOFFMAN and his associates as a Union League Association in the City of New-York, the object being to maintain the Union and defend the Constitution, real estate not to exceed $100,000; providing that real property adjudged to be sold may be sold in the county where it exists, by the Sheriff of said county.
[The dispatches, which were put on board the George Washington, at the Southwest Pass, on the afternoon of the 15th, give the latest intelligence, which we have from our own sources.
Advices from the Yazoo Pass expedition represent that the movements are slow, but that there is every prospect of getting through successfully.

There is nothing new on the subject of Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch; not a single journal has contained a "leader" on the subject, and the majority of the papers have not mentioned it at all in the way of commentary.

The splendid chapter in Les Miserables which describes the battle of Waterloo, is marred in several places by the author's absurd speculations upon what might have hapdened, if certain things had not happened; if the peasant that guided the Prussian column had lost his way, if NAPOLEON had not had a pain in his stomach, or if it had not rained.

In a late letter I furnished a meagre account of an expedition of colored troops to Florida. A recent arrival from the scene of operations puts me in possession of details which are interesting, and promise important results.

Our Washington correspondent repeats the report that the rebels are falling back from the line of the Rappahannock, based on the statements of refugees who came within our lines on Monday. They represent that the entire force left in Fredericksburgh on Sunday night was only 8,000.

Another severe storm has raged yesterday and to-day. The ground is covered to-night with several inches of snow, and the view from my tent door reminds one strongly of the old "Berkshire Hills" in the month of December or January.

The body of Major-Gen. SUMNER was removed from his residence to the City Hall at 9 o'clock this morning, under a military escort from the Fifty-first regiment, and to the sound of muffled drums, where it remains in state the entire day, and is being visited by thousands of our citizens, and many others coming in from the country.

All the iron-clad vessels building for the United States Government, save two, are, we believe, constructed from plans furnished by Capt. ERICSSON, and, as a matter of course, bear a certain resemblance to each other.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 82 bbls. Ashes, 8,003 bbls. Flour, 408 bbls. and 765 bags Corn Meal, 308 bush. Wheat, 415 bushels Corn, 1,270 bushels Rye, 11,993 bushels Oats, 2,260 bushels Malt, 10,637 pkgs. Provisions, and 797 bbls. Whisky.

The Commercial has a special dispatch from Murfreesboro, which gives the following intelligence: Within the last four days the rebels have made several reconnoissances, causing considerable picket skirmishing along our whole front. They do not appear anxious, however, to bring on a general engagement.

The Democrat learns from a gentleman just from Vicksburgh, that the steamer Diligent, with the Eighth Missouri Regiment, had succeeded in entering Yazoo River above Haines' Bluff. Her course was through Cypress Dayou, which debouches into the Yazoo opposite JOHNSON'S plantation, where Gen. SHERMAN'S troops landed last December; thence through Shelle's Bayou into the Sunflower, which empties into the Yazoo twenty miles above Haines' Bluff. The Diligent was accompanied by a light gunboat.

Last evening a large and spirited meeting of employees, representing different branches of trade throughout the City, assembled at the Cooper Institute, for the purpose of concerting some measures by which a great trades' combination may be formed, and the workingmen of all classes protected in their rights and interests.

In no more striking way could the difference between the mental and moral characteristics of the Northern and Southern people be illustrated, than in their respective modes of filling the ranks of their armies in the existing war. The South has been hasty, uncalculating and wasteful. The North has been cautious, conservative and economical.

The Richmond Enquirer and Sentinel, of this morning, has the following: CHARLESTON, Sunday, March 22. The enemy have been shelling the wreck of the Georgianna, off Long Island beach. Otherwise, all is quiet.

A large meeting of produce merchants was held yesterday afternoon at the Produce Exchange, to facilitate the removal of grain from the West to the this City, by procuring the enlargement of locks of the Erie Canal to correspond with the size of the Canal. The meeting comprised many of our best known produce merchants.

Col. CURRIE, at present commanding at Plaquemine, having been ordered to thoroughly reconnoitre the country west of Baton Rouge and Port Hudson, left Indian Village for that purpose on the 23d ult. with 500 men belonging to the One Hundred and Thirty-third New-York regiment, 40 of the First regular artillery, (24 of whom were to serve as cavalry,) and four men-of-war launches, under the command of Lieut-Com. WATSON, of the Hartford.
The steamship Europa, from Halifax, arrived at Boston at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. Her mails reached New-York last evening. Our files by her are no later than those by the City of Manchester.

The schooner I.L. Garritz is here from Matamoras, bound to New-York, with a full cargo of cotton and hides, and reports a large trade going on at Matamoras. When will our Government put a stop to this Texas trade by an army on the Rio Grande, which would be gladly hailed by thousands of the German population of that State.

At a special meeting held Tuesday evening, March 24, 1863, the President, Mr. DARLING, announced the death of Hon. ROBERT T. HAWS, whereupon the following preamble and resolutions, presented by E. DELAFIELD SMITH, were unanimously adopted:
Not since the opening of the war has a month passed so absolutely uneventful in a military way as the last. Hardly an advance step has been taken in any quarter, hardly a blow struck.

All England is in a state of extatic glorification to-day. The Royal Princess of Denmark passes through London on her way to Windsor Castle, where, on Tuesday next, she is to be married to the Prince of Wales. She arrived in the Thames yesterday, lands this morning at Gravesend, comes by railway to London, and will pass through the metropolis, from the Bricklayers' Arms station to Paddington, attended by the civic dignitaries.
On Monday, the Tribune, in defining and vindicating its new position that the rebel States might save Slavery by returning to the Union, in spite of the Emancipation Proclamation, said:
The Democratic General Committee of Mozart Hall held a special meeting at the hall last evening, BENJAMIN RAY, Chairman of the Committee.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The opera of "Linda di Chamounix" will be produced here this evening, for the first time under Mr. MARETZEK'S present direction. Madame MEDORI, whose enormous success has become the town talk, appears as the heroine, and Madame SULZER, Signor BELLINE, Signor BIACHI and Signor COLETTI are also in the distribution.
The rebel force which has occupied Danville, Ky., is believed to be the advance of Gen. LONGSTREET'S Division.

Twelve schooners from New-York are now taking in oysters near the mouth of Elizabeth River. The new gunboat Smith Briggs, (Capt. LEE, of the Ninety-ninth New-York, commanding,) received her guns at Fortress Monroe yesterday, and commences her services at once.

The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday morning, to take action respecting the death of Ex-Comptroller HAWS. Remarks eulogistic of the character of the deceased were made by Messrs. PURDY, DAVIS and TWEED, and resolutions were adopted deploring his loss, ordering the county offices to be closed during the remainder of the day, and that the Board would attend the funeral in a body.

Some four weeks since the first of a series of coal sales was had in this City, and yesterday, at the Merchants' Exchange in William-street, the principal coal dealers and coa1 speculaters of the City gathered to attend the second sale of 30,000 tons of Scranton coal. Mr. DRAPER was the auctioneer.

Events of an important nature have transpired since may last, in the Ninth Military District, now under command of Col. Wm. A. PHILLIPS. In that letter I gave items of interest in relation to the meeting of the Cherokee Legislature, to which the action of that body, since the date of those advices, have given greater importance, and the results of which will make them more prominent.

The following Quarterly Report made by Superintendent KENNEDY, exhibits succinctly and accurately the present state of the force, the vast amount of business transacted by the Department, and many other points of general public interest. At no prior time has the Police been so admirably disciplined or so generally effective, and the Superintendent, under the Commissioners, is entitled to much credit for the very favorable showing, which, with truth, he is enabled to make:

The news received, last night, of the occupation of Danville, Ky., by a rebel force, from 3,000 to 10,000 strong, and that a much larger force was following in its wake, seems to give consistency to the repeated intimations, of late, that the rebels contemplated another invasion of Kentucky. Danville is the first town of any importance reached in Kentucky on entering the State from the direction of Knoxville, Tennessee.

Last night resolutions were passed in the Senate denying the truth of the representations, made for partisan purposes, that New-Jersey intends to resist by force the execution of certain Acts of Congress.
Later news from Vicksburgh confirms the arrival of the sloop-of-war Hartford and gunboat Albatross at the mouth of the canal on the 20th.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 52 bbls. Ashes, 8,214 bbls. Floor, 327 bbls. and 868 bags Corn Meal, 300 bush. Wheat, 1,045 bushels Corn, 1,837 bushels Rye, 6,082 bushels Barley, 10,350 bushels Oats 1,125 bushels Malt, 6,285 pkgs. Provisions, and 470 bbls. Whisky.
The Commercial's special from Greenwood, says the Chilicothe, in the last engagement, was temporarily disabled by shot battering the slides to her port holes so they could not be moved.
The war-steamer Saginaw, having been thoroughly refitted at Mave Island, is now stationed in San Francisco harbor. Dr. JOSEPH PREFONTAINE, commercial writer for the San Francisco Press, died to-day.
Col. N.S. Berry, Col. J.B. Soneborn, J.C. Draper and David Mason, of New-Hampshire; R.H. Hopkins, of Cincinnati; and Jacob Naylor, of Philadelphia, are among the arrivals at the Astor House.
Gold at Richmond is at $4.25 premium, and the Richmond Examiner says that "the question of food ranks before that of money."

While the bill to provide for a loan of one million dollars for the defence of New-Jersey was under discussion in the Senate, Mr. RANDOLPH, a leading Democrat, who is said to hold confidential relations with Gov. PARKER, spoke as follows:

There was considerable skirmishing yesterday and the day before, between our cavalry and the rebel advance south of the Kentucky River.

There are very few persons on this side of the Atlantic, be they never so un-English in feeling, who can read the reports of the extraordinary excitement in London over the Prince of Wales' wedding without a certain degree of pleasure as well as diversion. We are all more or less moved when we witness genuine enthusiasm in others, whether it be inspired by a trifle or by the grandest circumstance.
The steamship Delta, from St. Thomas on the 17th, via Bermuda on the 23d instant, arrived here today.
Gen. LORING has whipped the enemy back from this point. They are now in full retreat to Yazoo Pass.

The partial check our Western naval force received in the loss of the Queen and the Indianola below Vicksburgh has been recovered from. Admiral FARRAGUT, whose intrepidity led the Union fleet to New-Orleans, through the fire of the forts below, has performed a like gallant feat at Port Hudson, and we are once more masters of the Mississippi River between Vicksburgh and that point.

Our Legislature has now been in session nearly three months, and not a syllable has it yet uttered upon the vital issue of war or peace with the rebellion. Other Legislatures, in behalf of their States, have spoken. Ohio has inscribed, in characters as bold as HANCOCK'S signature of the Declaration, that she is for war without ceasing, until the rebellion succumbs.
The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool on the 12th, via Londonderry on the 13th instant, arrived here this morning. Her dates are one day later than those already to hand.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 56 bbls. Ashes, 7,313 bbls. Flour, 1,627 bbls. 498 bags Corn Meal, 1,749 bush. Wheat, 1,990 bushels Corn, 510 bushels Rye, 6,263 bushels Oats, 1,517 bushels Malt, 7,788 pkgs. Provisions, and 789 bbls. Whisky.

A dispatch from Gen. VAN DORN'S army, under Gen. FORREST, numbering two thousand men, crossed the Big Harpeth, six miles below here, last night and attacked Brentwood Station, nine miles in our rear, destroying the railroad bridge stockade, telegraph wire and Government stores, and captured two hundred and fifty prisoners. The enemy were pursued by six hundred cavalry.

Whisky.

The Commercial has a dispatch from Memphis to the following effect: "FARRAGUT'S vessel discovered the Indianola at Hard Times Bend, and recaptured her without resistance. The rebels had been at work on her. She was nearly ready for service.

Flour, 140 bbls. and 970 bags Corn Meal, 918 bushels Wheat, 1,120 bushels Corn, 418 bushels Rye, 125 bushels Barley, 10,326 bushels Oats, 5,942 bushels Malt, 10,946 pkgs. Provisions and 956 bbls. The steamship Delta, from St. Thomas on the 17th, via Bermuda on the 23d instant, arrived here to day.
Adams Express steamship Augusta Dinsmore, Capt. CROWELL, from Port Royal March 20, and Beaufort, N.C., 24th, arrived yesterday morning.

The steamship Bohemian, Capt. BORLAND, from Liverpool on the 12th, via Londonderry on the 13th inst., with 311 passengers, arrived here at 9:15 this morning. Her dates are one day later than those already received.

Sanford et al. vs. Ruckman and one other case. --These actions were brought to recover counsel fees. The defence was that the plaintiffs, as attorneys of the defendant, were guilty of negligence, and, further, that the charges for term fees were not taxable as between the parties.

The Whig, Richmond, contains a detailed rebel account of the fight at Kelly's Ford, claiming that their force was but from 900 to 1,000 cavalry, but subsequently five regiments and one battery are enumerated. They claim a victory, because, as they state, the object of the raid was frustrated.

Sailed--Ships Starlight, for Puget Sound,Avery, for Liverpool, carrying 33,000 sacks of wheat. The salvors of the treasure from the wreck of the Golden Gate, offer to compromise with the original shippers, by paying them 50 per cent, of all money recovered. Some accept, and others will contend in the courts for more. The salvors hope to recover nearly all the treasure lost. They already acknowledge having brought between $600,000 and $700,000 to San Francisco.

I propose to give you to-day in brief what I understand to be the general opinion of the leading men of the Empire on the Mexican Expedition, and on the relations between France and the United States.
Last Saturday night another barge, containing one thousand bushels of coal, floated past the batteries at Vicksburgh safely, for the use of Admiral FARRAGUT'S fleet.

Late Saturday afternoon, some one said, in a company of Americans, "We ought to celebrate WASHINGTON'S Birthday." The proposition was adopted at once, and it was agreed to have a dinner, in which all loyal American citizens in St. Petersburg should be invited to participate.

Information has been received by telegraph, dated Fortress Monroe, of the arrival there to day of the United States supply steamer Massachusetts from Port Royal 23d, via Charleston, Wilmington and Beaufort.

The particulars of Gen. SUMNER'S last illness and death are briefly as follows: He reached his home in this city, from Washington, on Friday, the 13th inst. a week ago yesterday having just received from the President an appointment to the Department of the West, and intended early this week to take his departure for his headquarters, at St. Louis. On Sunday last he attended church, and appeared to be in his usual good health.
The Committee of the Public Stock Exchange Board, to whom was referred the matter of the Bucks County Lead Company, report:

Military and official circles in Havana were thrown into much bustle and excitetent by the order that a battalion of the Cazadores de la Union, and a battalion of the regiment Del Rey, in all two thousand men, should at once embark for San Domingo.

A dispatch dated Paris, March 11, says: "The answer of the Russian Government to the letter or the dispatches from the French Foreignoffice on the affairs of Poland is not satisfactory. It is described as stating that, whatever may be thought of the abstract justice of the demands of the Poles, the Emperor ALEXANDER can listen to no overtures so long as they continue to be in armed insurrection.

A recent debate in the House of Commons on the interruption of friendly relations between Great Britain and Brazil has added fresh interest to that question, and served to place in a still stronger light the imperious and arbitrary conduct of the British Government and its representative in Brazil.

Before Judge Betts. The United States vs. The steamer Anne and Cargo. This vessel was captured Nov. 22, 1861, in Mississippi Sound, by the United States steamer NewLondon. The vessel was, on appraisal, appropriated to the use of the Government, and the cargo transhipped to this port.

The undersigned members of the Seventh Connecticut Volunteers beg to express to their fellowcitizens at home their views in regard to the prosecution of the war in which we are engaged. Prevented from offering our sentiments at the ballot-box, we yet feel more intensely than ever before for the welfare of the ancient Commonwealth, of whose name and...

The only news we have from Vicksburgh and vicinity this morning is rebel news, and if at all to be relied upon, it is certainly bad enough. One of our gunboats, in attempting to pass the rebel batterles at Vicksburgh, is said to have been sunk with all on board, while another was very badly damaged.
The accounts of the insurrection continue vague. The insurgent forces are now computed at 50,000 men.

The Richmond Dispatch, of the 27th inst., notes the execution by hanging of Capt. M. DE HART, of Arkansas, who was sent out by Gen. HERRON to clear the White River District of INGRAM'S guerrilla band.

Friends of Justice, Humanity and Freedom: Poland is again in arms to achieve her indisputable rights as an independent nation, and, through her exiled sons in your midst, she appeals for goodwill and sympathy to the countrymen of WASHINGTON, to the descendants of the heroic patriots who fought side by side with PULASKI and KOSCIUSKO.

This is Palm Sunday next before Easter so called because the day of which it is the anniversary of Christ's entrance into Jerusalem, where with great honor he was greeted, the multitude welcoming Him with hosannas, strewed branches of palm in His way the palm, the emblem of victory.

All the London journals have their local columns full of reports of the inquests upon the unfortunate victims of the rush and crush in the streets on the day and evening of the wedding, and editorially they comment with much severity upon the inefficiency of the police. These are some of the painful incidents testified to:

The British mail steamer Callao arrived at Panama on the 8th inst., from South American ports. Her dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chili are to the 17th and from Callao and Lima to the 27th February. There is nothing new from Ecuador.

Impressed, undoubtedly, with the belief that Gen. HOOKER contemplates an early attack, and at this point, the rebels have, during the week past, increased the force opposite by the addition of several regiments. Balloon reconnoissances have discovered the fact that troops are arriving constantly by rail from Richmond.

Professor MORSE has had the goodness to furnish the public, through the columns of the World, with his reasons for becoming a member of that "Society for the Diffusion of Political Information," whose clandestine birth excited so much scandal a few weeks ago.

SUPPOSED SUICIDE IN THIRD AVENUE. Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday after noon, a man, whose name is given as Mr. JOHN SMITH, was found dead in his room at No. 572 Third-avenue, under very peculiar circumstances. He was a man about 39 years of age, a native of this City, where he has always resided, and so far as is known, he has always borne a good reputation.

On Thursday, three series of diplomatic correspondence on the affairs of North America were published as Parliamentary Papers. The first of these consists of letters and dispatches between Earl RUSSELL, on the one part, and Lord LYONS, and, during his absence from Washington, Mr. STUART, on the other part.

There was a highly-interesting joint meeting of the Canal Committees of the two Houses Wednesday afternoon, when several gentlemen aapealed against the small and in favor of the large lock system, and I am confident that the discussion was not without its results.

Two of the enemy's gunboats attempted to pass down the river this morning, when our batteries opened upon them with effect. One was sunk opposite our batteries. The other was badly riddled, and now lies opposite the canal batteries. It is expected that the latter will be sunk.

I have just returned from our camp at Triune, distant about twenty miles from Nashville, on an elegant turnpike road. This is our furthest advance and most exposed outpost, and is menaced directly by the forces of VAN DORN.

We are as much moved here by the news from the United States as though we were a dependency of that Government. Especially is this true in our commercial and political circles. The carrying trade of all nations is affected, and the state of Exchange is a direct result of affairs at the seat of war.

The Bank of France, on the 12th inst., reduced its rate of discount from 5 to 4 per cent. The monthly returns of the Bank of France show an increase in the cash on hand of over fifty-four millions of francs, and a decrease in the bills discounted of over sixty-one millions.

The suspension is announced of Messrs. PILKINGTON BROTHERS, of London and Liverpool, American merchants and shipbrokers. The liabilities are about 40,000, and the liquidation will depend upon remittances from America.

Three days ago, Gen. SHERMAN and Rear-Admiral PORTER went on board the Lafayette for the purpose of trying the range of her guns by a little practice upon Vicksburgh. About noon she was seen to leave her moorings in the Yazoo, and come down with her large ensign floating gaily in the breeze.

Mr. GEORGE TICKNOR CURTIS, delivered an address last evening, before the Democratic Union Association, on the "True Condition of American Loyalty." The Association is the same that has been recently addressed by Messrs. VALLANDIGHM, COX, OAKEY HALL, JOHN M. KRON, and others, who are opposed to the policy of the present Administration. The room was not filled.

A great obstacle to the restoration of a sentiment of loyalty in the reconquered districts of the South has been the ungoverned license of our soldiers both officers and men. The Government cannot be too soon or too thoroughly impressed with the importance of this truth.

There appears to be a better feeling arising in relation to the Ship Canal and eognate questions hereabouts. The action of your Chamber of Commerce, and the tone of the leading journals, have done much to allay the angry excitement caused by the defeat of our favorite measures in Congress.

The movement among the laboring classes for increased wages is progressing steadily, and is conducted with becoming dignity and order. A meeting of the Piano Makers' Association was held Saturday night at Turner Hall, in Orchard-street, ERYELLERT OESTERRENOHER in the chair. A Constitution and Bylaws were adopted.

GEORGE TICKNOR CURTIS, Esq., addressed the Democratic Union Association, Saturday evening, on "Loyalty." He denied that in time of war the people are bound to accept, without question, the policy of the Government; but argued that constitutional means only--the ballot-box and free discussion--should be brought to bear to remedy the evils complained of.

In my last I advised you of the sudden departure of Gen. PAES from this Capital for the Provinces of the East. He met everywhere with enthusiastic receptions, and on his return here was welcomed with demonstrations of joy.
We perceive, with great regret and apprehension, that various writers and orators have once more begun to prophesy that the war will be over by a certain day of a certain month.
In the Senate, on Saturday, a bill to provide a bounty for conscripts was reported favorably. A majority report was made in favor of allowing soldiers in the service of the United States to vote.
The expedition which went out in the direction of Liberty on Wednesday last, was attacked yesterday morning by 2,500 mounted rebels, commanded by the guerrilla, Gen. JOHN MORGAN.

The King of Prussia and his subjects have not yet come to an agreement upon the important questions which, during the past year, have been raised between them, and present appearances indicate that the prospect of a peaceable solution of the difficulty is daily decreasing.

We published a brief dispatch, yesterday, from Cairo, which is corroborated this morning, giving a report, received via Memphis, that two divisions of our troops had entered the Yazoo River by way of the Sunflower, and that they had been landed at Eagle Bend, just above Haines' Bluff, and only a mile and a quarter from the rebel fortifications.

Four performances were given at the Academy, last week, including a matinee on Saturday. The weather was unfavorable on the last-mentioned occasion, and the house suffered in consequence. An accident of this kind ought to be a slight matter, but where the balance between profit and loss is so finely adjusted, it is apt to be a very serious affair.
The enemy attacked Williamsburgh this morning with cavalry and infantry, and were repulsed by the Fifth Pennsylvania cavalry, under Col. LEWIS.

Woodbury B. Purinton vs. Edward Willets.-- This was an action against the defendant as survivor of Stephen and Edmond Willets, to recover damages for the alleged non-delivery of certain shares of the capital stock of the Farmers and Mechanics' Bank of New-Brunswick, N.J.

Senators Wilkinson and Rice; Hon. J.W. Edmonds, Boston; Gen. J.H. Ledlie and Capt. A.H. Davis, Newbern; Col. J.B. Kinsman and Dr.Shipman, U.S.A.; Judge Church, Pennsylvania, and H. Gillett and J. Matherson, Canada, are among the arrivals at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

Parson BROWNLOW has arrived from Tennessee, and reports that the rebels are concentrating all their infantry formerly in East Tennessee at Tullahoma, while their cavalry has made a diversion on East Kentucky, hoping to draw forces from ROSECRANS, and that reinforcements are arriving daily at Tullahoma, from Virginia.
The prize steamship Granite City, Acting Master KING in Chicago, from Bahama Banks March 23, arrived at this port last evening.

The young men of Brooklyn, thousands of whom are of New-England extraction, feeling that the claims of that section of our country for recognition and honorable mention can never be exaggerated, have invited Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, a son of Connecticut, to speak to them on the subject of the land of his birth.

The Prince of Wales is married. This is the great event of the week. The reception of the Princess of Denmark and her passage through London were safely accomplished, though an unmanageable crowd of more than a million of people in the city, and chiefly from London Bridge to the Mansion House, caused long delays, and great difficulties to locomotion.

The net-work of Railroads with which the South had been checkered prior to the commencement of the rebellion was as essential to the prolongation of the contest as the great accumulation of arms and munitions of war which the traitors in BUCHANAN's Cabinet had provided at the expense of the Government.

We have advices from Europe two days later, by the arrival at this port on Saturday of the steamship Asia. The dates are to the 15th inst. The news is important. The diplomatic correspondence, called for by Parliament, in reference to the war in America, had been issued.
Upon one most important point our people seem to be just at present absolutely unanimous. Men of all parties seem to agree that, whatever else may happen, the Union must be preserved.

The Journal learns from a creditable source that two divisions of rebel infantry crossed the Cumberland yesterday at Staggs' Ferry, near Wailsburgh, Pulaski County. Headquarters have received no notice of this invasion.

Considerably more than a year has passed since the arrival, in the neighboring Provinces, of several regiments of British Regulars, including a crack brigade of Guardsmen and several companies of artillery.

Broadway, in the Senate, gets on slowly, but, as its friends claim, surely. The amendment offered by Mr. MURPHY, confining the dividends to 10 per cent. per annum, besides 10 per cent. (not per annum) to be kept on hand for reequipment, together with the amendment changing the grantees into corporators, would seem to change the character of the bill materially.
MY FRIENDS: I beg to thank you for the very kind manner in which you have received me, and I take it as being the more complimentary since I have come home among my own people.

The prize steamer Nicolai I., Executive Officer ALFRED EVERSON, commanding, captured on the 21st inst. by the United States gunboat Victoria, Capt. EDWARD HOOKER, off Little River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday.

The fact that all through this terrible struggle for the life of the Republic, the work on the new Capitol has not been suspended for a day--not even when the enemy were intrenched for months almost within drum-beat --will, hereafter, point the line of many a poet and historian.
