Whisky.

Last evening a large loyal meeting was held at the New Tabernacle Church, Jersey City. Speeches were made by Rev. J. MILTON HOLMES E.N. DICKERSON and JAMES T. BRADY, and unbounded enthusiasm was manifested by the audience.

The New-Brunswick, which left New-Orleans on Sunday, 22d, arrived yesterday morning, and the McClellan, which left on the same day, arrived last evening, bringing details of Admiral FARRAGUT'S gallant attack upon the rebel batteries at Port Hudson, on Saturday, March 14, the army, under Gen. BANKS, proceeding by land.

We received by the last steamer a copy of the Blue Books, recently laid on the table in the British Parliament, Containing the correspondence between the British Government and our own on American affairs. From one of these volumes we copy the following dispatch:
A CIRCULAR FROM DROUYN DE LHUYS. The following circular, addressed to French diplomatic agents abroad, appears in the Paris Moni- teur:

Before Justices Sutherland, Ingraham and Clerke. The Manhattan Gas Light Company vs. Chas. Ely. This was an action brought to recover the sum of $578.58 for gas supplied on H.S. Crocker, from the 20th January, 1860, to the 18th of February, 1860, and for rent of meter during that time.

A large Union meeting of adopted citizens was held at the Cooper Institute last evening. Speeches were made in English by Mr. CHARLES SPENCER and Dr. KOCH; in French by Mr. FAIDER, and in German by Dr. DONAI all others. Resolutions ... were adopted protesting against foreign intervention in the affairs of this country, and pledging unconditional support to the Government.

Bills were reported by the Grinding committee, Relative to the tare on casks and packages, which passed to third reading. Relative to the securities in the custody of the Clerk of the Court of Appeals, which also passed to third reading.

Refugees from rebeldom, and deserters from the rebel army, are almost daily coming into our lines at Suffolk and Yorktown, and giving themselves up. Generally the deserters bring their arms and equipments with them.

Bills were favorably reported amending the Bounty Tax law; amending the law relative to the use of partnership names: relative to evidence; amending the act establishing the Metropolitan Police District, which was introduced by Mr. DRAN; regulating the sale of nay and straw in New-York; the Senate bill amending the Brooklyn Charter.

The United States steamer Arago, Capt. GADSDEN, arrived yesterday morning from Port Royal, having left there on March 28. The Arago brings 65 first and 140 second-class passengers, Government stores, and the usual mails. Sunday, March 29, at 1:20 P.M., Cape Hatteras bearing north, twenty miles, exchanged signals with steamer Fulton, with a ship in tow, bound south.

Foremost among the issues of the last few days are the Magazines for April, now just starting on their mission of civilization throughout the length and breadth of the land, where few indeed are the households altogether strange to their genial influence. First is:

The steamship Hansa, from Southampton on the 18th of March, arrived here last evening with three days later news from Europe. The Inman steamer City of Washington, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which left Liverpool at 10:30 on the morning of the 18th, and Queenstown on the 19th March, also arrived late last night.

Whereas the Senate of the United States, devoutly recognizing the supreme authority and just government of Almighty God, in all the affairs of men and nations, has, by a resolution, requested the President to designate and set apart a day for National prayer and humiliation:

The following document, addressed by Mr. JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, the Confederate "Secretary of State," to Hon. L.Q.C. LAMAR, the Confederate "Commissioner" at St. Petersburgh, has lately come into the possession of our Government. It is published for the information of all concerned, as serving to show the prudent and significant reserve which the Confederate authorities prescribe to themselves in refusing to enter into any engagements with foreign nations got to revive the African slave-trade.

Yesterday's Richmond Dispatch has the following : "On the morning of the 25th, four Federal boats were advancing toward our upper batteries at Vicksburgh. A vigorous fire was opened upon them. Two were driven back, and two passed under a rakfug fire. One received a shot from which she sunk. Part of her crew escaped to the opposite shore. The Benton was disabled, and the Albaltross towed her out of danger of our gunboats."
The rebels are retreating from Kentucky rapidly. PEGRAM, at last accounts, was south of Stanford, hotly pursued, and is reported to have been compelled to abandon his cattle and train.

The Times City Article says the announcement of the loan has caused an unusual amount of attention. The last quotation yesterday was 2 to 3 premium. The affair is to be regarded almost exclusively as a cotton speculation.

On Sunday last District-Attorney ISAAC W. SCUDDER, of Jersey City, received an anonymous letter informing him that a Mrs. SUSAN THOMAS, wife of JOHN JACOB THOMAS, a reputed wealthy dealer in silks and ribbons, doing business in New-York and residing at the country residence of Mr. JAMES GREGORY, and formerly owned by DANIEL WESSTER, situated on Weenawken Hill, had died suddenly, and under circumstances which led to the suspicion that there had been foul play.

The Washington authorities, who state that the rebel army is falling back from the Rappahannock to the defences of Richmond, have been misinformed. On the contrary, the enemy are hurrying forward reinforcements rapidly, under the impression that a second attack is to be made near Fredericksburgh. This I know to be true. An editorial on the situation, which appears in the Richmond Examiner of the 18th, contains the following significant sentence:

On Tuesday night, before the Young Men of Brooklyn, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHEB delivered an address at the Academy of Music on New-England. Despite the discomfort of the day, the slush upon the pavement and the prospect of more rain, the spactous auditorium was packed with people desirous of hearing the celebrated orator, divine and statesman upon one of the most interesting topics of he day. At 8 o'clcck precisely the Committee escorted.

The schooner Jane Morley, formerly La Fouavril, of Baltimore, owned by HOKES, BEEL Co., arrived at the steamboat wharf to-day in tow of a tug, having been sent up from the lower river, where she was captured yesterday. She had been engaged in the contraband traffic, which finds its way between the rebels in Maryland and Virginia, across the Potomac, near the extremity of the Peninsula between the Potomac and the Rappahannock.

As we have just been going through a fit of elation, for which there was no particular reason, we shall probably now for a few days experience a fit of depression equally unreasonable. Every one had last week got hold of the notion that Vicksburgh was about to fall, and that the Yazoo expedition was certain to be successful.

The rebels seem to be a good deal in doubt how to deal with the Northwestern Slates. They are very anxious to deal with them separately, and very desirous so to act as to induce them to desert the cause of the Union, for which they have shed so much noble blood, and take up arms to help the dilapidated and waning power of the Southern Confederacy.

This morning, at 4 o'clock, the passengers on the through train from New-York were startled by a sudden shock, followed by the shrill scream of the locomotive whistle, and then a terrible crash immediately preceding the stoppage of the train.
The steamship Eagle, Capt. ADAMS, from Havana on the 28th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. The correspondent of the Associated Press furnishes the following interesting items of news:

The French screw transport steamer L'Allier arrived here, yesterday morning, from Vera Cruz, in five days, but brings no news confirmatory of the report that appeared in the journals of your City, as given in a telegram from Fortress Monroe, namely, that Mexico City had been taken.

Both the official and the Press dispatches relating to the defeat of the rebels under PEGRAM, near Somerset, Ky., on the 30th ult., prove it to have been very complete. The enemy numbered over 2,600 men, and were at least two to one as compared with our force under Gen. GILMORE.

An ovation such as is rarely given men of whatever merit, was tendered Gen. B.F. BUTLER last night at the Academy of Music. The Mayor presided and welcomed the guest of the city in terms most complimentary, after which Gen. BUTLER delivered a lengthy and explicit address, giving his views as to the state of affairs, North and South.

SPECIE AND BANK NOTES Gold has declined to $4 premium-selling rate. The brokers are paying from $3.50@$3.75, according to amount. Silver is quotable at about 25 per cent, below these rates. Bank-notes are heavy at 75 per cent, premium, some asking 70. The buying rate is 60 per cent.

SPECIE AND BANK NOTES Gold has declined to $4 premium-selling rate. The brokers are paying from $3.50@$3.75, according to amount. Silver is quotable at about 25 per cent, below these rates. Bank-notes are heavy at 75 per cent, premium, some asking 70. The buying rate is 60 per cent.

The ship Washington is mentioned in the foreign news as having been captured by the Alabama, but released on bond, There are two American ships Washington one belonging in Gardiner, Me., and the other in New-York. We are left in doubt as to which is the one captured. The former is of 1,226 tons burden, and the latter 1,655 classes A2 and A 1 respectively.
A special dispatch from Cincinnati says: "The news from Vicksburgh is not encouraging. The Steele's Bayou Expedition had returned to Young's Point, and the troops were being disembarked.

Gen. JOHNSTON reviewed the troops on yesterday. The spectacle was by no means brilliant in point of pageantry, but as an exhibition of swarthy strength was imposing in the extreme. Gen. BRAGG was not on the field; he is with Mrs, BRAGG, who is lying dangerously ill at Winchester.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. GRACE, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 2lst of March, at 10 A.M., vid Queenstown 22d, arrived here at 3 P.M. to-day. She had been detained off the harbor since this morning by fog.

Just before the close of the late Congress, Mr. EDWIN A. STEVENS Proposed to complete the naval battery on the stocks, at Hoboken, at his own expense, and submit it to the severest tests known to modern navigation and gunnery, provided the Government would buy it at a stipulated price, in the event of its success. Mr. STEVENS claims extraordinary power of his Battery.

Mr. BILLAULT, on behalf of the Government, said a fresh insurrection can only bring fresh misfortunes, and it is neither good, useful nor humane to encourage it. The match has been concluded for the prize fight between HEENAN and KING for the championship and l,000 stirling a side. The 8th of December has been fixed upon as the day for the contest.

Interest has always been the Polar Star of British diplomacy. No historical fact is better established than that. But we do not recollect ever to have seen it quite so plainly avowed as in the closing lines of Lord LYONS' dispatch to Earl RUSSELL, lately published He winds up his considerations, which all lean toward the Confederacy, thus:

The report of the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the subject of mediation, is the best thing which has yet appeared from any source addressed to foreign nations. Mr. SEWARD said the same thing, but, unfortunately, the Foreign Secretary's florid style is not appreciated in France, and such a declaration as this, coming from a unanimous Committee and from the conservative Senate, was much needed, and will exert a most salutary influence.

Dispatches from Murfreesboro give an account of a brilliant skirmish on the 1st. inst. An expedition under Brig.-Gen. HAZEN and Col. ENVARDS started for Woodbury to attempt to capture the rebel force at that point. One hundred of the Fourth Ohio cavalry accompanied it.

Under the auspices of the Young Men's Republican Central Committee, a meeting was held at the headquarters, corner of Broadway and Twenty-thirdstreet, Friday evening, the first of a series intended to counteract the poisonous effects of the Copperhead gatherings periodically held in the vicinity. A number of ladies graced the occasion by their presence. Mr. ARMSTRONG, the Mayor's Private Secretary, opened the proceedings with a brief statement of the objects to be attained.

The following is a private letter just received MATAMORAS, Mexico, Wednesday, Feb. 18, 1863. I have seen and learned enough since I have been here to make my soul bleed over the unhappy condition of my friends yet in Texas. They are murdered one by one. A small force could lift the yoke of tyranny from their necks and give them relief.

The Indianapolis Journal, of March 28, details the circumstances of the execution of ROBERT GAY, a private of the Seventy-first regiment Indiana Volunteers, who had been sentenced to death for the crime of desertion. After the unfortunate man had been placed upon his coffin he made the following speech:

In a previous letter I alluded to the sympathy of the German people with the North in ita struggle against the rebellion. This feeling has been materially increased by the unfortunate condition of affairs at present existing here; and many are now looking anxiously to America for a return of that peace, which obtained, not by compromise, but by arms, will insure them for the future a tranquil home in the New World.

FIRE DEPARTMENT NOMINATIONS. The delegates to the Fire Department Convention to nominate candidates for Chief Engineer, Assistants and Fire Commissioners for the Jersey City Fire Department, held a meeting on last evening, (Saturday), at Fireman's Hall. S.W. HOYT was chosen Chairman, and F.P. BUDDEN Secretary.

The rebels made another break upon us yesterday, in the vicinity of Brentwood, nine miles from Nashville. Since the disaster at Franklin, early this month, portions of three regiments, most of which were lost at that time, have been stationed at Brentwood and the railroad bridge two miles bevond, comprising about 100 men each from the Twenty-second Wisconsin, Nineteenth Michigan, and Thirty-third Indiana.

The recalcitrant religionists of Baltimore, who could not worship in an edifice over which the national standard floated, recently appealed to Gov. BRADFORD to have the order of Gen. SCHENCK rescinded. The Governor replied to their request in a decided letter, which those to whom it was addressed had no desire to publish. Why they were so reluctant may be inferred from the concluding paragraphs of the document, which read as follows:

The splendid river steamboat Clifton came to the Brooklyn Navy-yard on Monday, having been purchased by the Navy Department. The price is about $100,000. The Clifton formerly run to Staten Island. Crews were sent from the yard for the prize Steamers Virginia and Adler, which have also been bought for naval purposes. All these vessels will be immediatcly taken in hand for conversion into gunboats.

One would think that our domestic troubles are pretty numerous already, without an Indian invasion being added to the number. Such a contingency would scarcely seem possible, yet it is really very likely to happen. The Kiowas have made up their minds for it; so have the Cheyennes, and so have the Comanches. Even the names of some of the chief warriors have come to our knowledge.

We surrender a large part of our space, this morning, to the unanimous report of the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War. It is an able, interesting and important document. It throws a flood of light on the history of the contest, and must go far toward settling the public judgment concerning many points on which public sentiment has hitherto been divided.

The Report of the Senate Committee on the "Conduct of the War" is a document of 64 closely printed octavo pages and would fill, if printed in full, not far from 20 columns of the TIMES. It opens by rehearsing the circumstances which led to the appointment of the Committee and by stating the leading motive which has guided their inquiries.

ODELL, of the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War, were present at the proceedings of the NewYork East M.E. Conference, at the South Secondstreet Church, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday.

We have no doubt that Charleston, its harbor, and its approaches, are very formidably defended. The city has been threatened for two years. During all that time the inhabitants and the military authorities have been able to look down the harbor, and behold hostile cannon mounted on first-class ships, whose commanders would have eagerly seized any chance to run in and salute the town.

An immense meeting was convened last night at the Academy of Music, to take measures to aid the starving poor of Ireland. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and addresses were made by Archbishop HUGHES, Brig.-Gen. MEAGHER, RICHARD O'GORMAN, Hon. Judge DALY and others. The affair was an entire success.

During the past week the roads have improved rapidly, and will soon be in fine condition, if the weather continues to remain favorable. Several hours are devoted daily to drilling by the various commands, which are scattered over hill and through dale as far as the eye can reach. It is the universal testimony of all the officers with whom I have conversed, that the army never was in so good fighting ...

GEN. WOOL ON THE WAR LIST OF APPOINTMENTS. In pursuance of an invitation extended by the Chairman, (Bishop BAKER,) Gen. WOOL, Judge BETTS, of the United States Court, and Hon. M.F. ODELL, of the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War, were present at the proceedings of the NewYork East M.E. Conference, at the South Secondstreet Church, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday.

We have no definite news yet from Charleston nothing in fact, but hints. We have the announcement from Washington that it is officially known there that our gunboats and iron clads left Port Royal on Wednesday last, and would probably reach their destination on Thursday evening. Up to 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, however, nothing further was known of their movements.

The first performance of a new opera, under any circumstances, is an event of great musical importence, but when, in addition to the novelty of the work itself, we are called upon to assist at the introduction of a new composer, the occasion is doubly interesting. Although Italy is the Mother of the Arts, its must be confessed that in music she has not lately had many additions to here family.

The meeting at the Academy of Music last night in aid of the suffering poor of Ireland, was an immense success, both in point of numbers and enthusiasm. During the past week the roads have improved rapidly, and will soon be in fine condition, if the weather continues to remain favorable. Several hours are devoted daily to drilling by the various commands, which are scattered over hill and through dale as far as the eye can reach. It is the universal testimony of all the officers with whom I have conversed, that the army never was in so good fighting ...

The first performance of a new opera, under any circumstances, is an event of great musical importence, but when, in addition to the novelty of the work itself, we are called upon to assist at the introduction of a new composer, the occasion is doubly interesting. Although Italy is the Mother of the Arts, its must be confessed that in music she has not lately had many additions to here family.

An immense meeting was convened last night at the Academy of Music, to take measures to aid the starving poor of Ireland. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and addresses were made by Archbishop HUGHES, Brig.-Gen. MEAGHER, RICHARD O'GORMAN, Hon. Judge DALY and others. The affair was an entire success.

We have no doubt that Charleston, its harbor, and its approaches, are very formidably defended. The city has been threatened for two years. During all that time the inhabitants and the military authorities have been able to look down the harbor, and behold hostile cannon mounted on first-class ships, whose commanders would have eagerly seized any chance to run in and salute the town.

Dispatches from Murfreesboro give the following account of the fight near Snow Hill: On the 2d inst. Gen. STANLEY, with two thousand cavalry, and Col. MATTHEWS' infantry brigade, started to capture MORGAN'S and WHARTON'S Eighth regiment of infantry and cavalry at Snow Hill. Beyond Auburn they drove in the rebel pickets.
A private letter dated off Charleston, 1st inst., says: "It is reported that charleston has been evacuated by all the women and children.

An immense trade is carried on over the Rio Grande, and our informant (says the Era) knew of a train of 600 carts loaded with cotton, which was on its way to Brownsville. These loads will average about six bales each, and probably covey not less than 3,500 bales of cotton. This will be exchanged for warlike stores, blankets, ammunition, etc., which will be carried back by the same train.
Richmond papers of the 7th are received. The burden of tde sentiment expressed is in exhortation to the people of the South to raise articles for food instead of cotton.

The United States steam transport Ellen S. Terry, Capt. CHAPIN, arrived at this port yesterday from Newbern, N.C., bringing a number of discharged, disabled and sick soldiers, and several passengers. She was boarded by our reporter, who gathered from the officers such intelligence in regard to affairs at Washington as had reached Newbern previous to their sailing. Their reports, however, are neither so direct nor so reliable as those in our correspondent's letter, given above.

We are still without news from Charleston. Up to yesterday afternoon the Government had received no definite intelligence reearding operations there. Private letters have been received from officers attached to the naval force, dated as late as the 1st inst., which speak of the attack as to take place at once, and expressing confidence in a good result. All the women and children were said to have left the city in anticipation of the attack.
The United States steamer Honduras arrived here yesterday from the Rio Grande, bringing about 260 Texas refugees.

Some additional advices form Mexico reach us by way of Havana, though nothing later than we have already had. The French forces under Gen. FOREY were still, on the 7 th of March, occupying the line twelve short leagues from Puebla, and seven from the outer posts. The Mexican vanguard was at Amozoo. The guerrillas were still very troublesome to the French.

The steamer Eastern Queen arrived at this port yesterday, from New-Orleans on the 29th ult., and the steamer Columbia arrived last evening, with advices to the 1st inst. The intelligence by these arrivals is of considerable importance.

President LINCOLN, accompanied by Mrs. LINCOLN and Attorney-General BATES, left Aquia Creek last night for Washington.

In view of the probable and speedy enforcement of the Conscription act, and the consequent necessity for the reorganization of our armies, we offer for the earnest consideration of the country some views written during this war by an officer of talent, rank and experience in the regular army.

There was no disturbance at Stalybridge on the 27th, but matters looked rather threatening. The great annual boat race on the Thames, be tween the Oxford and Cambridge Universities, resulted in the easy victory of Oxford.

One of the grandest and most imposing military spectacles of modern times took place yesterday, in which President LINCOLN and the Commanding General of the army, accompanied by a large Staff, assisted; grand not alone in view of the number of troops present, but mainly because imposing in all that gives invincibility to the general appearance and movements of troops. It was a review of a portion of the Army of the Potomac.

The latest accounts from Poland are confused. The only circumstance to be clearly defined is the prevalence of flight, and the sudden disappearance from the scene of several thousand men. The town of Kielce was reported to be threatened by the insurgents. The Russians had quitted Michaelowicz, and were marching upon Slomniki.

On the 26th ult. a memorial regarding the seizure, by Admiral WILKES, of the British steamer Peterhoff bound from London to the Mexican port of Matamoras, was presented to Earl RUSSELL through Mr. R.W. CRAWFORD, M.P. for London, and a reply was received that it should be laid before the law officers of the Crown, and have immediate attention.

The French mail steamer Floride, of the line between St. Nazarie and Vera Cruz, has arrived at Santiago de Cuba, but brings no news of a later date than was brought to Havana by the Allier, as mentioned in my last letter.
The review of the Third, Fifth and Sixth Army Corps, by President LINCOLN, took place to-day. The weather was favorable, and the affair passed off with much 'c clat and enthusiasm.

On the 26th ult. a memorial regarding the seizure, by Admiral WILKES, of the British steamer Peterhoff bound from London to the Mexican port of Matamoras, was presented to Earl RUSSELL through Mr. R.W. CRAWFORD, M.P. for London, and a reply was received that it should be laid before the law officers of the Crown, and have immediate attention.

No. 1 [Translation] MEXICO, Sept. 29, 1862. MR. MINISTER: A large number of foreigners have expressed to me their fears that the payment of the new tax of one per cent on movable and immovable property on the 12th of this month will be exacted from them.

To-morrow, in all probability, the attack upon Charleston will open, and upon the eve of the event, amid the distractions and excitements of the hour. I shall endeavor to give some account of the progress of our forces since their departure from Port Royal.
The Inman steamer City of New-York, Capt. KENNEDY, which sailed from Liverpool at 5 o'clock on the afternoon of the 1st, and from Queenstown on the 2d inst., arrived here this morning.

Parliament was not in session owing to the Easter holidays. The revenue returns for the quarter ending 31st March, show a slight decrese. The total revenue for the financial year ending 31st March, was 70,603,561--against 69,674,479 to March, 1862.

The Mexican Minister did not receive his mail today, brought by the last steamer, and we are yet without an authoritative contradiction of the French fables, put in circulation from Vera Cruz, of their military successes. It is enough for to-night to say, that Serior ROMERO confidently waits for intelligence from his Government, and has faith that the French war of conquest will yet be turned into a war of defeat.
The unsuccessful attack upon Charleston undoubtedly will be hailed with great satisfaction by the ruling classes of England as a serious damage to the National cause. This will be a mistake.
The news from Mexico which we published yesterday, was not of that decided character which the public had reason to expect. The dates from Puebla, the seat of war, are down to the 23d ult.

One can generalize better upon the effective condition of an army by its health returns than by any other single feature. A raw army in camp is invariably in a bad sanitary condition; the mortality lists of a demoralized or dispirited army are always frightful. The most favorable military health returns are from well-disciplined, high-toned armies, inured to the soldier's life.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC LAST MATINEE OF THE SEASON. Mr. MARETZEK announces the last matintee of the season for to-day. DONIZETTI'S opera "La Favorita" will be given entire, and with an effective distribution of the leading parts. On Monday evening the season closes, with a benefit to Signor MAZSOLENI when "Un Ballo Maschera" is advertised for performance.

The Committee of Arrangements for the Loyal Union meeting called for Monday next, have announced that Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT would preside over the meeting from the balcony of the Fitth-avenue Hotel, opposite to the principal forum for orators.

Richmond papers of the 16th inst. are received, from which we obtain the following intelligence: All is quiet at Charleston. The Federals occupy Coles, Kiawah and Seabrook Islands in considerable force. They are protected by their gunboats.

The called session of the General Assembly of this State was opened in Columbia last Friday night. A quorum was present in both Houses, and the following Message from Gov. BONHAM was received, read, and appropriately referred :

In the Senate, yesterday, the Rome and Oswego, the Malden and the Newtown and Astoria Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendment to the New-York Harbor Defence bill, increasing the appropriation to $1,000,000, was non-concurred in, and a Con-...

The following bills were ordered to a third reading: Relative to the Rome and Oswego Railroad. Incorporating the Maiden Railroad Company. Incorporating the Newtown and Astoria Railroad Company. The Senate non-concurred in the Assembly amendment to the New-York Harbor Defence bill, and increased the appropriation to $1,000,000. A Conference Committee on the subject was appointed.

Richmond papers of the 16th inst. are received, from which we obtain the following intelligence: All is quiet at Charleston. The Federals occupy Coles, Kiawah and Seabrook Islands in considerable force. They are protected by their gunboats.

The following speech was made to the troops at Helena, Ark., on April 6, by Adj.-Gen. THOMAS: "I thank you, fellow-soldiers, for the warm and hearty reception which you have given me. I receive it not as an ovation to myself, but to the Government which I represent.

You have of course been informed of the rebel advance upon Suffolk. The alarm was first given in the Federal camps last Saturday afternoon, and the men were called to arms. Rumors that LONGSTREET was advancing with a large force and heavy pontoon trains had been circulating previously for two or three days, but were generally not credited.

ORTRGA, when he was defeated by the French Gen. BERTHIER.

Judge BETTS, in the United States District Court yesterday, decided orally to accede to the request of the United States District-Attorney, that the mail of the Peterhoff might be delivered to him, to be disposed of according to the instructions of the Government. It is understood that the mail will be delivered to the British Consul.

ORTRGA, when he was defeated by the French Gen. BERTHIER.

A cold, cheerless rain commenced falling this morning, and our tickle, treacherous Virginia roads are again almost impassable. So we add forty-eight hours more to our suspense. But two such storms within a week are no more than we had on the Peninsula a year ago, and after we are once well started, we shall take such things as they come. But let us get started.

This place a small settlement in the midst of the richest county in the State is situated on the left bank of the Mississippi, one hundred and seventy miles above Vicksburgh. It is from this point that passing steamers have been most frequently fired upon; and it was to correct this and effect some other purposes, that Gen. STEELE landed here a few days since with his entire division.

The United States steam transport Dudley Beech, Capt. SMITH, from Newbern on the 21st inst., in ballast, to the United States Quartermaster, arrived yesterday.

Gen. REYNOLDS reports from Liberty the particulars of the McMinnville affair. The main mounted force, under Cols. WILDER and MINTY, arrived at McMinnville at 1 o'clock on Wednesday morning, taking the place almost entirely by surprise. A rebel force, under GRIGSBY, was in front of the town, but Gen. REYNOLDS amused them while Col. WILDER went into the place. GRIGSBY escaped.

The rebels have abandoned their attack on Washington, N.C. giving it up as a hopeless task. The fortitude and plucky perseverance with which Gen. FOSTER and his little band of 1,200 men held out successfully, and kept at bay for many days and nights 17,000 of the enemy, has endeared this popular leader still more strongly to his command.

Speaking with the diffidence becoming a non-professional critic on military affairs, we are disposed to regard this work as one of the most important on the science of war, considered with reference to our situation, and present and future condition, that the existing rebellion has called forth.

The pirates Florida and Alabama are both heard of again in the manner least welcome. An arrival at Halifax, from St. Thomas and Bermuda, brings intelligence that the Florida, in addition to the Star of Peace before reported, has recently captured the bark Lapwing, from Boston, and the bark M. J. Colcord, of New-York.

The bark Venus arrived at this port yesterday, from Curacoa, Venezuela, on the 10th inst. She reports that vessels were daily running the blockade at Maracaibo from Curacoa. The Government party of Venezuela are said to be daily losing ground.

The steamer Delta, from St. Thomas on the 14th and Bermuda on the 19th instant, has arrived here. A Danish brig landed at St. Croix on the 12th inst. the crews of the following vessels captured by the Florida:

The United States vs. Two cases of Wooden Smoking-pipes. This action was tried with another one involving the same questions. They were brought to forfeit the goods for alleged fraudulent undervaluation. The goods were imported in December, 1861, from Paris. On appraisement at the Custom-house here their value was advanced about twenty-five per cent., and thereupon these actions were brought to forfeit them. They were valued at about $1,200.

Dispatches, received at headquarters, announce the arrival of Gen. McNEIL'S command at Cape Girardeau yesterday. That place is now entirely safe from attack, being well fortified and fully garrisoned.

There are two classes of revolutions: one for a change in the form or administration of Government, the other for territorial independence. It is remarkable what a difference there has been between them in respect to success.

It is to be hoped that whenever the draft is made, enough men will be called for not simply to supply the actual wants of the army in the field, but to form a large and efficient reserve, to be kept under instruction and sent forward as fast as it is required.

GENERAL ORDER, No. 41. 1. The Commanding General having, in accordance with the spirit of the President's proclamation relative to the voluntary return of deserters, mitigated certain punishments inflicted upon such offenders by General Courts-martial in this Department, prior to the expiration of the time fixed by the said proclamation for their voluntary return, April 1, 1863, announces that hereafter no such leniency will be shown.

The Raymond (Miss.) Gazette publishes some extracts from a private letter written by Vice-President STEPHENS to a resident of that city. In reviewing the ability of the South to maintain the stand it has taken and held for the last two years, the Vice-President speaks confidently. He says:

GENERAL ORDER No. 6. 1. In the face of appeals to the people to give up the illegal practice of wearing concealed weapons, and to abandon secret and armed associations, the practice continues. The inevitable result has been the loss of valuable lives. It is the clear duty of every good citizen of whatever party, to maintain order and stop these things at once, ...

The steamer Planet has arrived from below, and brings later intelligence from Vicksburgh. On Monday night, fifteen transports ran the blockade and are now below Warrenton. The casualties are not known.

The steamship North Star, A.G. JONES commanding, with passengers, mails and specie, to D.B. ALLEN, Agent, arrived yesterday morning. The North Star sailed from Aspinwall on 17th Inst., at 12 M., and arrived at New-York on 25th inst., at 8 A.M. She brings $256,604 in specie.

The Raymond (Miss.) Gazette publishes some extracts from a private letter written by Vice-President STEPHENS to a resident of that city. In reviewing the ability of the South to maintain the stand it has taken and held for the last two years, the Vice-President speaks confidently. He says:
CHANGES IN THE POLICE DEPARTMENT. The following appointments and resignations were made in the Police Department during the past week.

We have published a brief account of the evacuation of Jacksonville by the Yankee negroes. A part of the town was destroyed by fire, but it was checked before doing more damage. The fortifications abandoned by the enemy were extensive and formidable.
The following dispatch from Majar-Gen. BURN SIDE has been received at the headquarters of the army here:

GENERAL ORDER, No. 41. 1. The Commanding General having, in accordance with the spirit of the President's proclamation relative to the voluntary return of deserters, mitigated certain punishments inflicted upon such offenders by General Courts-martial in this Department, prior to the expiration of the time fixed by the said proclamation for their voluntary return, April 1, 1863, announces that hereafter no such leniency will be shown.
CHANGES IN THE POLICE DEPARTMENT. The following appointments and resignations were made in the Police Department during the past week.

Our cavalry engaged the enemy, yesterday, at Birmingham. The fight lasted two hours and a half. The enemy was completely routed, with 15 killed and a large number wounded. Col. HATCH, of the Twenty-fifth Iowa, was seen to fall from his horse, which ran into our lines and was captured. Our loss was one killed and twenty wounded. The destruction of a bridge prevented pursuit.

He more than confirms all the published reports of our successes. The President, pointing on a map to the region about and below Port Hudson, playfully remarked, "that concern is closed up."

He more than confirms all the published reports of our successes. The President, pointing on a map to the region about and below Port Hudson, playfully remarked, "that concern is closed up."

A late telegram by the Persia announced that an Imperial manifesto had been issued granting a full amnesty to all Poles who shall lay down their arms and return to their allegiance by the 13th of May. A Cracow telegram of the 13th says;
The Georgia Legislature has passed a bill making it penal to buy, sell, circulate or receive any note, bill or draft of the United States.
The mails for Europe by the Jura, via Portland, close here on Friday at 12:45 P.M.

The article on "Limits of English Neutrality," published in this morning's paper, is abstractly correct; but in its application to the special circumstances of the outfit and departure of the Florida and Alabama,it seems to me to be incorrect.

The steamship New-York, from Southampton on the l5th inst., and the Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 15th and Queenstown on the 16th, arrived at this port yesterday, with European advices four days later.

Advices one day later from New-Orleans by the steamship Empire City, are important. News had reached the city that Gen. BANKS was at Opelousas, having taken possession of the place and all rebel property there, and opened communication with Admiral FARRAGUT above Port Hudson.

The steamship Europa, Capt. MUIR, from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 18th, via Queenstown on the 19th inst., arrived here at 11 o'clock this morning. Her dates are three days later than those per the Edinburgh at New-York.

In January last this city was politically excited by an election for members of Congress. Among the candidates whose names were before the people was T.P. MAY, Esq., a native of the State, and a large planter of the Parish of John the Baptist, forty miles up the coast.

We publish this morning an official list of the passengers on board the ill-fated steamship Anglo-Saxon whose lives have been saved, together with the statement of the first officer regarding the manner in which the vessel was wrecked. She is entirely broken up, and her mails and cargo are lost.

Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT reports to the Navy Department that on the 8th inst. he captured the steamer J.D. Clark. She had on board Maj. its WARD of the rebel Commissary Department, who was making extensive arrangements for the crossing of cattle over to the eastern shore of the river at various places, all of which was frustrated by his capture.

The reverend doctor announced as his text the 107th Psalm, from the 11th to the 14th verses. He commenced by saying the day and the service in which they were engaged were significant, the observance of the day was significant as was its appointment by the President; and so, also, was the neglect to observe it by so great a multitude.
It is stated that Bavaria has entered a special protest against the occupation of the Greek throne by any King not belonging to the Bavarian dynasty.

It was lucky that Mr. SEWARD did not yield to the importunities of Lord LYONS in regard to the purchase of cotton from the rebels. It is now clear that the object was to prepare the way for the fifteen million loan, and to secure for it a firm basis of credit.

Among the recent arrivals of fugitives from the South, I have met with one from the Central region of North Carolina, whose career, from its singularity, is calculated to awaken curiosity and interest.

The seizure of flour by the military authorities at Richmond, Va., a month or two ago, produced a deep commotion in the Old Dominion, and was felt throughout the South. The flour taken was the property, not of merchants or speculators, but of private citizens, and the Confederate Government seized it, fixed its own price which was below the market value, and compelled the owners to take their arbitrary valuation or nothing.

The Richmond Whig felicitates the Confederacy that Gen. McCLELLAN was chosen chief of the Federal army, and was continued so long in that position. It declares that "with the immense numbers at his command, an officer of truth, courage, enterprise and daring would have pushed us severely."
Field Marshal Lord VEATON, an old Peninsular and Waterloo hero, died on the 17th, aged 87. Rumor points to Lord DE GREY as the successor of Sir G.C. LEWIS, as Secretary of War.

Every race possessing any sort of vitality has some share of fighting men and military capacity. Not a few have developed a proportion amounting at times to national prowess of the most splendid character. And yet but two or three races have ever arisen so purely heroic as to endure the uttermost extremity and adversity of war without yielding.
The Paris Pays says the dispatches of England, France and Austria were presented to the Court of Russia on the 17th.
The Court-martial, in session here, have found guilty WM. F. CORBIN and T.G. McGRAU, of recruiting inside our lines for the rebel service. They were sentenced to be shot May 15.

In conformity with the President's Proclamation of the 30th of March, yesterday was very generally set apart by the citizens of New-York and Brooklyn as an occasion for fasting and prayer.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

In common with the rest of their fellow-citizens, the Israelites assembled in their respective places of worship and carried out the precepts of the President's Proclamation. Most of the Synagogues were opened and he Psalms appointed to be read on penitential days, read on the occasion.

Gov. Wm. Cannon, of Delaware, Adit.-Gen. S. M. Harrington, Col. Curtis, Dr. Wm. D. Nolan, E. C. Stolsenburg, Prof. Porter and Dr. Garrett, arrived from Baltimore this morning, and left at 1 P.M. for Yorktown and Gloucester Point, on a visit to the Delaware regiments stationed at those places.
We learn that the Imperialists have been again defeated at Shaonshing for want of besieging material.

A steamer arrived to-day with dates from Milliken's Bend to Sunday evening.
A battle was fought yesterday, commencing at 10 o'clock P.M., and lasting until 3 o'clock A.M. In the morning it was rumored that the enemy were retreating, without giving battle.
From the best attainable information from persons arriving from the Rappahannock, it appears that some important movements took place yesterday.

The National Republican, of this afternoon, publishes semi-official dispatches from Gen. BANKS, dated near St. Martinsville, April 17, from which it appears that when he left Baton Rouge three regiments of colored troops remained for its defence.
The Rappahannock is again crossed by the Army of the Potomac, and this time without the shedding of a drop of blood, or the firing of a single gun.

The United States steam transport Escort, Capt. R. WALL, (Capt. SHAW, Agent,) arrived at this port last night from Newbern, N.C., 29th and Hatteras Inlet 30th, at 6 A.M., making the passage in 55 hours.

We have a direct and reliable dispatch from Clarksburgh, stating that the Morgantown raiders were met, yesterday, midway between Fairmont and Clarksburgh, near Shinston, and defeated and driven back, with the loss of several killed and taken prisoners.

By the arrival of the steamship George Cromwell at this port, yesterday, we have advices from New-Orleans to the 26th ult. The advices from Gen. BANK'S army being as late as the 25th, at which time he had pushed his forces several miles beyond Opelonsas.

Our Special Correspondence from the Army of the Potomac, which is to Saturday morning, gives very full details of the important events which had occurred with that army up to that time. Everything had so far progressed in the most satisfactory manner.

This evening MAX MARETZEK commences a Summer season at the Academy, signalizing the occasion by the production, for the first time in America, of one of VERDI'S least known, but by no means least meritorious works. It is called "Aroldo," and the action of it is supposed to take place in England during the Saxon period.

Upon my return from United States Ford this morning the first news that greeted my ears was the death of that gallant and indomitable officer, Lieut.-Col. MoVicar, commanding the Sixth New-York Cavalry. It occurred last night, during a brilliant and daring reconnoissance toward Spottsylvania Court-house.

HOOKER has thrown his army down from the points at which it crossed the Rappahannock above Fredericksburgh, toward Chancellorsville, a hamlet lying a few miles in the rear of Fredericksburgh, with the design of flanking the rebel army and of compelling them to come out from behind their fortifications and give battle.

HURLBUT, commanding the Sixteenth Army Corps, upon the rebel lines of communication between Vicksburgh and Gen. JOHNSTON'S army.

Yesterday afternoon your correspondent learned that the gallant little remnant of the Sixth New-York cavalry, Lieut.-Col. McVICAR commanding, had started out upon a reconnoisance toward Spottsylvania Court-house. As there was nothing more interesting on hand I determined to see what a reconnoisance might be like. I accordingly dashed across the country and overtook the expedition about two miles beyond our outer pickets.

That portion of North Carolina lying north of Albemarle Sound and east of the Chowan River is now embraced in the Department of Maj.-Gen.DIX, and under the immediate supervision of Maj.-Gen. PECK, at Suffolk, Va.

The day has closed without firing on either side. The two lines of battle which the enemy showed last night were no longer visible to-day, the troops doubtless having been withdrawn to fight our forces in their rear. Their skirmish line has also been thinned out, and, to all appearances, the rebels have "raked and scraped" together all their forces to meet the rear attack.

Another bloody day has been added to the calendar of this rebellion. Another terrible battle has been fought, and more fields crimsoned with human blood. Few more such days as this will find no armies left on either side to fight battles.

We are informed upon trustworthy authority, that a prospectus has just been issued of an English joint-stock company, with a proposed capital of several hundred thousand pounds, for conveying cargoes of "assorted goods" from England to "a well-known port in Mexico," payment for the goods to be made in Confederate cotton.

The military operations which have been in progress on the line of the Rappahannock for a week past, have to-day culminated in what, if not precisely a great battle, only escapes that designation because we all feel that greater, by far, remains behind.
A heavy fight occurred this morning near Warrenton Junction between a portion of my forces, under Col. DEFOREST, and the Black Horse Cavalry and MOSBY'S and other guerrilla forces.

Rebel reports represent Gen. DODGE as having advanced eleven miles east of Tuscumbia. He had met the rebel Gen. FORREST, and fighting was reported to be going on on the 29th ult. Gen. DODGE was in possession of Courtland, Ala., on the 25th.
The Inman steamer Etna, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at noon on the 22d, and Queenstown on the 23d of April, arrived here yesterday afternoon.

PAGET, the British Minister, at which His Royal Highness declared that the only obstacles which had hitherto opposed the acceptance of the Crown of Greece, viz., the abdication of King OTHO, and the finances of Greece, having now been fully removed, he definitely accepted it for his son, Prince WILLIAM.

We have abandoned the lower crossing, not because compelled to do so, but in accordance with the general plan. On doing so, a few moments since, a rebel straggler came down to take a look at the bridge, but was kept back at a respectful distance by show of our artillery.

Our Special Correspondence this morning gives details of the important events at Fredericksburgh down to Monday morning. From the best knowledge in our possession, we think it unlikely there was any general engagement fought on Monday by Gen. HOOKER, although there was undoubtedly some heavy skirmishing.

The prize fight for the championship, between COBURN and McCooL, took place yesterday at Charlestown, Md., and was decided in favor of COBURN in one hour and ten minutes, after sixtyseven rounds had been fought.

The two salient points in the last intelligence from England were, a revival of the agitation for war and an intense interest in the result of the Connecticut election. This is no chance coincidence. Each has a bearing upon the other. They are, in fact, but different aspects of the same condition of the British mind, and every American should understand it.

At 9 o'clock, yesterday morning, Gen. PECK sent a force of infantry, cavalry and artillery across the Nansemond River at Suffolk to make a reconnoissance. DENNIS McDONALD was placed on trial yesterday, charged with stealing a pistol, valued at $50, from a stateroom in the steamship Baltic. HOWE, Esq., that the prisoner had purchased the pistol in good faith of one PETER MURPHY, and the jury accordingly acquitted him.

The annual meeting of the New-York Association of the Universalists was held yesterday morning, in the Lecture-room of Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, G.W. BARNES, Esq., in the Chair. There was a fair attendance considering the inclemency of the weather.

HOOKER has captured over eight thousand prisoners, and a large number of guns and rebel standards. Among the guns captured are ten belonging to the famous Washington Battery, of Louisiana.

Barton, James France and Jeremiah S. Lane, payable to the order of Lane. Barton has deceased since the action was commenced, and the action continues as against his executors, by an order of this Court.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamer Guatemala arrived at Panama on the 21st inst. Her dates are from Guatemala and Salvador to the 12th inst., Nicaragua to the 15th, and from Costa Rica to the 19th.

The Broadway Railroad bill has been vetoed by Gov. SEYMOUR. The Veto Message will be found in the morning's TIMES.

We published yesterday morning the proceedings of a Democratic meeting held at Mozart Hall on Thursday evening. It was emphatically a peace meeting and it took action which committed all concerned in it to a speedy and unconditional termination of the war, leaving the question of preserving the Union to the chances of future diplomatic arrangements. The policy of the Government in regard to raising and using armies, is open to a criticism that does little credit to its military sagacity or its resources. Last evening the Twenty-second regiment NewYork N.G. assembled at the pier foot of Cortlandtstreet for the purpose of extending a suitable welcome to the Fourth regiment New-York Volunteers, which was expected from Washington on the arrival of the afternoon train. Information, however, was received at 10 o'clock P.M., that the regiment would not reach this City till about 7 o'clock this (Sunday) morning.
Arrivals from the Chippewa Agency state that a difficulty has taken place between a number of Chippewa chiefs, 35 miles above Crow Wing, in which four of them were killed.

In this Court, yesterday, a motion was argued before the Recorder for a new trial in the case of ADOLPH BLANCK, convicted of grand larceny in February last. BLANCK at the time of the alleged larceny was a clerk in the employ of ALBERT DUNG, druggist, corner of Bowery and Canal-street.

The recent instructions of the Prussian War Minister, to the Commander-in-Chief of the armies of King WILLIAM on the Russian frontier, touching the mode of proceeding against such fugitive Poles as shall be so infatuated as to flee into Prussia for safety, reveal the nature of those "cartel conventions," on the fulfillment of which the royal Brandenburgher just now lays so much stress.

If there is any time at which we feel almost inclined to doubt our speedy success in putting down the rebellion and reestablishing the authority of the Government from the Lakes to the Gulf, it is when we look over the whole North and see how little it has been affected by the struggle in which the country has been engaged for two years and more.

The British steamer Peru, from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, arrived here on the 21st inst., bringing 35 passengers, $159,557 in specie for England, and the following freight: For Southampton, 406 packages bark, India-rubber, Liverpool, 381 packages; New-York, 296 packages merchandise; Acapulco, 3 packages; Central America, 11 packages; Panama, 193 packages. Her advices are from Valparaiso to the 3d inst.; from Lima and Callao to the 13th.

Brig.-Gen. Gilmore, the gallant, efficient and accomplished officer, so well known in connection with the memorable engineering operations of last year on the Southern seaboard, and who only a few weeks ago, defeated and routed a large rebel force at Somerset, Ky., is now in this City under medical treatment for disease of the throat.
The past two weeks have given historic fame to the Department of the Gulf, and the Nineteenth Army Corps. Events of the utmost importance in the present crisis have marked every one of their days.

The capture of Grand Gulf, on the Mississippi, by Gen. GRANT, and his immediate advance thence upon Port Gibson, where he attacked and defeated an army of the enemy 11,000 strong, seems at last to cut the gordian knot of the Vicksburgh difficulty.

The last work of this martyr-philosopher is preceded by a speaking likeness that will recall to many the fervid and glowing eloquence of Prof. MITCHEL, that seemed to kindle with his high themes and held its hearers spell-bound in admiration and delight.

The bold and successful raid of Gen. STONEMAN is the theme of universal and unbounded praise. He not only did all that Gen. HOOKER required him to do in the demolition of bridges and the cutting of railroad and telegraph lines in the rear of the rebel army, but more.

One of the most successful military enterprises of the kind ever undertaken, in this or any other country, terminated to-day. I refer to the recent raid of our cavalry to the rear of the rebel army, and within its lines.
It is reported by a gentleman who has just come through our lines, that Gen. VAN DORN was shot and instantly killed by Dr. PETERS, of Maury County, yesterday, at the latter's house.

The United States steamer Circassian, W.B. EATON, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday. Since leaving New-York she has visited every station in the Gulf squadron, at Sabine Pass, receiving on board Commodore FORBES, Confederate States Navy, commanding the rebel gunboats there that captured the United States ship Morning Light. He was captured by the United States steamer New-London.

AN ATTEMPT TO EXTORT MONEY BY MEANS OF THREATENING LETTERS. WM. SMITH MITCHELL, of No. 202 East Fourteenth-street, was arrested yesterday by Detectives KELSO and RADFORD, and brought before Justice DODGE, at the Lower Police Court, on the charge of having attempted to extort money from Mr. WM. J.G. ESCHMANN, of Nos. 293 and 295 Broadway, by means of threatening letters.

The number of magnificent steamships constructed within the past few months by the shipbuilders of New-York and vicinity for the China trade, deserves especial notice. Great success has attended American steamers in the waters of that Empire, and our mechanics in consequence have won the warmest encomiums.

MY DEAR FATHER: I have barely time, but will write a few lines to let you know that up to this time I am safe. On Tuesday, the 28th ult., we left camp and marched all night to the Rappahannock, which we reached the next morning at daybreak. We carried the pontoon boats, in order to avoid making a noise, two miles, thirty-six men to each boat.

I send you a short account of the engagement which took place at this post on Sunday, the 26th. The rebel horde, under MARMADUKE, was reported to be advancing from Arkansas, and preparations were made to resist him should he attack this place.

BURNSIDE'S attack on Fredericksburgh in December last, it is proper that we should also place before our readers so much of the reply of Gen. FRANKLIN to this allegation as the limited space at our command will enable us to do.

The Board of Councilmen held a special meeting at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to take suitable notice of the death of Mr. JOHN HOGAN, who died on Friday morning, and who was a member of the Board during the years of 1860, 1861 and 1862.

Maj.-Gen. Halleck, General-in-Chief: We landed at Boulinsburgh, April 30th, moved immediately on Port Gibson, met the enemy, 11,000 strong, four miles south of Port Gibson, at 2 A.M. on the 1st inst., and engaged him all day, entirely routing him with the loss of many killed, and about 500 prisoners, besides the wounded. Our loss is about 100 killed and 500 wounded.

The sudden change of plans for the formal reception of the First regiment New-York State Volunteers, has a brief history, of considerable interest. The notice of the programme for Sunday was issued on Saturday night.

The route from Milliken's Bend to this point, as constructed by our forces, is in the highest degree complimentary to their ingenuity and perseverance. The entire distance, by land, is about sixty miles, and for the greater portion of its length it has been constructed across swamps that at first sight would seem impassible for anything, save alligators or other amphibuous denizens of the country.

JAMES COSTFLLO, the man who was shot, in Grand-st., on Saturday evening last, by RICHARD JAYNES, died within a few hours after being taken to the New-York Hospital. Coroner RANNEY yesterday impanneled a jury, and proceeded to investigate the case. The following is the substance of all the material testimony given. It fully discloses the motives which induced JAYNES to commit the horrible deed:

GENERAL: I find it stated in the papers the NEW-YORK TIMES, the Washington Chronicle, the New-York Herald, etc. that it was my division which, in the action of last Saturday, threw itself flying upon the rest of the corps, and it is even said in the New-York Herald that I "led the disgraceful flight in person." These are statements against which I feel myself obliged to ask for protection.

Yesterday the First, Fourth and Twentieth regiments New-York Volunteers arrived in this City, and were received by multitudes of citizens, military and civic processions were formed, banners unfurled, salutes fired, and various manifesttations of delight exhibited.

The United States steam transport Dudley Buck, Capt. SMITH, arrived yesterday, bringing intelligence from Newbern to May 5. Gen. FOSTER was still at Newbern, superintending the strengthening of the fortifications. There had been nothing heard of the rebels in the vicinities of Newbern and Washington.

The announcement in the Philadelphia Bulletin of Saturday, published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, naturally created intense interest in this City. Its leading points were that Gen. HOOKER had recrossed the Rappahannock, and that Gen. KEYES had advanced upon and entered Richmond from Yorktown.

I have already forwarded you, by telegraph, a brief account of STONEMAN'S recent cavalry raid. The importance of this movement, in a military point of view, seems to warrant a more detailed statement of what transpired during this short but brilliant cavalry campaign the first worth mentioning undertaken during the present war, and the inauguration, it is to be hoped, of a new policy in its conduct.

Our loss is about 100 killed and 500 wounded.

The total loss of our army in the series of engagements which it has encountered during the last ten days is estimated by competent judges at about seventeen thousand. Dr. LETTERMAN, Medical Director of the Army, estimates the total number of wounded at ten thousand.

We published yesterday, on the authority of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, a statement that Gen. Hooker again crossed the Rappahannock in force on Friday, his men carrying eight days' rations. We now have positive knowledge that this statement is true. The crossing was successfully accomplished, but at what point, or in what direction the army moved, is not at present known.

The past week was an unfavorable one for Mr. MARETZEK'S operatic enterprise. Its opening was in dangerous proximity to the great "moving day," and its close, with the exception of Saturday, was moist and forbidding. Notwithstanding these circumstances the spirit of the manager was unflagging, and hence we had four splendid performances three of them being of VERDI'S new opera of "Aroldo," and the fourth of the same maestro's "Ernani."

From early sunrise yesterday morning till long past the small hours of evening this Metropolis was kept in a constant whirl of excitement, by the appearance on the streets of military and civic pageants, the beating of drums, the sounding of trumpets, the blazonry of banners and the firing of cannon. Not for a long period has New-York witnessed such an eventful Sunday.
By a flag of truce to-day we learn of the death of Col. VAN HOUGHTEN, who was wounded in the leg at the battle of Salem Heights on Monday evening, and taken prisoner. He was a brave man.

At a late hour on Saturday afternoon last, quite a number of the "fancy men" of this City received a notice to the effect that on Monday morning, (yesterday,) about daylight, a prize fight would take...

We have no later intelligence from the Army of the Potomac this morning. We have, however, from various sources, a reiteration of the statement made in yesterday's TIMES, that Gen. HOOKER is again across the Rappahannock.
The People on the Relation of the Pacific Mutual Insurance Company vs. John A. Machado. This case came up on certiorari, to review the proceedings taken before John H. McCunn, Esq., the City Judge.
How is it must a human creature smell powder to become a man? Is there indeed such virtue in "villainous saltpetre?" Surely there must be something strange to account...
The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 29th, and Queenstown on the 30th ult., arrived at this port about 1 o'clock this morning. Her advices are four days later than before received.
We get but few newspapers in these parts, and are, of course, in blissful ignorance of the grand victories which our forces have achieved at Charleston and other places.
Under the provisions of the Enrollment law, as construed at the War Department, the men will be in the service of the United States from the moment they are drafted.
Aon. Alfred Ely, Rochester; T.T. Davis, Syracuse, and Wm. Kelly, Rhinebeck; Maj. Lee. U.S. A., and Henry Sanford, Bridgeport, are among the arrivals at tde St. Nicholas Hotel.
The steamship Bohemian arrived off Cape Race yesterday morning, having left Liverpool on the 30th ult., and Londonderry on the 1st inst., and the City of Washington arrived at this port this morning.
