The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this city Sunday from the army, were yesterday honored with a municipal and military ovation.

The United States transport Oriole, Capt. HOLMES, from Port Royal, S.C., 6th inst., arrived yesterday, and reports that all the iron-clads had left Port Royal for the North Edisto, having repaired damages.
The gratifying progress that Gen. GRANT is making in circumventing the rebel army in Mississippi is one of the most hopeful features of the war.
The Memphis Bulletin says: "We learn that Jackson is already invested, and that the rebels have no way of getting out of Vicksburgh but by cutting their way through the National forces.
Capt. F.W. ARMSTRONG and Lieut. L.G. ESTIS, the latter detached from the First Maine cavalry, arrived here to-day from Col. KILPATRICK'S raids. After leaving Kelly's Ford on the Rappahannock, Col.
The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment, (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this City Sunday from the seat of war, met with an enthusiastic public reception yesterday.
Major-Gen. DIX and Quartermaster GILBERT left for Suffolk this fornoon:
COTTON Sales of the last four days 16,000 bales, including 5,000 to speculators and exporters. The market has been dull and all qualities have declined slightly, but is firmer at the close.
The forces of Gen. GRANT encountered some 10,000 of the enemy, yesterday morning, on his march toward Port Gibson, and had an engagement, lasting some two hours and a half.

in the brief dispatch of Gen. GRANT, concerning the fight on the 1st of May near Port Gibson, Miss., that he found and fought there a garrison of eleven thousand men, seemed almost incredible, as Port Gibson was a place...
THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
The announcement that WENDELL PHILLIPS would speak last night, upon the "State of the Country," at the Cooper Institute, drew together.

In the House of Commons, on the 28th, the annual effort was made to carry the bill for the abolition of the Church rate to a second reading was made. Although supported by Ministers, it was defeated by a vote of 285 to 275.

On Thursday, HOOKER'S right wing had reached a point near Spottsylvania Court-house, his left resting on the Rapidan at Ely's Ford, and his centre on Chancellorsville, ten miles southwest of Fredericksburgh.
Our files by the City of Washington, the receipt of which was acknowledged yesterday, furnish some intelligence of importance in addition to that already published.

GENERAL ORDERS, NO. 59. With heartfelt gratification, the General commanding expresses to the army his sense of the heroic conduct displayed by officers and men, during the arduous operations in which they have just been engaged.
In the House of Lords, on April 27, the subject of the seizure of British vessels with mail-bags, came up, according to notice, when the following debate transpired:

A telegram from Fort Monroe, 17th, contains a statement, based on what is claimed good authority, that JACKSON is not expected to live. He was accidentally shot by his own men. While another, dated Headquarters army of the Potomac, appears in the Star, saying the Richmond papers of yesterday contain obituary notices of JACKSON, who died Sunday afternoon.

We have received a copy of the Richmond Dispatch extra of the 6th, which says the fight on Sunday at Wilderness Church was one of the bloodiest of the war. It claims that the Confederates had taken at that date 5,000 prisoners, including Brig.-Gen. HAYS of COUCH'S corps, and his Aid-de-Camp, Capt. ECHOLS. It also claims that they captured five batteries of field artillery.

We published on Monday morning the charges upon which Mr. VALLANDIGHAM was recently tried by Court-martial in Cincinnati. We have no doubt that the evidence offered was sufficient to establish their truth.

Yesterday morning another daring robbery was discovered at the Brooklyn Navy-yard this time on board a man-of-war in commission. Between midnight and 4 A.M. the Quartermaster of the watch on board the United States gunboat Sumter, assisted probably by some accomplice, actually seized the safe locked up in the Purser's room, and absconded with it in a small boat, a watchman looking on, and believing all to be right.

The return of the two years' and nine months' men during the next few weeks will reduce our Army of the Potomac by a good many thousands; battles, marches and disease will reduce it by a good many more.

We publish this morning a congratulatory order from Gen. HOOKER to the Army of the Potomac. He says if it has not accomplished all that was expected, the reasons are well known to it. The obstacles were of a character not to be foreseen or prevented by human sagacity or resources. New laurels have been added to its former renown.

Owing to the rapid succession of engagements and the confusion censequent upon the enemy getting in our rear, I was unable, in my report of the storming of the Fredericksburgh Heights, to do more than describe the operations of the first division which reached the heights, contenting myself with a passing notice of the other two-HOWE's and NEWTON'S. I observe that this has been the case with the other accounts.
Dates from the City of Mexico to the 16th, and from Puebla to the 14th of April, are received.

Mr. WM. GOODHUE, the Vice-Consul of the United States at Zanzibar, reports that Messrs. SPEKE and GRANT'S expedition in search of the sources of the Nile, have been almost, if not entirely crowned with success.
The following is the portion of the Bohemian's news which failed to reach us on Monday night, owing to trouble on the telegraph wires at the eastward.

GRANT, THE BURGLAR. CHAS. H. GRANT, alias GORDON, the burglar, about whom so much excitement was caused some months since, in consequence of his numerous and successful burglaries, was arraigned before the Court of Sessions yesterday. The accused pleaded guilty to the indictments found against him, of which there are some eight or nine, and was remanded to jail to await sentence.

The facts connected with the flag of truce sent over by Gen. LEE, on Wednesday, are, as stated by himself, that he had exhausted his medicines, surgical appliances and hospital stores for the wounded, and asking for fresh supplies. These were sent over by the way of United States Ford.

One of the most terrific gunpowder explosions which ever took place in this City, occurred at a late hour on Monday night, at the foot of Seventy-eighthstreet, East River. The report was heard in every part of the country for the distance of fifty miles. The damage to the property is very great, and the wonder is, that no lives were lost by the catastrophe.
In the House of Commons, on April 28, a long debase took place regarding the condition of the British navy. In the course of it Sir J. ELPHINSTONE said:
The failure of the Federal attack on the Charleston forts was the theme of general comment; but there is a wide difference in the deductions drawn from the event.

Richmond papers of Saturday contain the following items. There is little in their editorials except favorable comments upon their most extravagant exaggerations of our losses, and the advantages gained thereby to the Confederate army.

The Government of Lord PALMERSTON has been forced into the confessional by threatening parliamentary majorities. In the House of Lords the aspect became cloudy enough far Lord RUSSELL when such a Whig placeman as the Marquis of Clanricarde undertook to expose the pusillanimity of his friend and patron in the Foreign Office.

The Richmond papers of yesterday announce the death of Stonewall JACKSON, on Sunday afternoon, from the effects of his recent amputation and pneumonia. His burial was fixed for to-day. The military band in Fredericksburgh had been performing dirges a greater portion of the afternoon.

Some of our readers may remember Mr. J. L. O'SULLIVAN, formerly of this City at one time member of the State Assembly, afterward Minister to Portugal, and now a resident, for private purposes, of London. He has just published in that City a letter to Prof. ...

Mr. MARETZEK, although the best of managers, is the most unfortunate of men. If his singers do not happen to be sick, or to have an appointment with their lawyers in Belgium, the weather is sure to be execrable.

The grand mass meeting of the citizens of Brooklyn, held last night at the Academy of Music, under the auspices of the "Irish Relief Executive Committee," for the purpose of collecting funds to aid the distress now prevailing in Ireland, was a complete success, in a pecuniary point of view, but not nume- ...

In the death of Stonewall JACKSON, the rebels have unquestionably lost by far their greatest military leader, in the peculiar style of strategy which has made his name famous. Immediately after the secession of Virginia he appeared on the scene, and ever since then he has been one of the foremost figures.

We have, from one of our Mississippi gunboat correspondents, confirmation of the statement already made by our correspondent with Gen. GRANT'S land force, that the troops who manned the rebel batteries and fought the action, in the recent battle at Grand Gulf, were negroes.
It is reported, rid Cairo, that Gen. GRANT has fought a severe battle at Clinton, ten miles from Jackson, Miss., and defeated the rebels. The fight is said to have lasted an entire day.

The English jour- nals at hand by the latest mail, discuss very fully the news they had received of the last attack on Charleston. They view the matter almost entirely in its scientific aspects, and come to conclusions as varied and inconclusive as those reached by different classes of speculators in this country.

We are glad to know that large preparations are being made to insure that the Convention of the Loyal Leagues of the State, to be held at Utica on the 27th inst., in pursuance of the resolution of the great Madisonsquare gathering, shall be worthy of the occasion. The design is to give concentrated expression to the war spirit of the Empire State.
The United States steamer Gen. Meigs leaves here for New-York at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

A large force has just been put ashore on the Mississippi side, at a plantation eight miles below Grand Gulf, known as "Bruenburgh," and is now marching toward Port Gibson. The intention is, as near as I can learn the plan of movements, to get in ...

Hon. ROBERT OULD, the rebel Commissioner for the exchange of prisoners, came down the James River to Newport's News, yesterday, to confer with Col. LUDLOW, the United States Commissioner, in reference to the delivery to the latter of the large number of officers and men now in Richmond, recently captured at Fredericksburgh. Transports were sent up to City Point for them this morning. Suitable provision has been made for the sick and wounded.
The mails for Europe by the Norwegian, vid Quebec close in this City on Thursday at 1 P.M.

The thirty-eighth annual meeting of this Society, at Irving Hall yesterday morning, attracted a large audience. Rt. Rev. CHAS, P. MCILVAINE, D.D., President of the Society, occupied the Chair, and Rev. JOHN M. KREBS, D.D., opened the proceedings with prayer.

The events of the week, since we last went to press, have made a revelation of the virulence and scope of faction, which goes far to account for the still prolongation of the war, and the want of unanimity and fixed purpose in the Government.

Maj. John Hancock, Assistant Adjutant-General: I beg most respectfully to tender you, and through you to the proper authorities, my resignation as Brigadier-General Commanding what was once known as the Irish Brigade. That brigade no longer exists. The assault on the enemy's works on the 13th December last reduced it ...
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

By the arrival of the English steamer Clyde at Havana, from Vera Cruz, and the steamer Eagle at this port, from Havana, files of papers from the Mexican Republic have been received, containing full details of the operations of the siege of Puebla.

Yesterday noon, in accordance with a previous arrangement, a large number of ambulances repaired to the Lacey House for the purpose of conveying the wounded who should be brought across to the various hospitals.

We have advices from Mexico of an important character, by way of Havana, received by the steamship Eagle, which arrived at this port last evening. The latest authentic news from Puebla is to the 23d ult., at which time the city was still in possession of the Mexicans, and was likely to continue so.
Copies of the Richmond Examiner, of Saturday last furnish us the following interesting extracts:

A fight for $250 a side, between ELLIOTT and DUNN, came off at 7 o'clock A.M., yesterday, at Weehawken. Twelve rounds were fought in the space of thirty minutes. During the last round DUNN fell upon the ropes, and while in that position was struck by ELLIOTT, which was decided by the referee to be a foul blow. Such being the decision, the fighting ceased, and the crowd dispersed.
The following letter is from a very high authority at Vera Cruz:

The Shipping Gazette says the information in the case of the gunboat Alexandra was filed as the first case to be tried in the Court of Exchequer, Westminster, before a special jury, either at the end of the present term or early in the next. La France says the elections will commence on the 31st of May, and the Corps Legislatif will reassemble for a fortnight's session in July.
We have already published a telegraphic account of this battle. The following further particulars are from a letter to the Chicago Tribune, dated the 2d inst.:

The NEW-YORK TIMES appears this morning printed on paper imported by the proprietors from Belgium. It is white, and of texture sufficiently good for newspaper use. It was bought in Belgium for seven and a half cents per pound, at the very time when the Paper Makers' Association or combination here had, by simultaneous action, forced printing paper up to twenty-two and twenty-four cents the pound.
Of the treasure shipped per the steamer Orizaba, to-day, $108,000 is for the London Lloyds, that being their proportion of the amount recovered from the wreck of the steamer Golden Gate.

The annual meeting of the Mercantile Library Association was held Tuesday evening at their rooms, Hon. JOHN COCHRANE presiding. The annual reports of the President, Mr. CHARLES OSGOOD, and the Treasurer, Mr. ALEXANDER RHIND, were presented, showing a very satisfactory state of affairs for the year just closed.

This day, which a year ago was signalized by the capture and occupation of New-Orleans by the Union forces, has been again rendered memorable by one of the fiercest and longest contested naval engagements of the war.
The National Convention of the Women of America, met at the Church of the Puritans at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. A large audience was present composed mainly of ladies.

The Macon House and Ocean House, formerly hotels, and recently used as hospitals under those names, have just been consolidated, and will hereafter be known as the Cuyler General Hospital, under the superintendence of Dr. McKAY, formerly of the Chesapeake Hospital at Hampton.

The British frigate Rinaldo arrived this afternoon, having left Charleston at 3 P.M. last Monday. By this steamer a copy of the Charleston Daily Courier, of May 11, has been received, which contains the announcement of the death of Gen. THOMAS J. JACKSON, known as "Stonewall JACKSON." It states that he died at Guinea, Virginia, on the 10th, at 3 o'clock P.M., from the combined effect of his wound and an attack of pneumonia.
Senators WADE and CHANDLER, after a lengthy interview to-day with the President and Secretary of War, left, this evening, in a special boat for the army.

The receipts of the principal kinds of produce since our last have been 115 bbls. Ashes, 20,042 bbls Flour, 554 bbls, and 741 bags Corn Meal, 224,449 bushels Wheat, 439,876 bushels Corn, 330 bushels Rye, 61,549 bushels Oats, 8,148 bushels Malt, 5,101 pkgs. Provisions and 454 bbls Whisky.
Consols, after official hours yesterday, were very firm at 93 5/8. Railway stocks were stronger. Mexican bonds were much higher. The French funds on the Paris Bourse opened at 69f. 65c.
Congressman WASHBURNE left the extreme front on Friday. From him we learn that GRANT'S advance was then within 15 miles of Edward's Station, which was 18 miles east of Vicksburgh.

Official advices from Gen. GRANT to the 8th inst. have been received in Washington. He expresses himself as satisfied with the condition of affairs in his vicinity. His satisfaction seems to be justified by the tone of a rebel letter from Vicksburgh, published in the Jackson Appeal, which takes a gloomy view of affairs, and says that Gen. GRANT'S movement has deceived the rebels, both civil and military.

Mr. L.L. CROUNSE, of the New-York TIMES Staff on the Rappahannock, sends to this Bureau the following exceedingly interesting extracts from the Richmond Enquirer of the 13th, and Sentinel of the 14th.

From every side we hear that the spoils left by HOOKER'S army exceed these on any previous battlefield, not excepting the engagements around Richmond. Not only an immense number of small arms variously estimated from 30,000 to 50,000 but an almost infinite quantity of overcoats, knapsacks, caps and blankets.

WENDELL PHILLIPS, in his speech on Monday night, spoke of the danger that the rebels may adopt an emancipation policy, and asked, argumentatively, "If loyal men will surrender their slaves to save the Union, don't you suppose the disloyal will surrender theirs to save the Confederacy?"

The Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, plaintiffs and respondents, vs. The Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Railroad Company, defendants and appellants.?Both parties are foreign corporations?the plaintiffs being incorporated under the laws of the State of Connecticut, and the defendants under the laws of the State of Ohio.

Col. JACOB, in Sunday's fight with the rebels CLARKE and CHENAULT, at Horseshoe Bottom Narrows, on the Cumberland, lost 42 men, including 3 officers. Capt. CHENAULT, and several other rebel officers, and 98 of their men were killed, and 3 taken prisoners.

The public mind has been so much engrossed by the late movement upon Richmond and its unfortunate sequel, that the new movement upon Vicksburgh has excited little attention; and yet the latter promises far more important reslts than could have come from the former, however successful.

Lieuts, WOOD, ROACH and WEART, of the Ambulance corps, who have been engaged on the opposite side of the river in securing the wounded of the Sixth corps, returned yesterday, having seen the last man over. They have been treated very kindly by the rebel authorities, and every assistance has been rendered them in getting the wounded to this side of the river.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Old Sol long hidden by murky clouds that shadowed and showered o'er sacred soil now rays like a red hot coal on Potomac's expectant army.

[The following letters from our special correspondent with the fleet which recently ran the Vicksburgh batteries, have been delayed for some time in their transmission to us, but they are still exceedingly interesting. ED. TIMES.]

On the 16th ult., a movement of importance the result of a consultation between Gens. ROSECRANS and GRANT was inaugurated. From our Bermuda files we learn that the House of Assembly convened on April 15, and was opened with an address from his Excellency the Governor, which contained the following allusions to American affairs:

There have been two important land cases, affecting real estate in this city, decided during the past week. The first was one in which Mrs. F.B. NICHOLLS vs. W.B. OGDEN and others among whom was CHARLES BUTLER, of New-York were interested, known as the Northwestern Land Company. Mrs. NICHOLLS sued for her right of dower in a large amount of real estate, her husband having been a member of the Company.

Mason vs. Ring, Administrator. So much of the order appealed from as directs a reference, reversed; in other respects it is affirmed, without prejudice to the plaintiff's right to apply hereafter to substitute other security for the residue of the lots, or to obtain a release of other of the lots, on making a case calling for the interposition of the Court. Opinion by BOSWORTH.

As I informed you in a previous letter, our list of missing would be greatly reduced when the official returns came in. Already there has been a great diminution, although the returns are not complete as yet. Many supposed to be wounded and prisoners have turned up safe.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Inclosed, please find a complete list of the casualties in this regiment, in the late engagements. Please publish in the form sent for the information of friends and relatives in the different parts of the country.

Two weeks ago to-day was fought the great battle of Chancellorsville, or, as the rebels prefer to call it, the battle of the Wilderness. One week ago to-day we had news, which stirred the City and the whole country, that Richmond had fallen into our hands, and that Gen. HOOKER'S army had again crossed the Rappahannock, to assail the rebels.

Capt. PERCIVAL DRAYTON has been detached from the command of the iron-clad battery Passaic, at his own request, and will in a few weeks relieve Capt. NICHOLSON, as Chief of Ordnance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, who also desires a change of duty. The Navy Department has tendered Capt. NICHOLSON the command of the Passaic, but it is not yet known whether he will accept it.

The truth that both officers and men to a considerable number daily arrive from the Rappahannock and proceed to their homes, on leaves of absence, is regarded as an additional indication that the Army will not immedlately make a movement against the enemy.

A meeting was held in Albany last evening, to protest against the arrest and trial of VALLANDIGHAM. Speeches were made by Hon. AMASA J. PARKER and others, and a letter condemning the arrest, from Gov. SEYMOUR, was read. An attempt was made to break up the meeting, by the dispatch says some returned soldiers, but it did not succeed.
Since the last steamer everything remains unaltered in Panama, and there is really not a word of local news worth reporting.
The mails by the steamship America arrived in New-York last evening, and we give below such extracts from our foreign files as we find of interest.

Notice is hereby given, that the New-York State Soldiers' Depot will be opened on the 15th inst., for the reception of the sick, wounded, furloughed and discharged soldiers of the State, and for others requiring protection and assistance to and from the field.

The meeting to protest against the arbitrary arrest and sentence of Hon. CLEMENT L. VALLANDIGHAM, at the Capitol to-night, was largely attended. Strong speeches were made by Hon. AMASA J. PARKER, Hon. FRANCIS KEDNAN, JOHN MURPHY, Esq., of Buffalo, and others.

In the House of Lords, on the 30th: The Earl of Hardwicke asked what course the Government was going to adopt in relation to the continuation of the works on the forts at Spithead, and stated that about 100,000 had been sunk under water, and would be lost unless the forts were proceeded with. He referred to the recent affair at Charleston as another proof of the superiority of forts over ships.

The following named officers are announced, having been appointed by the President, in conformity with sections 5 and 8 of the approved March 3, 1863, "for enrolling and calling out the National forces," They will be obeyed and respected accordingly:

Ellen Burns vs. Charles Erben and Thomas Frost. This was an action for a false arrest. On Saturday evening, July 6, 1861, the plaintiff, a young sewing girl, and a minor, visited her acquaintance, a chambermaid in the employ of Henry Erben. Soon after she left, it was discovered that a drawer of silver had been stolen from the sideboard in the basement.
It is well understood that Maracaibo and Barquisimeto have both within the last month declared for the Federation, and divested themselves of the equivocal character they had hitherto maintained.

After the wounding of Gen. JACKSON, Gen. A. P. HILL assumed command of his corps, and he being disabled, Gen. STUART succeeded to the command, retaining it for the present. It consists of four full divisions of fifteen thousand men each.

It is clear that a pause has been established in the rapid depreciation of Confederate money. There are decisive indications, indeed, of a positive appreciation; afforded by the distirct rise in price of many articles of trade. The recent legislation of Congress, judicious though tardy, must have two results; namely, it must put a wholesome check upon speculation, and must recall from circulation a large amount of redundant paper.

The Germans in the West are engaged in a very general and very determined effort to influence President LINCOLN to remove Maj.-Gen. HALLEOK from his position as General-in-Chief of the army. The Tribune, of this City, makes an open and almost petulant complaint of the Administration for not having placed Maj.-Gen. SIGEL in a command which he has frequently and quite recently sought.

EDWARD PRINCE moved with his regiment, the Seventh Illinois cavalry volunteers 542, officers and men from Lagrange, Tenn., at 10 o'clock A.M., on the 17th of April, 1863, on the Ripley road, and camped on the plantation of Dr. ELLIS, four miles northwest of Ripley, Miss. distance about 30 miles.
The Inman steamer City of New York, Capt. KENNEDY, which left Liverpool at noon on the 6th, and Queenstown on the 7th inst., arrived here at 12 o'clock last night.

Lieut.-Col. WATKINS, law partner of Judge WILMOT, reported killed at the battle of Chancellorsville, has arrived here. He was shot through the body and left on the field for dead, but falling into the hands of Dr. BRECKINRIDGE, Medical Director of LEE'S army, his life was saved.

By the arrival at this port of the steamship George Washington, we receive highly important intelligence from the Department of the Gulf. She left New-Orleans on the 10th inst. On the 2d inst., a deputation of Trades Unionists waited upon Mr. ADAMS, the American Minister, to present the address recently adopted at a public meeting of that body, sympathizing with the North, and applauding President LINCOLN for his emancipation policy. Mr. BRIGHT introduced the deputation, and made a few pertinent remarks. Speeches were also made by several members of the deputation.
We had intelligence from the Southwest, a week ago, that part of Admiral PORTER'S fleet had gone down the Mississippi as far as the mouth of the Red River, and ascended the latter stream.

Senators WADE and CHANDLER returned last evening from Falmouth. Confidence in their ability to observe accurately and judge correctly will be universally felt. They report the troops in most effective condition and in the best spirits, and impatient for another and an immediate chance at LEE's army, asking only that the ground shall be such that they can get at the rebels and keep at them.

The Union-square meeting, last enemy, for the purpose of sympathizing with Mr. VALLANDIGHAM and denouncing his recent arrest, trial and imprisonment, was attended by about three thousand persons, Most of the distinguished gentlemen announced to speak, excused themselves for non-attendance. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the arrest, and all trials by military commissions, as unconstitutional.

In response to a call for a meeting of citiizens of New-York to protest against the recent arrest and trial of Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, a gathering of about three thousand persons look place in Union-square, last evening. GRANT'S forces have captured Jackson, the Capital of Mississippi, lying 45 miles in the rear and directly east of Vicksburgh. FELLOW-CITIZENS: I desire to address you very briefly on subjects connected with our present national difficulties. But it will not be necessary for me to attempt to retrace the history of the war. It is written in the memory and upon the hearts of all our people. I desire only to present to you some general views in relation to it, which will enable me better to explain and you better to understand the course.

The President has approved the findings of the Court-Martial in VALLANDIGHAM'S case, but has ordered him to be forthwith sent beyond our lines. General satisfaction is expressed at the result, which so happily meets the difficulties of the case avoiding the possibility of making him a martyr, and yet effectually destroying his power for evil. It is understood that Gen. BURNSIDE has already executed the order.

The United States frigate St. Lawrence has returned from another crulse. This is her tenth, and at its close she is as sound as when she sailed from Boston, needing only such general repairs as vessels require when a long time on active service.

WADSWORTH. The World has for some days past devoted a large portion of its space to attacks upon Gen. WADSWORTH, based mainly upon the testimony which he gave in the McDowell Court of Inquiry, touching the forces left for the defence of Washington when Gen. McCLELLAN took the Army of the Potomac to the Peninsula.

One of the commonest of the small jokes by which Pro-Slavery fanatics have always sought to confound the Abolitionists, consisted in asking them why they did not go and preach their gospel in Charleston, or Richmond, where Slavery exists, instead of preaching it here, where there is no Slavery. The same humorists have, since the war began, resorted to another piece of wit of the same character, but intended to be much more biting.

Over one hundred and fifty years ago, the first Bible ever printed in the American colonies made its appearance, bearing the Imprint of WILLIAM BRADFORD, whose name bears the same relation to the art of printing in this country as does that of CAXTON to the art in Great Britain.

A grand military and civic reception was extended yesterday to the Seventeenth regiment, N.Y.V., which arrived in the City at 8 A.M. The procession was formed at 2 P.M., and after passing in review the Mayor, marched up Broadway to the upper end of the City, and then returned to the Park Barracks, where the Seventeenth was entertained in the evening with a dinner given by the City authorities.

The Seventeenth New-York State Volunteer regiment, under the command of Lieut.-Col. N.B. BARTRAM, arrived in this City from the Rappahannock yesterday morning at 8 o'clock. The regiment numbers about 300 men. It was organized by Col. H.S. LANSING, who was with it up to the time of his appointment as general recruiting officer for the State of New-York, which position he now holds.

DODWORTH'S HALL. OSCAR WEIL, a composer, who has obtained notice in Germany, will give a concert here to-night, for the purpose of introducing several of his compositions. Miss LOUISE LUDEOUS, Mr. THEODOR THOMAS, Mr. ROBERT GOLDDECK and Mr. H.C. TIMM will assist Mr. WEIL.
The repulse of the fleet of iron-clads and "monitors" at Charleston, has given, you may well suppose, the keenest satisfaction to the English Government and people.

The Eastern and Western Gulf Squadrons continue to send in prizes to this port, the last ones being two schooners with cargoes, from Havana, which were condemned and sold here about three weeks since, and after loading at Havana, have already found the blockade too vigilant for them and were again captured one by the Kennebec, off Mobile, the other by the Kanawha, off Pensacola.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS In this Court yesterday LOUIS MARX and GOTLIEB KAISER were placed on trial, on the charge of misdemeanor in maintaining a bone-boiling establishment in the town of Flatbush, near the city line, which proved to be a nuisance to many residents of the neighborhood.

DISCHARGE OF THE ARRESTED PRIZE-FIGHTERS. The Democratic State mass meeting to-day was largely attended. D.W. VOORHEES presided. Messrs. MERRICK and EDON, of Illinois, and McDONALD, of Indiana, were the principal speakers.

In the course of my journeyings as a correspondent, I have met with many old classmates and acquaintances of the late rebel Gen. JACKSON, from whose lips I have heard much about him; and as everything pertaining to this remarkable man seems to interest the public. I will set down two or three anecdotes which have not yet found their way into the public prints.

In an article, a few days since, we attempted to show the different positions in respect of Slavery as affected by the present war, of the three great Border States--Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri. We showed that secession had destroyed, in great part, the external commerce of these States which was based on the products of slave labor, and had also in great measure annihilated the value of their slaves as property.

The notion that the grass would grow in Broadway, if New-York lost the Southern trade, on which the Pro-Slavery partisans used to rely so much in their appeals to Northern baseness and cupidity in old times, has at last been thoroughly disposed of. The hardiest plant in the American fauna has never had less chance of supporting life on Broadway than at this moment.

Our correspondent at Fort Snelling on the Upper Mississippi, furnishes rather a surprising idea of the magnitude of the military operations being carried on under Gen. POPE against certain Indian tribes of the Northwest.
The steamship North American passed Father Point yesterday, on her way to Quebec, with news fram Europe one day later. Politically it is unimportant.

The Richmond Sentinel characterizes the lies which floated about the North for a few days after HOOKER recrossed the Rappahannock as "false and absurd beyond precedent." They were false and absurd enough, but the Sentinel need not have gone outside of the columns of the Richmond papers to find in their statements, in relation to the late battle, precedent enough, if that were wanting.

Orders have been issued from the Provost-Marshal General's office to be prepared for making a draft immediately on the completion of enrollment. The hope is now expressed that the draft may be made before the 1st of July.

Generally monotonous as is the face of the Western county, the constrast is striking when you launch upon the Upper Mississippi, with its tireless succession of lofty peaks and rounded heights, its labyrinth of deep valleys descending from the back country, its groves of stately trees along the bottom lands, and then for miles its mural bluffs of limestone, two hundred feet in height, like colossal ramparts, darkly reflected in the glassy surface beneath.

The supply steamer Union arrived yesterday, having completed the round of the blockading stations. She left New-York April 8, with supplies for the South Atlantic and East and West Gulf Blockading Squadrons, and stopped at the following places: Port Royal, New Inlet, Key West, Charlotte Harbor.

The expedition was under the command Lieut-Col. LEWIS.

HARRY SANDERSON IN BROOKLYN. TO-night, at the Brooklyn Academy, Mr. HARRY SANDERSON, a young pianist of great talent and much culture, will give a grand concert. He will be assisted by Mr. GOTTTSCHALK, Miss. JENNY KEMPTON, Mr. THOMAS, Mr. WM. CASTLE and a host of other talent. In the present dearth of music in Brooklyn this concert will prove a most grateful and timely attraction.

In the House of Lords, on the 8th, the Earl o Shaftesbury brought the subject of Poland before the house of Lords, making a very strong pro-Polish speech.

Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOT CO., of London, the large and wealthy manufacturers of submarine telegraph cables, have subscribed 40,000 sterling to the new guaranteed stock of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, in addition to the 25,000 subscribed by them last October, making their cash subscription 65,000 sterling, or in American currency at the present rate of exchange between London and New York, $500,000.

THE UNION HOME SCHOOL SOCIETY. The second annual meeting of the Union Home School Society was held at the Home, Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth streets, near Eighth-avenue, on Friday, at 3 P.M. On the 14th of April Prince GORTSCHAKOFF replied to the protest of England in behalf of Poland. Earl RUSSELL'S dispatch, dated April 10, instructed Lord NAPIER to protest against the infraction of the treaty stipulations of 1815 by Russia, and expressed the opinion that the insurrection of the Poles was justified by the course of action which Russia had pursued.

The Thirty-first regiment New-York Volunteers arrived in this City yesterday via Camden and Amboy line from Philadelphia. The regiment numbers 313 men. The original number was enlisted principally in this City, although two or three of the companies were from Brooklyn and Willamsburgh.

The NEW-YORK TIMES appears this morning printed on paper which was manufactured to order, in Belgium. The article is fully as good as the average used on the morning journals, being white, soft, smooth, and sufficiently strong and heavy for newspaper purposes. At the same time, the price, in spite of the duty and the high rates of exchange, is such as to impose an effectual check upon all combinations of paper-makers for the future.

THE ADRIATIC ACCIDENT. The injuries to Mr. IRA BUCKMAN, of the Custom-house, and formerly Superintendent of the Grand-street and Newtown Railroad, are not likely to prove fatal. On Saturday his right arm, which had suffered a compound fracture, was amputated, and he was otherwise very low, but since that he has rallied considerably, and is now believed to be out of danger.

The Government are evidently bent on provoking an outburst on the part of the Lower Chamber, and if they fail to do so, the fault will not be theirs.

GENTLEMEN: Your letter of invitation, dated 12th inst., was received at my camp on the 23d. I regret that my duties will prevent me from addressing the assemblage at Utica, on the 27th; and, not having been favored with a copy of the resolutions to be submitted to the meeting. I can but imperfectly respond to your request for cooperation in this patriotic movement.
Pursuant to orders from the War Department of the 12th inst., the undersigned relinquishes the command of this Department to Major-Gen. SCHOFIELD.

Yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, a meeting in favor of VALLANDIGHAM's course, and in opposition to that of the Government, was held in Military Park, in the City of Newark. There was a pretty good gathering around the stands, if the children and boys be included, otherwise it was a signal failure both in influence and respectability.

Up to a late hour last night, no later official advices had been received from Gen. GRANT'S army. A dispatch received in Cincinnati yesterday, via Memphis--date not given--says no fighting had taken place since Monday. Most of the river batteries had been silenced, and the gunboats were engaged in shelling the rest.
General Instructions to District-Attorneys and Marshals relative to Proceedings under the Act of Congress for Confiscation.
GEORGIA, ALABAMA AND TENNESSEE. A Union man, who has just made his escape from the rebel States, makes some interesting statements to the Nashville Union. That paper says:

A meeting of the Joint Committee appointed to make arrangements for the reception of the above regiments was held at the Astor House last evening. During the day the Committee conferred with Gens. SANDFORD and HALL, and received from those officers the assurance that they would make suitable arrangements in regard to the military display on the occasion of the arrival of the two regiments.
A special to the Bulletin, dated Cincinnati, May 30, says:

The popular novelists have, thus far, only nibbled at the fruitful subject of railway financiering. DICKENS, at various times, incidentally, and LEVER, in more elaborate form, have made some use of the theme for public amusement or instruction; but there is a world of unexplored plottings, involving grotesque and tragic incident in about an equal degree, which a master hand might illustrate with great success.

The election in Norfolk and Portsmouth, yesterday, resulted in the election of the entire Union ticket. The election passed off quietly. In the afternoon the citizens of Portsmouth had a pole raising. Speeches were made by Col. JOHNSON, of the One Hundred and Forty-fifth New-York Volunteers, and several prominent citizens.

Capt. WILKINS, of Gen. WILLIAMS' Staff, who was captured in the battle at Chancellorsville, has reached Detroit, and makes some interesting statements to the Free Press. At the time the Eleventh corps was routed, he was dispatched by Gen. WILLIAMS with some important orders. The Free Press says:
The following is the full statement gathered at the Philadelphia Exchange regarding the operations of the rebel privateers, the points of which have already been given by telegraph:

The Copperhead evening organ was careful last night to inform its readers of a further invasion of the liberty of the citizen by a party of civil and military officials. During the afternoon of yesterday, a company of gentlemen, of the order vulgarly termed bummers, were peaceably enjoying themselves in a public bar-room near the Old Bowery Theatre, when an enrolling clerk entered the house in pursuance of his duties.

MOSEBY'S GUERRILLAS. MOSEBY'S guerrillas made their appearance to-day at Catlett's Station, on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, and this time with artillery, which was brought to bear with effective force on one of our trains standing on the back there. Ten cars and a locomotive were destroyed.
Col. PHILLIPS, commanding in the Indian Territory, had a severe fight with a portion of PRICE's army on the 20th.

An occasional correspondent of the Times--an English officer, who has received an appointment under the Confederate Government--gives an account of a night spent in the camp of the late Stonewall JACKSON. Writing from Charleston, he says:

From what can be learned, Gen. LEE is evidently contemplating a movement, but as to what point can only be a matter of conjecture. He continues to "show off" troops in front of Fredericksburgh, as if with the design of deceiving our military.
The Buenos Ayres papers of March 9 note the occurrence of fearful inundations at Tucuman. One of them says:

Whatever may be the issue of the conflict that has been, and perhaps still is raging, in and around Vicksburgh, there can scarcely be a doubt that it will take its place on the page of history as one of the most desperate, stubbornly contested and bloody, that has ever been fought.

Peter T. Washburn, Adjutant and Inspector-General: SIR: In my account of the part taken by the Vermont troops of the storming of the Heights of Fredericksburgh, I promised to furnish further particulars. The rush of events that followed, and a constant employment of time since, must be my excuse for the delay.

We have already had, by telegraph from San Francisco, the announcement of the explosion of the steamer Ada Hancock at San Pedro. The Bulletin gives these additional particulars of the sad affair. It says:
The following extracts from a private letter, written by a soldier in Gen. PLEASANTON'S cavalry division, are of interest:

The Press of this City has announced frequently that HENRY WARD BEECHER was about to visit Europe, to be absent on a health-seeking tour during the coming four months. At last, we are pleased to announce, he has gone.
The steamship Jura, from Liverpool on the 21st, via Londonderry on the 22d instant, was boarded by the news-boat at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Her dates are five days later.

A riot of some magnitude occurred here last night. It was emphatically "a war between the races"--first, black pitted against white, and then (to do black no injustice) white against black with a vengeance--in which white, of course, came off triumphant and victorious. It was almost literally "a war carried into Africa."
HE INVADES GEORGE JORDAN'S DOMESTIC RIGHTS. The London papers of May 13 report the following interesting case:

Yesterday afternoon, a guard, acting under the authority of Marshal ERHARDT, of the Fourth District, arrested HENRY McCLUSKEY, WILLIAM BARCLAY, GEORGE NASH, MICHAEL HOLLY, MORTIMER McGUFF, and four others, in a saloon adjoining the Bowery Theatre. The facts involved in this arrest, which have been gathered after diligent inquiry from persons of veracity, are these: On Thursday the Provost-Marshal's Guard learned that there was a deserter at No. 44 Bowery.
In a letter to the Philadelphia Press, dated Nashville, May 20, Parson BROWNLOW writes:

In the New School Presbyterian General Assembly, at Philadelphia, on Friday, 22, an invitation to visit the Union League Rooms was accepted, and a number of addresses, approving the objects of these leagues, were made.

There is a very great THE CITY HALL PARK.--There is a very great difference, these Summer days, between the appearance of City Hall Park and Union Park. Union Park, with its luxuriant and verdant grass plots, its heavily-foliaged, nicely-kept trees, its singing birds, its fountain, its tidy domestics and troops of romping children-- all these things of a pleasant afternoon give it a cheerful and animated aspect.

The Boston Journal says: "The ship Oneida, of New-Bedford, from Shanghal for New-York, had a valuable cargo of teas, She belonged to Messrs. T. F. S. HATHAWAY, and was valued at $30,000, and insured at offices in New-Bedford for 25,000. Her cargo was only partially owned in that city, upon which there is an insurance there of 10,000. There is also an insurance of $2,500 at the Mercantile Marine office in Boston."
The following is an extract from a private letter from an officer of Gen. ULLMANN's brigade, dated Baton Rouge, April 28, 1863:
An ordinary party crisis in Canada would not be likely to disturb the balance of power in either world; and would, perhaps, fail to excite any particular emotion beyond a limited provincial circle.

It is now fifteen days since the battle of Big Black Bridge, and fourteen since the investment of Vicksburgh. With the first of these events, Gen. JOHNSTON saw the desperateness of the rebel situation at Vicksburgh, and the necessity of the utmost energy in concentrating all possible troops to flank GRANT, and, if possible, to raise the siege.

Unofficial dispatches were received here today from the army of Gen. GRANT dated on the 26th. They represent that there had been no material change in affairs there since the 25th. The dispatch boat New National, from Young's Point on Tuesday afternoon, has arrived. The fighting on Monday lasted from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., when there was a cessation of hostilities to bury the dead.

SIR: Two days ago I read Gen. BRAXTON BRAGG's official report of the battle of Stone River, before Murfreesboro, and after a proper time for reflection, I think it my duty to send you this communication.
The Cunard screw steamer Sidon, which left Liverpool at about 10 on the morning of Tuesday, the 19th, and Queenstown on the 20th May, arrived here yesterday.

If our readers can for the moment divest themselves of the exhibitionary influences so apparently inseparable from the Lilliputian Thumb group now at the Museum, and will look at those four little men and women as immortal beings and fellow-creatures, they will doubtless be struck, as we have been, with the singularity of the attitude assumed by the dwarfs, and the peculiarity of their mental as well as physical condition.

An important change of programme takes place to-night at Niblo's Garden, where, instead of the ordinary "star" performances, we are to have a new, and according to rumors, good play, produced with new scenery, dresses, and a competent company.
On Thursday next Gen. BURNSIDE Will remove the headquarters of the Department of the Ohio to Hickman Bridge, Ky., about ten miles south of Nicholasville.

The Chairman of the Emancipation Society had received, through the American Minister, the following reply on behalf of President LINCOLN to an address which was adopted at a meeting held in London, on January 29:
In the House of Commons, on the 18th, the estimates for the postal packet service for the year ( 956,878 sterling) were voted, Nothing was said in opposition to the Galway subsidy.

We have had rather exciting and stirring times here since my last. The Government troops met with some disasters and were compelled to capitulate in the province of Coro. They also suffered a momentary disadvantage, which was in some measure subsequently retrieved at Barquisimeto.

Our correspondence from Venezuela this morning assures us of the end of the civil war in that country, and of the recognition of the Government of Gen. PAEZ by the Federals. A treaty of peace has been signed. Business, in consequence, had become very brisk, and the country bid fair to become once more prosperous.

Steamship Sidon (Br. screw,) McMickan, Liverpool May 19, and Queenstown 20th, at 6.P.M., with mdse. and passengers to E. Cunard. Steamer Exact, (new,) Philadelphia, to Loper Kirkpatrick.
The Chattanoogo Rebel says: "Capt. DE MYER, of MORGAN'S cavalry, was killed in a skirmish near Readyville, on the 26th."

We learn that official information has been received of the arrival at Fort Abercrombie, on the 19th inst., of JOSEPH DEMEREIS, a son of the interpreter now at that post. He came from St. Joseph by way of Devil's Lake, leaving Devil's Lake on the 9th inst., where he reports there were encamped about 500 teepees of Indians, for about 1,800 warriors, with LITTLE CROW at their head.

The Democratic State Committee has held another meeting at Albany, in order to define, over again, the position of the Democratic party. The progress of public sentiment sweeps their party landmarks away so rapidly as to render absolutely necessary these reiterated endeavors to keep the party together by constructing new platforms from time to time, as exigencies may require.

The steamship Jura,from Liverpool on the 21st and Londonderry on the "2d, arrived off Cape Race on Friday afternoon, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. The steamship Sidon, from Liverpool on the 19th and Queenstown on the 20th, arrived at this port yesterday. The advices by these arrivals are five days later, but are of no great importance politically.
COTTON Sales of three days 10,000 bales, including 4,000 to speculators and exporters. The market is irregular and dull at a slight decline on all descriptions.

At the departure of the Asia from England the result of the fighting in Virginia down to the evening of the 3d May had been received by the Persia, and had created a great sensation, but without any material effect in a commercial sense. The accounts were regarded as indefinite and the next steamer was looked for with much eagerness.
The steamship Jura, from Liverpool May 21, via Greencastle (below Londonderry,) May 22, en route to Quebec, was boarded by the Press yacht, off this point, at 5 P.M. to-day.

Semi-official advices from Gen. GRANT'S army to the 26th of May have reached the Government. At that time the condition of affairs in the rear of Vicksburgh was mainly unchanged. On the evening of the 25th Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces, asked for two and a half ...

FUNERAL OF A SOLDIER. The remains of the late Lieut. BLOOMFIELD, of Company E, Fourteenth Brooklyn regiment, were yesterday consigned to their last resting place in Cypress Hills Cemetery. The funeral ceremonies were conducted at No. 9 Libertystreet, by the Rev. Mr. DE HASS, who preached a fitting and eloquent discourse on the occasion. The deceased was wounded in the last assault upon Fredericksburgh, and died from the effects of the injuries then sustained.

One who is in the service of the Government can calculate but slightly on his whereabouts. To obey orders implicitly, and go whither he is sent, is the duty of officer as well as of private of the soldier and the sailor alike.
Col. PHILLIPS, commanding in the Indian Territory, had a severe fight with a portion of PRICE's army on the 20th.

COTTON The market yesterday (Monday) was quiet, at rather irregular prices. Surats, to arrive, are quoted d.P.D. cheaper. The sales of the day were about 5,000 bales, one half for speculation and export.
ALBANY, Sunday, May 31.

JOHN C. BRECKIN RIDGE has been as unfortunate as a General as he formerly was fortunate as a politician. In political service he obtained every honor which he coveted, except the highest; and this, too, while yet a young man.
The Bulletin of this city has the following special dispatch:

SIR: The recent avowal of Mr. GERRIT SMITH that he is in favor of a restoration of the Union, even if such restoration should involve new power to Slavery, is a slight indication of that counter-revolution in public sentiment on this subject which the war is calculated to effect, and which political leaders seem determined through it to bring about.
The following correspondence on a subject of considerable importance to tax-payers explains itself:
We publish, this morning, advices from Mexico, purporting to give the details of the defeat of the Mexicans, and the occupation of Puebla by the French forces commanded by Gen. FOREY.
Gen. HUNTER has been relieved from the command of the Department of the South. Gen. GILMORE, who reduced Fort Pulaski, succeeds him.
The United States steamer Dudley Buck leaves here at 5 P.M. for New-York.

It is becoming more and more evident every day that, to all practical intents and purposes, the people of the North are unanimous in support of the war for the preservation of the Union. There has been a very great change in the public mind on this subject within the last six or eight months.

U.S. transport Dudley Buck, Smith, Newbern May 29, with passengers to U.S. Assistant Quartermaster. May 30, at 7 A.M., passed transport E.S. Terry passing through Hatteras Inlet. 9 A.M., same day, off Hatteras Light, passed transport Tillie; afternoon of same day, off Loggerhead, passed steamers George Peabody and Thomas Collver.

We hope THE PRESIDENT'S FOOT NEEDED. We hope the President will at once "put his foot down" upon a quarrel which is raging between certain officers of our army at Port Royal under Gen. HUNTER and certain officers of our army at Newbern, under Gen. FOSTER and which, if it does not extend to the chief officers in command of the respective Departments, looks very much as if it did.

The Memphis Bulletin, of May 30, says an expedition from Germantown, under Col. McCRELLIS, attacked a rebel force of 2,500 men at Senatobia, on on the 25th, and drove them south of the Tallahatchie, with a loss of 6 killed and 3 wounded.
We publish letters from our correspondent with GRANT, giving an account of operations from the capture of Jackson, of which we have heretofore had details, up to the 24th ult., Sunday of last week.

The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, Commander E.C. BAILEY, of the Boston Herald, celebrated its 225th anniversary with full ranks and the usual demonstrations by a dinner at Faneuil Hall. Maj.-Gen. BUTLER responded to the following sentiment:

The steamship Sheldrake, from Havana on the 25th ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. About an hour previous to her sailing, the Diaro de la Marina, of Havana, issued a bulletin, of which the following is a translation:
Up to 11 o'clock last night the Government had received no further advices from Gen. GRANT'S Army.

The American rebellion is an anomaly in the spirit of the age, not only because it is a movement for Slavery instead of Freedom, but because it seeks a division instead of a union of people of the same blood. Everywhere else the nationality of race is the great idea. It is deemed the almost indispensable condition of national well-being.

Walking into a reading-room the other day, my eye fell on an article in the National Intelligencer, headed "The Law of the Case." I confess to a feeling of indignation as I perused the grave and legal argument to prove that everybody Generals, Courts, and people were wrong in the Vallandigham case, and nobody knew anything, except only the National Intelligencer.

The United States steam transport Arago, HENRY A. GADSDEN Commander, from Port Royal, S. C., at noon Friday, May 29, consigned to Major STEWART VAN VLIET, Quartermaster United States army, arrived at 4 A.M. yesterday time, sixtyfour hours.

Up to 11 o'clock to-night, no additional intelligence had been received from Gen. GRANT'S army later than the previous dispatch of the 28th, when it was stated that Gen. GRANT'S forces were progressing as favorably as could be expected, and Gen. GRANT had no fear of the result.
The following official dispatch from Gen. BLUNT, regarding a movement which we noticed on Sunday, hardly justifies the statement regarding the advance of Gen. PRICE:

By the Creole at this port, we have three days' later advices from Havana; but no corroboration of the Mexican advices, published yesterday, do we find in the Havana papers; nor do we ascertain that private letters make any mention of the reported capture of Puebla, except doubtingly.
Official advices received to-day from Vicksburgh up to the 29th of May, indicate that there is no change in the state of affairs there; but that the prospects of Gen. GRANT are still encouraging.

The French steam-transport Le Finnesterre, Commander CARDIN ESTENE, from Vera Cruz, May 19, arrived yesterday morning. She has a crew of 219 men, mounts six guns, is of 1,500 tons, and has a screw engine of 250-horse power.
The steamer Emilie, from Newborn on the 31st ult., arrived this morning. She reports all quiet in that Department.

A collision occurred this evening between the 2 o' clock train from New-York and the 6 o'clock freight and accommadation train for New-York, on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, at Fish House, three miles above Camden. Both locomotives, and several cars, were crushed, but fortunately only two persons were injured THOMAS HARTMAN, of this City, and a newsboy, slightly. The 2 o'clock train was thirteen minutes behind time, but had the right track.

We observe that Ex-Mayor WOOD is announced to speak first in the main hall where the Peace Convention is to be held, and then at each of the five stands which are to be erected outside. The Ex-Mayor certainly does not mean to be lost sight of at this Convention. The managers of the Democratic party at Albany have for some months past been unable to see him: ...

Official advices from Gen. GRANT's Army to the 29th ult. were yesterday received by the Government. They inidicate that there was no change in the condition of affairs at Vicksburgh, but that the prospects were encouraging. A dispatch from Memphis brings us unofficial advices to the 28th, which state that on the 26th the gunboat Cincinnati was sunk by the fire from the rebel batteries, with a reported loss of over twenty killed and wounded.

There is a story told of a certain athletic wag that he laid a wager with a friend that he could throw him across a tolerably wide river. The friend submitted himself to the experiment, and, finding himself soused into the water about four feet from the bank, swam ashore and claimed the stakes. "No," replied the other, "I am going to try again; I know I shall succeed in the end."
General Orders No. 84, from Maj.-Gen. AMBROSE E. BURNSIDE, prohibits the circulation of the NewYork World and Chicago Times in this Department.

The proprietors of the Times were notified to-night by Capt. PUTNAM, commanding Camp Douglas, that if they attempted to issue their paper for to-morrow morning, he would, in accordance with a telegraphic order from Gen. AMMEN, take military possession of the office.

It is announced from Washington that Gen. HUNTER has been relieved from the command of the Department of the South, and that he is succeeded by Gen. GILMORE. We have as yet no statement of the reasons for this change. Whether Gen. HUNTER is relieved at his own request, or in consequence of some failure in duty, we are not aware. His letter to JEFF. DAVIS, which we published yesterday morning, was ...

The arrival of the steamer from above brings us intelligence that Gen. AUGUR, with his forces, is within two miles of Port Hudson, having driven the enemy's pickets in, with some skirmishing. He now holds them in check, and in all probability a general engagement has ere this taken place for the reduction of Port Hudson and the opening of the Mississippi, so as to admit the transportation of supplies from this place to above.

The steamship Creole, COUCH, from New-Orleans May 24, via Havana 28th, with merchandise and passengers to LUDLAM, HEINEKEN Co., arrived yesterday. She experienced in the Gulf a heavy southeast gale of sixty hours' duration, and has had heavy southeast winds, with squalls of rain, since leaving Havana.

Over a hundred boxes have within the last four days ...

"The telegraphic news of yesterday announced that BANKS had crossed his army at Bayou Sara. This is about ten miles above Port Hudson. His object is to get behind the post and carry it by a land attack. This movement is designed to finish the work started by GRANT, and clear the Mississippi. A few days will tell the story. The next news will probably be of an assault upon Port Hudson."

We trust that the Administration will spare no pains to complete the preparations for the conscription by the earliest day possible, and that the conscription when made will be on an extensive scale. The National Canal Convention was called to order at 11 o'clock this morning, by Dr. BRAINARD Chairman of the Committee, who nominated CHAUNCEY J. FILLER, Mayor of St. Louis, temporary Chairman.

I have just arrived here from Simmesport, and find everything in the highest state of glee and excitement. Events crowd so thickly upon each other that it is really difficult to keep the "run" of them.

I have no wish to conceal or disguise ...
Parliament was not in session owing to the Whitsun holidays, and the English political news is consequently unimportant.

The Canal Convention assembled at 9 o'clock, the President in the Chair.

Shortly after 12 o'clock last night Judge DRUMMOND issued a writ directing the military authorities to take no further steps or measures to carry into effect the order of Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE for the suppression of the Chicago Times, until the application for a permanent writ of injunction could be heard in open Court to-day.
The steamship Columbia, Capt. BARTON, from New-Orleans, May 28, and steamship George Cromwell, Capt. POST, May 27, arrived yesterday morning.
No advices from the army at Vicksburgh had been received in this city up to noon to-day.

The Cunard Mail steamship Persia, Capt. LOTT, which left Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 23d, and Queenstown on the 24th ult., arrived here early yesterday morning. She brings only two days later intelligence than that received by the Jura via Cape Race.
It is reported that the Trinity Board have resolved to establish a floating beacon off the extreme southern point of Cape Race.

Ex-Mayor WOOD'S Peace Convention yesterday was, in many respects, a decided success. It was a large gathering--one of the largest recently held in the City, and its proceedings were marked by energy, directness and a fair degree of enthusiasm.

We understand that dis patches have been received by French officials in this City from Mexico, confirming the reported capture of Puebla by the French army. On the other hand, two arrivals from Havana, later than that of the Shelldrake, which first brought the news, fail to bring any decisive confirmation accessible to the public.
The London journals of the 23d all comment upon HOOKER'S retreat across the Rappahannock.

The latest news from Gen. GRANT'S army is to the effect that Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, with a considerable rebel force, was approaching by way of the Yazoo River. Gen. GRANT was confident of his ability to take care of him.

The British prize steamer Dolphin, about which there has lately been so much said in the English papers, has just been condemned as lawful prize. A large quantity of Enfield rifles and sabres were found ...

By the arrival at this port of the steamship Eagle, which left Havana on the 30th ult., we have advices from Vera Cruz to the l9th, which do not confirm the report of the capture of Puebla by the French. No such intelligence had reached Vera Cruz at that time.
The following is the text of Col. D'UTASSY'S sentence:

KILPATRICK is perpetrating another raid. It will be remembered, that at the conclusion of STONEMAN'S raid, that portion of the forces under Col. KILPATRICK rendezvoused at Gloucester Court-house, on the York River. There they have been resting for the past three weeks. Last week Col. KILPATRICK was ordered to bring his command back to this army, and preparations were made accordingly.

In pursuance of a call issued some weeks since, a Mass Convention of citizens in favor of peace was held last evening in and about Cooper Institute. There were five organized gatherings, the principal one being held in the Hall of the Union, and the others in front of stands erected about the adjacent square.

We sympathize thoroughly with the feeling manifested by our German-born citizens against the attempts to make the German soldiers responsible for the failure of Gen. HOOKER'S operations at Chancellorsville. In our opinion, nothing could be more unjust.
COTTON--Sales, to-day, 10,000 bales, including 5,000 to speculators and exporters. The market is firmer, and all qualities slightly advanced.

We left New-Orleans on the Morning of Tuesday, 19th, for Brashear City, and being joined by Gen. BANKS and Staff at the latter place, the same evening, on board the St. Maurice, Capt. BROWN, started early the next morning (the 20th), for Simmesport, where we have just arrived.
Gen. HUNTER has just issued from Port Royal, a General Order which sounds more like business than his letter to JEFF DAVIS. Its substantial part is in the words following:...
Scouts who have thoroughly scoured the country on our left and in our rear, report having neither seen nor heard of any rebels.
The case of John M. Griffin and Thomas Lees, indicted for murder at sea by poisoning Capt. Bunce, on board the bark Betsey Williams, was brought on this morning.

Our intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army this morning is to the 31st ult.--one day later. At that date there had been no material change in the condition of affairs. The siege operations were being energetically pushed forward, and the army was in good condition and fine spirits.

The U. S. steam transport Ellen S. Terry, CHAPIN, from Newbern, N.C., arrived at this port last evening, bringing the mails and a large number of passengers. She reports all quiet at Newbern. The transports Pocahontas and S. S. Tilley would sail for Boston on the 8th inst, with the Forty-fourth Massachusetts regiment. The transport Convey was waiting orders.
Wilson vs. Holden.--Judgment reversed, and new trial ordered. Costs to abide event. Opinion by INGRAHAM.
The above regiments will arrive here this morning. The following is a brief history of the Thirtyseventh since its organization:

Unofficial, but reliable dispatches received here today from our army, dated near Vicksburgh, May 31, represent no material change in affairs. There had been no fighting for several days, but the siege works were being energetically pushed forward. Our army is in good condition and fine spirits.

Of course, we do not give any credit to the rebel report that Gen. GRANT is preparing to raise the siege at Vicksburgh. Neither the rebel Press nor the rebel military leaders know much about Gen. GRANT'S besieging operations, as the absurd telegrams we have received from the South show. Their communication with Vicksburgh itself is only by stratagem, and, in our rear, they have no force within many miles of our army.

The cavalry raid of Gen. STONEMAN'S command was concluded yesterday by Col. KILPATRICK'S brigade in one of the most brilliant acts of the war. Sarah Fairbanks vs. Jonathan Fairbanks.--The plaintiff brings this action for a divorce from bed and board, on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment. The marriage between plaintiff and defendant took place in 1853, and one child, a son, is the issue of the marriage.

Two large brick buildings on the corner of Washington and Wide Water streets, Norfolk, were destroyed by fire last night. They were used as a Government storehouse. All the property belonging to the Government, except about $2,000 worth, was removed. The fire was no doubt the work of an incendiary.

It is generally supposed that the Americans, as a people, are keenly alive to the ludicrous, and that a party which, in this country, lays itself open to the shafts of ridicule, is already as good as dead, if not buried. If this be true, the Fernando Wood faction must be in a parlous state; for the recent peace meeting was certainly the most notable farce ever played in this City.

The Philadelphia newspapers have remarkable imaginative powers, and they manage to procure correspondents and contributors of unequaled inventive genius. The consequence is that there is never a lack of brisk, startling and astounding news to be had from the Quaker City. We have had occasion heretofore to allude to some of the more extravagant achievements of the Philadelphia papers in deceiving themselves and deluding the simple minded, who are agog for sensations.

The "Coldwater" cotton, which has passed through many hands, and become somewhat famous by reason of the transactions connected with it, has been on trial during this week before Judge TREAT and a jury, in the United States District Court. Yesterday the jury found a verdict for the Government and against the private parties, of whom there were several, who claimed the cotton, thus condemning the cotton to the use of the Government.

Telegrams were received to-night from Richmond papers of to-day. Those who have read them say the rebels are exulting in what they allege to be great losses on the part of GRANT'S army. ROEBUCK sustains his reputation in his Sheffield speech on the war. No man in England could have uttered such an amusing series of logical contradictions and non-sequiturs. Times was not only anxious to have the Union broken up, but it is anxious to have the Military Despotism which has been built on the ruins of the old Union broken up. This morning the members of the family of WILLIAM STEELE, of East Hartford, on going to his oom, found his chamber deluged with blood, and Mr. STEELE lying dead on the floor, with his throat horribly cut, His wife was on the bed, with her throat cut from ear to ear, and an infant, six months old, had its head almost cut off. All were dead the child still warm.

Puebla has fallen! After a heroic defence of sixty days remarkable in the annals of warfare the Mexican defenders of their first stronghold have been obliged to succumb, not ingloriously, but in obedience to the imperious necessity caused by the total failure of supplies and ammunition. Such is the intelligence received by telegraph, vi San Francisco, corroborative mainly of the report received vi Havana, eight days ago.

Mayor KALBELEISCH occupied the Chair, and speeches were made by himself, Hon. AMASA J. PARKER, ALONZO C. PAIGE and others. Notwithstanding the unpleasantness of the weather last evening, a very fair audience, in point of numbers, assembled at the Church of the Puritans, drawn thither by the announcement that there would be presented a report of the Committee which recently waited upon President LINCOLN to confer with him in relation to the enlisting of colored troops and their incorporation into the Fremont Legion, the corps to be under the leadership of Gen. FREMONT.

The question submitted, the other day, to Commissioner LEWIS, of the Internal Revenue Department, by certain Oswego merchants, was met by an answer so clear and explicit that it will be found impossible to cavil at his decision. As the matter, however, has been supposed to involve, in some remote degree, the integrity of an international covenant, it is worth a moment's notice in one or more of its collateral bearings.

We have stupendous stories every few weeks of the discovery and unearthing in some State or other, mainly in the Northwest, of some new, secret, treacherous and wide-spread organization of the Knights of the Golden Circle. The biggest story we have had of late, and which was widely published and believed, was that of the discovery of an organization in Pennsylvania, which comprised nearly the whole able-bodied.

Our Vicksburgh correspondent photographs Gen. GRANT and the leading Generals of his army. GRANT has been peculiarly fortunate in the brilliant array of officers he has gathered around him. There have been few changes in the chief officers of his army. He selects them with sagacity, puts them in their proper positions, and retains them there. Even Gen. SHERMAN, who has been one of the most unfortunate officers, he retains in high command knowing, probably,

The report telegraphed to an Ohio paper, two days ago, that VALLANDIGHAM had been cast into prison by the rebels, is contrary to the universal manifestations of sympathy for him with which his presence within their lines was greeted. We are constrained to believe that the story is wholly false, and that it was invented to aid in procuring for him the Demo- cratic nomination for Governor of Ohio.

A Cincinnati newspaper NEGRO NEWS. A Cincinnati newspaper contains the important announcement that an intelligent contraband who lately came within Gen. GRANT'S lines, brought the news that he had overheard PEMBERTON remark that there were six months' provisions in Vicksburgh. This settles the question as to the leugth of time it will take Gen. GRANT to starve out Vicksburgh. It will be effected about December next.

The public have grown familiar with the diurnal telegraphic announcement that "everything is progressing favorably in the rear of Vicksburgh." For more than a fortnight we had the encouragement that this general assurance is calculated to give, and sometimes the effect has been heightened by the additional information that "Gen. GRANT is in excellent spirits."

Some of our neighbors comment in a tone of censure upon the neglect of the TIMES to be represented at a recent meeting of Editors, held to discuss the restrictions, if any, proper to be placed on the discussions of the Press during the war. We did not attend, because we regard this whole matter as one upon which each individual Editor must exercise his own judgment and act accordingly.

The Inmax steamer Glasgow, Capt. GILL, which left Liverpool at 3 P.M. on the 27th, and Queenstown on the 28th of May, arrived here yesterday afternoon. Her advices are not so late by three days as those by the Africa at Halifax, which we published yesterday, but we find some additional items of interest in our files.

The match of mile heats to wagons, best three in five, between Patchen and Butler, took place Wednesday on the Fashion Course, and terminated in favor of Patchen, who won the first, fourth and fifth heats, after a very exciting contest.

Affairs along the front of the Army of the Potomac remain as at the last advices, the enemy, as well as our own troops, maintaining their original lines of battle below the town. Occasionally a gun is heard, and some scattering shots from the skirmishers.

EXHIBITION OF PUBLIC SCHOOL No. 6. The Academy of Music was crowded Wednesday evening to the gallery on the occasion of the first public exhibition of the Ward School No. 6, S.M. PERKINS, Principal. The exercises consisted of singing, tableaux, declamation, drills by the boys, calisthenics by the girls, and special addresses. Not for a long time has a more interesting entertainment been presented in our sister city.

It is ascertained that there was some shelling on the Rappahannock this morning, but all was soon quiet except occasional picket firing, while our lines remain the same as yesterday.

TIONS. Several new and valuable military institutions are at this moment rounding themselves into form. There is the Soldiers' Home, for such soldiers of this State as have faithfully served their country, and are disabled from further service.

IMPORTANT ARREST OF BURGLARS. For several weeks past, burglaries, some of them of an exensive character, have been perpetrated upon the citizens of the Twentieth Preoinct. On the 21st ult, the store of MAURIOE SIMON, No. 521 Eighth-avenue, was forcibly entered in the night time, and over $100 worth of hats stolen therefrom.

WILLIAM of Brandenburgh has just put an end to the controversy between his Government and the Lower Chamber, by closing the Diet. The reasons assigned in the royal speech for this arbitrary proceeding cannot justify it.

EXPLOSION IN A PERCUSSION CAP MANUFACTORY. An explosion occurred in the percussion cap manufactory of JOSEPH GOLDMARK, Carroll-street, near Third-avenue, about 10 o'clock on Friday morning. It was caused while charging the caps, and resulted in serious injuries to Miss MARY CUNNINGHAM, one of the girls employed there.
The rebels made another attack on Triune, Tenn., yesterday. At about 5 A.M., General FOREST, with 5,000 rebel cavalry and two batteries attacked the cavalry division commanded by General MITCHELL.

PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, June 14. The General Loan Agent reports the sale of $1,260,900 five-twenties on Saturday, over one-half being from Kentucky and other Western States, who are coming np nobly to the work. The sales will continue increasing largely up to the 1st of July; and there is little doubt that efforts will be made by capitalists and others to take large amounts for future sales here and abroad.

We must leave it to our readers to imagine what the sensations of our fellow-citizens in the seceded States will be, when they learn that the Democratic Convention of Ohio " will hail with delight a desire on their part to return to their allegiance," and that the Convention aforesaid " will cooperate with them to restore peace."

CONCORD, Sunday, June 14. Gens. BUTLER, HAMILTON and FREMONT, Hon. MONTGOMERY BLAIR, JAMES T. BRADY, Gens. GILMAN and MARSTON, and Hon. HENRY WILSON, have positively engaged to be present at the great Union demonstration in this city on the 17th of June. It will be the largest gathering ever held in the State.

Sailed from New-York March 13 for Shanghai; had a long passage to the Equator; was becalmed on the Equator twelve days; crossed in about 28 50' W.; had the wind prevailing from S. E. to S. S. E., which forced me to the westward. On Sunday, April 26, was chased and captured by the privateer Alabama, at 5 P. M., in lat. 7 35' south, lon. 31 35' west.
