We have been anxiously expecting the arrival of the Spanish merchant steamer Mexico from Sisal and Vera Cruz, which might probably bring us further news of the progress of the French in Mexico, but we have been disappointed; the Mexico has not yet arrived.
Archibald Hall vs. Joseph Hall. This was an action brought to recover $50 the penalty provided for by the Harbor Masters' Act of 1862, for a neglect or refusal to obey the order of Harbor Master.
Gen. MILROY was surrounded at Winchester by 18,000 rebels; but, after a desperate fight, he cut his way through, and united with our forces at Harper's Ferry.
The New-York Seventh have offered their services to aid in resisting the invasion of Pennsylvania, and are expected to leave for Harrisburgh tomorrow.
The situation of the State of Pennsylvania is, at this moment, a most painful one. With or without cause, there is a wide-spread and startling rumor and dread of rebel invasion.
Special dispatches from Indianapolis say: "The detachment of soidlers sent to Rush County, Indiana, to arrest all persons engaged in resisting the enrollment have returned."
The steamer Hiawatha from below, with dates to the 10th, has arrived.

The interest in Stuart's cavalry operations up the Shenandoah Valley has been absorbing here to-day. Nothing else has been talked of but little else thought of. The heat has been awful, and Washington has sought its aliment of news literally in a furnace.

If the rebel cavalry, now supposed to be on a grand raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania, should be so successful as to penetrate either State, we venture a prediction or two as to the result. 1. They will utterly fail to be impressed by ...

The Philadelphia Ball Players, consisting of a selected nine of the Athletic Club and their friends, to the number of about thirty, arrived in this city yesterday at 12 o'clock via Jersey City, where they were met and cordially welcomed by delegations from the Clubs of this and the surrounding cities.
THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

An arrival at this port from Havana announces the arrival there of a steamer which left Vera Cruz on the 6th of June. The only Mexican news, however, is a confirmation of the report that Gen. ORTEGA, lately commanding at Puebla, had succeeded in making his escape from the French at Orizaba. A number of other Mexican officers also escaped at the same time.

The City Inspector gives no tice this morning that all the obstacles which have heretofore embarrassed the operations of his Department in the matter of street cleaning have now been removed, and he has entered upon the prosecution of his work, including the removal of ashes and garbage, with the whole force at his disposal.
It is ascertained that Gen. HOOKER'S Headquarters left the station, near Falmouth, on the morning of the 14th, and proceeded toward Dumfries, where there was a rest for the night.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 74 bbls. Ashes, 23,958 bbls. Flour, 2,763 bbls., and 464 bags Corn Meal, 122,084 bushels Wheat, 35,910 bushels Corn, 263 bushels Rye, 78,950 bushels Oats, 5,463 packages provisions, and 1,698 bbls., Whisky.

It is understood that Maj.-Gen. DAN SICKLES will not return, for the present, to the Army of the Potomac. We know nothing of the ground on which the ru mor to this effect rests. But we are ready to assert, what will certainly meet general concurrence, that the services of this distinguished officer, or of any other of like ability, cannot be very well dispensed with at the present exciting stage of affairs.

The rebel raid, or rather invasion, which has been so long talked about, is becoming an earnest fact, as you already know. It is difficult, in the confusion and excitement prevailing here, to ascertain the real facts, or to separate the true from the score of false and exaggerated reports flying about.
In the house of Lords, on the 4th, the Earl of Malmesbury gave notice that on the 16th inst., he would call attention to the state of relations with Brazil.
Carl Cornfeld vs. Julia Cornfeld. Judgment of divorce granted.
The following official telegram from Gen. MILROY has been received:

The rebels are reported to be near the town of Carlisle, Penn., which is one day's march from Harrisburgh. If it be true that they are burning the towns that they reach, Carlisle will be a victim certainly; but even if some are spared, this town will probably be doomed to destruction because of the existence there of a United States Military School and other Government buildings.
Dispatches from Harrisburgh to the Inquirer and Press, of this city, dated at 2 o'clock this morn ing, confirm the report of the capture of Chambersburgh by the rebels.

WASHINGTON, Monday, June 15 P.M. Another battle, bloody and frightful it most certainly will be, is now impending between the forces of Gen. HOOKER and those of Gen. LEE. The movements of the Army of the Potomac, as well as those of its fierce opponent, have for many days past, been wrapped in profound mystery.
A letter in the Knoxville Register, of the 9th inst., from Meridian, says:
A telegram received at 9 o'clock to-night by Col. PULESTON, from Gov. CURTIN, states that the enemy was at Chambersburgh and Scotland, and within seven miles of Shippensburgh. The Governor adds:
The steamship America, from Boston, arrived here yesterday, the 6th inst.
Gov. BRADFORD has issued a proclamation calling upon the citizens of Baltimore, and people of Maryland, to rally to defend their soil from invasion.

Gov. CURTIN, of Penn sylvania, has been under the necessity of sending personal appeals to the Governors of various Eastern States to hasten forward the militia of their respective States to aid in the defence of Pennsylvania.

At the time of writing the intelligence is that communication between Chambersburgh and Hagerstown has been cut, and that the enemy is on his way into the interior of the State. Great confusion exists in Chambersburgh, as the rebels are expected there by 3 o'clock this afternoon.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 3. The Twenty-second, Fortyseventh, Fifty-second, and Fifty-sixth regiments, National Guard, of the State of New-York, are hereby ordered to hold themselves in readiness to go to Philadelphia, at once on short service, in compliance with orders from HORATIO SEYMOUR, Commander-in-Chief.

The commandants of regiments and companies of Virginia Militia will immediately call their com panies and regiments together, to be held in readiness to go to the field at an hour's warning, and will provide such means as shall be effective in giving immediate notice to all. Arms and equipments will be furnished at the several places of rendezvous.

News of the advance of LEE'e army reached Pittsburgh on Sunday, and on the evening of that day the citizens had intelligence that "an immense force was then marching to Pittsburgh, with the avowed object of laying the city in ruins." A dispatch was also received from Gen. HALLECK to the effect that an attack on Pittsburgh was imminent, and that the city should be put in a state of immediate defence.

We observe that in the general attack of all persons in high places, the General-in-Chief does not escape. He seems to be particularly singled out by some German papers in the West. His generalship, his Union feelings, his sincerity in carrying out the President's policy concerning negroes in the disloyal States all are criticized, doubted, and even perversely assailed.

Seven papers in Berlin have published a joint declaration preserving their rights, in view of the royal ordinance of the 1st inst. relative to the Press. They say that the Government has yet to furnish the nation with proofs of the legality of that measure.
It appears that the Moniteur underrated the number of opposition members elected to the new Legislative body, as it is supposed that 25 Independent members have been chosen.
In the absence of farther news from America the English journals are more than usually dumb in regard to American affairs.
Thirteen rebel deserters arrived here to-day from Gen. JENKINS' command on the Blackwater, They report that the rebel force at that place comprises but one brigade.

The frank and cordial manner in which our Southern brethren are responding to the offer of the Ohio Democrats, "to cooperate with them in the restoration of peace," fully justifies the anticipations which we ventured to express on this head a few days ago.
To the People of Philadelphia: For nearly a week past it has been publicly known that the rebels in force were about to enter Pennsylvania.

The very urgent appeal of Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, for help to expel the invaders who are expected, this day, to be in sight of Harrisbugh, though addressed to Pennsylvanians only, must excite the earnest sympathy of every one who reads it.

The Governor is receiving urgent messages from the authorities of Pennsylvania asking for troops, and is doing everything possible to hurry them forward. Gov. CURTIN advises that they be shipped via Easton.

Everything looks very gloomy here. The indications are that the rebels will be within sight of Harrisburgh to-morrow, and in the absence of troops to stop the advance of the rebels, the destruction of all the bridges along the Susquehanna is inevitable.
The Brazilian Minister and his family, accompanied by the members of his legation, quitted London for Paris on the 4th inst.
All the Central Railroad laborers are on a strike to-day for higher wages.
In accordance with the National requisition and the call of the State authorities, the militia of our City and of the neighboring city have responded promptly and without reserve.
Benhard Hullon vs. Babcock Milnor. This action was brought to recover six quarters' rent of the five-story marble store No. 142 Duane-street, amounting, with interest, to nearly $23,000.

We observed around town last evening a large number of officers and soldiers of the United States. They were evidently not the returned two years' soldiers for these have nearly all doffed their uniforms. They were not our militia soldiers hastening to the war. They were mostly offi cers and soldiers on leave of absence, on furlough, and such like.

A dispatch was received here last night by the Governor of New-Jersey from the Governor of Pennsylvania, asking for the nine months' New-Jersey men, now about to be mustered out of the service, to come on to Harrisburgh.

A severe gale occurred at Apalachicola, Florida, a few days since, during which two of our vessels were wrecked at the entrance to that harbor and totally lost. The steamer Hendrik Hudson, Capt. CATE, has just arrived from there and from Capt. CATE I learn these particulars:

The Northward movement of the rebel army is certainly very audacious, though we are not yet able to divine its precise course, nor the special object it may have in view. We do not even yet know whether it has crossed the mountains or is still on the upper waters of the Rappahannock.
The Tribune of yesterday delivered itself of its thoughts upon the advance of the rebels, in the following fashion:

LEE's rebel army is advancing in force upon Pennsylvania, Western Virginia and the eastern portion of our own State. To meet this horde of rebels, the President of the United States has, by proclamation, called out 100,000 militia for the period of six months, unless sooner discharged. Of this force 30,000 are called from Ohio.

The news this morning from the Pennsylvania border is extremely meagre; and regarding the movements of LEE'S main body we yet know nothing whatever. We get not a glimpse of their general purpose, or the special end they propose to attempt.

The following is a complete official report of the casualties in the First and Second brigades o the Third division volunteer cavalry, in the action at Brandy Station, Tuesday, May 9, 1863, under the command of Brig.-Gen. GREGG. It is additional to the list which we have already published:
The quiet pervading military matters in this Department has been a little varied within a week past, by rebel cavalry attacks in the direction of Frankiln and Triune.
Another of the Canadian steamship line has been lost--the Norwegian, which left Liverpool

Mr. ROEBUCK has not brought forward his motion for recognition. If the news by to-morrow's steamer should be favorable to the South, it will come up next week. There will, in that case, be a strong but not a successful demonstration. France is not ready.

News from Vicksburgh shows that Gen. JOHONSTON, in GRANT'S rear, is being reinforced from the rebel army of BRAGG in Tennessee. News from Murfreesboro shows that none of BRAGG'S troops have left him, but that his...

DANTE describes one of his condemned as forever moving round a dreadful crater, and, on his arriving at a certain point, ripped almost in twain by the stroke of an avenging sword. The wretch pursues his endless journey, piteously moaning, and with difficulty...
The United States transport Arago, HENRY A. GADSDEN, Commander, from Port Royal at 12 M. of Sunday, the 15th, arrived yesterday morning.

Two reporters have just returned from in front of the rebel pickets, who are forty-seven miles from Harrisburgh, at Scotland Bridge, which they burned this morning. A party of 15 set fire to the structure.

During the year ending May 31, 1863, the business in Petroleum, Mr. C. J. TURNER reviews thus: "The position of affairs in June, 1862, as affecting the Petroleum market, when the product of the wells was fully equal to the present yield, (said by some to have been at least 30 per cent. in excess,) has peculiar significance. The price was 25 cents per gallon.

It having become entirely apparent to the enemy that the army of the Potomac is in motion, I presume it cannot longer be contraband to inform the anxious public that this army has again "changed its base," or rather has abandoned its old base of Aquia Creck, and gone to find another.

Our latest reports from Harrisburgh indicate that the rebel cavalry, under JENKINS, have retreated from Chamoersburgh. They are supposed to be about 3,500 strong. There was said to be another force, however, under IMBODEN, on another route of advance. STUART himself is not in Pennsylvania, according to the latest advices, but in Shenandoah Valley.

No doubt whatever exists as to the presence of the enemy at Chambersburgh up to about 3 o'clock this afternoon, when they retreated, it is supposed, toward Hagerstown. The operator is at Chambersburgh, and telegraphic communication has been reestablished.

It is a glorious thing to recognize--the exhaustless patience and the exhaustless patriotism of the loyal people of the United States; although it is a burning shame that these noble qualities should be taxed so often and so severely as they are.

The results of the Paris elections have just reached me, and though the figures are not absolutely official, yet as they are given out by the authorities they may be considered thoroughly reliable. The issue of the contest bears out the most sanguine anticipations of the opposition; the Government has courted defeat and has not courted it in vain.

Public interest has been for some time directed to a vessel building in the Tees, at the shipbuilding-yard of Messrs. M. PEARSE Co. (formerly LOCKWOOD PEARSE.) It was currently reported that this ship was intended for war purposes, and with the object of following in the steps of the notorious Alabama.

Another large number of refugees, men, women and children, arrived here from Chambersburgh and Carlisle, last night. The number of men who have come is not large, having come mainly for the purpose of accompanying their wives, children and sis ters to a place of temporary safety, many of them having this morning started on their return up the Valley to aid in repelling the enemy's advances.

The people have not yet recovered from their surprise, nor the Government from its indignation, at the result of the late elections. Not only are the Democracy radiant, but the whole people seem to be under the spell of a newborn and strange sensation, which they can hardly realize.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 40 bbls. Ashes, 5,195 bbls. Flour, 60,313 bushels Wheat, 15,083 bushels Corn, 48,328 bushels Oats, 1,627 packages provisions, and 453 bbls. Whisky.
The Inquirer has a special dispatch from Washington, dated last night, which contains the following intelligence:

WINTER GARDEN.--Mr. EDWARD MOLLENRAUER'S tragic opera, called the "Corsican Bride," was produced here Monday evening, The libretto is derived from a sanguinary piece called "Rosa Gregoria,"and has been twisted into a lyric shape by Dr. A. KOEHLER, who is said to have a great deal to answer for.

No general attack from JOHNSTON is expected for some days. Firing is continued upon Vicksburgh from all sides. There are no further demonstrations on the Louisiana side.

The steamship Norwegian, of the Canadian Steamship Line, which left Liverpool at half-past 12 o'clock, noon, of the 4th, and Londondery of the 5th instant, for Quebec, was wrecked on St. Paul's Island, this (Sunday) morning, 14th instant, during a thick fog.

What means it? The Copperheads have clamored from the beginning about "the Union as it was, and the Constitution as it is." They have done their best to make it their distinctive party motto. And it was not a bad one. While it all had a pleasing sound, the first clause was so indefinite that nobody cared, and the latter so just that nobody.

A telegram from Harrisburgh expresses the opinion that there are now no rebel troops in the State. JENKINS' cavalry left Chambersburgh on Wednesday afternoon, after robbing all the drugstores in the place and setting fire to a warehouse and were at Hagerstown on Wednesday night. They took with them a number of the most promminent farmers in the valley. There is a report

BROOKLYN ATHENEUM. To-night, at the Brooklyn Atheneum, the WEBB sisters will give a second protean character performance. The first was given on Tuesday night, before a very large and wellpleased audience, who laughed and cried, as the fair ones on the stage directed.

In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, nominating GEORGE W. BLUNT for City Inspector, vice DANIEL E. DELAVAN, the present incumbent, whose term of office expired last Monday. The nomination was rejected, by 16 to 1. The Mayor sent in another communication accompanying and favoring an application from Gen. WARD B.

The time has not yet come for an impartial judgment on the military operations immediately preceding the late irruption of rebel forces into Maryland. Our cavalry yesterday encountered a portion of STUART'S cavalry, whipped them, and captured two squadrons, including eight officers.

SENATOR WILSON. Senator WILSON is here on the patriotic errand of persuading the Government to adopt his plan for bringing immediately back into the service the discharged two years and nine months men, in anticipation of the draft. By special inducements, he proposes to get the whole of these expperienced soldiers, who are worth treble their number in green troops.
The enemy has retreated to Williamsport. A small rebel force is at Hagerstown.

The Twenty-third regiment departed for Pennsylvania yesterday morning. They formed in line on Orange-street, near Fulton-street, about 7 o'clock A. M., and marched down Fulton-street to the ferry at 8 o'clock. A large number of the friends and relatives of the members assembled at the armory to see them leave. On reaching New-York they marched

Yesterday evening a banquet was given to Gen. THOMAS F. MEAGHER by his friends and admirers' at the Astor House, on which occasion a medal was presented to him. The number of tickets was limited.

MAIDHOFF, secured their arms, uniforms and equipments on Wednesday evening, and orders were at once issued for their distribution yestersay, and the departure of the command at 4 o'clock. Their armory was densely crowded all morning, the bustling scenes of preparation filling every room.
Late yesterday afternoon Rear-Admiral FOOTE was in a very critical condition at the Astor House. All visitors, save a few family friends were excluded.
A ride along the lines developed a change in the position of the enemy. Their batteries are silent on all sides, and there are only a few of their riflemen firing.

The Twenty-second, under command of Lieut.Col. ASPINWALL, was busy at the armory at Palace Garden all day, preparing to leave. It was expected that their supplies would be forthcoming, so that they could get off at 12 o'clock, but, as usual, there was delay "some one had blundered" and the men were kept changing around until late in the afternoon.

These, with BROWN'S brigade of McCORMICK'S division, left behind, form the new division of STEWART, in HARDER'S corps. BRAGG now has eighteen brigades of infantry and cavalry. Considerable excitement has prevailed at Columbus and Hickman for a day or two past in consequence of an expected attack by the rebels.
Numerous mail-bags have fallen into the hands of the National troops in Louisiana.

At the request of Gov. PARKER, Commodore STOCKTON, who was appointed a Major-General last winter, has consented to take command of the division of the State soldiers which is being raised to assist in the defence of Pennsylvania.
The Democrat, of this city, has a special dispatch from Vicksburgh, which says:
The street-corner and fireside strategists have a splendid field for their wits at present.

A couple of deserters from STUART'S cavalry, who have come within our lines, say that STUART'S cavalry force is at Warrenton, twelve thousand strong, and that LEE'S army is massed in the Shenandoah Valley, near From Royal, or somewhere between that point and Winchester.

The Fifth regiment N.Y.S.M. effected its departure for the seat of war about 8 o'clock last evening, numbering about six hundred men, fully armed and equipped. They were escorted on their route down Broadway by a very large number of our German fellow-citizens, of which nationality the regiment is composed. They are a credit both to the Teutonic race and the Metropolis, and will compare favorably with almost any of our City corps.

Jane Weeks vs. William Elliott. The plaintiff was a lady boarding-house keeper, and brought her action to recover of the defendant for an alleged unlawful taking and detention of personal property used by her in conducting the business of boardinghouse keeping at No. 69 West Forty-fifth-street, in this City.

Our Board of Councilmen have adopted a resolution urging upon the Administration the restoration of Gen. McCLELLAN to the chief command of the Army of the Potomac. JONES, Ex-United States Senator from Iowa, and Minister to New-Granada under the last Administrator, has brought an action in the Supreme Court against Secretary SEWARD, laying his damages at $50,000, to recover for his arrest upon his arrival in this City, on his return to the United States, the particulars of which will be remembered. Governor CURTIN visited Camp Curtin to-day, and was received with a warm and enthusiastic welcome.

The flag-of-truce in charge of Capt. MULFORD, general truce officer, left for City to-day noon, taking up a few rebel prisoners and some women.

The United States transport Emilie arrived today from Newbern, with advices from our correspondent there to the 17th. He reports as follows:

An important order, organizing the National Guard of the State of New-York, uniformed militia, was issued by Gov. SEYMOUR to day. It provides for the formation of a separate regiment or battalion of infantry in each Assembly District, and constitutes each Senatorial District a brigade district.

MURDER TRIAL. MARY ANN McLAUGHLIN was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer on Friday, on the charge of killing her mother, CECELIA McLAUGHLIN, the wife of THOMAS McLAUGHLIN.

The Middle Departments will be subdivided into two departments, to be commanded by Major-Generals SCHENCK and MILROY. With a large field Gen. MILROY will quickly follow up his brilliant operations, so auspiciously commenced at Winchester, and prove himself before the country one of its best officers.

The recklessness of M. DE PERSIGNY, has given a triumph to the opponents of Imperialism, and placed his master in a false and awkward position. The Minister of the Interior entered the arena against the independent candidates, and in the nine arrondisements ...
The State of West Virginia is now a fixed fact. Hon. A.J. BORMAN was, to-day, inaugurated as the first Governor of the State.

The Philadelphians, accompanied by representatives from the leading Clubs of this City and Brooklyn, left Jersey City yesterday in the 1 P.M. train for Newark, where they arrived after a pleasant ride of half an hour.

A good commercial transaction should never be considered amiss, either in peace or war, and therefore we read wild lively interest, that Mr. CLARK MILLS has offered to sell to our City an equestrian statue of Gen. JACKSON for the trifling sum of $30,000.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 163. 1. The following revised order, in relation to advance pay, bounties and premiums, as paid by the United States, is pub lished for the information of all concerned, and will govern in lieu of all other orders on the subject:

During the past week this city has been in a state of unusual excitement, the fact having transpired that His Excellency Gov. STEPHEN S. HARDING had received an appointment to the Vice-Consulship of Valparaiso.

A difficulty, which had, to some extent, been foreseen, has occurred in the organization of the new troops. It arises principally from the confusion in the various orders. First came the order in which Gen. COUCH took command, and called upon the people to protect themselves from invasion.

The expedition that left here on Friday noon proceeded to South Quay, where a small body of rebels were discovered, but who, upon the approach of our men, fled across the river. The reconnoissance was pushed alone the line of the Blackwater to op posite Franklin. The rebels at this point also retreated across the river, and stationed themselves behind their earthworks.

This section of Pennsylvania forms, as you are aware, with the contiguous Counties of Carbon, Luzerne and Northumberland, the principal anthracite coal mining district of this country. Schuylkill County is the heaviest producer.

The bodies of Capt. John B. Hubbard and Lieut. D.P. Allen arrived in this City by the steame Fulton, from New-Orleans, at 12 o'clock Tuesday, in charge of Lieut. Show, the personal friend and fellow-townsman of Capt. HUABARD, and were taken to Boston by last evening's train on their way to the respective families of each.
All is quiet here.

The intelligence from the Uupper Potomac and Western Maryland, and Western Virginia continues to be of a very important character.
Gen. McCLELLAN left this city for New-York yesterday afternoon. A large number of troops have been furnished to the Government with extraordinary promptitude.
The Missouri State Convention met and organized to-day.
When the history of this most bloody war is written, few, if any, incidents will be of more thrilling interest than the capture, trial and execution of Col. WILLIAMS and Lieut. PETERS.

GENTLEMEN: I have to report that all of your stored have been safely removed from Falmouth and Aquia, and are now at the dock on the steamer Elizabeth. The only thing we were obliged to leave behind was the portable house at Aquia. This was so dilapidated that it is no loss.

Two more regiments the Fourth and Twelfth left this City yesterday, making nine in all that have responded to the call to meet the emergency in Maryland and Pennsylvania.

Almost every peo ple of Europe has a newspaper organ in this country, and indeed in this city. The deep interest taken in the affairs of Poland has led to the establishment of an organ in the language of that country. It is called Echo z Polski, or Polish Echo, and contains full details concerning the present Polish war for independence. It is published under the auspices of the Central Polish Committee.

My DEAR FRIEND: Yours of May 18 is received. I thank you for the kind sentiments expressed, and authorize you to carry to the Union Club the assurance of my continued interest and affection.

The Yankee propeller Boston arrived here this morning, having been captured by a party of sixteen men from this city, near Pass a POUTRE. On their way out they burned the barges Lennox and Texas, at the mouth of the Mississippi. Both of them had valuable cargoes for New-Orleans. The crew of the Boston, and a position of the crew of the barges are prisoners here.

Yesterday about one hundred of the Fourth Kentucky rebel cavalry crossed the Ohio River into Harrison County, Ind., for the purpose of making a raid into the interior.
A detachment of Gen. JENKINS' forces of mounted infantry, under the command of Col. FERGUSON, entered this place at 4 o'clock this morning.

THE STRAWBERRY EXHIBITION closed yesterday, and notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, which impaired somewhat the flavor and good appearance of the fruit, it was an eminent success. We gave yesterday the names of cultivators to whom first prizes were awarded.
Operations were commenced on our side to-day by a portion of a New-York cavalry regiment capturing twenty rebels at McConnellsburgh.
Reaching this place this morning, we found the gunboat Marmora and one or two others, which are engaged in conveying steamboats up and down the river from here to Young's Point.

The steamer Imperial has arrived, bringing official advices from Gen. GRANT'S army down to Sunday last, the 15th instant.

The Fifty-sixth regiment took their departure for Harrisburgh at noon on Friday. They formed on Raymond-street, in front of the Armory, about 9 o'clock A.M., but it took nearly two hours' time before the men were supplied with all that was required for the campaign.
There seems to be no end to the grand column of the loyal sons of Pennsylvania that is pouring into Harrisburgh from all points east of the Alleghenies, for the defence of the State.

No regiments left the City for Pennsylvania yesterday. The Sixty-ninth was to have gone, but it was found impossible to procure transportation. They will go at 7 o'clock this morning, and will be followed during the day by the Sixth, the Fifty-fifth and the remaining companies of the Seventy-first.

It is reported from reliable sources that forty thousand rebels are at Hagerstown and Williamsport. Three hundred cavalry are at Mercersburgh, stealing all the horses they can find and pillaging property. The rebels have with them eighteen pieces of artillery, and a force is reported within eight miles of Gettysbursh. Ample preparations on our part have been made to receive them.

We have intelligence of the capture of two rebel iron-clad vessels--one of them the blockaderunner Calypso, an English-built iron screw propeller, which was captured near Wilmington, N.C., on the 11th inst., and the other the famous ram Fingal, which was attacked on the 18th or 19th inst., near Savannah, by two of our Monitors, and captured after an engagement of thirty minutes. We think it must be something like fifteen months.

Information has been received that Frederick was occupied by a small force of rebels last evening about 5 o'clock, The rebel pickets night. ed thirteen miles east on the Frederick turnpike. There is no panic in this city.
This favorite New-York regiment is now on its third tour of duty since the war commenced.

The annual oration before the Literary Societies of the College will be delivered, in the First Presbyterian Church, on Tuesday, the 23d inst., at 11 o'clock. The orator is Hon. JOHN T. NIXON, of Bridgeton. N.J.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. The last performance of the season will be gives at this establishment to night, when Mrs. INCHBALD's comedy, "To Marry or not to Marry,"will be played. New-Yorkers will then have to bid good-bye to good acting until September next, when the establishment will reopen.

Arrived, steamer Orizaba from Panama. The news or the burning, by a rebel privateer, of a third California bound ship, causes many importers and commission merchants to withdraw their staple goods from the market, giving prices an upward tendency. Jobbers show a tendency to lay in heavy stocks.

In the House of Lords on the 8th, the Earl of Ellenborough made some inquires in regard to the diplomatic negotiations with respect to Poland, in the course of which he strongly denounced the policy of Russia.

SIR: I have the honor to report to the Department that on the night of the 5th inst., a steamer attempted to run out of Charleston. she was turned back by the Wissahickon, which vessel pursued her over the bar, firing at her repeatedly. The steamer was sunk. From subsequent information from two deserters from Charleston, (whom I send North by the Massachusetts,) there is reason to believe the vessel was the Isaac Smith.

MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Tuesday, June 16, 1863. Late rebel papers, among them the Chattanooga Rebel, the Knoxville Register, the Charleston Mercury, the Savannah Republican, and the Huntsville Confederate have come to hand. I send you some interesting extracts.
The Greek Deputation had an audience of the King of Denmark to-day at the Castle of Christainsborg. Admiral KANARIS, the spokesman of the deputation, made the following speech.
The report of a battle at Centreville between the National army and the rebel forces is without and foundation whatever in truth.

All the rumors of battles, victories and disasters in front of Washington last week, were canards. All the statements that HOOKER'S army had retreated behind the defences of Washington, were false. All the detailed accounts that LEE's army was planted at Bull Run, and stretched from Dumfries to Leesburgh, and across the Potomac, were bogus.

SEVEN LIVES LOST. One of the most terrible steamboat disasters that has occurred on the river for many years, took place last Monday afternoon. The new tugboat Greenwood, owned by GEORGE H. POWER, of this city, in making her first trip up the river, with a heavy tow, exploded her boiler when opposite Barrytown, killing at least seven persons, and seriously injuring others, and making the boat a complete wreck.

We learn from Mr. M.Mey, who was at the trial and execution, that WM. CANNON and JAS. MELVINE were hung at Highland, in Doniphan County, on Wednesday. June 3. They had robbed CHARLEY DEVINE, Mr. BEELER and Mr. MARTIN of a pair of mules, a wagon and three saddies.

Official advices from Vicksburgh to the 16th are received. The siege was progressing slowly but surely. Our total loss during the past week is estimated at less than forty. Not over eight or ten were killed. The garrison continued a vigorous firing of musketry and shells up to the time the dispatches were written, but with no success.
Richmond papers of the 20th received, say that the City off Darren, Ga., was burned by the Federals on the 11th inst., and is now one plain of ashes and blackened chimneys.

ASPEY DAY, C.B., Wednesday, June 17, 1863. yesterday, blowing a heavy gale from the eastward and heavy sea. Ship settled down alt. The sea is at high water up to the spar deck, as far as the mainmast. Part of the cargo above hold is dry. To-day the weather is moderate.

The screw steamer City of New-York, Capt KENNEDY, which sailed from Liverpool at 2 o'clock P.M., on the 10th, and from Queenstown on the 11th instant, arrived here yesterday. The news is not so late as that by the Norwegian, telegraphed from Cape Race, but she brings mails several days later than before received.

An advance was made upon this town to-day, the Tenth New-York cavalry in front. The enemy, after the sound thrashing received yesterday, fell back during the night, leaving only a strong picket force behind.

We learned ten days ago that the name of the "acting telegraphic supervisor," or censor, at Washington, to whom we are indebted for so many sensations and misbeliefs, was "Mr. LYNCH." We now learn an additional fact concerning him, which we hasten to publish. It is from the Washington correspondent of the Commercial Advertiser.
This has been truly a glorious day for that portion of the army commanded by Gen. PLEASANTON.

STUART'S cavalry has suffered another defeat at the hands of Gen. PLEASANTON a worse one, apparently, than either of the preceding ones. Gen. PLEASANTON, in an official report of the affair, states that he moved with his command, on Sunday morning, to Middleburgh, and attacked STUART.

STUART does not, we are convinced, over-estimate the value and brilliancy of his late victory, nor do more than justice to the conduct of his splendid command. The propeller John Rice arrived here last evening from Baltimore, with 1,100 rebel prisoners en route for City Point.

The ship Isaac Webb, HUTCHINSON, from Liverpool May 17, has arrived here, and reports that, on the 20th inst., at 8:30 A.M., in lat. 40 35'; lon. 68 45'; she was captured by the rebel bark Tacony, and released on giving bonds for $40,000.

SMITH before the City Judge at his chambers, on the 11th inst. The petition sets forth that HENRY is a minor, 20 years of age, and enlisted, six months since, in the Fourth Metropolitan regiment, without the knowledge or consent of his mother his father being dead.

Another heavy cavalry fight took place yesterday at Aldie Gap between PLEASANTON'S and STUART'S forces. The battle began at an early hour in the morning and continued until nightfall.

Brig.-Gen. S. Williams: GENERAL I moved with my command this morning o Middleburgh, and attacked the cavalry force of the rebels under STUART, and steadily drove him all day, inflicting heavy loss at every step. We took two pieces of artillery one being a Blakely gun together with three caissons, beside blowing one up.

The rebel newspapers always become peculiarly ferocious and bloodthirsty when their army is on the offensive. We have, among other Southern papers, the Richmond Whig of last Saturday, which contains column after column of matter that might make one think that the editor was a ghoul, writing exclusively for confederated ghouls.

SHOOTING AFFRAY IN BROOME-STREET. HUGH McCROW, a carman, residing at No. 181 Varickstreet, was shot so fatally in the abdomen on Sunday morning, that his life is despaired of. The disturbance took place in a saloon kept by ELVIA BROWN, No. 450 Broome-street, and known as the Monte Cristo. McCROW was taken to the City Hospital, and all persons found in the house were arrested by the Eighth Precinct Police.
Col. MONTGOMERY is out on another of his forays, and we have further good news direct from him.

We have advices from the City of Mexico to the 24th ult., by way of San Francisco. All the French residents have been compelled to leave the city. JUAREZ had taken command of the Mexican troops in person, and the fortifications around the city were being strengthened. Three more regiments left the City yesterday for the seat of war, making twelve in all, since the present emergency the Sixth and Sixty-ninth militia, and the One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Volunteers.

Col. CORNYN, of the Tenth Missouri cavalry, succeeded in scattering several camps of rebels who were gathering cattle for BRAGG'S army. He destroyed large quantities of forage and brought in numbers of cattle.
The markets are considerably excited. Staple articles, groceries, oils snd liquors, sold at extraordinary prices.
The steamship Locust Point, from New-Orleans on the 14th inst., arrived at this port last evening.

The principal fighting at Vicksburgh has lulled, and the enemy has fallen back and commenced fortifying among the hills, in parallel lines with those of PEMBERTON. His assaults on the Vicksburgh works have been terribly disastrous. More of the enemy have been slaughtered before the Vicksburgh trenches, than in any other battle of the war.

About 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon an explosion of saltpetre occured at No. 25 John-street, near Nassau, whereby several persons were seriously injured, and a large amount of property was destroyed. Mr. PECKHAM, proprietor of the premises where the accident occurred, is not expected to recover from the effect of the burns he received. An investigation as to the cause of the explosion will be made to-day.

THE HUDSON RIVER BAPTIST ASSOCIATION. The thirteenth anniversary exercises of the Hudson River Baptist Association were commenced at the Hanson-place Church yesterday morning, before a large congregation. The body is composed of about 40 churches.

The Mayor took the occasion to deliver himself of a long speech, which makes it apparent that there is not the most harmonious feeling between the military and civil authorities.

Gen. HOOKER visited Washington yesterday, and after interviews with the President and Secretary of War, returned to the army. Our special correspondence from headquarters, which is to the 21st, indicates no material change in the situation of the two armies at that time.

The steamer Luminary, from Chickasaw Bayou, with official reports from Gen. GRANT to the 18th, arrived to-day. Everything was progressing finely. The enemy kept up a steady fire of heavy artillery, but accomplished nothing. Scarcely a man had been injured on our side.

The ship Boanerges brings 500 Chinese passengers from Hong Kong.

The Thirty-eighth Annual Exhibition of the National Academy of Design having been open several weeks, we may now notice its various works in detail, without the danger of forestalling the public judgment.

We take great pleasure in announcing this week the capture, in Wassaw Sound, of the celebrated rebel ram Atlanta, better known to many of our readers as the Fingal, concerning which the rebels have been a long time boasting, and about which some of our people have had considerable fears.

The cavalry raid at Elizabethtown, on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, on Saturday last, with the particulars of which the telegraph will have put your readers in possession are this reaches you, prevented for that day the arrival of the regular daily train from the former city.

I think it cannot be for a moment doubted that the rebels are in large force north of the Potomac. The latest new you have already received by telegraph, and I need not repeat it. I can give you my reasons...

Official advices from Gen. GRANT to the 19th, at noon, report some advantage gained by our forces on the 18th. The siege was progressing satisfactorily. Gen. McCLERNAND had been removed from the command of the Thirteenth Army corps, by Gen. GRANT, and Gen. OAD assigned to command in his place.

Gen. PLEASANTON had the greatest cavalry fight that has yet taken place.
Gen. HOOKER arrived here this morning. Had interviews with the President and Secretary of War, and returned to the army this afternoon.
The situation is not materially changed since my last. STUART'S cavalry still range through the lower part of London Valley and hover about our forces in the vicinity of Aldie and Thoroughfare Gaps.

The Democrat's Murfreesboro dispatch gives the following Southern news:
We have received a number of Richmond, Mobile and Augusta (Ga.) papers, some of them as late as June 20, from which we make the following extracts:

Commodore STEPHEN C. ROWAN, Commander of the iron-clad frigate Roanoke, has been ordered to proceed to Port Royal, and to relieve Commodore CRAVEN in command of the iron-clad frigate NewIronsides. Commander CREIGHTON it is said will assume command of the Roanoke, and proceed South with her. It is believed that the Government will charter a vessel to convey to Port Royal Commodore ROWAN and all the other officers recently ordered to the South Atlantic fleet.

BREADSTUFFS. Messrs. Richardson, Spence Co., Gordon, Bruce Co., and Wakefield, Nash Co. report; Flour tending downward; American, 21s, @ 25s. Wheat heavy, and all qualities slightly lower; Red Western, 8s. 9d. @ 9s. 3d.; Red Southern, 9s. 5d. @ 9s. 6d.; White Western, 10s. @ 10s. 5d.; White Southern, 10s. 5d. @ 11s. Corn declining; Mixed 28s., White 30s. @ 32s.
The monthly return of the Bank of France shows a decrease in cash of twenty-seven and a half millions of francs, and an increase in bills discounted of thirteen millions.
The situation is not materially changed since my last. STUART'S cavalry still range through the lower, part of London Valley and hover about our forces in the vicinity of Aldie and Thoroughfare Gaps.

The position of the army of the rebel Gen. LEE seems gradually to be developing. All accounts, for two days past, concur in placing it in the Shenandoah Valley. The corps of Gen. EWELL was sent ahead to clear the way...

Hon. Ira, Harris, Albany; Judge Crosby, Lowell, Mass.; Col. Z.H. Benton, Pa.; Capt. B.F. Sands and Ira Harris, Jr., U.S. Navy, are at the Astor House.
A body of cavalry belonging to Gen. COUCH'S command entered Frederick yesterday afternoon, and drove the rebels out of the place.

Recorder HOFFMAN, yesterday, rendered his decision in the case of Dr. BROWN, the abortionist, whose counsel, it will be recollected, put in a special plea to the last indictment against him, that their...
In the Convention, to-day, Gov. GAMBLE, Chairman of the Committee on Emancipation, presented the following ordinance from the majority of the Committee:

Information received at the headquarters of Gen. SCHENOK to-night, and other sources, state that Gen. EWELL'S forces, to the number of from 35,000 to 40,000 men, are now in Maryland, in the Boonsboro Valley.

The politics of Missouri were never in a condition of more violent excitement than at the present time. The ordinary "high-pressure" action of everything personal, political and military, in that State, has just received a heavy fillip in the reassembling of the State Convention, charged now with the duty of relieving that Commonwealth from the curse of Slavery.

Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at the Fourth Precinct station-house on the body of JOSEPH NIXON, who at a late hour on Tuesday night, was shot in Cherry-Street, near Oliver, with a pistol in the hands of WALTER D. BELL.

The rebel cavalry advanced to Shippensburgh this afternoon at 3 o'clock. Telegraphic communication was suspended at that place. The operator retired to Newville, and at last accounts was at Graysonville, six miles above Carlisle and twenty-four from Harrisburgh.
Our military correspondent at Harrisburgh, in a letter which we published yesterday, made the statement that.

ANNUAL REGATTA OF THE JERSEY CITY YACHT CLUB.--The Annual Regatta of the Jersey City Yacht Club came off Tuesday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, from McGiehan's Basin, foot of Van Vorst-street, a large number of spectators being present. Messrs. QUAIFE, REA and SMITH were the judges.

Two regiments still remain--the Forty-seventh infantry and Seventieth cavalry--both of which are under marching orders, and will leave some time during the week. Both the brigades at the seat of war--the Fifth and Eleventh--will then be full. The Generals in command received their orders on Tuesday, and last night proceeded with their commands to Harrisburgh.

At 11 O'clock lastnight dispatches were received by Gen. COUCH, informing him that rebel scouts had reentered Greencastle, and that a considerable force were preparing to march into Chambersburgh. Our troops at the latter point were immediately ordered to fell back to Carlisle.

Our dispatches from the headquarters of Gen. HOOKER'S army, this morning, renders it positive that the bulk of the rebel army is west of the Blue Ridge. STUART'S cavalry range up and down under its eastern shadows, but Gen. PLEASANTON keeps sharp watch of him, and skirmishes occur daily.

The Spanish mail steamer Expana, from Cadiz, arrived here yesterday, and, in addition to news from Spain, brings the latest intelligence from the sister Spanish island of Porto Rico, where this line of steamers touch on their voyage out.
Major OSCAR A. MANN, of the United States artillery, is appointed Acting Assistant-Provost-MarshalGeneral of New-Hampshire.

In the accounts which we published yesterday of the iron-clad battle between the Monitor Weehawken and the rebel iron-clad Atlanta, we have the first true test of the wisdom of ERICSSON'S system of building vessels of war.

When Gen. GRANT lately ordered the ravaging of a large section of country between Vicksburgh and Canton, he took a step not only necessary in itself, but justified by the laws of war. It was done purely for military purposes.

The achievements of our cavalry are the topic of much favorable comment among the men and officers of the army, particularly among the infantry, who are fast getting in love with the cavalry--there having been, heretofore, plenty of room for an increase of affection between them. The early end accurate accounts of the late cavalry battles, from the TIMES cavalry correspondent, are the only ones that have appeared here, and are read with much avidity.

The schooner Lawrena arrived at Gloucester this morning and reports that on Monday afternoon, forty miles east-southeast from Chatham, saw the schooner Marengo on fire. Soon afterward saw a bark running for a fleet of thirty fishing vessels, and while we remained in sight three of the fishing vessels were set on fire.

Portions of Gen. GREGG'S cavalry command have been engaged skirmishing with the enemy nearly all day. The enemy's line of skirmishers were met early this morning in a piece of woods a little to the west of Middleburgh, and they were gradually forced back about five miles on the road leading to Ashby's Gap, where, it is said, the enemy have two brigades of infantry.

The Spanish merchant steamer Mejico brought nothing later from Vera Cruz than had been already received by the English mail steamer. The only matter of interest which the newspapers contain is the confirmation of the escape of ORTEGA and other Generals from Orizaba, and also that up to the 25th ult., the City of Mexico had not been evacuated by JUAREZ' Government.

Later news from Mexico, by way of Havana, is received, but it is not important. The escape of ORTEGA and other Mexican officers from Orizaba is confirmed. ORTEGA and his companions were at Jalapa on the 29th ult., and intended to leave immediately for the Capital. The resignation of COMONFORT had been received by the Government.

The enemy finding that Gen. PLEASANTON was moving back, ventured to come out of the Gap (Ashby's) and make an attack upon our rear, to-day. A portion of the column was halted and the advance of the enemy was checked. Their attack did not create any alarm, nor were many lives lost. A.P. HILL'S corps is known to be in the Gaps, and EWELL'S just beyond in the Shenandoah Valley.

The Pennsylvania Reserves, under Maj.-Gen. CRAISFORD, have been transferred from the Department of Washington to the Army of the Potomac. Their number has been increased by the return to service of many who were disabled or wounded in the many battles through which they have passed. Applications have been made by the officers, and desires expressed by the men, to be led against the enemy now invading their native State.

The second day'a races on the Centreville Course took place yesterday, and were well attended, the President of the Brooklyn and Jamaica Railroad superintending the arrangements of the trips, in person; in consequence of which every facility was extended to the visitors to the races.

The rebels talk wildly about marching through Pennsylvania. Probably they will not try it. They profess great contempt for the militia troops that may be sent against them. We hope their contempt will not be justified by events. Even if the State cannot at once organize a great army to meet them, the people ought to make the march of a rebel force for any distance impossible.

After a series of almost interminable delays, caused by the nature of the expedition in which we are engaged, we may be said to be fully on the "war path." One column of our army is ascending the Missouri, with all the rapidity that dull and sluggish stream will admit of, and our own division is under marching orders for the 15th instant.

An alliance between a young reprobate and the broker against his "governor" is not an uncommon thing; but it is a ticklish arrangement, and requires discretion. These young blades have high notions, and it don't do for their business agents to be too free with them.

MAN MISSING. Mr. JOHN SCOFIELD, dyer and hat curler, of the City of Newark, N.J., has been missing since the 25th of April last. His family are in the utmost grief in consequence. Any one knowing anything of him or his fate will confer a great favor by addressing his wife, at Mr. JAMES STOTT'S, corner of Myitle and Nostrand-avenues, Brooklyn.

GRANT and KNOWLES, the deserters, who shot McKENNEY, Chief of the Police of this City, on Sunday, while attempting to arrest them for horse stealing, were discovered in the woods yesterday by three of the posse sent in search of them. The desperadoes resisted, and a desperate and bloody affray took place.

The delegation from the Cincinnati Common Council, who arrived in this City on Saturday last, remaining until Sunday evening, returned from their visit to Boston to the St. Nicholas Hotel last evening. They will leave for home by the 7 o'clock A.M. train New-York and Erie Railroad, to-day.

The following letter from Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER will be read with interest by his many friends in our sister city, as well as by those who have not the personal interest in his welfare which his fellow-citizens so frequently evince. In his old role of contributor to the Independent, he is most welcome:

The navy has once more been stirred up by the depredations of the privateers. Hardly had the steamers returned which were sent away a few days since, and reported their failure to discover the whereabouts of the pirates, than orders were received here to prepare once more all available vessels, and to charter every fast one to be had.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by tolegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.

The expedition that proceeded hence on the 11th of the current month, and returned to this point on yesterday, was not without both important prospects and results. Its leading object was to investigate the strength of and destroy the three leading strongholds of the enemy on the Blackwater River, all of which were within a distance of twenty-five miles from Suffolk.

The promptness with which Gov. PARKER, of New-Jersey, responded to Gov. CURTIN'S recent call for aid to repel the invasion of Pennsylvania, drew forth, as it deserved, very general commendation, in which the TIMES was happy to join. On the 22d inst. Gov. PARKER issued a proclamation, calling back all the troops he had dispatched to Pennsylvania, to receive their discharge.
The newly-appointed Consul to Chee Fow was captured by a rebel pirate recently on his way to China. All the Consular property books, forms, stationery, , was burned with the ship.

Was Pennsylvania, invaded two weeks ago by 1,500 or 50,000 rebels? Who knows? The Government at Washington evidently thought the latter number, or they would nor have called for 120,000 volunteers to repel the invasion. But as yet there has been no evidence whatever that the danger menacing the North which called forth such herculean preparatians for repulsion, came from over a couple of thousand of JENKINS' guerrilla cavalry.
The Nineteenth army corps still lays in the rear of the formidable rebel works. The works are thoroughly invested, any other event than that of an eventual surrender is impossible.

Our dispatches from Harrisburgh state, that at last accounts the rebel were within four miles of Carlisle, Gen. KNIPE, in command of the small National force there, had drawn his men up in line of battle, prepared for an attack. The enemy was expected to reach Carlisle before night, but for some reason did not make his appearance. McConnellsville was entered by the rebels in force on Wednesday night, at 8 o'clock.

If to no one else, it will be a matter of delight to Secretary WELLES to learn that a large United States steamer was seen cruising off Chatham on Wednesday last. Only a couple of days previous the rebel brig Tacony had committed a series of daring depradations in that vicinity.
The following dispatch has been received by Major-Gen. BURNSIDE from the expedition sent into East Tennessee:

The Sixth Annual Regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, which came off yesterday, was a complete success both numerically and pecuniarily. The weather, which, next to the water, is the most important thing in a regatta, was decidedly favorable; a cool breeze blowing throughout the day from the southeast, rendered the atmosphere pleasant and lessened the effect of the sun.

It is no discredit to any community to be "alarmed" by the announced approach of the public enemy. The discredit and the disgrace consist in remaining "alarmed" after time has elapsed and been unimproved for ascertaining the extent of the danger, and preparing to meet it.
The capture in Warsaw sound of the Confederate iron-clad Atlanta, alias Fingal, by Capt. RODGERS, of the Weehawken, is a splendid affair, and the most important naval capture of the war.

So far as all the rest of the world goes we are here at this point as yet in a fog, and I will therefore only speak of things hereabouts. On last Monday the excitement commenced by news of a raid on the road below, and orders were received for all the troops along the line of the road to concentrate at Grafton. This order was subsequently changed to New-Creek, twenty miles distant.

The story that I was so much inclined to disbelieve on Sunday, seems to be generally credited now, and the fact of the existence of thirty or forty thousand rebels between Williamsport and Hagerstown is placed beyond much doubt. Scouts from two directions report that number.

The elevation of Mr. BOOLE to the office of City Inspector, has been received with singular favor by all parties, people and papers. Few men have reached the purple of office amid more general acclamations.

The Indian De partment has news of the assemblage of 10,000 warlike Indians of different tribes at Fort Larned, Kansas. It is thought that unless they are soon enlisted to fight for the Union, they will give us much trouble.
It is remarkable that during the war we have, until the death of Admiral FOOTE, lost none of our great naval commanders, and even he died of disease, and not by the hand of the enemy.

The United States transport steamer Albany, Capt. LEWIS, leaves here at 5 P.M., for New-York. Two deserters arrived here from Wilmington a few days since, with the intelligence that two rebel ironclade, with five inches plating on eighteen inches of wood, mounting heavy guns, were about ready to mate a raid on our blockading squadron.
PENNSYLVANIANS: In the name and by the authority of the Com- monwealth of Pennsylvania, ANDREW G. CURTIN, Gov- ernor of said Commonwealth:
Official intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army to the 26th inst., is received. JOHNSTON is said to have withdrawn his troops from across the Big Black, moving toward Clinton.

The steamship Champion arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall, which port she left on the 17th inst. She brought $187,000 in treasure. Everything was quiet on the Isthmus. The news from Central and South America is of no importance.

It is now forty days since the siege of Vieksburgh was commenced. It was on the 18th of May the day after that on which was fought the last of the five-victorious battles which illustrated GRANT'S march, that the investment of the city was effected. The three corps of the army moved up to the siege...

The steamer Bohemian, from Southampton on June 11, arrived at this port yesterday.

At no period during the present invasion of that of last year has there been so much excitement in Harriburgh as now. In fact, if excitement and be- wilderment were the chief essentials to discomfit and defeat the rebels, that wished-for result would have been attained.

A telegram, received yesterday at the Austrain Embassy, announces that a courier was on his way to Paris with the acceptance by the Vienna Cabinet of the French note to Russia on the affairs of Poland, as referred to in my letter of Monday.
The Matanzas was to go direct, and leave at 6 o'clock last evening. At 5 o'clock the Quartermaster sent an order for her detention, to take on board fifty prisoners, and to land them at Key West.
The steamer Creole, from New-Orleans on the 19th instant, arrived here yesterday afternoon.
The good people of Paris were startled yesterday by the roaring of the big guns at the In valides in honor of the fall of Puebla the Mexican Sebastopol.

The people turn to the newspapers daily, with anxiety never surpassed in the war, to learn the military situation around Washing- ton.
Gov. CURTIN last evening received information that the rebels occupied Gettysburgh yesterday with ten regiments of infantry, and with cavalry and artillery.

EWELL has issued a proclamation from Cham- bersburgh pledging protection to the citizens unless they offer resistance. He enjoins upon them to abstain from dealing out liquor to his soldiers, and if a violation of the order occurs be will seize and destroy the entire stock.

The public will not be unprepared to learn of the demise of Rear Admiral ANDREW H. FOOTE. The painful disease under which be has suffered (albuminuria) left no hope of his recovery, and for days his friends have waited, with what resignation they could, for the hour of his departure. He died last night, at half-past 10 o'clock, at the Astor House, and is now beyond all mortal anguish.

Friday was the last of the three days' race meeting on the Centreville Course, the programme of which has been so honorably carried out to the letter by Capt. T.G. MOORE, of Kentucky.

The week has been characterized by a series of dreary rains which have continued up to this morning. At the present writing it is warm and clear, but lazy looking clouds still hand heavily in the east, indicating that the "rainy term" is not yet over.

A naval officer, just arrived from off Wilmington, reports that the rebel schooner Hattie was captured last Saturday by the United States gunboat Florida. She was running out with turpentine, cotton and resin.

An authorized dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, announces that the Army is in motion, and will soon be to the front and north of Baltimore. We are enabled further to say that the entire army of Gen. HOOKER is on the north side of the Potomac, and will soon be head from by the public.

From the Savannah News. Our readers have been informed that the City of Darlen, one of the oldest towns in the State, the New Inverness of Oglethorpe's time, has been totally destroyed by Yankee negro forces.
On last Wednesday the Tennessee Confederates held a convention at Winchester, and proceeded to nominate Hon. ROBERT CARUTHEES as candidate for the office of Governor.

GENERAL ORDERS No.7. I. The late deplorable accident in the Second U.S.V., occurring from the negligent handling of firearms, admonishes the General Commanding, that it is his duty to issue this order.

If PEMBERTON had not stopped the speculation in breadstuffs in his Department, the garrison of Vicksburgh would to-day have had to succumb to a more powerful enemy than the Federal army now "bearding him in his den." As it is, his supplies are said to be ample for a good siege.
Interesting exercises, incident to the graduating of the senior class of Grammar School No.47, Fifteenth Ward, were held on Friday afternoon, at the school building, in Twelfth-street, near Broadway.
Attorney-General BATES arrived here last night and will be sercnaded to-night.
A squadron of Scott's Nine Hundred cavalry-, under Maj. REMINGTON, on their way to Centreville, this morning, encountered near Fairfax the Sixth Virginia cavalry, and dashed at them with the sabre.

One of the most daring and hazardous raids ever attempted has taken place in Indiana. Dr. FRY, commanding the post at New-Albany, informs us that, on Tuesday night or Wednesday morning last, two hundred rebels crossed the Ohio at Flint Rock, near Leavenworth, and struck out for the interior of Indiana.

The remains of the late Rear-Admiral FOOTE were yesterday conveyed to Hartford, Conn., where a public funeral will take place on Monday. You will probably hear in brief by this mail, via England, of the new phase affairs in Japan have taken within the last few days. We take the same opportunity of giving you a little more at length, perhaps, the exact state of things, as we find them, up to the present moment.

A party of our daring marines started to get a steamboat; the party was under the command of Capt. JAMES DUKE. After experiencing rather hard face in the marshes of the Mississippi for some days, they discovered the Boston towing the ship Jenny land, loaded with ice, up to New-Orleans.

The fight at Winchester Va., actually began on Friday evening at Newtown, a village on the Strasburgh road, about ten miles south of Winchester. Maria Todd vs. Robert T. Kerr and Ann M. Kerr. It appeared on evidence that the plaintiff and her husband Richard J. Todd, the father and mother of the defendant. Mrs. Kerr, were married in Ireland and came to this country when the defendant was about one year old, and resided in Brooklyn until the 16th February, 1862, when the husband and father died.

The Cumberland River is rising at the rata of an inch and a half an hour, with 10 feet of water already on the shoals.
