The President to-day pardoned WILSON VICKERY, who was convicted at the June term, 1863, of the Circuit Court of the United Statos for the Northern District of New-York, for making counterfeit coin, and sentenced to imprisonment in the Albany Penitentiary for a term of years.

The long-heralded Democratic State Convention has been held. The result has rather disappointed the leaders, and has made something of a breach in the ranks. You have doubtless been made acquainted with the main features of the proceedings by telegraph.

One of the most interesting yacht meetings ever known in this country is now in progress, and has been during the past three days. To all yachtsmen, professional and amateur, it is an occasion of great and all-absorbing interest, and doubtless when...

From the Star and Banner, June 25. A company from the Two Taverns, Mount Joy Township, commanded by Capt. COLLINS, came marching into town on Monday last, and struck for headquarters, where they offered their services to Major HALLER, commandant in this county, and were accepted.
A detachment of the Seventh regiment left this City yesterday to join their comrades in Baltimore.
King WILLIAM and VON BISMARK seem to have adopted the political maxim of STRAFFORD "Thorough and thorough." No half measures for them, any more than for the "Great Apostate."
The Democratic State Convention for the nomination of a State ticket, and for the election of four delegates at large to the next National Democratic Convention, was held here to-day.

Any statements of military movements here would be injudicious. Much has been said, both by the newspapers here and correspondens from abroad, that, perhaps, ought not to have been said, and hence premises, forbidding the transmission of all contraband intelligence. Sutlice it to say that the arrangements for the reception of the enemy have been well...

The steamers Prima Donna, Jacob Strader and New Kentucky, laden with commissary stores, convoyed by two Iron-clad gunboats, were fired into by a large body of rebels at Cypress Bend on Monday. Several persons on board the steamers were killed...
The Savannah Republican's army correspondence, under date New Fosterville, June 10, has the following from the front:
The rebels occupied York at 5 o'clock this morning. No resistace was made by our troops.
A most interesting debate has recently taken place in the British House of Commons on the state of Turkey, tho condition of its Christian population and the Eastern policy of England.

From the Yazoo Banner, June 5. Thursday, the 21st, our town presented a scene of bustle and confusion unprecedented in our annals. Squads of gold-laced gentlemen, with their Staffs and dependents, might be seen hurrying to and fro, making ready to leave our "dear, damned, distracted town."
We have just returned from our expedition in pursuit of the enemy's transports, and have been highly successful.
A pilot up from Southport reports that four fishing vessels arrived there this morning, who made the following report:

Since the departure of the Creole, which was detained for dispatches the steamer Iberville has ar- rived, under convoy of a gunboat. She confirms the report of the burning of four steamers near Plaquemine. The Sallie Robinson and other boats, having 12- pounders on the decks, have gone up the river with ordnance stores, c., under convoys.

Here we are still, among these grand old magaolia forests, with the almost incessant roar of artillery and musketry in our ears; the desultory firing, kept up night and day, being enough to keep the beleaguered rebels, one would imagine, perpetually without rest.

The rebels have repeatedly of late hung, and otherwise put to death in the most barbarous manner, such negro soldiers of the Union army as they have taken prisoner in battle. The details of their massacre, in cold blood, of 200 negroes at Franklin, La., and of others at Milliken's Bend, and again, at Port Hudson, have been published in our columns.

In order to secure the families of colored troops in this department from all danger of recapture by the enemy, and for the purpose of educating and giving them permanent homes, Maj.-Gen. FOSTER has recently founded an extensive colony for them on the fertile grounds of Roanoke Island, where they are to have all the advantages of civilization.

Though the late Canal C onvention at Chicago failed to forward the object for which it was called, in as great a degree as had been expected, it yet did good in bringing before the country some vital facts regarding the growth and prospects of American products and American commerce, and the consequent necessities of greater and better courses and means of transit between the West and the East.

The remains of the late Rear-Admiral FOOTE, were on Saturday conveyed to Hartford, Conn. where a public funeral will take place on Monday. The body was escorted from the Astor House to the Hartford boat by a large number of naval officers, preceded by two companies of marines and a band from the Brooklyn Navy-yard.
The steamship George Griswold, from NewOrleans on the 21st inst., arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices are two days later.

We have from our correspondent a vivid account of the second great assault on the rebel works at Port Hudson, which took place on the 14th two weeks ago yesterday. We are enabled also to relieve a wide-spread public anxiety, by publishing a list of the killed and wounded, which is in great part official.
The old familiar disputes as to which General is getting the better of the other in strategy are beginning to rage again, and they are just as vain now as ever they were.
A report that Gen. HOCKER has been relieved of the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. MEADE appointed in his place, comes to us through our Special Washington Correspondent.
On the second day of the Convention, and shortly before it adjourned, Mr. S.B. RUGGLES, Commissioner and Delegate from the State of New-York, offered the following resolution:

The steamer Blackstone arrived at this port yesterday, from a cruise from Sandy Hook to the Banks, under command of A.S. BALDWIN, Com- mander U.S.N. Her officers are, Commander A.S. BALDWIN; Acting-Master, P.S. BORDEN; ActingMaster's Mate, E.P. PALMER.

A member of Gen. ASBOTH'S Staff, from Columbus, reports Gen. PRICE with six thousand rebels in the vicinity of Island No. 37. It is said he is preparing rafts to cross the Mississippi, his object being to cooperate with the rebel force in the vicinity of Memphis. Another report says he will occupy Island No. 35, and intercept navigation. Capt. PENNOCK, of the Navy, is alert and will entrap Price.
We accept as truth the rumor that Gen. Hooker has been relieved of the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. Meade put in his place.

Our forces have slowly retired, and are now in and around the fortifications of Harrisburgh. The enemy is advancing slowly, and in all probability will soon commence an attack. Gen. SMITH has made proper disposition of his troops.

GENERAL ORDERS No. , First In order to increase the armies now in the field, volunteer infantry, cavalry and artillery may be enlisted at any time within ninety days from this date, in the respective States, under the regulations hereinafter mentioned. The volunteers so enlisted and such of the three years' troops now in the field as may reenlist, in accordance with this order, will constitute a force to be designated "Veteran Volunteers."
The country will be astounded by the news from Washington this morning that Gen. HOOKER has been relieved from the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. MEADE appointed as his successor.

I have barely more than time to announce to you by this morning's mail, that the whole Army of the Cumberland is in motion. The silence of five months is broken by the tramp of solid columns marching on to meet the enemy once more the same enemy which on the first day of the present year was driven from his position at this place.

ARRIVAL OF SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDIERS. Between three and four hundred sick and wounded soldiers arrived in the steamer Cosmopolitan, from Newbern, yesterday. Surgeon McDOUGALL, Medical Director of the Department of the East, visited the steamer soon after her arrival, and made arrangements to have the men sent to the hospitals nearest their homes.

We yesterday published a series of dispatches from Portland, Maine, giving the particulars of a daring raid made into Portland harbor, on Friday night, by a party of rebels under command of Lieut, REED, from the pirate bark Tacony, who succeeded in running out the revenue cutter Caleb Cushing, and putting to sea with her.

The siege still progresses in most respects as it has heretofore. Gen. SHERMAN has his approaches so near that his men can use hand-grenades, throwing them up over the high parapets of the enemy McPHERSON has made an equal advance. McCLERNAND has not advanced so far.
A motion by Mr. HENDERSON, to reconsider the vote of yesterday, by which it was agreed to submit the ordinance of emancipation to the people, was carried, 65 to 21.

Refugees who have reached the Army of the Potomac from Richmond, represent that there was quite a panic there. Only a very small guard was left there, and many of the citizens were leaving and going to Staunton. This would seem to indicate that the Richmond people are rather uneasy at the almost total abandonment of that city by the rebel forces.

The adventures of the rebel privateer Tacony along the Atlantic seaboard, almost in sight of our harbors the impunity with which she captured and burnt the numerous craft she encountered, until her victims numbered...

There appears to be no longer a doubt that the whole rebel army under LEE, with the exception of STUART's cavalry, is in Pennsylvania. Thirtyseven thousand troops, with 104 pieces of artillery, had passed through Chambersburgh up to Saturday last. Gen. LEE himself, with his Staff, was in Chambersburgh on Saturday morning.

We all hope that within a few weeks LEE'S army will have suffered so signal a repulse that he will be forced to retire into Virginia in such a broken, disorganized and demoralized condition, that he will be incapable of standing his ground anywhere on this side of Richmond.
The steamship Pera has arrived from Alexandria, Egypt. She brings 12,087 in specie, and Capts. SPEKE and GRANT, of the Nile expedition, as passengers.
Business is almost entirely suspended in all its departments.

The commencement exercises incident to the Twentieth school year of the Mount Washington collegiate Institute took place, Friday afternoon, at the marble church, Fourth-street, near Washingtonsquare, and were attended with the most brilliant success.
It is said that one hundred and fifty colored men were captured by the rebel cavalry at Edwards' Ferry, yesterday.

The Quaker City seems to be aroused at last. Stores and factories are closing, business is pretty generally suspended, and thousands of able-bodied men are addressing themselves with becoming interest and energy to the work of organizing military companies.
The political aspect of the Polish question had undergone no change.

The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 17th, via Queenstown on the l8th inst., was boarded off Cape Race on Friday evening. Her advices are only one day later than those per the Hecla at New-York.

Information was received here late yesterday afternoon, by the arrival of two stages with passengers from Hagerstown, that Gens. LEE and LONGSTREET were both at Hagerstown yesterday morning. They took breakfast at a farm-house one mile from the town, and afterwards passed through toward Chambersburgh, attended by their Staff officers and a small guard.
THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
SILAS CROUNSE, the brother of L.L., in the service of the TIMES, sends to this Bureau the following dispatch:
Advices from Europe, four days later, reach us by the arrival of the steamship Hecla, at this port and the City of Baltimore off Cape Race. The news is to the 18th inst.
The flag-of-truce steamer Monitor left for City Point this afternoon, with 600 rebel prisoners, in charge of Maj. JOHN E. MULFORD, General Flag-oftruce officer.
Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening, a horrible murder is alleged to have been committed at No. 80 Nassau-street.

The Ohio Democratic State Convention Committee received an answer from the President to-day. He agreed to release VALLANDIGHAM, provided they would personally conform to certain terms, which the Committee were not at liberty to do without consulting with the entire Committee in New-York to-morrow. Several of its members have already reached that City.
The rebels who cut the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad at Sykesville and Marriottsville numbered about twenty. The culvert at the former place was not disturbed.

Some thirty citizens of Kentucky, of fair fame hitherto and of considerable personal influence, have called on Hon. CHARLES A. WICKLIFFE to become a Democratic candidate for Governor of Kentucky. What it means out West to be a "Democratic candidate," we hardly know.
The clergy men of Philadelphia held a meeting yesterday, and offered their services to the authorities to work on the fortifications of the city.

The rebels are slowly advancing toward this place, having entered Carlisle at 1 P.M. Telegraphic communication with Carlisle was suspended at about 12 M. Our forces have retired to Mechanicsburgh, which is nine miles from Harrisburgh. All...
The body of a Mr. LOVETT was found at a late hour last evening by Mr. HOLMES, janitor of the building No. 80 Nassau-street, in a water-closet of that building.

Advices from GRANT'S army to the noon of the 22d, say the siege was progressing vigorously. On the 20th the cannonading was kept up from morning until noon by the army and navy, but elicited no reply from the garrison. A large number of buildings were destroyed; bat beyond that it is not ascertained that much damage was done.

In the House of Lords on the 15th, the Marquis of Clanricarde moved for copies of any reports that may have been received from the Admiral commanding Her Majesty's squadron on the North American and West Indian station, concerning the protection

PRESENT William Walsh, Esq., President, Aldermen Fox, Henry, Hall, McCool, Reed, Chipp, Mitchell, Ryers, Jeremiah, Hardy, Masterson, Ottiwell, Farley, Long. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

In addition to the royal congratulations previously announced, the Emperor had received the congratulations of the King of Italy, the King of the Belgians, the King and Queen of Spain, and the Queen of Holland, upon the capture of Puebla. La France states that the departure of troops for Mexico has been deferred until the arrival of Gen. FOREY'S report.

A Murfreesboro dispatch, dated 27th inst., says; "In skirmishes on the 24th and 25th inst., at Guy's Gap, between the advance corps of Gen. McCook and a rebel brigade, our loss was two hundred and twenty-five killed and wounded, including Capt. Vattier and Lieut. Thomas, of the Seventy-seventh Pennsylvania, killed; and Capts. Martin, Laine and Kambo, and Lieuts. Foulke, King and Jones, of the same regiment, wounded."
The alarm this morning was occasioned by soldiers seeing two schooners below Fort Preble, acting as if they intended to make an attack.

The city is at last waked up. Notwithstanding the telegrams that come from Washington that Harrisburgh is in no danger, the population within it is, and are flocking to arms with a good will. We are surrounded on all sides.

This morning, Gen. KNIPE'S force had fallen back to a small village called Oyster Point. The enemy continued to press them, so that, later in the day, they abandoned that position, and are now with the main force, in and about the defences across the Susquehanna. The main force of the rebels is at...
Throughout the day our forces have held a position beyond the Harrisburgh fortifications, in anticipation of the enemy's advance. The rebels have not shown an inclination to make an attack.

It is settled that LEE has the great body of his army not only north of the Potomac, but on Pennsylvania soil. It is a movement of extraordinary boldness, accompanied with great risks; and yet its wisdom is so apparent that it ought to have been clearly foreseen and seasonably prevented.

An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner NAUMANN, upon the body of LOVELL, the man whose death from violence, at No. 80 Nassaustreet, has been published. The jury rendered a verdict against HENSHAW as a principal in the homicide, and also against ADAMS and BRIGGS as accessories before the fact. The three persons above named have been arrested, and are now in custody.

The advance of the Army of the Cumberland has, up to the present time, been attended with entire success, although the heavy rain that has fallen ever since we started has retarded movements somewhat. The Third corps, forming the centre and wing of the army, have for three days been marching southward,...

The Chattanooga Rebel of the 24th inst. editorially says:

The rebels no longer menace Harrisburgh. The Army of the Potomac, under its new commander, Gen. MEADE, was in rapid motion on Monday and yesterday. Its progress on Monday was such as to relieve the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad from rebel cavalry, and to...
Port Hudson has not been taken, Gen. GRANT was deceived by a false report to that effect, gives out before the best landed.
The City of Baltimore arrived at this port yesterday. The main point of her news was telegraphed from Cape Race, but the malls bring the following additional details:

Next to Gen. MEADE, no man in the military service has a harder job than Gen. BANKS. The operations of GRANT and ROSECRANS are more gigantic, but in some respects not as difficult. Gen. A Committee of the City Councils and citizens had an interview with Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE last night in relation to the defences of the city. The Committee adjourned without action, to meet again this morning.

In the TIMES of yesterday we gave all the facts which were then known relative to a homicide which was committed on Monday evening, in the premises No. 80 Nassau-street. Coroner NAUMANN yesterday impanneled a jury, and proceeded to investigate the facts and circumstances connected with the unfortunate occurrence. The following is the substance of all the testimony which is material:

Following the example of the enemy, your correspondent has concluded to "invade." The transition from the soil of traitorous Virginia to that of loyal Maryland is quite as pleasant to me as to the rebels. We leave barren wastes and desolate ruins for well-tilled fields, quiet villages, and well-filled lardres--only I fear to leave some of these as barren and as desolate as some we have mourned over in other regions.

Advices received here this evening indicate that LEE is at last thoroughly aroused to the peril of the position in which he has entangled his army. He is drawing in his forces to the neighborhood of Shippensburgh, where a great battle will probably be fought.

There is one circumstance is Gen. MEADA'S history, for which, now that he is in command of the army, we may all feel devoutly thankful. He was born in Spain, and consequently is not eligible for the office of President of the United States.

I have just had an extremely interesting conversation with a young man whose name I dare not mention, because if the rebels should ever catch him they would surely shoot or hang him as a spy--for such he was. He voluntarily went within their lines, and traversed all their camps in the vicinity of Car-...

FOSTER, commanding the Eighteenth army corps, at Newbern, N.C., to collect at the North a large quantity of supplies appropriate for colonizing the families of colored soldiers upon Roanoke Island. They are to be placed there as being a safe place, well fitted by situation and resources for this purpose, and...

The steamship Columbia, consigned to Messrs. SPOFFORD TILESTON, arrived yesterday from NewOrleans on June 24, having made the trip in 5 days and 22 hours.
The Commercial, of this city, has a dispatch from Central Kentucky, which says:...

We have special dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to yesterday noon, which give some idea of the movements recently made, and which seem already to have resulted in great advantages for us. It appears now that the rebel cavalry force which made the recent raid on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad...

I fear that no map which you either have access to or can publish will enable you to fix the point at which headquarters are now established, and which I have localized at best I can in the heading of this letter.

It is somewhat paradoxical, but strictly true, notwithstanding, that the greatest disadvantage of the war is the prosperity of the country. Everybody admits that, in the main, the industry of the North is very flourishing.

There is a political, commercial, as well as geographical, meaning in the elections just concluded in Canada, which it would be unwise to overlook. The contest is the most remarkable that has taken place since the year preceding the Canadian rebellion.

A party of Col. SHARPE'S gallant scouts, only nine in number, headed by Sergt. M.W. KLINE, dashed into Hagerstown this morning, in the very rear of the enemy, and captured ten prisoners and a large rebel mail, which was on its way from the South to LEE's army.
This important case, which involves some $300,000, was continued this day, pursuant to adjournment.

In these columns, last Saturday, we observed, that though the rebel Gen. LEE might advance with comparatively little fear of the bayonets in the hands of the raw militia suddenly called out to meet him--that though those bayonets might not be held so firmly as his own, and might give back as he advanced --this state of things could not exist long.

The order of Gov. SEYMOUR to have thirty regiments of militia immediately organized in New-York and Brooklyn is so much in accordance with the lessons of the hour and the wishes of the people, that no delay will occur in its execution. The regiments are to be drilled in artillery as well as infantry practice. They will be prepared to man the forts or meet an enemy in the field, as emergency may require.

The freedom for Missouri ordinance has passed by 51 to 30. Slavery is to be abolished in 1870. Those then over 40 are to be servants during life; those under 12 till they are 23; those over 12 until the 4th of July, 1876.
The Emancipation ordinance passed through the Missouri State Convention yesterday. Slavery is to be abolished in 1870.
The announcement, which appeared in the columns of the TIMES yesterday, that Gov. SEYMOUR had ordered Inspector-General MILLER to come to NewYork immediately and commence the organization...
The Union State Convention assembled in Novombega Hall, this morning. The gathering was the largest of the kind ever assembled in these parts. Quite a number of Democrats were present.
Dates from the City of Mexico from the 30th of May to the 6th of June are received. The news is of the highest importance.
We publish this morning important advices from the City of Mexico--by telegraph via San Francisco--down to the 6th of June.
A heavy engagement has been going on since 9 o'clock this A.M., between the rebel forces of LONGSTREET and HILL and the First and Eleventh corps, under Gens. REYNOLDS and MEADE.

I am just in from the front, and send by a messenger to Frederick a brief dispatch of the occurrences of yesterday and to-day. The rebel force which made the said on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad consisted of STUART'S whole force, with eight pieces of artillery. On Monday night they arrived at Westminster and interrupted the Western Maryland Railroad.
The American Telegraph Company have completed their line to the Franconia Mountains, and opened a telegraph office in this house.

Advices from Vicksburgh just received report no chance in regard to the state of affairs. On the night of the 21st, the enemy sprung a mine to blow up an angle of our works. The effort was a complete failure, and killed a number of their own men.

In the battle fought on Wednesday, near Gettysburgh, an exclusive announcement of which was made in the TIMES of yesterday morning, but a comparatively small portion of Gen. MEADE'S army appears to have been engaged. The advance of our forces passed through Gettysburgh at 10 o'clock in the morning, and a quarter of a mile west of the place, encountered LONGSTREET and HILL, who attacked Gen. We have received several communications, some of them controversial, and others laudatory, in regard to the projected railroad to the Pacific. ACCIDENT TO MRS. LINCOLN. Mrs. LINCOLN met with an accident this forenoon. Her horses took fright and ran away as she was riding from the Soldier's Home to the city. Seeing her imminent danger she leaped from the carriage, and was stunned and severely bruised, but no bones were broken. Surgeons from Mount Pleasant Hospital were promptly in attendance. She soon recovered sufficiently to be taken to the White House.

--It appears that a num ber of Northern newspapers, declared contraband in Kansas and the Indian Territory, were seized, and burned in the streets of Leavenworth, a few days ago, and that a kind of "war dance" was performed by enthusiastic patriots around the bonfire. July first, eighteen hundred sixty-three, is a date destined to be forever memorable inAmerican history. It will figure as the starting point of State emancipation. The Constitutional Convention of Missouri on that day adopted an ordinance providing for the complete extinction of Slavery in that State. No act of the kind has been done since the formation of the Federal Constitution, save in a single instance; and that was on so small...

Military movements of the most important character are now is progress hers. Indeed they have proceeded so far, that's a mere announcement of them, unaccompanied by details, cannot possibly be construed as injurious to the interests of the Government.

The people of New-York and the country generally, as well as the Government at Washington, were in hourly expectation of the news of a battle in Southern Pennsvlvania yesterday, when they learned by the special and exclusive dispatch from Gettysburgh to the NEW-YORK TIMES that one had actually been fought on Wednesday at that place. The dispatch was brief, but up to 2 o'clock this morning no material facts had been added to it.

Up to yesterday skirmishing has been going on along the whole line of our rear front, or rather that portion of it from Snyder's Bluff to the Big Black Railroad crossing. There being every indication of a fight immineat, the rear front was put in order to resist an assault.
I shall send you soon an account from the battleseld near Gettysburgh of yesterday's battle, which is very favorable.

Maj.-Gen. Halleck, General-in-Chief: I telegraphed you on Sunday the occupation of Shelbyville and Manchester.

-That class of people whose calling imposes more distress on families, more burdens on society, and more expense on Governments than any other class known to our civilization, is always foremost and most notorious in its resistance to the very laws under which its license to do wrong is countenanced and protected. We can mean no other class, of course, than the more degraded liquordealers of this City.
Last evening an express arrived from Eagle Pass to a sentleman in this city, with the following important intelligence. I can vouch for its being perfectly reliable:

The Board of Aidermen, yesterday, by a strict party vote, concurred in the resolutions from the Councilmen, lauding Gen. McCLELLAN, and requesting the Administration to place him in the position demanded by the crisis of the country. The twelve Democrats present voted affirma tively, and the two Republican of the Board-- Measrs. HALL and OTTIWELL--voted in the negative. Is it permissible to write on any other subject than the war?--just now--before Vicksburgh falls, or LEE'S Army retreats discomfited, (as it will do.) Perhaps I may say a word, which is at least suggestive. In my remarks on West Point, and on the National Academy of Sciences, I suggested some things which were doubtless considered heresy, but which will be the orthodoxy of another generation.

The War Depart ment has sanctioned the issuing of medals and chevrons to the veterans who may rejoin the service after their regular period of enlistment has expired. Public virtue will not suffer by conspicuously distinguishing the men who have nobly offered their lives to maintain it. In every European army the gallantry of regiments, and even of individuals, is thus commemorated. The French soldier would rather part with his life than...

The Morning Star, Capt. A.D. PERKINS, left New-Orleans on the 27th June, at 8:10 A.M., and arrived at her wharf at 5 P.M. yesterday, making the run in 6 days and 9 hours. The Morning Star brings a full freight of sugar and cotton, $170,000 American Gold, and 230 passengers.
Rumors from Fortress Monroe, by the Old Point boat, have given rise to the serious impression that Richmond has been closely invested by Gen. Dix, and is, probably, captured.

I herewith send you a list of nearly 900 of the heroic men who have volunteered to lead the "forlorn hope" in the grand forthcoming assault upon Port Hudson; the remainder I had not been able to obtain up to the moment of closing the mail, but will send you by the very first opportunity.

The Special Committee to whom was referred the annexed resolution directing them "to examine and report at as early a day as practicable, all the information they may be enabled to obtain, touching the administration of the Street Department, during the pendency of the controversy for the control of the office by Messrs. Devlin and Conover," , respectfully.

The intelligent readers of the elaborate expositions we have been enabled to give, in the TIMES correspondence from Gen. ROSECRANS' headquarters, of the military situation is Middle Tennessee, remember that no very valuable results were predicted from the advance that Gen. ROSECRANS has just made Gen. ROSECRANS himself doubted the policy of an advance, and for causes that his march so far appears to have verified.
Gov. Seymour is expected to arrive in the City, this morning, apartments en suite, having been engaged at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
Early this morning the battle was renewed with increased vigor, and throughout this day has proved the most fearful of all the war.

The Committee appointed by the Common Council of Portsmouth, Va., to investigate the matter of the issue of $50,000 in city scrip by the rebel City Government previous to the evacuation of the city by the rebels, have passed the following resolutions:

Our special telegrams this morning give a clear understanding of the momentous events which have taken place at Gettysburgh, Penn., within the past three days. The reports which have previously reached us have been incorrect in essential particulars--especially in regard to the battle of Wednesday. On that day the action was brought on by Gen. REYNOLDS, simply because he thought himself in superior force to that of the enemy.

The Eighty-seventh Anniversary of our National Independence takes place to-day. Notwithstanding the war, and the anxiety that all loyal men feel for the triumph of our arms, arrangements for a fitting celebration of our Natal day have not been forgotten. At noon the Veterans of 1812 will raise the National Standard on the Battery, and fire a salute; at sunrise a National salute of 34 guns will be discharged. At 8 o'clock A.M.,
Steamship Morning Star, Perkins, New-Orleans, June 27, at 10 A.M., making the passage in six days and nine hours.
The Second Kentucky cavalry in the advance of Gen. BRANNAN'S division and the Thirty-ninth Indiana mounted infantry, in the advance of Gen. MENBAR'S division entered Tullahoma at noon to-day.

The President, to-day, received a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated June 27. He says he learns that JOHNSTON would be reinforced by ten thousand men early this week. He thought we would have Vicksburgh ere that time, but if not, he could take care of both PEMDERTON and JOHNSTON.

At seven o'clock this morning, JOHN MORGAN, with 4,000 cavalry, attacked the Twentieth Kentucky infantry, 400 strong, under Col. HANSON, at Lebanon. After a seven hours fight MORGAN'S forces commenced burning the town, setting fire to the railroad depot and six or seven houres. Col. HANSON'S forces surrendered, and MORGAN'S forces left in the direction of Springfield. There were six or seven killed on each side, and several wounded.

LOUIS NAPOLEON seems quite inclined to try his hand again at intervention in our affairs. The news this morning announces that he has invited England to join him, and intimates that if he cannot set England, he will be content with Spain. There has been four days' fighting near Gettysburgh, commencing on Wednesday July 1, and ending on Saturday night, July 4. It is reported here that A.P. HILL, EARLY and RODES fought the enemy principally on Wednesday, beginning at 1 o'clock and lasting two hours. We drove the enemy through Gettysburgh and two and a half miles beyond. At Gettysburgh we captured their wounded--3,500 in number.

Our dispatches from headquarters of the Army of the Potomac state that there was no fighting on Saturday beyond a few unimportant skirmishes, but that our forces were in a position to advance and give battle when the proper time should arrive. Yesterday morning the position of affairs appeared to be mainly unchanged, though a report reached Boonsboro that the rebels were retreating toward Hancock.

Gov. SEYMOUR arrived in this City yesterday morning, and at 12 o'clock addressed a large crowd of men and boys, numbering 800 or over, from the steps of the City Hall. On taking the stand he was greeted with vehement and prolonged cheers. He said he had come from his quiet home to this scene of excitement to do what he could to preserve the public peace.

Laura Gildersleeve vs. The Board of Education of the City of New-York.--DAILY, F.J.--The certificate given by the City Superintendent to the plaintiff was to the form prescribed by the Board of Education. The City yesterday, during the daytime, was comparatively quiet. The streets were no longer under the control of the mob. No more buildings were fired--no more citizens were assassinated--no more negroes were hung--no more manufacturing establishments were stopped and their workmen turned adrift.

I have just learned by telegraph that my two last letters on the campaign in Tennessee formed part of the mail the other day captured by JOHN MORGAN on the line between Nashville and Louisville. Surgeon Gen. HAMMOND left to-day for Gettysburgh to look after the wounded there. About 5,000 Union, and 6,000 rebel wounded yet remain in the hospitals in that vicinity. They are being removed as rapidly as possible to Northern cities. Supplies of all kinds are plenty.

The only great rebel army in the whole Confederacy that now appears on the field intact and formidable is the army of Gen. LEE. It is still stationed in the vicinity of Winchester. It has not yet moved any great distance down the Shenandoah Valley, as we were led to believe it had done. It shows no purpose of making a precipitate retreat upon Richmond, as was universally believed it would do.

Yesterday, the Grammar Department of Ward School No. 33, located on West Twenty-eighth-street, favored the public with an unusually interesting entertainment in the way of a reception. As on former occasions, the rooms were crowded to repletion by the parents and friends of the pupils. The exercises consisted of singing, reading, recitation, calisthenics, , and were conducted in a very creditable manner by the Principal, Miss CLARA M. EDMONDS, and her assistants.

On Thursday, the 16th, a severe fight occurred between Gen. BLUNT and the rebel Gen. COOPER, at Elk Creek, fifty miles south of Fort Gibson, which resulted in a complete Union victory. Gen. BLUNT had twenty-four hundred men and twelve guns; COOPER five thousand, on his own ground.

This stereotyped expression "in good spirits" may be heard at any street corner, and even in any news journal of the day. It is the language both parties in this gigantic war employ, from time to time, to describe their respective feelings. It is sometimes sincerely uttered, sometimes hypocritically. It is the expression of a cheerful courage, it is also the deceitful language in which some disguise their anxieties.

England is likely to have enough of her "excellent ally," France. Amiable John Bull is led into every imaginable quarrel by his restless, scheming neighbor, and must either fight and increase taxes to advance "French glory," or back out and lose prestige as a great power.

The draft has hit the typos hard. The Government office "Swamp" catches it to the extent of forty-two names. Out of a club of thirty made up at that office to raise an exemption, fund, fifteen were drawn, and the fund is of course a drop in the bucket to meet the requirement.

The repulse at Fort Wagner, so nearly a succees, will be long remembered for its gallantry and its loss of valuable life. Three young men fell on those bloody ramparts, who had recently walked our streets full of vigor and promise each of them worthy to assert his preeminence even in South Carolina, where pride is a monomania and treason an inheritance.

The following letter from Rev. F.S. RISING, one of our New-Yorkers, now on the Pacific coast, has such a silvery ring of liberality, patriotism and piety, that we take pleasure in laying it before our readers:
Capt. Fitzhugh Birney, Assistant Adjutant-General First Division:

We are officially informed that the order for the draft has been received at the Provost-Marshal's office, and the drawing of the names will commence at 10 o'clock Wednesday morning, in the Court-housesquare, in the rear of the Court-house. The drawing will be suspended on Thursday, on account of the National Thanksgiving, but will be resumed on Friday morning and continued until completed for the entire district.

In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the case of JAMES H. WHITTEN, alias Whitter, indicated for leading the riot against the Tribune office, was brought on for trial,and occupied the entire day. The jury retired at 5 P.M., and at 8 returned with a verdict of "guilty." The jurors were discharged for the term.

ARREST OF A DEAD MAN; THE DEAD AND LIVING. Ex-policeman CUSICK, a fellow some time since turned out of the force, was arrested and lodged in Headquarters yesterday on charge of riot, arson, It is alleged also that he was one of the dastardly assailants of Superintendent KENNEDY. After the riots he was dead and buried killed by the Police.

The match between these Clubs was resumed yesterday morning at Hoboken, and terminated about sunset in favor of St. George, by a majority of seventy-five runs; the total score standing; St. George, first innings, 124; second innings, 122. Boston, first innings, 104; second innings, 67.

I hear that it is the intention of those interested in the Peterhoff to carry the case up to a higher Court. THE ONE MILLION DOLLAR CONSCRIPTION LOAN. The Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council, appointed to make arrangements for the loan of one million of dollars, to be applied to the paying of exemption for men of large families who should be drafted, held a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday morning for the purpose of receiving the replies of the Brooklyn Banks in relation to the loan.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
The following letter has been issued by the "Merchants' Relief Committee for Suffering Colored People:"

To His Excellency Horatio Seymour, Governor of the State of New York: SIR: In accordance with your directions I have made the most thorough examination practicable, into the manner in which the draft of conscripts, under the act passed at the last session of Congress, has been apportioned. For that purpose, I proceeded to Washington, and conferred upon the subject with the President, and also with the Provost-MarshalGeneral.

The United States revenue transport steamer Flora, Commander W.A. BOOTH, arrived here last evening from Charleston. She reports that she left Port Royal on Friday, the 7th, and passed by Charleston at 11 o'clock that evening, when heavy and rapid firing was heard. The bombarding was between Fort Sumter and Morris Island, and the sky was brilliantly illuminated by the shells.

Some coal oil in cars on the side tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company at West Philadelphia, took fire this morning about 4 o'clock, destroying a number of cars loaded with coal oil, and damaging some others loaded with coal and other freight.

GOV. SEYMOUR, in his correspondence with the President, accuses him of having made an unfair enrollment in this State a partisan enrollment. He gives as a ground for this accusation the fact that in the Countries of New-York and Kings more men are enrolled than in certain rural counties, in proportion to the number who voted in the election last Fall.

The present condition of military operations, more especially in the West, are bringing into peculiar prominence an arm of the service which may almost be called the creation of this war namely, "mounted infantry." It is, as the name indicates, a hermaphrodite organization, combining certain peculiarities of the cavalry arm with certain peculiarities of the infantry arm.

The State is full of rumors of a contemplated rising of the Secessionists, consequently there is an uneasy feeling in the public mind. On the 6th an affray occurred at Visalia, a small town in Tillare County, between the Secessionists and the soldiers stationed there. One of the latter was killed.

PROBABLE MURDER. Yesterday noon a colored man named SAMUEL JOHNSON, was arrested in Brooklyn, E.D., charged with killing an old man named SAMUEL BRAEUER, residing at No. 7 Marshall street. It appears that in a difficulty the old man was knocked down and fell, striking his head heavily, and died shortly afterward. The Coroner will investigate the case to-day.

We arrived off here yesterday, and found naval vessels of every kind, size and description, and army and navy transports by the dozens anchored down the coast as far as the eye can reach. The time approaches when it must be determined whether diplomacy or the sword is to solve the Polish problem. The defiant tone of the Russian dispatches would seem to indicate that the Czar had chosen war rather than concession. But when those dispatches were written, the impression at St. Petersburgh was that Austria could be seduced from the coalition, and that, without her, the Western Powers would not venture to have recourse to arms.

The im mense number of deaths from sun-stroke during the last four weeks may be accounted for in part, not only by the great heat of the sun, but by the extraordinary prevalence of southeast winds. These winds come directly off the Gulf stream, heavily laden with moisture, which induces so damp and heavy a condition of the atmosphere, that it prevents or retards the natural perspiration of the body.
We have been permitted to copy letter received by a gentleman of this city from a son who was on board of the steamer Ruth, which was burned a few days since on the Mississippi River:

Almost the only item of war news we have this morning comes from Missouri. Col. CATHERWOOD, commanding a Misouri regiment of artillery, telegraphs to headquarters at St. LOUIS, from Pineville, McDonald County, that he was attacked by the rebel Col. COFFEE yesterday, and that the rebels were severely handled. COFFEE'S force was completely routed, with the loss of thirty or forty killed and a number wounded. The rebels were completely scattered.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. CHRISTIE, the late English Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to this Court, who quarreled with the Internuacio of the Pope, the Russian, Prussian, Austrian, Portagueae, Spanish, Belgian and Montevidean Ministers before Gen. WEBS came here, and subsequently with him, when he found himself more roughly used than he anticipated, is no longer here.

DEAR FRIEND: The boys have probably written you concerning our trip down here, and of the battle of the 17h. I have been pressed with official business, besides being sick. This is the lesson I have not written before, My health is quite good again now, although the "fat boy" has lost about thirty pounds since leaving Fort Scott.

The iron-clad Miantonomah was launched from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday. This is the first iron-clad built in this country by the Government. Our naval reporter gives some interesting facts concerning her character, size and armament. The fact is recalled that at the time the iron-clad mania took possession of the country, the stocks of our Navy-yards were all occupied with wooden vessels-of-war. Armored ships were wanted...

The next biennial examination of army invalid pensioners, required by an act of Congress approved March 3, 1859, will take place on and after the 4th day of September, 1863, and must precede the payment of pensions then falling due. No certificate of such examination bearing date prior to the 4th proxiing will have any validity.

This is a point so vitally important to the future of our country that it cannot be too often referred to in the columns of so important a paper as the TIMES.

By the steamship Hibernian which passed Cape Race on Friday evening, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Greencastle on the 7th inst. The politcal news is reported of but little importance. The Liverpool Cotton market was flat and unchanged. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. Consols were quiet at 93@93 1/8 for money. The Rebel Cotton Loan had touched a point as low as 35 cent. discount.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the year 1813, O.H. PERRY, a brave, loyal sador, fought and won the battle on Lake Erie; his flagship was the Lawrence; the ship of the second in command was the Niagara, JOHN D. ELLIOTT, Cap- tain.

The principal part of the proceedings of the Teachers' National Convention consists in elaborately prepared addresses or essays upon various subjects connected with the general one of education. It is impracticable to attempt anything like a thorough synopsis that will come into the space you may have left in the well-filled columns of the TIMES. All that can be well-attempted, therefore, is a meagre outline, sufficient to give can idea of what is going on.

The Police of the Thirteenth Precinct, under Capt. STEERS, are deserving of much credit for having effected a very important arrest. If all that has been stated under oath be true, the prisoner whom they have just taken into custody was one of the most determined and influential, and consequently one of the most dangerous leaders of the mob that for three days ravaged this City.

The match which was commenced at Hoboken on Thursday, between the first eleven of the NewYork Club and a Massachusetts eleven, ended yesterday in the defeat of the latter by 100 runs. The NewYork eleven included two professionals; and they met with a loss in the fact that CROSSLET, their other professional and ground-keeper--who was to have played in this match--was sick, or otherwise the Massachusetts cricketers might have met with a much severer defeat.

During the past week the Board of Enrollment have had before them 476 cases, and of this number 296 have been exempted; 161 offered substitutes, which were accepted; of the original drafted men 1 were accepted, and 6 paid the $300 commutation. Thus out of 476 drafted men 180 soldiers have beean obtained.

After careful and particular inquiry, it cannot be ascertained that any prominent parties in the South have made any formal proposition to the United States authorities for terms of peace. Nor has even a hint for an accommodation been suggested. The vigorous prosecution of the war is regarded by the Administration as the best mode of ending it.

In the Democratic State Convention of Maine, held in Portland last week for the nomination of State officers, the question was asked whether Hon. BION BRADBURY, the candidate for Governor, "would, as he would have a right to do, withdraw the troops now in the field?" To this Gen. S.J. ANDERSON, his special friend, replied: "When Gov. SEYMOUR withdraws the New-York troops, then I pledge you that BION BRADBURY will withdraw the Maine troops."

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 41 1. The construction of military roads in the State being a necessity, by the order of the Major-General commanding the Department, six thousand laborers from the negro population of the country through which the roads pass will be impressed.

The Third colored regiment, under command of Col. C.B. TILGHMAN, numbering one thousand men, who have for some time past been encamped at Camp William Penn, Chelton Hills, about eight miles from Philadelphia, on the line of the North Pennsylvania Railroad, took their departure for Charleston yesterday morning. The regiment left campt at halfpast seven o'clock, and taking the cars of the North Pennsylvania Railroad, arrived at America and Master streets about nine o'clock.

The ordinance of the City Government, appropriating three millions of dollars to relieve citizens of New-York from the draft, has been so perfected as to free it from many of the objections that lay against it in the first case. As it now stands, it need not become very oppressive to the City treasury, nor at all embarrassing to the Government.

Sergt. CHARLES G. FRAZER, of the Second Delaware regiment, a paroled prisoner, just from Richmond, called in yesterday, and gave us the cutjoined statement with regard to general affairs at Richmond, and what he saw while en route there. The Second Delaware was attached to HANCOCK'S corps at the battle of Gettysburgh, and Mr. FRAZER was captured on the second day of the light, together with about two hundred others, belonging to various other regiments.
The following letter from Capt. SAWYER to Mr. JOSEPH S. LEACH has been furnished for publication:

There has been a very large assemblage of Christian patriots here to-day, at a Convention of the Christian Commission, which crowded the Baptist Church in this place morning and evening. President HOPKINS, of Williams College presided. After the reading of the Scriptures and prayer, Rev. GEO. J. MISGINS, a delegate of the Commission, made a most earnest and eloquent address. Some of the incidents which he related drew tears from unaccustomed eyes.

Gov. SEYMOUR has issued a Proclamation, which will probably be issued to-day, warning all persons against any disorderly conduct during the progress of the draft in this City and Brooklyn, which will commence to-morrow.

The Inman steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at noon on the 5th, and Queenstown on the 6th inst., arrived here last evening. The advices are not so late as those by the Hibernian, which passed Cape Race on Friday, but her mails are four days later than before received.

The State of Minnesota, feeling aggrieved by the Government's slow and humanitarian mode of conducting war against the hostile Indians within her borders, has lately adopted some very decisive but questionable measures of her own for getting rid of the "red devils." A proclamation appeared offering a State bounty for every "scalp" of a Sioux that should be brought in by volunteer and amateur hunters.

The final honors to the remains of the lamented MORRIS, whose death and services have been announced in the TIMES, were paid yesterday morning by a large concourse of relatives and friends. The Commodore died at the house of his nephew, No. 155 East Twelfth-street, at which place the preliminary services were held at an early hour in the morning.
The Fourth Massachusetts and the Twenty-eighth Maine regiments arrived here on Sunday, and left immediately for home.

A few days ago we had some shocking news by telegraph from California concerning a secession rebellion there, which some of our cotemporaries worked up into a first-class sensation. But we observed on a close reading of the dispatch that it consisted of a "rumor of a contemplated uprising of secessionists," and that "it was discredited." Sensible people could not be expected to go into spasms over a rumor, a discredited rumor, of the belligerent...
The steamer Kennebec, Capt. GARTON, arrived this morning from Newbern, N.C., with about 100 passengers, among whom was Col. BIGGS, Chief Quartermaster of this Department.

RECOVERED. Yesterday morning Coroner BARRETT held an inquest on the body of a boy named CHRISTOPHER MCELLIGOT, five years old, who was drowned some days since at the foot of North-secondstreet, E.D. The body was recovered yesterday in the dock at North Fourth-street, E.D. When the lad was drowned fifteen persons stood by without attempting a rescue.

A conscript just from Wilmington, N.C., reports that within the past few days seventeen large steamers have arrived at that port, having run the blockade, loaded with stores for the rebel army, among which are 96,000 English rifles, 160,000 army blankets, 131,000 ready-made uniforms, 23,000 cases of ready-made army shoes, 11 locomotives, 6 rifle cannon, heavy calibre, five cargoes of railroad iron and skillful men accompanying them.

The business at the Coroners' Office, during the last month, has been greater than at any time for many years past; indeed, we may safely say, greater than for any one month since the last cholera season. These officials have been constantly busy every day in the week, all through this hot term, and the duties of their clerk and deputies have been correspondingly arduous.
The steamer S.R. Spaulding arrived this morning from off Charleston.
The body of Col. CORNYN reached this city yesterday. His funeral takes place this afternoon, with appropriate military honors.

The draft will recommence to-morrow, and will go straight on to its termination without the slightest trouble. Chicanery in high places has been exhausted, and the riotous spirit in low has been cowed. Law again assumes its rightful sway, and faction hides its head.

Accounts come, via Los Angelos, of the discovery of a very rich and extensive gold mining region in the San Francisco mountains, lying east of the Colorado River. The La Pas and other recently formed mining companies on the Colorado have been deserted for new mines. The latter are described as a New California.
The Paris Patrie, in an article on the objections raised by England to the principle of an identical note to Russia, says:

The administra tion of the Conscription law in other States has brought to light many of the deceits and frauds by which it is sought to be evaded, and the officers of the Government should benefit by the knowledge thus gained. It is an unpleasant thing to acknowledge, but, nevertheless, it is true that perjury is not unfrequently committed, not only in regard to the residence.

A dispatch was received this morning by the Government, dated the 17th inst., from a distinguished military officer in Tennessee, stating that the Chattanooga Rebel, of the 16th inst., announced that the bombardment of Charleston on Saturday, the l5th inst., was awful, and that the firing from GILLMORE'S land batteries on Morris Island, and from the Monitors, was chiefly directed against Fort Sumter.

Gov. SEYMOUR'S Proclamation regarding the draft, alluded to yesterday, is published this morning. The Governor still clings to the idea that the constitutionality of the draft should have been tested before putting it in force, but is explicit enough in warning his "friends" against any riotous opposition to it. The draft will certainly commence this forenoon at 10 o'clock, as previously announced.

Every Northern man ought to read the article from the Raleigh Standard, which we published yesterday. The session of the Union State Convention commenced yesterday forenoon at 11 o'clock. Judge Low, Chairman of the State Committee, called the Convention to order. There being some differences of opinion among the delegates as to the proper mode of organization, the Convention took a recess until 2 o'clock P.M., with a view to more harmonious action. Upon reassembling, WARD HUNT, of Oneida County, was chosen temporary Chairman.

Hon. James C. Conkling: MY DEAR SIR: Your letter inviting me to attend a mass meeting of unconditional Union men, to be held at the Capital of Illinois on the 3d of September, has been received. It would be very agreeable to me thus to meet my old friends at my own home, but I cannot just now be absent from this city so long as a visit there would require.
The Mass Convention of Loyal Young Men, met at Wieting Hall, at 11 o'clock this morning. The body of the Hall and the galleries were well filled.

The Union State Convention at Syracuse, which closed its labors on Wednesday night, was followed yesterday by a Mass Convention of Loyal Young Men, which met at Wieting Hall at 11 o'clock in the forenoon. ELLIOT F. SHEPARD, of New-York, was selected as presiding officer. President LINCOLN'S letter was read, and received the most enthusiastic indorsement of the Convention.

It is believed, on the contrary, that he is waiting the result of the operations of Gens. ROSECRANS, BURNSIDE and GILLMORE, and that, should they be successful, LEE will exert his influence in favor of peace.

We have important news this morning from East Tennessee. Kingston was captured by Gen. BURNSIDE on the 2d inst., our forces meeting with little serious opposition. Part of a brigade from Gen. ROSECRANS' army entered the place simultaneously with Gen. BURNSIDE'S troops. The dispatch which brings us this information also announces that all East Tennessee, with the exception of the Chattanooga region, has been evacuated by the rebels, and is now free!

It was there that barbarism made its most determined stand, and the terrible scars of the conflict long remained indelibly impressed upon the hearts and souls of her people.

BRUTAL TREATMENT OF A SERVANT GIRL. A notice was received yesterday, at the Coroners' office, requesting that an ante-mortem examination be made in the case of a German girl named GERTRUDE WEBER, who according to the testimony of her physicians, was lying at the point of death at house No. 130 Seventh-street. The President's letter to the Springfield Convention receives the unqualified admiration of loyal men throughout the breadth of the land. Various as have been their sentiments on some of its topics, it is yet their universal testimony that nothing could have been more true or more apt. Its bard sense, its sharp outlines, its noble temper, defy malice. Even the Copperhead gnaws upon it as vainly as did the viper upon the file.

Appreciating the great growth of the population of Brooklyn, and the evident demand for a nightly dramatic entertainment, an enterprising citizen of that unique place of habitation, has erected quietly and unostentatiously, in one of its most frequented thoroughfares, a beautiful; theatre. It faces on Fultonstreet, immediately opposite the City Hall, in the immediate vicinity of the new Court-house, and at the intersection of the various lines of City railway. Its location is wisely chosen.

L.L. CROUNSE sends to this Bureau the following: Cavalry skirmishes across the Rappahannock on our extreme right flank, are becoming quite frequent. On Friday a scouting party of the Sixth Ohio, while returning to our lines, were ambuscaded and some thirty killed, wounded and captured. Maj. PRYOR, commanding the detachment, was severely wounded, but escaped capture.

For some months past the whole country has been assured by gentlemen of the "Peace party" that President LINCOLN had declined a proposition from leaders of the Southern Confederacy, which looked toward and would have insured a restoration of the Union.

Yesterday Commodore JOSEPH SMITH, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, arrived in this City from the National Capital, on his annual tour of inspection of the Navy-yards. He was received at the Brooklyn yard by Admiral PAULDING, and after staying some time at the quarters of that officer he pro ceeded to the different departments, which he examined critically.

Hon. Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States DEAR SIR: On the 25th of November last I was advised by an authority, which I deemed likely to be well informed as well as reliable and truthful, that the Southern States would send representatives to the next Congress, provided that a full and general amnesty should permit them to do so.

The Chilian bark Caspar, of Valparaiso, BAIN, master, from Pisaqua, (Peru,) for New-York, foundered at sea, in lat. 36 20', len. 71 40', on the morning of 29th August. She was 362 tons burden, and had a cargo of 300 tons (nitre of soda) saltpetre, consigned to GEORGE B. HOBSON, of New-York. She had experienced some heavy weather off Cape Horn, but had not received any damage.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.

Substantially, the only addition to the public debt since the last official statement is that which has accrued from the sale of five-twenty bonds.

Gen. BLUNT, with his army, forty-five hundred strong, including twenty pieces of artillery, crossed the Arkansas River on the 22d, and offered battle to the rebel Gens. STEELE and COOPER, who had massed on his front 11,000 men. After a faint show of resistance the army commenced a retreat, which soon turned into a disorderly flight. They abandoned all their property.

Rebel dispatches from Charleston bring us advices to the morning of the 6th inst. It is stated this after a bombardment of 52 hours a part of our forces landed on Cummings' Point and attacked Battery Gregg, but were repulsed. Dispatches from Chattanooga to the 5th inform us that no battle had been fought there up to that date.

The Democratic State Convention meets at Albany to-day. It is expected to be largely attended. It appears to be settled that Tammany and Mozart will coalesce, and that FERNANDO WOOD will wield a large influence in tempering the proceedings. Hon. AMASA J. PARKER is expected to be Permanent President.

BOLD ROBBERY. Yesterday forenoon the house of Mr. HENNION, No. 98 Coles-st., was entered and robbed of silver spoons and some jewelry. As the thief was making his exit he was discovered by Mrs. H., who gave an alarm, and the fellow was finally taken into custody by Officer McWILLIAMS, and the property being on his person he was committed for trial. He gave his name as CHARLES HART.

Abram Wakeman, Chairman Convention, SIR: I am in the receipt of your communication of to-day, officially notifying me of my nomination by the Convention of Union men at Syracuse for the office of Attorney-General of the State. I need hardly say how much I was surprised to learn from the newspapers that such a nomination had been made.
Admiral PORTER has just arrived in the Gen. Lyon from below.

The Innman steamer City of Manchester, Capt. HALOROW, which left Liverpool at noon on the 2d inst. and Queenstown on the 3d, arrived at this port last evening. The advices are not later than those brought on Monday by the Hansa, but our files and telegrams via Queenstown furnish additional details that are interesting.

Standard published another remarkable article urging the inauguration of some steps looking toward the conclusion of a peace. It was written as a reply to some strictures made by the Fayetteville Observer. The following extracts will show the spirit of the article:

The notorious guerrilla, Capt. RUCKER, has at length been recaptured. He was, it will be remembered, confined in Gratiot-street Prison, last Winter, and effected his escape by digging out. Since his escape he has cooperated with JACKMAN in robbing and scattering terror among loyal men. It was RUCKER who captured Gen. BARTHOLOW, at his house, in the dead of night, pretending that he was a messenger from GUITAR.

When the Missouri Slaveholders began, seven years ago, the practice of making raids into an adjoining territory for the purpose of murdering and plundering everybody who happened to object to the extension of Slavery, and its introduction among them, the groans and lamentations of the Kansas people furnished a good deal of amusement to the very same men at the North who are now horror-stricken by the threats of Gen. JIM LANE.

To the Hon. Hugh L. Bond, Ballimore: SIR: Your letter of the 15th ult., addressed to the secretary of War, treats with great ability a subject of vast importance to Maryland, and it is believed to be one of vital consequence to the whole country.

There has been but little doing at Quarantine the past week. The reports received there are to the effect that yellow fever in all infected ports is losing its epidemic character, and is purely sporadic. In Havana, Matanzas, Nassau and Vera Cruz this is its character now. Not a vessel the past week has arrived with a case of lever on board, and there is not a case in the hospital.

The United States dispatch steamer Mary Sanford, Commander ROGERS, from Charleston Saturday night, 12th, with dispatches to the Department, and a mail from the flect, reached here yesterday morning. She arrived at Fortress Monroe on the afternoon of the 14th, and after communicating with the fleet at Newport's News, sailed same evening for this port.

It would appear from the Richmond Enquirer, that fraternal feeling has so far revived at the South that Southern politicians are anxious to act once more with their old allies, the Northern Democrats, at the approaching election.

The first of a series of discourses was delivered Sunday evening, on the above subject, at the Tabernacle of the Christian Allfance, by the Pastor, Rev. C.C. Goss. It was somewhat introductory, showing the importance of great cities as centres of great influences. Corinth, Antioch, Athens, Rome, Paris and London were cited as exerting a vast influence upon the surrounding region. Reforms had their origin in large cities.

SECOND DISTRICT EXEMPTIONS THE EIGHTH WARD, BROOKLYN, BEGUN, Yesterday the Board of Enrollment, in session at No. 26 Grand-street, examined 66 out of the 133 names drawn in the Eighth Ward of Brooklyn. The exemptions for non-suitable age, 27: physical disability, 21; aliens, 18; father of motherless children, 1; paid commutation, 1; only son of a widow, 1; non-resident, 1; only son of aged parents, 1.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, and concurred in overruling the Mayor's veto on the resolution granting the right of the streets for laying mains, for a period of fifty years, to the "Anthracite Gas-Lighting and Heating Company." The vote was 12 to 3, Messrs, FROMENT, MASTERSON and JEREMIAH voting in the negative.

The Unconditional Union Committee of Maryland advise the people of that State, in the address which we published Wednesday, to abolish the institution of Slavery at the earliest possible period. "The substance of Slavery," they say, "is gone, and they are of opinion that the sooner the skeleton is removed the better will it be for the true interests of the State and of the nation."

Io triumphe! The day of deliverance has dawned at last, and the chains are riven from the limbs of the noblest peope that ever breathed God's air. Free at last! Free as their own mountain air, they stand erect in all their manhood. Freed, too, without the loss of a single one of their deliverers by battle--their oppressors fled as much from the moral power of their loyalty as from the bayonets of Gen. BURNSIDE.

BEFORE JUDGE M'CUNN. In this Court, yesterday, JAMES STUART alias HANFORD, pleaded guilty to burglary in the third degree, in breaking into the dwelling of LEWIS H. BONE, No. 114 West Sixteenth-st. He was sentenced to the State Prison for four years.

We publish, this morning, an extended report of the proceedings before Judge BETTS in a habeas corpus case, with the decision of the Judge in full. It is highly important as being the first decision reported upon the effect of the recent habeas corpus Proclamation.

Our latest news from the Army of the Potomac informs us that the rebels made an attempt on Wednesday to recross the Rapidan in three columns, but were checked by our forces. The indications are, that Gen. MEADE'S passage of that river will be stubbornly contested.
A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, at which, in the absence of A.A, Low, President, Mr. WM. E. DODGE presided.

Several other charges were made, and the enemy were finally driven across the river.

On evacuating Chattanooga the enemy retired to Lafayette and massed a force at that place, taking possession of the gaps of the Pigeon Mountain directly in front of Gen. THOMAS' column. The rebel force had been made formidable by new additions from JOHNSTON, HINDMAN, BUCKNER AND MAURY.
The editor of the Star, who left Culpepper yesterday, says, in his paper of to-day:

We learn that Gen. LEE's army, or a portion of it, was in line of battle near the Rapidan yesterday, (Tuesday, the 15th,) the enemy having advanced to the Rapidan in force. There was some skirmishing between the pickets; but the enemy having suspended his forward movement, there was no serious collision between the opposing forces.
All is quiet. No attack has been made. The enemy remains in possession of the gaps of Pigeon Mountains and about Lafayette. The lines are very close, and there is occasional skirmishing.

The Charleston Mercury, of Friday, the 11th, says that the enemy has retrained from firing since his unsuccessful assault on Fort Sumter. Our batteries on James and Sullivan Islands, together with Fort Moultrie, keep up a steady fire on the Morris Island works. It adds:

A yankee Lieutenant and seventeen men were captured yesterday morning by the militia on Walker's Mountain, twelve miles from Marion, in Smythe County. They were making their way to the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, with the intention to arrive these in time to catch a train after dark. They were armed only with navy revolvers. They say there are 800 more in Abbs's Valley, in Tazewell County.

Notwithstanding the frightful ravages of war in the States of Arkansas, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana, that have been recovered from the rebellion, the injuries inflicted are not without their compensations. Houses may have been burned and slaves may have been demoralized or fully emancipated, but the soil remains unharmed, and it is still capable of yielding in undiminished quantities that staple which the world clamors for, and cannot do without.

The United States Mail steamship Columbia, D.B. BARTON, Commander, from New-Orleans, Sept. 13, with mails and passengers to SPOFFORD, TILESTON Co., and with a cargo of cotton and sugar, arrived last evening. The Columbia experienced heavy weather during the entire passage.

We are in expectation of stirring news from the Department of Gen. ROSECRANS. The combined and rapid advance of this chief and Gen. BURNSIDE evidently took Gen. BRAGG by surprise, and compelled the abandonment of Chattanooga. The evacuation of this place was not intended by the Confederates. Since the first of this year they have been at work upon it, steadily increasing its fortifications, and trying to make it impregnable.
The following interesting report by Col. MANN, of the Thirty-ninth Illinois Volunteers, of the occupation of Forts Wagner and Gregg, is published in the Western papers:

Political matters are quieting down that is, if Copperhead machinatio's come under that head. The enrollment list been completed, and only three of the officers engaged in it have been murdered. I have not learned that any of the assassins have been arrested. It was found necessary in several counties to employ military force for the protection of those engaged in the enrollment. At the same time they busied themselves in hunting up deserters.

We hope none of our readers who have taken an interest in the discussion of the authority of the State Courts over the Provost-Marshals and other officers of the United States, will fail to read the decision of Judge WHITE, of the Superior Court, in this City, in the case of the habeas corpus of MICHAEL COX.

The United States steamship McClellan, Capt. GRAY, arrived here yesterday, from Hilton Head the 15th, and Morris Island the 16th, at 10:15 A.M. She brings a mail, a number of passengers and 100 rebel prisoners taken at Fort Wagner.

GENERAL: For the information of the Generalin-Chief and the War Department, I respectfully submit the following report of the preliminaries and operations which resulted in driving the rebels out of Middle Tennessee, from the occupation of Murfreesboro, a point 212 miles from the nearest point of supplies.

By the arrival of messengers from Gen. BLUNT'S headquarters at Fort Smith, Arkansas, we have confirmation most certain of the complete evacuation of the Indian Territory by the rebel forces. This gratifying result has been gained with but trifling loss on our part, and the complete disorder of the rebels.
We have the following brief and very painful news from Gen. ROSECRANS' army. The occupation of the telegraph lines for military purposes prevents, for the present, the transmission of details:

Gen. ROSECRANS has again met the enemy, whom he fought and defeated at the opening of the year, and whom he has been pursuing for the past three months, for the purpose of fetching to the test of battle. It has been an unaccountable mystery why Gen. BRAGG should have executed such a series of retreats as he has carried his army through since it occupied Murfreesboro ...

ROSECRANS' army, under Gens. THOMAS, McCOOK, CRITTENPEN and VAN CLEVE.

On the morning of the 13th the cavalry division of Gen. KILPATRICK crossed the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford, and marched in the direction of Culpepper by Brandy Station. No rebels in force were encountered until reaching Brandy Station, where the advance, consisting at the Harris Light, or Second New-York, met them in some force. A brisk skirmish ensued, the rebels, however, immediately falling back toward Culpepper.

Our island has for the last two weeks undergone a period of unusual quietness and repose, resulting mainly from apprehension felt abroad concerning the health of the town, and more particularly as to yellow fever. Steamers pass by us both ways with no more of ceremony or notice than occasionally to stop at Sand Key and leave us a mail.

The foreign papers continue to circulate the report that our Government has issued a formal protest against the French operations in Mexico; and some of them add that this protest is couched in such direct and energetic terms that it can scarcely fail to incur the displeasure and resentment of the Emperor of the French.

In April I warned the Democracy of Connecticut of a defeat which was realized. For unavoidable reasons the Union strength of that State was then so much impaired, that the Democracy might have carried it easily. But, lacking both sense and patriotism, it adopted a "Copperhead" Platform, and was beaten.

ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Saturday, Sept. 19, 1863. Though storms raged, and battle threatened, and commotion was everywhere in the ranks of the Army of the Potomac, yet the anniversary of the great battle of Antietam did not pass entirely unheeded. A portion of this army, a portion, too, whose ranks are thinner because of that conflict, fitly celebrated the day.

The weather yesterday was all that the most ardent lover of rural pleasure and field sports could wish clear, sunny, and yet not sultry the glow of departing Summer tempered by the cool breath of advancing Autumn.

Additional particulars respecting the great battle near Chattanooga on Saturday, are given in yesterday's Cincinnati Commercial. Soon after the opening of the battle the fighting became general, and an impetuous dash of the enemy upon the well-known LOOMIS battery resulted in the capture of Capt. VAN PELT, its commanding ...

Gen. SCHOFIELD has just published a most stringent order in his Department, and it is to be hoped that he will have the nerve to execute it, and that the Administration will have the courage to suffer him to do so.

La France has intelligence from Moscow, which, if authentic, will entitle the Czar to hold the first rank among the reformers and patriots of the present century. It is to the effect that the Emperor ALEXANDER has resolved not only to give a Constitution to Poland, but even to convert the whole of his vast empire into a constitutional State.

WINTER GARDEN. The returning engagements off Mr. EDWIN BOOTH have become so acceptable a feature of the Winter season, that it is fair to say they are looked forward to by the most intellectual part of the community with the greatest possible anticipations of delight.
As was anticipated by Gen. ROSECRANS, thegreat battle which opened on Saturday forenoon, and raged till after nightfall, was reopened on Sunday morning, and continued throughout the day.

ADVANCE OF CAVALRY. A movement of the Army of the Potomac has commenced, so far as to send forward BUFORD'S cavalry across the Rapidan. The crossing was effected without opposition. It is prophesied that but a feeble force of rebels intervenes between MEADE and Richmond.

The most important feature in our European news this morning is the semi-official announcement put forth by the London Morning Post that the two rams "powerful iron-plated steam rams," as Earl RUSSELL, described them which are lying in the Mersey, all but ready to start out in Confederate service, are to be detained by the British Government, under the terms of the Foreign Enlistment act.

The Commercial of this city gives the following account of the great battle near Chattanooga on Saturday: "The battle opened at 11 o'clock in the vicinity of Widow Glens, on the road leading from McLamore's Cave to Chattanooga.

Another new fast steamer, besides that spoken of, is to be built at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Orders have been received from the Navy Department to commence as soon as convenient, and yesterday active preparations were begun to fit a place for her keel.

The Emperor NAPOLEON'S departure for Biarritz, first announced for the 7th, and then postponed till the 10th, may very possibly, it is now said, be still further delayed. Cabinet councils have been frequent since His Majesty's return from Chalons, and there seems to be a great deal going on in high places. It is not, I believe, any one great question that thus occupies the Government, but several of more or less interest.
The United States steamer Continental, Capt. MARSHMAN, from New-Orleans in six days and twelve hours, arrived at this port last evening, bringing passengers, mails, and a cargo of merchandise.
