SAMUEL. L. CROCKER, Jr., a member of the Suffolk bar, has been arrested for desertion, he having been drafted and failed to report in due form to the Board of Enrollment of the Third District.

The army of Gen. MEADE and the army of Gen. LEE are evidently engaged in some shrewd manoeuvering at the present moment. Among all the congresses held this Summer, of princes, lawyers, musicians, schoolmasters, social science men, political economists, and a hundred others, one very notable meeting has almost escaped public attention. A few days ago, our Paris correspondent told us that a congress of the members of the illustrious house of ROTHSCHILD has been sitting at Paris. The purport of the meeting was nothing less than to rearrange the dominions of the great banking dynasty.

The Prussian atmosphere is full of political rumors. It is said that the dissolution of the Diet was not the work of VON BISMARK, but the tale is that it was brought about in this way. One of the most curious and novel rural festivals ever witnessed in America, closed last Saturday at Egg Harbor City, N.J. It is a genuine German October Festival an old-fashioned Weihlese, or Wine Harvest, so called as practiced in Vaterland, and, in various forms, in all the wine-growing countries of the world since the palmy days of ancient Judea.

Military law is distinguished from municipal law in having personal extent, or in being a personal law. Laws govern persons and territory. By governing persons, law is said to have personal extent. By governing in certain territory it is said to have territorial extent. We speak of personal law and territorial law. The municipal, or civil law, extends to persons generally, within a certain territory.

They burned no railroad property at Tipton, as previously reported, but plandered the town of a large amount of money. The citizens of Warfield, Greenfield, and other towns though which the rebels passed, suffered in a like manner.

On the 26th of September Earl RUSSELL was entertained at Blairgowrie, Scotland, by a number of his friends, and made a speech of interest and importance on the foreign relations of Great Britain, and especially on her relations to the United States. By the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 30th inst., we have full files of European journals, from which we make up an interesting budget additional to that received by telegraph and published yesterday. The speech of Lord JOHN RUSSELL on American topics we present in extenso, and it will be found well worthy of attentive perusal.

The steamship Jura from Liverpool, 1st, via Londonderry, 21, passed this point this evening, en route to Quebec. The Scotia from New-York arrived at Queenstown on the 21. Peritreal news in unimportant.

A SAD FAMILY BEREAVEMENT A BROTHER AND SISTER DIE ON THE SAME DAY. Last week a sadly thrilling event took place in the family of one who was, while living, a citizen of the highest respectability and worth, Mr. PETER McLOUGHLIN.
The Tribune closes an article on the contest going on in Missouri and Maryland between the friends of immediate and gradual emancipation, with the following:

Early on Saturday a brigade of cavalry belonging to KILPATRICK'S division, attempted a reconnoissance on the south side of Robertson's River. They were attacked by a large force of rebel cavalry, amply supported by infantry and artillery, under command of STUART in person. The infantry force was one of EWELL'S divisions, and numbered about 8,000 men.

The specific issue of the approaching election in this State is the merit or demerit of Gov. SEYMOUR'S official conduct. All personal considerations respecting the candidates vanish before this one supreme concern.
The United States steamer Circassian, from Pensacola, Key West and Charleston Bar, has arrived here. She reports there was to be a combined army and naval attack at Charleston on the 11th inst.

DE TOCQUEVILLE was the first to call attention to the enormous gain to humanity that would result from the success of the political experiment which we were making on this continent, from the single fact that it would accustom great and powerful communities to submit their differences to judicial arbitrament, and would make it a point of honor with them to abide by legal precedents, instead of resorting to the sword.

The steamer Albert Pearce, from New-Orleans with a large cargo of sugar and molasses, has arrived.
The steamship Continental, Capt. MARTHMAN, from Charleston Bar Oct. 9, arrived yesterday. Our correspondent sends us the following important dispatch:

Though there was nothing definite as to the result of the elections yesterday in Ohio and Pennsylvania up to the time of our going to press, yet the indications promised a success for the Union candidates. The returns from Pennsylvania almost all show slight Republican gains over the vote of last year, and in Ohio, so far as heard from, the gains are still more marked.

The arrival of the steamship Africa at St. Johns, N.F., from Liverpool on the 3d inst., puts as in possession of two days later news from Europe. The English Press comments freely on the recent great battles in Georgia, those which are ever willing to hail disaster to the Union arms regarding them as great victories for the rebels.

MUSICAL At the Academy of Music, "lone, or the last days of Pompeil" will be given this evening with the original cast, including MEDORI, SULZER, MAZZOLENI, BELLINI, BIACHI, and others. This opera was the great success of last season, and will undoubtedly draw an immense audience.

The County Convention of the McKeon Democracy met last evening at their rooms in the St. Clair Hotel, corner Broadway and Eight-street, for the purpose of making County nominations. Dr. WILLIAM MURPHY, of the Seventeenth Ward, was called to the Chair and made permanent Chairman of the organization. GEORGE WHITE, of the Ninth Ward, and HENRY ROOME, of the Twelfth Ward, were elected permanent Secretaries.
The election passed off quietly throughout the State. A very large vote has been polled. The following returns have been received:

The correspondent of the American writes from Charleston Harbor as follows:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The fine attendance yesterday evening, when PETRELLA'S Opera of "Ione" was given, recalled the best triumphs of last season. The house was fashionable and brilliant beyond the ordinary experience of the past week, and the quaint rhythms and vigorous instrumentation of the composer brought down, as of old, plenty of applause.

H.J. Raymond, Esq.: The Copperheads, with marked pertinacity, profess still to claim the victory, but CURTIN is certainly elected by a satisfactory majority, more likely, in the judgment of those here best informed, to be above than below twenty thousand. It may possibly be less, though the returns show large Union gains in nearly all the Union counties. PULESTON.

A NEW DODGE. Last week a man entered the cigar-store of Mr. COOK, on Broadway, while that gentleman had gone to dinner. He made inquiry of the lad in charge for Mr. COOK, and especially whether that was his usual hour for dinner, having, as he with apparent impatience said, called the day before, and not found him in.

The latest accounts of SHELBY'S raiders say that they divided eight miles southwest of Arrow Rock yesterday morning. About 2,500 Federals were in pursuit, and had killed twelve rebels and lost four men.

Forces of rebel cavalry and artillery, reported at from 8,000 to 15,000 strong, have been threatening the Memphis and Charleston Railroad for some days. Gen. HURLDURT'S force has been constantly skirmishing with them, defeating every attempt to do serious damage. RUGGLES, CHALMERS and LEE, are said to be in command under JOE JOHNSON.

We have news from Viginia this morning which is startling, if true. It is reported that Gen. MEADE'S Army after crossing the Rappahannock, has fallen back as far as Manassas Plains that the Army of LEE has also crossed the Rappahannock that our army was stripping for the fight that a battle was imminent, and Washington rumor even adds that the struggle opened at daylight yesterday on the old Bull Run battle-ground.

Hon. SALMON P. CHASE, Secretary of the Treasury, arrived at Cincinatti on Monday last, on a brief vacation visit, and was welcomed most enthusiastically by an immense crowd of citizens, who greeted him at the railroad depot with salvos of artillery and a grand military and civic procession.

It was difficult to tell the precise import of the heavy cavalry skirmishing which has been going on since Saturday last in the space between the Rapidan and Rappahannock rivers. The fact, however, that Gen. MEADE thought fit to march the whole of his army to this side of the Rappahannock on Sunday, indicated that he considered himself menaced by something of far greater magnitude than STUART'S cavalry.

The United States transport Fah-Kee, from Charleston the 10th inst., arrived here this morning. She had in tow the gunboat Madgie for repairs, which sunk off Frying Pan Shoals on Sunday last. All her men were saved.

The Committees of Conference appointed by Tammany and Mozart, for the purpose of effecting an organization between the parties, met last evening at Tammany Hall, to heal their allenations. The Committees consisted of one of each party from each Ward.

There is no longer room for doubting, notwithstanding the incompleteness of the returns, that the elections held in Pennsylvania and Ohio last Tuesday have resulted in the success of the Union ticket by immense majorities. The probability is that Gov. CURTIN in Pennsylvania has beaten WOODWARD by from 20,000 to 25,000 votes, as the returns thus far exhibit a steady gain over the vote of 1860.

ARRAIGNMENT OF PRISONERS. D. Hall and Edward Seymour, pickpockets, not guilty; Elizabeth McKean, grand larceny, guilty...

The Union men hold a meeting, one of the regular weekly series, this evening at Cooper Institute. Senator WILSON OF Massachusetts, Hon. D.S. DICKINSON of Albany, and some local speakers, are expected to make addresses.
The Board of Aldermen failed of a quorum at their meeting yesterday, and adjourned to Monday. Afterward a call was signed for a special meeting at 1 o'clock P.M. to-day.

The semi-occasional sessions of the Court of Oyer and Terminer in this City, is an annoyance which ought to be abated. They not only do not facilitate but they actually obstruct the dispatch of criminal business. Take the present term for example.
The full height, breadth and depth of the delusions under which the South commenced this war will probably only be fully revealed alter most of the actors in it have been gathered to their fathers.

Wednesday morning, at 9 o'clock the ironclad Manhattan was launched at the yard of Mr. SECOR, in Jersey City. Over 6,000 persons were present, amougst whom we noticed Rear Admiral FARRAGUT. Admiral GREGORY, Chief Engineer STIMERS.

By the regular British mail steamer from South American ports, we have dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chili to Sept. 17, and from Cattac, and Lima to 29th same month. The Lima Coxarcio, of Sept. 29, has the following:

JAMES DALE OWEN, son of the eminent geologist, DAVID DALE OWEN, late professor in the geological department of the Smithsonian Institute, and an old friend of Mr. ADAMS.

Hon. DAN. H. COLE, of Albion, has been nominated for Senator in the Genesee, Niagara and Orleans District. He is a man of ability, of excellent character, and of great personal popularity. He has filled many important local offices, being elected always by large majorities. He was Member of Assembly in 1855.

"Profound indignation" is the sentiment entertained among all classes in Chile, at the action of the French Government in forcing a monarchy upon Mexico. A discussion on the subject had taken place in Congress, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs was requested to exprees himself as to whether Chile ought to recognize such a Government.

Brig.-Gen. J.M. Lee, Missouri; Dr. O. Macomcomber, New-York; Col. Samuel Bell, San Francisco; Col. W. Owen, U.S.A.; Capt. W.C. Burgess, Jas. Hammersly and Aftred Roberts, Philadelphia, are at the Metropolitan Hotel.

Yesterday morning, Admiral LISOVSKY, with a portion of the officers of his fleet, visited the public institutions, in pursuance of an invitation from the Commissioners of Public Charities and Corrections. The party was not large, most of the officers of the fleet being debarred by other engagements. The tour of inspection was pretty much the same as that made with the French and English officers on Tuesday, and afforded to the guests much interest.

At the meeting of the Board of Alderman yesterday, the Railroad Committee reported in favor of concurring to repeal the Broadway Railroad grant to the Harlem Company. The report was laid over. Resolutions of respect to the memory of Col. A.H.Y. ELLIS, of the One Hundred and Twenty-fourth regiment N.Y.V., who fell at Gettysburgh, were adopted. A resolution to increase the fire bell-ringers salaries to $1,000 per annum was tabled.

A report has been made to the Board of Commissioners of Health by WILLIAM H. ARMSTRONG, Esq., the Clerk of such Board, which sets forth concisely and clearly the powers of the Board as to nuisances and the authorities therefor. It is a compilation which has long been needed, and bears the evidence of a latorious, thorough and intelligent examination. Heretofore the Board of Health and the Commissioners have been groping in the dark.

An exciting rumor that a corps of the rebel army, (supposed to be A.P. HILL'S) had moved from our front in the direction of Leesburgh, was circulated in Wahington Thursday night. An advance in that direction might mean another invasion of Pennsylvania, and a heavy force was immediately dispatched to check the enemy's design.

The New-York Independent recently had an article comparing CHARLES SUMNER to EDMUND BURKE. I have no objections in re gard to Mr. SUMNER. If he can stand in. I can: but I have some objections in regard to BURKE. BURKE was one of the most illustrious statesmen of modern times. If he saved England from the wild overthrow which overtook France, he did a beneficent work.

Since the 7th, no hostile demonstrations have been made by the enemy upon our front. Their batteries on the northeastern stope of the Lookout Mountain have undoubtedly been withdrawn, while those on the left have remained silent.

The vote at the recent election shows that California is being rapidly depleted of her population. There is little doubt that the vote was a full one, as it followed an exciting campaign, in which both parties exerted themselves to their utmost to bring out their party strength. The cities and towns throughout the state, with the exception of San Francisco, show the effects of the depletion.

The net result of the draft in this City cannot be ascertained fully as yet, but judging form the returns already, in it will be far more satisfactory than is generally supposed and infinitely better than the Copperheads have prophesied or desired. In the case of the Schooner Prince Alfred, captured by the United States steamer Susquehanna, Sept. 6, 1861, and the schooner San Juan, captured by the same vessel, Sept. 28. 1861, prize lists have not been forwarded to the Department, and the distribution of the prize money is thereby prevented.
Washington has been filled with rumors and excitements throughout the day.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--An excellent and brilliant audience--the most metropolitan in character that we have seen this season--witnessed the performance of "Ernani" last evening, and testified its approval of the same by repeated and long-continued bursts of applause. The opera is one that peculiarly suits Mr. MARETZEK'S artists, whose voices are great and whose styles are vigorous. It is said that VERDI never wrote better...

At 7 P. M. the procession, headed by Mayor OPDYKE, the Russian Minister and Admiral, the officers of the fleet, and the Joint Committee, entered the hall and took their seats at the places assigned to them.

We have authentic accounts of the proceedings of the deputation that went to Miramar, near Trieste, to offer the Crown of Mexico to the Archduke MAXIMILIAN. They left Paris on Sunday, and arrived at Vienna on the Tuesday following. At the request of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs special carriages were provided for them by the Eastern Railroad Company; and, we further learn, they were treated with the utmost distinction along the line.

The shock of an earthquake, more or less severe, was felt in all parts of England at about twenty two minutes past three o'clock on the morning of the 6th inst. At some places the shock is represented as having been quits severe, and accompanied by a loud rumbling report, while at others it was slight and without noise. No damage was sustained anywhere.

There is the same ebb and flow of rumor to-day as yesterday. Cavalry soldiers, returned from Edward's Ferry, report that there was heavy cannonading throughout yesterday about twelve miles away, and seemingly at Point of Rocks.

The Inman steamer City of New-York. Capt. KENNEDY, which left Liverpool at 2 P.M. on the 7th and Queenstogn on the 8th inst., arrived here yesterday afternoon.

Pursuant to call the Loyal League State Convention met in Mechanics Hall at noon to-day. Nearly 200 delegates are present, among them GERRIT SMITH, E.P. SPAULDING, of Buffalo: Dr. BATES, Senators BELL and SANFORD, N.W. DAVIS, and several other members of the last Legislature.

SETH C. HAWLEY, Esq., Chief Clerk to the Police Commissioners, recently received a letter highly complimentary to the Eighteenth Ward Police, from the Hon. HAMILTON FISU, inclosing a check for $100, to be appropriated toward purchasing an American flag and flag-pole for the new Station-house of that Precinct.
Major-Gen. GRANT assumes command of the armies of the Ohio, the Cumberland, and of Kentucky, with plenary powers. He left for Nashville this morning to assume the direction of affairs at Chattanooga.

About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the colors ordered by the City, for the Fifth regiment N.Y.S. N.G., were presented by President WALSH, of the Board of Aldermen, who was acting as Mayor, in the absence of Mayor OPDYKE.
Little Rock advices to the 14th, state that the rebel army is scattered in every direction, and an extraordinary revival of Union sentiment has taken place among the people.
The Richmond Enquirer, of the 16th inst., contains the following editorial, entitled "Peace," which must profoundly interest alike the friends and enemies of the country:
At the opening of the Court, Monday, the roll of Grand Jurors was called, and the following gentlemen impanneled and sworn:

GENTLEMEN: I am in receipt of your communication announcing to me that I have been nominated as the Union candidate for the responsible and honorable office of Senator for the Eighth Senatorial District.

The recent movements of the two great armies now confronting each other in Virginia are not without interest, particularly by reason of the science and skill displayed by the Commanding Generals, and the indomitable energy manifested by the men composing both armies. Within a period of five days these two formidable bodies have traversed a distance of between seventy and eighty miles, in an air line, ...

The Seventeenth New-York Volunteers Veteran regiment leaves on the 21st inst. for the field. This is the only regiment of the two years' men raised in 1861, that returns with its numerical designation. Having raised more men in the reorganisation than any other regiment, it was filled in the consolidation. This regiment was raised in the Spring of 1861 by Col. H.S. LANSING, at present commanding NewYork troops in process of organization.
The Board of Supervisers met yesterday, when the following preamble and ordinance were offered by Mr. BLUNT and referred to the Special Committee appointed to provide substitutes for drafted men:

The President of the United States has called upon me, as Governor of the State of New-York, to furnish its quota of three hundred thousand men, to recruit the volunteer forces of the United States, which will be largely reduced during the coming year, by the expiration of the terms of enlistment.

I. Recruiting officers and others are forbidden to grant permits to conscripts or deserters, allowing them to visit their homes or to remain there for any purpose. The notice already given conscripts is deemed sufficient, and deserters are not entitled to indulgence.

Gen. ROSECRANS has been relieved from command, and Gen. THOMAS has been put in his stead. Gen. GRANT takes command of the Department and of the three armies known as BURNSIDE'S, ROSECRANS', and GRANT'S, and all operations will be conducted under GRANT'S order.
United States Senator G.B. DAVIS is very ill, and slight hopes are entertained of his recovery.
The mystery of LEE'S movement last week is uncovered; a part of his army was at Culpepper this morning, being vigorously embarked on trains of cars for the Southwest.

The Memphis Bulletin of the 17th gives additional particulars of military operations on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad. Our force at Collersville was less than 500, without artillery, commanded by Lieut. JAMES, Third United States cavalry, a member of Gen. SHERMAN'S Staff, and Gen. SHERMAN himself, as previeusly reported.

The Richmond Examiner, of the 12th inst., says that on Saturday, the 10th inst., a very large and spontaneous meeting of the mechanics and workingmen of Richmond was held to consider their interests and obtain a free expression of the sentiments of the people generally.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 29 bbls. Ashes, 9,559 bbls. Flour, 192 bbls. and 245 bags Corn Meal, 41,774 bush, Wheat, 7,424 bush. Corn, 375 bush Rye, 15,146 bush. Barley, 56,774 bust. Oats, 1,658 bush Malt, 724 pkgs. Provisions, and 695 bbls. Whisky.

We have this morning the news that Gen. ROSECRANS has been relieved from the command of the Army of the Cumberland; and that Major-General ULYSSES S. GRANT takes command of that Department and of the Army of the Tennessee, (GRANT'S old army,) the Army of the Cumberland, (ROSECRANS' late army,) and the Army of Kentucky (BURNSIDE'S.) Gen. THOMAS, who fought so splendidly at Chickamauga takes the immediate command vacated by Gen. ROSECRANS.
The Damocratic Ratification Meeting held last night in Cooper Institute, was a large gathering of the "Unterrified." Judge GILBERT DEAN

RE-ARREST OF AN ESGAPED BURGLAR. A young German, named CONRAD SCHMIDT, alias Schnelder, well known to the Police as a burglar, was arrested yesterday by Officers RODGERS and SHANGLE, of the Eleventh Precinct, charged with having committed a burglary at the store of Mr. STRAUSS, in Avenue D. a few weeks since.
The Paris Patrie maintains the complete accuracy of its statement, that Prince CZART0RISKI had demanded from the Cabinets of London and Paris the recognition of Poland as a belligerent nation.

Mr. BEECHER has been delivering addresses at Glasgow and at Manchester. At the latter place his reception was most enthusiastic. The Examiner and Times gives over four of its broad columns to the report of an address which Mr. BEECHDR delivered to an audience of 6,000 persons.
During the past three or four days there has been very little firing on either side. The enemy is evidently waiting for the iron-clads to come up, for which event he is reserving his ammunition.

Quartermaster-General MEIGS and Staff arrived here this evening. He reports that Gen. GRANT assumes the command of the Department of the Cumberland, Tennessee and Ohio, to be called the Military Division of Mississippi.

Maj.-Gen. H.W. Halleck, General-in-Chief, Washington: On the 8th inst. the enemy held down as far as Blue Springs, and a cavalry brigade of ours held Bull's Gap, supported by a small body of infantry at Morristown.

In the Federal Diet at Frankfort, the four Governments called upon by the Federal decree of the 1st inst. to carry out the execution in Holstein, announced that they would obey the order in the event of its becoming necessary.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The revival of VERDI'S opera of "Macbeth" last night must be recorded as the best success, so far, of Mr. MARETZER'S season, Intrinsically there is no interest attached to any Haliar, version of SHAKESPEARE'S plays and least of all to those that have been prepared for the operatic stage.
The seventh annual fair and festival of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul opened at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 446 Broadway, on Tuesday, and will continue every day and evening this week.

The latest reports from the Army of the Potomac report it to be in full pursuit of the retreating rebels. Yesterday the advance of our right column had reached the town of Warrenton and the left column was at Greenwich.
The news brought to this port yesterday by the steamship Scotia, two days later, contains one item of vast interest, which will give great satisfaction to the people of this country.
A mass, meeting of the Democracy was held last evening at the Cooper Institute. The hall was filled, but not overcrowed.

To-day a Government warrant was received by the Customs officials at this Court, authorizing the defention and seizure of the two rams recently built by LAIRD BROTHERS for the confederate Government of America. The broad arrow has just been placed upon one of the rams.

Gen. SCHOFIELD has issued an order for the government of the November election in this State. Judges of Election will be held strictly accountable that none but qualified voters are allowed to vote, and any action on their part excluding qualified voters from the polls will be punished as a military offence.
The removal of ROSECRANS is the subject of much and contradictory comment. The more correct understanding of the causes that led to it is that charges were preferred against him by Gens. McCook.

GILLMORE and Admiral DAHLGREN.
Our army is following the enemy up to-day rapidly. No rabels were discovered this side of the Rappahannock by a reconnoissance to-day.

A Nashville dispatch to the Journal says the command at Columbia attacked and killed a number of guerrillas yesterday, and took 13 prisoners.

President LINCOLN'S reply to the Missouri delegation, his letter of instructions to Gen. SCHOFIELD, together with an address by Mr. DRAKE in answer to the President's reply, appear in the Democrat of this morning.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The opera of "Martha" was the attraction last evening. The house, although not crowded, was brilliant, and the ready and discriminating applause testified that it was composed of the right material. We have rarely heard FLOTOW'S favorite work given to greater advantage.

Memphis dates of the 21st are received. Loyal Tennesseeans from the upper counties of Tennessee are coming to Memphis in large number to avoid the rebel conscription bands and guerrillas. It was estimated that over 200 were seen only five miles below Memphis, and it was supposed they design to operate against steamboats.

The Army of the Potomac has at length settle down, after its great race up and down Virginia. The whirl, and bustle, and confusion of the backward and the forward movement have so far given place to calmer moods, that it is possible now to survey with some satisfaction of the series of complicated and exciting events whose relations and upshot it was at the time impossible to grasp.

GILLMORE and himself, the following note from Gen. GILLMORE will satisfy the Department upon this subject, at least to its date, namely, the 23d of September:

Our special correspondence from the Army of the Potomac gives a very comprehensive account of the recent military movements in Virginia, and the present situation of the opposing armies. A dispatch from Washington informs us that Gen. MEADE yesterday returned to the front, and the report that he had been superseded by Gen. SEDGWICK seems to have had no foundation.

Alexander P. Strout el al. vs. The Steamer City of Washington SHIPMAN. J. This is a liabel for collision. The City of Washington was, by His Honor Judge BETTS, held liable. The case is now before the Court on exceptions to the Commissioner's report, fixing the amount of damages. The report is special, and sets forth the items objected to. I will consider them in the order in which they are presented by the report.

The Dano-German question is beginning to assume an aspect of gravity. Matters are evidently approaching a crisis, and if the Western Powers do not promptly interpose between the belligerents, and compel them to come to terms, the consequence may be a general European war.

Within the last two weeks all the vicissitudes of army life have passed with us in rapid succession, Last week we were a quiet army of observation. Brilliant reviews took the place of grim lines of battle. One fine October morning last week Gen. PLEASONTON reviewed Gen. KILPATRICK'S division.

The English Press, for the past few months, has been over-lavish of hints and groans, bearing upon the non-success of certain artillery and prorjectile experiments, the initiation of which, two or more years ago, with the most fearful boasting, was calculated to make all the world shake in its shoes at the threatened tripling and quadrupling of John Bull's shooting ability.

The Special train from Albany, bearing the Russians route for Niagara Falls, reached here early this morning. The train consists of four passenger cars, a lunch car and baggage car, and is under the charge of conductor B.B. YATES, who puts the Russians through at the rate of 45 miles an hour, running time.

The present system of electing Judges seems now to be on trial. Some think that it would be well to let the system have full sweep, and the very scum of the Bar placed in judicial seats, to the end that the system itself might be thus overthrown by its own excesses preferring to endure the temporary evil of such dispensers of law for the sake of the permanent good.

The Synod of the Baltimore Old School Presbyterians, now in their annual session here, like their immediate predecessors of the New School, this afternoon proceeded to the White House, where they were received by the President. Dr. FUSLIN, the Moderator, stated that the Synod wished as a body to pay their respects and salutations; each member, he added, belonged to the Kingdom of God, and was loyal to the Government.

The steamship Morning Star, Capt. J.M. COURTENAY, arrived at this port last evening, from New-Orleans and Havana, having left the former port at 9 o'clock A.M., Oct. 17.

As the time for the elections approaches, the policy and tactics of Ministerialists and Nationalists become more clearly defined. The rumors about the King's sudden conversion to liberalism were all fictions. Despite the warnings he has received of his waning popularity, and of the consequences of persisting in his career of despotism, he has taken his stand by VON BISMARK, and indorsed all the unprincipled devices of that reckless statesman.
THOMAS J. CLAY, the youngest son of Col. HENERY CLAY, of Buena Vista fame, died on the 13th inst., at Atlanta, of congestive fever. He was Inspector on Gen. BTCKNER's Staff.
The Boston Journal publishes a long letter, written by a rebel officer, under date of Richmond, July 29, to a friend in Europe. The following are extracts:

These races commenced on Tuesday, and were to have continued four days, but were closed after the second day's races for want of public patronage on the part of the respectable portion of the community. They had been disappointed in the racing on the first day, and robbed and cheated by the threecard monte men and pickpockets, who were allowed on the Course, and no check offered to their operations by the proprietors.

The Lexington (Ky.) Union gives an account of the shooting of Dr. BENTON, at Marshall. Saline Country, on the 6th inst. A writer in the Richmond Examiner proposes a plan for stowing the population of the entire Confederacy in Richmond, and supplying them with food. He details the plan at great length, making it a cover for satire upon the civil and military management, and the social condition of the Confederates.

The military telegraph between Chattanooga and Nashville has been closed to the Press. A dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette, dated Chattanooga, Oct. 24, says that Gen. GRANT arrived there on the 23d inst. Deserters report BRECKINRIDGE and HINDMAN'S forces to have withdrawn from our front and moving in large bodies to our left. The object of the movement was not clear.
Both Boards of the Common Council had long sessions yesterday, and acted upon a large num ber of minor matters.

The facts concerning the seizure of the steam rams appear to be as follows: On Thursday last a revenue cutter conveyed a Custom-house officer into the Great Float, and put him on board of the El Tousin. On Friday this proceeding was followed by the appearance of a second Custom-house officer, who, it is said, put the "broad arrow," on the vessel, and remained in charge of the ship.

The most important event of the past fortnight is the opening of the railway connecting Santiago with Valparaiso. On the 14th of September trains left Santiago and Valparaiso, starting each at 10 o'clock in the morning, and they met at a central station called "Llai-llai," where luncheon was provided, and afterward the line was formally declared by the President to be opened.

The steamer North Star, from Aspinwall, A.G. JONES commanding, consigned to D.B. ALLEN, has arrived. The North Star sailed from Aspinwall on the 17th inst., at 3 P.M., and arrived at this port yesterday. Experienced heavy northeast winds from Cape Antonio. Brings $296,705 in specie.

Gen. ROSECRANS arrived at about 11 o'clock this forenoon, and was escorted to the Burnet House by an immense crowd of citizens. He was enthusiastically welcomed throughout the entire line of march.

But for the last ten years, most of his time has been employed in the manufacture of the various Solid and Fluid Extracts.

I left Chattanooga four days ago. At that time nothing of exceeding importance at regards field operations was transpiring at that point. Our officers and the enemy communicated almost every day via the picket lines. Reports reaching us through rebel couriers represented the Union movements at several points in a favorable light.
The Memphis Bulletin, of the 24th instant, says: On the 21st the advance of the Union forces eastward from Corinth met with resistance near Cherokee Station, eighty-nine miles from Tuscumbia.
No information has been received here indicating that the two hostile armies upon the Reppanannock have come into collision again that is, since Saturday last.

A mass meeting of the "Regular Representative Democracy," as it was named in the call, as opposed to the "close corporations" of Tammany and Mozart, was held at Cooper Institute last evening. Although the announcement that JAMES T. BRADY and JOHN VAR BUREN would speak which is always a sufficient inducement to crowd any Hall where they appear was not verified, yet there was a very respectable attendance at the hour named.

A faller synopsis of the European news, left by the Canada at Cape Race, on Monday afternoon, has been forwarded. The American war had been the subject of public discussion. Two meetings for the consideration of this topic were held on the 16th, at Liverpool, one of which was addressed by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, who had an immense audience, but whose remarks were stamefully interruped by secession sympathizers.
A party of Col. STREET'S command made another raid into Brownsville, Missouri, on the 16th instant, plundering many stores and committing other outrages.
The Board of Supervisors met yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, and finished the appointment of Canvassers and Inspectors of Election. They adjourned to meet on Monday next.

The rebels last night opened their batteries on James Island, and for an hour or more kept up an active fire. Their fire to-day has also been, more fre quent than for a week past. Gen. GILLMORE is rapidly mounting guns noon his now nearly completed works, and it is probably a knowledge of this fact, and a desire to delay his progress, that has induced the enemy to resume their artillery practice.

A meeting of the association having in charge the matter of urging the extension of the Eighthavenue Railroad to Harlem River, was held at Bright's Hotel, Manhattanville, on Tuesday evening last. A deputation from Westchester County was present. The Westchester County men are beginning to take the matter up, as they feel deeply interested in the completion of the project, and they stated that at the next meeting they would send a large deputation.

Yesterday Rear-Admiral PAULDING, commanding the naval station in New-York, accompanied by this Aid and Capt. This is the last day of the sessions of this Committee. At noon the Committee will pay off and discharge all their employes, and after that no business will be transacted further than to pay for the obtainment of substitutes for such drafted men as have had their application papers signed by the acting Chairman, Supervisor BLUNT, and have not yet furnished substitutes.

Dates have been received from the City of Mexico up to Oct. 1. A conspiracy against the Imperial Government had been discovered, and a large number of accused persons had been imprisoned, some shot, and others sent to Martinique.

Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday at 1 o'clock P.M. The Aldermen had a very brief session, and did not transact any business worthy of special mention. A Mass Meeting of the Democracy was held last night at the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the McKEON General Committee, to ratify the Judiciary and County nominations of that branch of the Democratic party. The hall of the Institute was crowded, the great mass of the assembly being men who have always acted with the Democracy.

From Charleston Harbor we have the exciting news that on Tuesday last Gen. GILLMORE brought three of his heavy guns to bear upon the city, and flung shells laden with Greek fire into its very heart. A Correspondent of the Augusta (Georgia) Constitutionalist writes of affairs at Charleston:

I fear that my last Winter troubles were nothing to what they will be this coming Winter. I have heard nothing but Indian accounts of the movements of troops below this, and they are discouraging enough.

The "State Fair" of the "Deseret Agricultural and Manufacturing Society" came off on Friday and Saturday last, and was generally considered a failure. Indeed, a gradual decline has been noticed the past two or three years, but this last exhibition was the poorest, by far, within my experience. The causes of the lack of interest and emulation it is diffcult to accurately determine, but some of them undoubtedly originate in the prize system.

Deputy Provost-Marshal-Gen. NUGENT has been relieved from his position and will resume his former one of Captain in the regular army. Brig.-Gen. HAYES, of the United States army, supersedes him, and will at once enter upon the duties of his position.
An English magazine for the current month contains an interesting article on the nature and operations of the French conscription as it is now enforced. From it we draw the following facts:

The Northwestern Fair is, as it should be, all the rage here just now. During the past week the arrival of articles to-be displayed and sold has been constant. Contributions have been pouring in not only from the States which were first intended to be included, but from every port of the loyal North.

On returning hither from the North I found headquarters moved from Morris to this Island, which is an improvement, as Morris is pretty nearly washed away. Here we have plenty of wood, and the camps are very picturesque with Palmetto trees and the luxuriant growth of vines and underbrush.

UNION MEETING AT GOTHIC HALL. A Union meeting was held at Gothic Hall Friday evening, for the purpose of ratifying the nominations, and hearing Gov. YATES, of Illinois, speak upon the topics of the day.

The arrival from New-Orleans of the stemship George Washington puts us in possession of interesting information concerning the troops under Gen. BANKS, who are moving through Western Louisiana, as in supposed, with the ultimate object of redeeming Texas from the rebels.

Who shall govern New-York? It contains the extremes of society, brought together and thrown into daily contact with each other the very rich and the very poor. Though these classes, and all classes, have a common...
The Convention of the National Telegraphic Union will be held on Monday evening the 2d inst.
Sixty rebles, including nine officers, captured by Major FITZGIBBON, near Columbia, arrived here to-night.
SIR: I have the honor to report the capture and entire destruction of the blockade runner Venus, from Nassau to Wilmington, with a Cargo of lead, drugs, dry goods, bacon and coffee.

The Philadelphia and Erie Railroad was opened to Emporium, Cameron County, on the 19th inst. Eighty-five miles more of the road are under way, which will carry the road from Sunbary to St. Mary's, leaving only a gap of twenty-three miles unfinished between Philadelphia and Erie.

We, the undersigned, residents of the above District, take the liberty of calling your attention to the necessity, in these times of peril to our common country, of supporting at the coming election the nominees of the Union party, and in view of the extraordinary efforts being made to distract the Union...
The steamer S.R. Spaulding, Capt. HOWE, sailed from here this afternoon, with 600 soldiers, sick, from the Hampton hospitals, bound to NewYork.

Frankie Bragg, aged only fifteen, one of the bravest of Birgis' sharpshooters in the battle at Donelson, when dying in the hospital, was asked why he joined the army. He replied: " I joined, Mrs. S-, because I was so young and strong, and because life would be worth nothing to me unless I offered it to my country!"

At this moment, when the President is calling for 800,000 volunteers, and we are about entering on another campaign of voluntary enlistments, it will not be malapropos to look a little into the ways in which other nations accomplish the same end, that we may pattern after them, if there is anything worth copying. England being the best specimen of the voluntary enlistment plan, we shall give that.
We make the following clippings from the Rio Abajo Press:

THE SUIT FOR BEING CHARGED WITH SHOPLIFTING. The famous shoplifting case of E.M. CURRIER against CHARLES PIERSON, of the well-known firm of UBSDELL, PIERSON Co., of this City, and which was tried in May last, in Superior Court, has...
The United States mail steamship George Washington, E.V. GAGER, Commanding, from New-Orleans Oct. 24, with merchandise, mails, specie and passengers to H.B. CROMWELL Co., has arrived.
We have received a copy of the Vera Cruz Del Commerio of the 17th of October, from which we translate the following important address of Gen. FOREY:

The financial feature or the week past was the large subscription to the Popular Loan of the United States. The total in this market is not short of TWENTY MILLIONS. The amount of Money actually paid on this account into the Treasury Office at New-York is $17,660,000, as follows:

Our special correspondent at Washington says that Maj.-Gen. BUTLER has at last been assigned to active service. He is ordered to relieve Maj.Gen. FOSTER of the command of the Department of Virginia and North Carolina, and will at once enter upon the duties.

BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY The whole number of deaths in this city last week was 130. Of these 13 were men, 25 women and 82 children. The causes were: Zymotic diseases, 11; nervous system, 26; heart and blood vessels, 8; respiratory organs, 46; digestive organs, 24; generative organs, 2; bones and joints, I; injury, 2; stillborn, 8; unkown, 1. Natives of United States, 94; Ireland, 24; Germany, 5; England, 6; unknown, 1.

Gov. SEYMOUR has just made his third appearance as a speaker in New-York since his entrance into office. The first was at the Academy of Music, on July Fourth, when he addressed the Democracy in an elaborately prepared speech, the whole burden of which was denunciation of the Government as an insufferable tyranny, and an averment that the war, as conducted, was a dead failure.

The brig Santiago, from Port-au-Platte, Oct. 6. via Grand Turk, arrived to-day. She carried 109 refugees from Port-au-Platte to Grand Turk. The Hamburg and Bremen Consuls at Port-au-Platte were passengers to this Port, Reliable news by this arrival confirms the previous reports that after the destruction of the town of Santiago de Caballeros, the Spanish garrison, with 2,000 reinforcements, retreated to Port-au-Platte.

Mr. JAMES T. BRADY has for many years enjoyed a large practice at the Bar of this City, and has, probably, done it as much credit as any other member. He has been all his life a Democrat, and is fond of boasting himself an Irish Democrat a class of politicians who pride themselves on their fidelity to their party, almost as much as their forefathers prided themselves on their fidelity to their clan.
We have received a copy of the Vera Cruz Del Comercio of the l7th of October, from which we translate the following important address of Gen. FOREY:
The following is a copy of the President's letter to the Sanitary Commission Fair at Chicago:

An extraordinary case of treason has recently come to light, implicating several persons in this city, Columbus, Covington, and Newport, in conspiring to release the rebel prisoners at Camp Chase, and overthrow the State Government. The conspiracy was brought to light by United States detectives, who were supposed by the parties implicated to be spies from the rebel army, and were treated with full confidence.
The steamer Liberty, from Memphis, and the Crescent City from White River, have arrived, bring ing 1,980 bales of Cotton.

While many of our steamships of war are being severely criticised for inefficiency, more especially on account of the miserable failures of their expensive engines, it is pleasant to notice those that "have done the State some service."

An experimental suit against the Hon. SIMON CAMERON, for alleged illegal arrest and imprisonment at Fort Lafayette while he was Secretary of War, will come on for trial to-morrow at Baltimore. It will probably be removed into the United States Court on a preliminary motion.

I was excessively amused and a little surprised on reading in your paper of yesterday, a communication signed "L.M.D.," intended no doubt to be a severe reflection upon my recent exploit of taking large brook trout.

The arrival on Saturday of the Bremen brig Santiago, from Santo Domingo Oct. 6, gives us the only connected and authentic account of the disturbances on that island. In the various collisions between the insurgents and the Spanish troops, the advantage has been mainly on the side of the Dominicans. The towns of Santiago de los Caballeros and Puerta Plata had both been destroyed by fire.
Our forces which occupied London have retreated to the north side of the river, and now occupy the heights commanding London. The other dispositions of our troops remain unchanged.
The following are designated as the places in each Election District in the several Wards of this City, at which elections shall be held, until otherwise ordered:
The China could not leave the Mersey at her regular hour, owing to a dense fog. She sails this afternoon.
The Richmond Whig of Oct. 31 has been received here, and contains the following dispatch:

Gov. SEYMOUR Sir: Will you permit me, as one of a class untrammeled by political partisanship, and who seeks only to ascertain which are the best measures and who are the best men before casting his vote for those measures and men, to propound to you or your spokesmen a few questions suggested by a careful perusal of your speech delivered on Saturday evening, at the Cooper Institute!

A few days since, the Albany Atlas and Argus published a long report of the attempts made by Gov. SEYMOUR to secure for the wounded NewYork soldiers in the front ranks of the Army of the Potomac the presence and services of Dr. SWINBURNE, who went on as agent of the State.
A City paper copies the following from the Washington Union, of Saturday:

Last night, under the auspices of the Emancipation Society and the London Committee of Correspondence on American Affairs, a meeting was held in Exeter Hall to hear an address from Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, the distinguished American clergyman and Abolitionist.
The Invalide Russe has the following from a Warsaw letter, dated Oct. 8, addressed to the Russian journal Golos:

The EMPIRE STATE speaks to-day. She in turn pronounces her judgment upon Faction. The whole country awaits her voice with intensest interest. Every citizen of the State, from Montauk Point to Lake Erie, ought to help give that voice a distinctness and a force worthy of her rank. Every vote ought to be cast to tell with the directest emphasis against the policy which Gov. SEYMOUR has been, with such infatuation, pursuing.
The following was received to-day at the headquarters of the army:

The steamship China, from Liverpool on the 24th, via Queenstown on the 25th of October, passed this point en route to New-York at 8 o'clock this (Saturday) evening, where she will be due on Tuesday night. The China reports that she experienced strong westerly gales during the passage.
A special dispatch from Cincinnati to the Evening Bulletin of this city contains the following respecting the treasonable plot discovered there:

Max Mareizek vs. Couldwell and Whitney. This was a motion to vacate an order of arrest which had been obtained against the defendants as proprietors of the Sunday Mercury, upon a charge of libel made against them by the plaintiff as the lessee and manager of the present opera season at the Academy of Music.
The luman steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which sailed from Liverpool at 2 P.M., on the 21st of October, and from Queenstown on the 22d ult., arrived here yesterday morning.
The Board of Aldermen failed of a quorum at their meeting yesterday, and adjourned to Thursday.
We take great pleasure in confirming the World's statement that "eighteen thousand or thereabouts of New-York troops have been or are to be sent home to vote" at the election to-day.

The State election to-day is one which should enlist the active interest of every patriotic man of every one who desires to see the policy of the Government sustained, and the Union preserved and vindicated by an unembarrassed prosecution of the war to a successful issue.

In magnificent contrast to the bankruptcy and financial lunacy which rule and ruin in Richmond, Secretary CHASE'S administration of the Treasury will show to the world a clean balance-sheet on the 1st of November. It will show the filling of Seventyfive millions of suspended requisitions. It will show the payment of every creditor of the Government, whose claim was on that day audited and established!

Last evening was a busy one at the theatres an anxious one for the critics; and a festive one for the public at large. Why Monday should be selected by all the managers of our places of amusement for the production of their novelties surpasses our power of comprehension.
President DAVIS, accompanied by Gen. JOHNSSTON, Lieut.-Gen. HARDEE, and Maj.-Gen. FRENCH reached Brandon, Miss., on the evening of the 21st:
Mercer County, Assembly. Trenton District Weart, Democrat, 130 majority; First District, Boeurre, Republican, elected; Third District, West, Republican, elected by small majority.
The firing upon Sumter and other rebel works, has been continued day and night since the comemencement on last Monday.
The Mobile Register has the following account of the recent review of the military forces there by President DAVIS:

Secretary CHASE to-day instructed Treasurer SPINNER to pay all certificates of indebtedness bearing interest in coin, whenever they should be presented, and whether they are matured or not. The Treasury is so rich that Mr. CHASE has judiciously determined to stop interest.

The Union State ticket prevailed yesterday by an overwhelming majority. In the City, the heavy Democratic majority of last year is cut down over thirteen thousand votes, or about three thousand more than the entire majority of Gov. SEYMOUR in the whole State.

For a long time the importance of East Tennessee to the Confederacy seemed to be unappreciated. Not until that country fell into possession of the enemy was its incalculable value realized. Except what was furtively obtained from Kentucky, the whole army supply of pork came from East Tennessee and the contiguous counties of adjoining States. The product ...
Officer MILLER, of the Sixth Precinct, arrested JOSEPH WOOLDRIDGE on a charge of illegal voting, in the Sixth Ward. The complaint was made by JOHN QUINLAN, of No. 140 Leonard-street.

There was a report yesterday evening, believed to be groundless, that the enemy were crossing the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford. This place, at which HOOKER crossed before the battle of Chancellorsville, is twenty miles above Fredericksburgh, and about the same distance southeast of Rappahannock Station, the supposed present headquarters of our army.

No new reports from above by telegraph. The following has been received by mail: MISSIONARY RIDGE, Thursday, Oct. 29. The enemy have crossed a division at Brown's Ferry, three miles below Chattanooga, and are in possession of Raccoon Mountain, which they are apparently fortifying. A rapid shelling of our camps on the west side of Lookout Mountain was kept up by the enemy to-day, our batteries replying.
The arrangements for disinterring the bodies of soldiers who fell in battle at Gettysburgh, and for their removal to "The National Cemetery," are now completed.
The election is progressing quietly here. No special interest is manifested in it. The vote is light, but it may be considerably increased this afternoon.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been : 45 bbls, Ashes, 13,633 bbls. Flour, 43 bbls, and 1,282 bags Corn Meal, 27,050 bushels Wheat, 7,153 bushels Corn, 63 bushels Rye, 7,595 bushels Barley, 21,393 bushels Oats, 2,300 pkgs. Provisions. and 247 bbls. Whisky.
Rev. D.B. BRADLEY, of Bangkok, Siam, a self supporting missionary of the American Missionary Association, addressed the Treasurer of that Society, July 29, 1863, as follows:

Our correspondent at Morris Island, under date of Oct. 30, sends a confirmation of the news published yesterday from the Richmond papers, respecting the bombardment of Fort Sumter, which was renewed on Monday, the 26th inst. Under the destructive power of our projectiles the walls were gradually crumbling, and it was believed that they would soon be completely demolished.

The Corporation of the Madison-avenue Baptist Church, vs. The Alleged Corporation of the Madison-avenue Baptist Church, Judgment for defendants on demurrer with costs. The motion for an attachment is denied without costs.
The prize steamer Jupiter, from Nassau for Savannah, captured Sept. 13, in Warsaw Sound, by the gunboat Cimmerone, has arrived here.
The steamer Anderson has arrived, with 200 bales of cotton, and Memphis date of Oct. 31.

There are the strongest indications that the rebels are meditating, if not now actually executing, a movement against Gen. BURNSIDE'S force in East Tennessee. The intention to do so is even boldly announced in the Richmond papers. The Enquirer of the 29th
A special dispatch from Des Moines says that the Indian troubles on the Upper Missouri, notwithsatanding the victory of Gen. SULLY, are far from being quiet.

Yesterday awoke sombre and gloomy enough. The clouds early dropped a few tears in compassion for the Democracy, who were to be so badly beaten in the State. But toward noon it broke away for the sunlight, gladdening over the success of the loyal.

The military situation in this Department, though it may have lost some of its interest because of the cessation of active movements, is nevertheless very interesting to contemplate, and full of features of vital importance. Especially is this the case now
The Convention of the National Talegraphic Union yesterday elected the following officers for the ensuing year:

We have a copy of the Cape Town Advertiser and Mail of Sept. 19, which contains the journals of the United States steamer Vanderbilt and of the Confederate pirate Alabama the latter a very elaborate record taken from the private log of one of the officers. In an editorial the paper says:

On Oct. 24 Mr. JOHN LAIRD took advantage of a gathering held at Music Hall, Birkenhead, with the object of presenting prizes to successful competitors at the annual meeting of the Cheshire Volunteers, to express his views on the defences of the country. In the course of his remarks he said:
The Richmond Examiner of Monday contains the following:

The funds on the 23d were without variation. Consols closed at 93@93 1/8. Business on Change continued very dull. The demand for discount was moderate, and the market was easy at 3 @3 7/8 for choice bills.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, Capt. TINKLEPAUGE, from Aspinwall, Oct. 27, arrived at this port last evening, bringing us our correspondence from Central and South America. The following is the Ariel's.
In a Cape Town letter of the 20th of September we have the following account of the doings of the Confederate cruisers on that coast:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "Lucrezia Borgia," last evening, was as complete a success as on the first night, and the house was a perfect bouquet. We have nothing to add to our former commendation of the performance, except to express the hope that it may be again repeated.
The Royal Mail steamer China, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 24th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 25th October, arrived here yesterday morning.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS.
Gov. ANDREW has decided to call a special session of the Legislature, to meet on Wednesday next, to consider the matter of offering additional bounties to volunteers.

Corning Hall was packed last evening to its utmost capacity on the occasion of the last Union rally of the campaign. The evening was stormy, but that had no influence to keep back the crowd. Hundreds who could not gain admission to the hall were turned away.
Steamship China, (Br.,) Anderson, Liverpool Oct. 24, and Queenstown 25th, at 4 P.M., with mdse. and passengers to E. Cunard.

The Examiner, speaking of affairs in Richmond says that the speculators are now masters of the situation in regard to the prices of flour per barrel, of which any king at any price is next to impossible to obtain. The hoarders should be made to come to terms that is, to put their stores in the market.
Rear-Admiral Davis, U.S. Navy; Surgeon E. Russell, Fourth Louisiana volunteers; Ed. Gilmore. Liverpool; and Capt. E.J. Strang, Warrenton Junction, Va., are at the Astor House.

The American West India Company's steamship Tubal Cain, A.P. FOSTER, Commander, arrived at this port last evening, with dates from St. Domingo City to the 18th, Mayaguez 19th, St. Johns, P.R., 21st, St. Thomas 23d, and Bermuda 31st, ults.
The regular semi-monthly meeting of this Commission was held yesterday afternoon, President DRAPER in the Chair.
Sailed, ship Young America, for Liverpool, carrying 220 casks of tallow, 300 bbls, copper ore and 35,000 sacks of wheat.
A Baltimore dispatch last evening to the Philadelphia Inquirer says:
The Chamber of Commerce held their regular monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, commencing at one o'clock.

Sufficient returns have been received to make it certain that Maryland has pronounced for the Administration, with a very large vote. Three at least out of the five Union candidates for Congress have been elected, and the Union local officers generally throughout the State. Indeed, in no State of the North, considering the opposition to be overcome, has there been a more decided victory for the Union cause.

A dispatch from Knoxville, dated the 4th inst., says: East Tennessee is once more clear of rebels, with the exception of guerrillas, who hover around our wagon trains and infest our mail routes above.

Gen. THOMAS officially announces the capture of BRAGG'S forage train, with its escort, and the arrival of the captures at Chattanooga. The train was seized in the Lookout Valley, in front of BRAGG'S position.
The schooner Cammilla, from St. John's, N.F., arrived here this morning. She brings as passengers, Mr. HOXIE, Second Mate, and 6 seamen, part of the crew of the whaling brig Pavilion, of Fair Haven.

The royal mail steamship Adriatic, from Glasgow on the afternoon of the 27th ult., arrived here at 6 o'clock this (Wednesday) evening. She experienced head gales during the entire passage. It is stated that Austria and Prussia have agreed to decline the arbitration of England in the conflict with Denmark, regarding it as of a purely German character.

Memphis papers of the 2d contain indefinite accounts of a fight at Pine Bluff, Ark. MARMADUKE attacked the place with 3,000 men, and was repulsed with considerable loss. The garrison of Pine Bluff consisted of 700 cavalry, under Col. CLAYTON, and lost 12 killed and 15 wounded.

The imperial City of the West crowned the hospitalities it has extended to its imperial guests from the East most worthily by the charming and brilliant festival which turned last night into brightest day in Irving-place. As a triumph of social art the Russian Ball will be remembered as long as any triumph of any kind can very well be in this land of things "a moment bright, then gone forever."
We sum up the result of the election in this State as follows: Senators holding over Republicans, 4; Democrats, 9; newly elected Democrats, 5; Republicans, 3.
The steamer New York sailed this morning for City Point, in charge of Maj. MULFORD.

The long-expected event of the senson, the grand fete given by the citizens of New-York to Rear-Admiral LISOVSKY and his fellow-officers, came off last night at the Academy of Music with unrivaled splendor. The very full and detailed account of the preparations for this superb festival, published by us in the TIMES of yesterday morning, was more than realized in the execution.
All continues quiet with the army, and no important movements have been made within the last few days.

From the latest returns of the recent election we are inclined to believe that the Union majority will vary very little from 35,500. A revised calculation shows that in the composition of the State Legislature the Unionists will have twothirds of the Senate but not of the House. From present indications the Senate will stand Union 22, Democrats, 10; and the Assembly, Union 82, Democrat's 46.

All is quiet to-day. The enemy keep up a lazy fire from a 20-pounder on the crest of Lookout, and their shell occasionally reach our lines. They varied the entertainment by throwing a few shells inside of their own lines, which strange conduct elicits much comment.

Banks Township, Carbon County, Pennsylvania, is a mining region of little note, yet a district lively with work, and embracing within its narrow circuit some of the richest coal orchards in Pennsylvania. Perched on the very highest portion of land in the State, in a cold and desolate ragion, peopled only by Irish, Welsh and German miners, and the few agents and owners of the mines, but little that transpires below ever comes up here.
The mail-boat Thomas A. Morgan, from Yorktown, brought down two officers, Maj. HOUSTON and Lieut. D. VON WEITZEIN, who had made their escape from Richmond.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 17 bbls. Ashes, 19,278 bbls. Flour, 445 bbls. and 124 bags Corn Meal, 86,375 bushels Wheat, 215 bushels Rye, 28,050 bushels Corn, 2,194 bushels Barley; 41,411 bushels Oats, 2,467 bushels Malt, 3,780 pkgs. Provisions and 850 bbls. Whisky.

It is calculated that the Wool clip of Minnesota the present year will not be less than 500,000 lbs. The progress in Wool-growing in Minnesota has been unprecedented. Commencing in 1850, the increase is shown by the following table:

If McCUNN had been defeated on Tuesday, owing to the accidental division of the Democratic forces, a large portion of the public would have relapsed into the comfortable conclusion that an elective Judiciary is not so bad after all, and that if the "respectable people would only work," the elevation of an unfit candidate to the Bench could always be rendered impossible.

Decidedly, the event of the week has been the appearance of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER the gentleman whom the London Times has so ofter designated as " Mr. BEECHER STOW" at Exeter Hall, on Tuesday evening. It had all the characteristics of a great sensation.
The Inquirer and the Bulletin, of this city, have reports of a terrible riot in the coal regions around Mauch Chunk.
Gen. SANDORS, commanding the cavalry corps, reports overtaking a rebel regiment at Metley's Ford, on the Little Tennessee River, yesterday.

The importants of the following document will at once be recognized, if it is in reality what it is alleged to be an intercepted letter from the rebel Commissary-General, designed only for perusal by high officials: ATHENS, April 25, 1863.

Some weeks ago it was announced in the journals of Nantes and Bordeaux that vessels-of-war were being built in those towns for an unknown destination, but which were suspected to be for the Confederates. Since then investigations have taken place which appear to establish the following facts: After the judicial decision in England in the case of the Alexandra, several of the leading shipbuilders of France, who, till then, had resisted the offers of...

A special meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was held Friday, at the Common Council Chamber, to take action in reference to offering a suitable bounty, whereby the quota of 603 men may be raised on the last call within the prescribed time, in order to avoid a draft.
Rev. D.B. BRADLEY, of Bangkok, Siam, a selfsupporting missionary of the American Missionary Association, addressed the Treasurer of that Society, July 29, 1863, as follows:

Everybody doesn't read the Atlantic Magazine, and everybody can't be at Rockville, Maryland. So, but for the kind offices of the NewYork TIMES, I should not know what a body of elegant and valuable literature had been spread

The elections had taken place for members of Congress, but the results were not yet declared. In Caliao and Lima severe conflicts took place at the polls for the possession of the tables. In Callao, where Ex-President CASTILLA and Gen. VALLERIESTRA were candidates, nine persons are said to have been killed, and fifteen or twenty wounded. In Lima four were killed.
The Yankees maintain possession of Raccoon Valley, having been heavily reinforced.

A new paper called La Pologne (Poland) has just been started at Paris and Brussels in the French lan guage; that is to say, it is printed for appearances at Brussels, but managed at Paris, which is destined to be the organ of the secret Government of Poland.

Good tidings from India are no longer so rare as they, once were, but it is seldom that we can report so decided a step towards prosperity as that described in our last letter from Calcutta. The cultivation of tea has at last got beyond the experimental stage, and is rapidly becoming the foundation of a vast and lucrative trade.

Nothing is more strange than to observe that the Confederates on the continent should appear to feel so deep an interest in the question, whether his Highness, the Pacha of Egypt, is to be allowed to take away two steam rams, which, it seems, have been built at Liverpool for that enlightened potentate.
On Oct. 9, BRIGHAM YOUNG made a speech to the Mormon Conference in Salt Lake, in the course of which the following passage occurred:

The drian in the Summer by the heavy emigration through this Territory, coupled with the later demand for breadstuffs by the inhabitants of Idaho, has caused the price of wheat and flour to rise, as was foreshadowed some time ago.
The President's call for 300,000 volunteers, to serve three years or during the war, to fill up the old regiments, makes the allotment to Kentucky of 12,000 to be raised.

DEATH OF A WOMAN FROM SUFFOCATION. RESULT OF THE CORONER'S INQUEST. About eight o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the three-story brick building, No. 548 Eighth-avenue, occupied on the first floor by Mrs. CAROLINE MEYERS as a millinery and fancy goods store.
The State election in Minnesota on Tuesday last, resulted in the election of STEPHEN MILLER, the Union candidate for Governor.

The Mobile Register and Advertiser asserts that Col. JOHN TRAVIS, (of pistol-shot notoriety,) has discovered, if not the ancient, at least its counterpart any equal, the modern "Greek fire." Its components are kept secret, but Col. TRAVIS tenders the use of his invention to the Confederate States. The Register gives the following account of a test of this fire:

The steamer Pizarro arrived on Sunday, having left Santo Domingo City on the 25th. She landed several wounded and sick at Santiago de Cuba on the 28th, but brought 22 prisoners, which have been sent to the Moro, among them several old Spaniards, all brought in the most wretched state, shoeless and half-starved. Still there seems to be no likelihood of the rebellion being put down.

Rov. GEORGE H. HAMMER, Chaplin of the Twelfth Pennsylvania cavalry, has in the Philadelphia Inquirer a narrative of his late captivity at Richmond, which is of the most interesting, though painful character. With regard to his capture, he says:
The steamer Silvor arrived at this port to-day from Morris Island, and brings the most glorious intelligence.

The town was excited yesterday afternoon by a rumor of the surrender of Fort Sumter to Gen. GILLMORE. Such an event is, of course, among the earliest probabilities, but in this instance we are inclined to doubt. There is no better foundation for the rumor than a dispatch from Philadelphia announcing the arrival there of the transport Salvor, direct from Hilton Head.
The following extraordinary story is told by the Bristol Times:

The Terre Haute Express is much gratified at the promotion of Gen. CHARLES CROUFT from a brigade commander to the command of a division. He commends Gen. PALMER'S old division, consisting of five brigades and four batteries, Gen. PALMER having been assigned the command of the Fourteenth Army Corps, formerly the corps of Gen. THOMAS.

Mozart Hall was nearly filled last night, by a highly intelligent assembly, drawn thither by an announcement of a lecture, to be delivered by the Archbishop of the Catholic diocese. The subject of the lecture was not announced, but it was surmised.

The San Francisco Bulletin is in receipt of news from Mexico, via Manzanilla, to the 23d of September, and from the City of San Luis Potosi up to the 1st of that month. The news is interesting. The activity of the guerrillas had become very harrassing to the French forces in the City of Mexico, the former having at the present time control of the roads leading from Vera Cruz to the capital.

Gen. HOOKER, who, with a large force, has been marching toward this place from Bridgeport, had a sharp engagement with the enemy this morning, about 1 o'clock. His advance, under the command of Col. ORLAND SMITH, had been skirmishing with the enemy since they had left Shell Mound, driving them everywhere before them. Last night they encamped near Brown's Ferry, some five miles from here.

The last Oriental mail brought bad news from New-Zealand to our British relatives. The Anglo-Maorian war has assumed an alarming aspect. The Colonists are now almost reduced to the necessity of fighting for their hearths and altars.
Arkansas advices represent that Arkadelphia, recently Gen. PRICE'S headquarters, is in possession of Gen. STEELE.

There is nothing of the least importance to American readers from Chili. The railroad between Valparaiso and Santiago, in nine days' only experience, had not given as profitable results as had been anticipated. In that time 2,500 passengers had gone over the road, paying about $11,000 for tickets. The management of the road remains at present in the hands of the Government.
From a citizen of Mayfield we learn that the guerrillas who captured LUCIEN ANDERSON, Member of Congress, in the late raid, assert that he is to be held as a hostage for TRUSTEN POLK.
Monthly report of the Dispensaries of the City of New-York, for October, 1863:
Gen. BLUNT leaves this post to-morrow for the Indian Territory, with the intention of turning over his command to Gen. McNEILL, hit successor.

The Corricre Sicitiano of Palermo relates the following anecdote, which may contain a useful hint for our own Provost-Marshals: "An officer in command of a detachment having received information, that a young conscript had concealed himself in a villa, proceeded thither, and stated the object of his visit to the lady of the house, who immediately affirmed that he was mistaken, and produced her two daughters, as the only inmates of the house.
In the beginning of this war, nothing could be heard from Southern trumpeters but songs of the self-sacrificing of the blue blood of the South.

Gen. WALBRIDGE, of New-York, just arrived from an extended trip in Southeast Missouri, reports that part of the State free from organized bodies of rebel troops, but that bushwhackers continue to commit depredations there.
Gen. W.T. SHERMAN has issued the following order, No. 2, from headquarters at Iuka, Miss., Oct. 25:

HUNTING. Extravagant reports of a superabundance of game in the neighboring forests, have succeeded in getting up a furore among amateurs and pot-hunters. Traps and shot-guns, shot, powder and caps, since Monday, have been in demand, the first mentioned article, being wholly confined to the denizens of the suburbs, and first hand speculators in fresh fish and game.

Anything emanating from the Executive of a State that has done so much to crush out this rebellion as Indiana, is always worthy of more than ordinary attention. In this view especially, Gov. MORTON'S late plan, submitted to the War Department, is deserving of notice.

It will be seen by the accompanying letter, written by Col. WILLIAM R. BREWSTER, commanding the Excelsior Brigade, and addressed to the AdjutantGeneral of the United States Army, that this veteran organization offers to reenlist for three years or the war, on condition of being allowed the privilege to reorganize as mounted infantry. They also, desire to be permitted to return to New-York for a period of sixty days to recruit.

The Philadelphian tale, Which excited the country on Saturday, to the effect that Gen. GILLMORE had captured Fort Sumter's ruins, and that the "Stars and Stripes waved over" them, etc., etc., was a little too fast.

The U.S. steam transport Daniel Webster, Capt. SHERMAN, arrived at this port this morning from NewOrleans, Oct. 29, Ship Island, 30th, and Tortugas 2d inst.
The long-expected advance of the Army of the Potomac to offer battle to Gen. LEE, after delays respecting its supplies, was finally made on Saturday, and with gratifying success.
The rebels threw some half-dozen shells at us to-day from Lookout Mountain, doing no damage.
If Mr. Engineer STIMERS had consulted the interest of his reputation, he would not have published the paper which, under the title of his "Defence," he has given to the public prints.

Gen. GEARY'S (Second) division. Twelfth army corps, under command of Maj. Gen, HOOKER, fought the battle of Wauhatchie, Tenn., in Lookout Creek Valley, early on the morning of the 29th of October, 1863. Three brigades of HOOD'S division, LONGSTREET'S corps, sought to surprise and capture Gen. GEARY'S advance, which was holding the intersection of the Wauhatchie and Brown's Ferry Road with the Kelly's Ferry Road.
The intelligence of the advance of the Army of the Potomac, coming as it does with such happy omens and actualities of preliminary success, will thrill the public nerve with pleasurable surprise.

M., 13th inst., bound for Liverpool, and the steaming out of the buy at 5:20 P.M. of the United States steamer mobican, steering for Liverpool also right after the Gracle.

The close of the Vicksburgh campaign left no considerable enemy within the Department of the Tennessee. The National forces, within the same limits, comprised four army corps the Thirteenth, Gen. ORD, the Fifteenth, Gen. SHERMAN, the Sixteenth, Gen. HURLEUT, and the Seventeenth, Gen. McPHERSON.

Only a little more than five months ago, R. Dr. STORES, Judge GREENWOOD, Prof. WEET and a few other, met to form the nucleus of this Society. It was felt that the treasures of historic matter, which lay thickly strewn along the cycle of more than a century and a half, of Long Island's history in its original Indian tribes, in its Revolutionary scenes, and in the lives of its many noted and able men.
The party subriqueting itself as the "People's Union" held Councilmanic Conventions last evening, or was supposed to.
