This was an action brought on a bond given by the defendant, who was the owner of the brig Joshin, to obtain the dischange of the vessel from an attachment under the lien law of 1839, the bond being conditioned to pay all such claims against her as should be established as liens, which had been exhibited to the Justice issuing the warrant.
We have received full files of Richmond papers as late as Nov. 6. The following will be found of importance.

Intelligence has been received here, dated Clarksburgh, Va., that Gens. AVERILL and DUFIE, commanding separate forces, after several severe engagements of Friday and Saturday last, succeeded in driving the enemy, under "Mudwall JACKSON," for several miles down the valley east of Greenbriar Mountains, into and through the town of Lewisburgh, in Western Virginia.

To the United States Sanitary Commission, MISS CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN has presented, as the aggregate amount of the several benefits she has recently devoted to the sick and wounded-the sum of $8,267. The following card from the President of the Commission is the response to this munificent gift:

According to announcement, a meeting was held in the large hail of the Cooper Institute last evening, under the auspices of the National Freedmen's Relief Association, in behalf of the suffering contrabands in the Department of the Mississippi. That speedy and effectual measures might be taken to improve their condtion and prevent future suffering, Gen. GRANT sent Rev. A.S. ...

The cold weather and rain which have prevailed for a week or so have nearly put an end to the operations of the gold miners on the Chaudiere River, yet the speculation connected with lands near the "diggings" still continues. A New-York company have bought about 60,000 acres in the neighborhood of the gold pits, and intend to commence opera tions of an extensive character in the Spring:

It is a matter of deep regret that so few of our public men and political leaders have made a study of International Law. Several very foolish and inconsistent positions, into which the guides of popular opinion have been betrayed during this war, might have been avoided by a more thorough acquaintance with this science.

Yesterday the officers of the Italian line-ofbattle-ship Re Galantuomo, which arrived here a few days ago, paid an official visit to Admiral PAULDING at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. On their arrival they were most cordially received by the Admiral and the officers of the station, who escorted them through such of the departments as they desired to see.

The Relay of the Potomac does not appear to have done any very heavy fighting since Saturday. Beyond brisk cavalry skirmishes, no engagement is reported. Gen. MEADE has steadily pressed forward his columns, and the bulk of the army is again across the Rappahanneck, in the vicinity of Culperper. Court-house. Out cavalry have reconnected to the banks of the Repidan without meeting the rebels in considerable numbers, and it begins to be generally believed at...

Our information from Headquarters this evening is that Gen. BUFORD had a short skirmish with the enemy yesterday, near Rixleyville Headquarters. At Bewens' house, near Beverly Ford, Gen. MEADE yesterday (Sunday) crossed at Keily's Ford, and made his headquarters a mile beyond for a while, and then returned to the forementioned point.
LES has very promptly followed up his late campaign from the Rapidan to Bull Run, by an official report of its purpose and progress.

It is reported to-day on authority of the surgeons in the Army of the Potomac, that our losses on Saturday were about 400, as stated in the Press telegram last night; 260 of these who are wounded, arrived here this morning, and were placed in the hospital.

A wrecked ship at Key West has, during the last three years, become quite a novelty, and on Monday evening the town was startled into more than ordinary excitement by the report of a ship ashore, which proved to be the ship Templar, from Philadelphia, laden with coal for the navy, and bound to Pensacola.

On Nov. 2 JEFF. DAVIS arrived at Charleston by special train from Savanah. He was escorted to the City Hall, where an address of welcome was made by Mayor MACBETH to which Mr. DAVIS replied in a speech which is reported by telegraph.

The question whether the President's call for volunteers shall be met with in the period to which it is limited, depends mainly upon the public spirit of the young men. They are the class from which alone serviceable soldiers can be obtained. "Young men for war" is the accepted maxim in all nations.

Under an arrangement with the Federal authorities for the appointment of four Military Commissioners in each Congressional District, the former to appoint two and the Governor two, to aid in raising volunteers, Gov. SEYMOUR has appointed the following officers:

In accordance with the custom and laws of this State, I, HORATIO SEYMOUR, Governor of the State of New-York, do hereby designate Thursday, the 26th instant, to be a day of thanksgiving and prayer, and I hereby declare the same to be a legal holiday.

The advance of Gen. MEADE, if pushed with the vigor the occasion demands, should disturb the rebel plans for an offensive campaign in East Tennessee. It was the avowed belief of the rebels, in their late advance movement in Virginia, that the destruction of the railroad would so embarrass the Union army that the season available for active operations this Fall would be consumed, and that a small force would serve to cover Richmond...

As regularly as the Municipal election comes round, feeble groans begin to issue from the property-holders of this City touching the increasing weight of taxation, and the growing abuses and corruption of the City Government.

The Legislature met in Jefferson City to-day and adjourned untill to-morrow for want of a quorum. News from below says JEFF. DAVIS is about to send commissions to notorious bashwhackers in Arkansas, to raise men to carry on a guerrilla warfare.

PRISONERS DISPOSED OF. The captured rank and file temporarily crammed into the Old Capitol Pilson were sent yesterday to Point Lookout. Fifty-eitht more prisoners were brought up to-day. All these prisoners will soon be transmitted to Johnson's Island, off Sandusky, Lake Erie. This would indicate that the resumption of exchanges is as far off as ever.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Nov. 10. 1863--6 P.M. The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 14 bbls. Ashes, 13,825 bbls. Flour, 1,325 bbls. and 1,457 bags. Corn Meat, 78,611 bushels Wheat, 15,725 bushels Corn, 11,377 bushels Barley, 6,694 bushels Peas, 197,293 bushels Oats, 2,073 pkgs. Provisions and 517 bbls. Whisky.

Gen. ROSECRANS having been received, with a popular ovation by the people of Cincinnati, is on a visit to his family at Yellow Springs. The removal of a General from one post to another, or his retirement for a time, ought to excite no extraordinary comment--if the Press of NewYork and Washington had not made it.
The steamer Wann has arrived from Memphis with 470 bales of cotton for Cincinnati and 33 for Louisville. Her news is anticipated.

The letter of Mr. G.B. LAMAR to FERNANDO WOOD, proposing a joint stock blockade running undertaking, which first saw the light in the columns of the TIMES, has been republished in the Southern papers, and has created great excitement. The Richmond Examiner, of Nov. 2. says:

The slow depreciation of Federal currency is one of the most remarkable phenomena of this extraordinary war. Contrasting the market prices of Confederate with those of Federal money gives a low opinion of Mr. Hunter's, compared with Mr. Chase's, financial abilities.

A Stockholm journal reports a recent speech of the King of Denmark, in which he declared his readiness, in case of his States being overpowered by Germany, to start a Republic, to consist of the Danish Isles. The King said: "I will descend from the throne to proclaim the Republic. I am convinced that no people in Europe is more fitted for the Republican sceptre than my dear Danish people."
Dates have been received from Hakodadi, Japan, up to Oct. 6.
The main force of the rebels were at Gordonsville yesterday and Monday morning, making two-forty time to Richmond.

About twenty-five refugees, men, women and children, mostly from Richmond, arrived here last evening. They came into our lines at Portsmouth, and had been several days upon their journey, having tell Richmond on Tuesday last.

Gen. LEE, it is pretty evident, declines to take up the guage of battle which Gen. MEADE has urgently pressed upon his acceptance. The Army of Virginia, excepting its rear guard, have again ensconced themselves within their strong fortifications on the south bank of the Rapidan, or are making swift time toward Richmond.

It was stated, several days ago, that two of Gen. BURNSIDE'S most eastern outposts in Tennessee had been attacked by the rebels, and that half of the garrison, consisting of two regiments and a battery, had been captured.

The special dispatches from Cincinnati give an account of a singular story about two suspicious vessels discovered yesterday hovering about Sandusky Bay, supposed to be privateers fitted up by Secessionists in Canada, aided by their sympathizers there and in the United States. The supposed object is to release the rebel prssoners on Johnson's Island, and commence piracy on the lakes and pillage on the land.

No satisfactory arrangement has been made with the Navy-yard workmen, and the strike still continues.
The Extra Session of the Massachusetts Legislature assembled at noon to-day.

GENERAL: I have the honor to submit herewith a report of the operations of this army during the month of July, including details of the battle of Gettysburgh. The report has been detained by my failure to receive the reports of the several corps and division commanders, who were severely wounded in the battle.
Recorder HOFFMAN occupied the Bench yesterday, Judge McCUNN being necessarily absent.
The bark Venus, Capt. ATKINSON, from Curacoa, arrived yesterday morning, bringing dates to Oct. 22
In Brazilian brig Iabciao, from Pernambuco. Capt. H. Manter. late of ship Samuel Robinson, of New-Bedford, condemned.

On the 12th inst., the United States gunboat Tahoma, Lieut.-Commander SIMMES, after three months' repairing and preparation, and taking on board a 200-pound Parrott rifle, left here for Tampa Bay, arriving on the evening of the 13th, where she found the United States steamer Adela, Acting Volunteer Lieut. STODDER, and schooners Stonewall Jackson and Ariel, blockading.

It is positively ascertained that the whole rebel infantry force crossed the Rapidan on Sunday last. The only forces left this side are recoconnoitering bands of STUART'S cavalry, covering the rebel front on the south bank of the Rapidan, which they are fortifying with care.

The rebel General RICHARDSON struck the Memphis and Charleston Railroad six miles east of Salisbury yesterday morning, destroyed the railroad bridge at Middletown burned two small bridges, tore up several miles of track, and cut the telegraph badly. The latter was repaired this morning. The former will be in running order to-morrow.

Between 5 and 6 o'clock yesterday morning the porter-house No. 48 Madison-street, kept by Mr. JOSEPH KING, was the scene of a most revolting murder. A man named JOHN CUSICK, aged about 23 years, was shot dead, the ball penetrating the region of the heart. Two men, named JAMES WHITE and THOMAS BROWN, were arrested immediately after the shooting by Sergeant JOHN DELANY, of the Tenth Precinct, aided by Officers CRAIG and LOCKWOOD.
The State of Indiana has already more than half raised her quota under the last call of the President, and the residue will be ready in about two weeks.
The General position of the Army of the Potomac is mainly unchanged. Gen. BEFORD yesterday passed through Culpepper, and reconnoitered the enemy's position on the Rapidan.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
The United States Court is in session. Two men, named SMITH snd VAN BUREN, were tried for enticing soldiers to desert, and were both acquitted.

The young Territory of Nevada is putting up silver bars against treason. The following letter announces the second bar of silver sent from that distant community to the United States Christian Commission, the first "brick " having netted upward of $2,200, and the present one over $1,300.

A meeting of the telegraph operators of this city was held this evening, to testify their respect for the memory of their deceased fellow-operator, FRANK T. McINTIER. Messrs. JAMES ELVERSON, JAMES MOLAN and W.F. SHIEDLER were appointed to draft suitable resolutions, and reported the following, which were unanimously adopted:
Arrived ship Aquella, from New-York. Markets are quiet. Much of the Fall trade seems over.

Your Committee beg leave to report, after such inquiry as a short time permits them to make of the Government Commissioners and citizens of Vicksburgh, the following results, to wit:

Yesterday afternoon, Capt. UPTON, who commanded the brigade which last Saturday so successfully charged and captured the enemy's works at Rappahannock Station, accompanied by deputations from each of the regiments participating in the assault, presented Gen. MEADE with eight battle flags taken at that time. No previous notice had been given, and the affair was entirely unexpected and unprovided for.

MOST RESPECTED SIR: Since I last had the honor to address you in January 1862, the courage, skill and perseverance manifested by you in your efforts to maintain and defend our Union of States, with all their rightful authority and power, has commanded my heartfelt gratitude, confidence and respect.

In the recent affair at Rodgersvile, Gen. BURNSIDE'S forces were overwhelmed by superior numbers. Gen. BURNSIDE has taken over 1,500 prisoners since he came into Tennessee, independent of the garrison at Cumberland Gap, putting us far ahead of the rebels.
Present William Walsh, Esq., President, and the following members:
The following was received here to-day: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 11-Midnight.

The drivers and conductors on several of the principal City Railroads have struck for higher wages, and as the companies have not seen fit to comply, with their demands, three or four of them were compelled to suspend operations yesterday. As a matter of course, this led to very serious public inconvenience, and for a variety of reasons the public sympathy does not, as a, general thing, go with the companies.

The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool at noon, 29th, via Londonderry 30th ult., passed this Point at 8 o'clock this morning:

THE CHOSEN FREEHOLDERS AND THE BOUNTY QUESTION. The Board of Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County, at their meeting yesterday afternoon, discussed at considerable length the subject of raising the quota under the last call, by offering a bounty in order to equalize the taxation throughout the county.
A meeting of the subscribers to the Riot Fund, for the benefit of Policemen and others, was held yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, at the Hall of the Chamber of Commerce.

All is quiet in front, and positions are mainly unchanged. Any discussion of prospective movements would be contraband. The public may be assured that such a thing as idleness and losing time has no place here, and it will thunder again in this quarter of the sky before it clears up.

Richmond papers of the 11th inst., received at Fortress Monroe, contain the following items of news:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Within the last week I have seen several articles, both in the NEW-YORK TIMES and the Baltimore American, in regard to our paroled prisoners returned from Richmond. These accounts seemed horrible enough to have aroused the sympathy and indignation of the people, and yet, with the exception of a few persons, they were either passed by or forgotten as being among the inevitable horrors of civil war.
The Cotton Market is buoyant with an advance of d. @ d. The sales of three days foot up 40,000 bales, of which speculators and exporters took 20,000. The market closed somewhat easier.

There is something very extraordinary in the impunity enjoyed by the guerrillas who are operating within our lines in Virginia. From "gobbling up" small parties of our men, cutting off trains, robbing sutlers, and stampeding mules and horses, these gentry have now commenced the practice of assassination on a great scale. They lie in wait in the woods, singly or in parties of two or three, and fire upon passing officers or soldiers.

The military authorities of the Eleventh District of Pennsylvania are making short work with the Carbon Thugs. The call of the mine owners for assistance was promptly answered on Sunday, by the arrival at Beaver Meadows of two companies of the Invalid corps, under the command of, Capt. D.L. BECKWITH, as senior Captain and ranking officer.

Nothing of special interest was done in the Legislature yesterday. The Governor's Message relates almost entirely to State matters. It recommends that inducements be held out by the State to emigrants from all countries. Of the relations of the State to the Federal Government, it says :
The Richmond Whig, of Nov. 11, contains the following:

Detachments of our infantry and cavalry this morning handsomely thrashed STUART'S cavalry near Mitchell's Station, three miles southwest of Culpepper. The rest of the army was quiet; but it is the quiet that precedes the storm. We now hold all the ground in Culpepper County that we held six weeks ago.

A very large meeting of the citizens of Wilmington was held at the City Hall on the evening of Friday, Nov. 6, which was addressed by Messrs. H.J. RAYMOND, of New-York, and BUTLER G. NOBLE, of Wisconsin. Mr. RAYMOND'S remarks were substantially as follows:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of "La Somnambula" was the attraction here last night. How marvelously fresh and charming are the melodies in this work, notwithstanding the many, many years of hackneying they have had to undergo! Would that we had more of such subjects treated in so superb a manner.
Consuls, after official hours yesterday, closed at 92 7/8@93. The markets were flat all round, that for foreign stocks especially.

Gen. FOSTER has been assigned to the command of Gen. BURNSIDE'S army, and will leave here to-morrow. BURNSIDE'S resignation has been accepted by the President.
Everything is quiet here and in this vicinity.

We notice the affirmance in the United States Circuit Court of the decree of forfeiture against the bark Augusta as a slaver. Our readers will recollect that she was a vessel fitted out by the notorious APPLETON OAKSMITH, of this City.
Quiet in and around Chattanooga prevails.

The Persia's news had little effect on the markets, though much surprise was evinced at the removal of Gen. ROSECRANS. The Cotton market is firm at unchanged races. Sales, to-day, 8,000 bales, including 4,000 bales to speculators and exporters.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: I beg to reply to your Washington correspondent's dispatch, under the above head, in your paper of the 6th inst. In the course of it he says, in italics:

United States vs. The Schooner Ezilda and Cargo. NELSON, C.J. The vessel and cargo in this case were captured about the 12th of October, 1861, by United States steamer South Carolina, while attempting to break the blockade off New-Orleans. The proof is full on this point.

The following plan for recruiting operations has been submitted to us for publication by an officer from the West who has had large experience in high position, and who is connected with the government of a State that has furnished the most successful example of voluntary enlistment:
The Legislature of Massachusetts convened in special session on Tuesday last, for the purpose of adopting measures to promote recruiting for the army by supplying the State's quota.

A very active political canvass is going on in Delaware for the election of a Member of Congress. Mr. SMITHERS, the Union candidate, is a man of ability, an eloquent speaker and a thoroughgoing supporter of the Government in its prosecution of the war against the rebellion.

Several valuable prizes have recently been finally adjudicated, and the money will be ready for distribution in the course of a week or ten days. Among them are the Memphis, the Britannia and the Victory. The former was captured by the United States steamer Magnolia, and yielded the snug sum of $510,914.07, after paying the expenses of adjudication.
The War Department has received dispatches from Gen. THOMAS, at Chattanooga, and from Gen. BURNSIDE, in East Tennessee.

The World comes promptly and properly to the rescue of the Central Railroad management. As the special guardian of the Democratic interest in this State, that journal becomes necessarily the special champion of its most powerful ally.
The steamship Yazoo, from New-Orleans 4th instant, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The picture drawn by an eye-witness of the condition of the paroled prisoners just returned from Richmond, which was given in our last issue, though so horrible, we trust was not passed over by any of our readers.
FELLOW CITIZENS: New-York State has but a few weeks within which to raise her quota of over one hundred thousand men by volunteering.

Oliver W. Bird vs. Henry H. Hayden. The defendant was one of the Directors of the "Dagget Manufacturing Company," a corporation formed and organized under the laws of Massachusetts, located and having its place of business at Attleborough, in the State of Massachusetts. This action was brought to recover the amount due upon two promissory notes made by the agent of the corporation, each for $995.50.

The British force which lately assailed Kagosima was more formidable, the fight more desperate, the result more tragic, than the account via San Francisco led us to suppose.

Among the numerous movements in various branches of labor which have been inaugurated within the past week, none is more worthy of serious and abiding notice, or sadder, than that of the working woman. We say sadder, because while almost every branch of man's work, striking for enhancement of wages, will be successful, that of women will be, as always heretofore, a fruitless effort.
To the Editor of the New-York Times. We, the "Drivers" of the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company, return to you our sincere thanks for your advocacy of our cause in your valuable journal.

The transport Pioneer, from Fortress Monroe, when arriving at Jersey City, ran into the schr. Wm. Bement, loaded with Government stores, for Alexandria, carrying away the schooner a jih-boom with rigging attached, which will cause her delay for several days.

The McKeonites have disposed of their part in the Mayoralty question, by heretofore nominating Mr. GUNTHER, and this evening hold their Judicial Conventions; on Monday evening they hold their Councilmanic and Aldermanic Conventions, and during the week the delegates meet for nomination of School Officers.

The ingenuity and industry with which both the English Courts and the Press have searched through the whole history of our jurisprudence for precedents to justify their action in the case of the rebel privateers, would be something admirable in any other cause.

The late fight at Pine Bluff occurred on Sunday morning, the 25th ult., about 8 o'clock. The rebels attempted a surprise on Col. CLAYTON, by 4,000 rebel cavalry. The troops were commanded by Gens. MARMADUKE and CABELL. Col. CLAYTON had an hour's notice of their approach, and immediately set himself about preparing for defence.

Reports were brought to Washington, last night, of engagements on the Rapidan, between the opposing cavalry forces. As on Sunday, the fighting was in the vicinity of Stevensburgh, but there are no details given. The enemy captured a wagon train, on Sunday, near Stevensburgh.

As before announced, the return of Mr. BEECHER from his tour to Great Britain and the Continent is to be celebrated by his congregation in fitting style. Never at a loss in devising resources for securing rational and positive enjoyment, there is a probability that on this occasion they will furnish the lovers of good things with a better opportunity than ever before for testing their abilities in this direction.

We are much pleased to learn that the Government has been enabled to send supplies of clothing and victuals to our suffering prisoners in Richmond. There is a strong movement on foot for the nomination of Gen. Dix for mayor. It has its origin apparently in the ranks of the Democratic party, with men of position and character, who are dissatisfied with the selection made by the two wings of that party, and seek to rally the people en masse to the support of another man.
The Inman steamship City of London, Capt. PETRIE, which left Liverpool at noon on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived here at 6 o'clock last evening.

TWENTIETH WARD CLUB OF INDEPENDENT CITIZENS. The members of this Club, composed principally of the most prominent German citizens of this Ward, held a meeting last Friday evening at Nehring's Hall, No. 465 Eighth-avenue, for the purpose of nominating candidates for Police Justice and Councilman. The meeting was largely attended, and a unanimity of action prevailed. After the ordinary business was disposed of the President of the Club.

In the nomenclature of medicine there is no disease so little thought of and yet none, when permitted to become chronic, so subtle or so fatal in its character as catarrh. It often originates in coryza, or ordinary cold, and as such, when the inflammation is local, extending not beyond the Schniederian membrane, it is readily reached and with proper attention may be removed.

The great gun, which has been for some months in course of construction for the navy by Mr. JOHN ERICSSON, arrived in this City a few days ago, and is now at one of the Iron Works being prepared for service. For obvious reasons we are not permitted to state its location. It is one of the most marvelous inventions of the time, and if successful, will revolutionize naval ordnance.

Much has been written and said on the extent and quality of the tobacco crop of 1863, showing that from droughts and a scarcity of plants that a limited crop was planted, which was generally damaged by the September frosts, and in many districts ruined.

Neither Board of the Common Council had a quorum at their meetings yesterday, most of the members being engaged in matters pertaining to the ensuing Charter election. The Aldermen Stand adjourned to 1 o'clock, and the Councilmen to 4 o'clock P.M., on Thursday.

Rumors reach here to-night of cavalry fighting today on the Rapidan. Firing was heard yesterday in the direction of Stevensburgh, and again to-day in the same direction. The rebels captured a wagon train yesterday near Stevensburgh. The cause of the firing to-day is not known up to this hour, 11 P.M.

The Greek tragedians were fond of introducing upon the stage the hereditary misfortunes of particular families, which, for some inexpiable sin committed by one of their line, were doomed to be the victims of a Divine persecution. Whatever these unfortunate people undertook whatever they set their hearts upon was sure, before long, to turn to their destruction.

Some days since the French residents of the City tendered to Admiral RENAUD, of the La Guerriere, and the officers of the other French men-of-war in the harbor, the compliment of a banquet, which was accepted, and which took place at Irving Hall last evening.

SIR: The continued depredations of the rebel cruisers on the mercantile marine of the country have not only destroyed a large amount of the active capital of the merchants, but seriously threaten the very existence of that valuable part of our commerce.

The firing from the rebel batteries on Sullivan's Island yesterday was more heavy and rapid than it had been for some days previous. Mortars were used principally. A very few shots were thrown from the James Island batteries. We replied sparingly. Only one casualty occurred on our side.

ARREST OF A RIVER THIEF AN AMUSING SCENE AROUND THE TOMBS. Officers SULLIVAN and CORNELL, of the Harbor Police, arrested a notorious river thief named JOHN SULLIVAN, on the charge of having stolen, upon several occasions recently, large quantities of rope from vessels to the harbor.
Forty-five prisoners, among them one Captain and three Lieutenants, captured by Major FITZGIBBON, of the Fourteenth Michigan, at Lawrenoeburgh, reached this city to-day.

GENERAL ORDER, No. 47. The Committee in charge of the arrangements for the dedication of the National Cemetery for the freemen who fell on the field at Gettysburgh have appointed that the ceremonies shall take place on Thursday, the 19th of November, 1863.

The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia has just decided that it cannot limit the sale of rebel estates under the Confiscation act to the term of the traitor's life; that such limitation is not the intent of the act of Congress, and in the case of HUGE LATHAM, the Court, by Judge UNDERWOOD, ordered a sale and an execution of a deed in tee by the Sheriff to the purchaser.

LECTURE BY JUDGE KELLY, OF PHILADELPHIA. The next lecture in the course of the Women's Loyal National League will be delivered by Judge KELLY, of Philadelphia, at the Cooper Institute, on Friday evening of this week.

Yesterday afternoon a most outrageous homicide was committed by a driver of one of the "Dry Dock" line of stages. The victim was Mr. HUGH LANCEY, residing at No. 335 Tenth-street, a gentleman over 55 years of age. The driver is well known among his associates by the name of "Dutch Smith." What his real name is did not transpire.

A preliminary meeting, for the purpose of forming a Working Women's Protective Association, was held last evening at No. 187 Bowery. Delegates were present from many leading houses where women are employed, and the personal comeliness and bright intelligence for which this class of NewYork's population is famous, were very fairly represented.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 52. In obedience to Paragraph 13, War Department Special Orders No. 497, of the 9th inst., and Special Orders No. 99, from the headquarters of the Department of the East, the undersigned turns over the command of the City and Harbor of New-York, to Brig.-Gen. GEORGE J. STANHARD, United States Volunteers.

The news from East Tennessee this morning is late and important. There seems to be no doubt but that the rebels are operating in considerable force against BURNSIDE from the Southwest, and that this force is a part of BRAGG'S army, detached for that especial purpose, and commanded, probably, by LONGSTREET.

It was appointed by law in Athens, that the obsequies of the citizens who fell in battle should be performed at the public expense, and in the most honorable manner. Their bones were carefully gathered up from the funeral pyre, where their bodies were consumed, and brought home to the city.

The County Canvassers met at 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, and the matter of the returns from the Tenth District of the Eighth Ward was immediately brought up. Anticipation of an interesting discussion upon it had attracted a crowd of spectators larger than the room would accommodate, so that, when it was well filled, the Sergeant-at-Arms guarded the door against the further incoming of any persons but those connected with the Board.

At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, the Croton Aqueduct Board sent in a communication in regard to the construction of a storage reservoir in the valley of the Croton River. The subject was referred to a Special Committee, and Messrs. JEREMIAH, HARDY and OTTIWELL were appointed.

We have late and very important news from Gen. BURNSIDE'S Department this morning. The enemy Tuesday commenced an attack upon Gen. BURNSIDE'S position near Knoxville, and it seems that in the first encounter our troops, which were wholly composed of cavalry and mounted infantry, were compelled to yield, and fell back a short distance to a stronger position.

Yesterday the Emperor delivered his anxiously looked for speech at the opening of the Chambers, and the public are naturally absorbed to-day in its consideration. By general consent the speech is colorless and meaningless the mountain has given birth to a mouse.

The ceremonies attending the dedication of the National Cemetery commenced this morning by a grand military and civic display, under command of Maj.-Gen. COUCH. The line of march was taken up at 10 o'clock, and the procession marched through the principal streets to the Cemetery, where the military formed in line and saluted the President. At 11 the head of the procession arrived at the main stand.

We devote a broadside of this morning's TIMES to the publication of two orations which we are sure will command the attention of the day. And not of this day only. Elaborate and finished discourses from two such men as EDWARD EVERETT and HENRY WARD BEECHER, upon topics of such great National interest as those they discuss, will not lightly be passed over, much less ignored altogether, by any intelligent citizen.

The Mercantile Mutual Insurance Company vs. The New-Haven Steamboat Company. This was an action at common law to recover the damages occasioned by a collision which occurred in the East River, on the 19th of November, 1861, between the defendants' steamboat Continental and a canal-boat called the Charles Hubbell, laden with corn, while in tow of the steam-tug Helen Brown, whereby the corn was damaged.

Schuchardt Gebhard vs. Reimerset al. This was an action to make the defendants liable upon a bill of exchange drawn by them on Seibring Son, of London, for 784 6s, 5d., and accepted by the latter. The plaintiff received about half the amount of the bill from Seibring Son, and Seibring Son then failing, the plaintiff discharged them from all further liability on the bill by erasing and canceling their acceptance.

RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. During the past week, some sixty recruits have been sworn in and sent to Riker's Island. On Saturday, twelve enlisted. The prospects are that there will be a large increase during the present week. As no Surgeon has yet been appointed for Gen. SPINOLA'S headquarters, a good deal of difficulty is experienced in procuring the examination of recruits.

GETTYSBURGH, Pa., Friday Evening, Nov. 20, 1863. The dedication of the National Cemetery, which passed off so auspiciously here yesterday, has been followed to-day by a most lamentable occurrence which has spread gloom over the village of Gettysburgh, and added one, and perhaps two more victims to those deadly missiles which were hurled over this town, filling the air like hail-stones in a storm, on the 2d and 3d of July last.

It has been stated that the iron-clad Dictator would be launched on Thanksgiving Day. We are requested to say that this is not so, as the launch will not take place till Saturday, the 28th inst. No tickets of admission to the vessel can be given, as the ship-house is only large enough to accommodate the workmen making the launch. Only a few officers of the United States Navy will be admitted into the ship-house.

Great military events, whether favorable or adverse, impress everybody. But few make any account of the little contingencies on which these events turn. A mighty battle or grand campaign is a mighty sensation; but the minor circumstances, antecedent or collateral, which decide the fate of a battle or campaign, generally pass almost unnoticed.

The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, other have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and soften even the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Salvador arrived from Central American ports on Sunday. She brings dates from Guatemala to the 7th, Salvador to the 10th, Nicaragua to the 12th, and Costa Rica to the 14th. She has but little freight for New-York, viz.: 1,576 hides, 49 bales deerskins, 17 seroons cochineal, 2 bags coffee, 2 bales cotton, 2 cases mats, 8 cans balsam, 1 box silver, 1 parcel gold.

CINCINNATI, Friday, Nov. 27. We have some reports from Knoxville which seem to indicate that Gen. BURNSIDE is perfectly secure in his position. The rebel cavalry are now in the country lying between Cumberland Gap and Knoxville, but no damage has been done to our communications with Gen. BURNSIDE as yet.

The great barrier to the enemy's advance at Chattanooga is Lookout Mountain. This is Bragg's stronghold, and his position there is so impregnable to an assault that the enemy has not had the temerity yet to attempt to carry it. Yet he is busy with his operations, and it may be that he may soon attempt a forward movement. The army correspondent of the Savannah Republican writes:

WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 28. E.A. PAUL writes the following:

A book, entitled Notes on the Rebel Invasion of Maryland and Pennsylvania, and the Battle of Gettysburgh, by Dr. JACOBS, of the Pennsylvania College at Gettysburgh, has made its appearance, and is circulating somewhat in the Army of the Potomac. Regarding the battle of Gettysburgh, it contains several serious errors, which the following letter emphatically corrects, and gives to the world a piece of eloquent history, yet imperfectly known outside of mili- tary circles:

By the arrival of the steamer Corsica at this port yesterdy, we have later advices from Havana, Nassau, and Santo Domingo. The revolution in the latter island presented no new features. Everything was quiet. At Nassau, N.P., the blockade business had assumed increased activi- ty. A dozen vessels were in port, bound on this trade. A rumor was current at Havana that the sloop-of-war St. Louis had sunk the pirate Georgia, off Canary Islands.

Army officers from Bealton Station to-night report that heavy cannonading was heard since early this morning in the direction of Orange Court-house. The firing was so heavy and continuous as to preclude the possibility of its being a skirmish. It was their opinion a general engagement was in progress at the time they last heard the firing, which was at 11 o'clock this forenoon.

Information received from the Army of the Potomac up to Monday noon. The election for Directors of the New-York Central Railroad takes place next week. The indication of a purpose on the part of the stockholders to effect a reform in its management, has aroused its present officers to unusual and remarkable efforts to retain their places.

I have again to record the lamentable fact that the navy lies unmoved off Charleston Harbor. Why Admiral DAHLGREN does not push forward and make an attempt, if nothing more, to gain possession of the inner harbor, is an enigma to us all.

The canvass for Speakership continues active, but in good feeling. As members come in, the preponderance in favor of COLFAX is very manifest. His friends claim three-fourths of the vote of the entire caucus. It is probable that a caucus of Union members will be held on Saturday night to nominate a candidate for the Speakership. Other officers of the House may not be nominated until Monday night.

Gen. HITCHCOCK, the officer who has had the general direction of matters referring to the exchange of our prisoners, has written to the TIMES a highly important letter upon the subject, to which we give place this morning.

WHEELER'S division of 5,000 rebels.

By the arrival of the schooner Oliver S. Breeze, from Vera Cruz on the 26th October, we have been put in possession of some late and important facts in regard to Mexican affairs. When the Breeze left Vera Cruz a report was prevalent in the city among the French that the Mexicans had recaptured Puebla. There was no doubt of the truth of the report, although no particulars are given.

Since the late successful movement of our army on the Rappahannock, we have been lying encamped near Brandy Station, with little or nothing to break in upon the monotony of camp life, or to mar the quiet that seems to pervade an army after active movements against the enemy.

There is no room for doubt that the rebels employ bloodhounds to track and catch Union men for the purpose of forcing them into the rebel army. Hon. LUCIEN ANDERSON, of Kentucky, Congressman elect, who was recently captured by rebel guerrillas and afterward released by exchange, says the rebels had bloodhounds with them. He saw the dogs. He conversed with conscripts who had been chased, caught and lacerated by them, their wounds being yet unhealed.
The steamship Columbia, from Galway on the 24th of November, arrived here at 6 o'clock this (Saturday) evening.

A HOTEL THIEF IN CUSTODY. Mr. JOHN GALLAGHER, night watchman at the Merchants' Hotel, in Cortlandt-street, detected one of the lodgers in the house, named THOMAS RILEY, in the attempt to enter the room of Mr. JOHN PINKERTON, another lodger, at about two o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. GALLAGHER observed RILEY leaving his room and saw him attempt to open the door of his fellow-lodger's room, by means of a false key.

The plan of pumping out the sunken Acquilla containing the iron monitor, has been abandoned. Proposals are advertised for to raise the ship, and offers made to give bonds for $500,000. A company of wealthy men are forming to contract for the job.

The rebels, after burning their stores at Chicamauga Station, continued their march southward. At every mile they left deserters, and the road was strewn with guns, haversacks, and blankets, which they could not carry. It was supposed that as they were going tolerably far South, they would not need their blankets. It is certain they went in great haste. Their march was very different from that of this army when it fell back from Chickamauga.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. FLOTOW'S opera of "Martha" was given here last night with complete success. It was the best performance of Mr. ANSCHUTZ'S season, and we are glad to state was enjoyed by a fine and fashionable house. Mme. FREDERICK and Herr HIMMER were heard to great advantage.

The monitor Weehawken sunk at her moorings off Morris Island, S.C., on Sunday last, during the prevalence of a gale. Thirty of her crew perished, among whom were four of her engineers. The Captain and remainder of the officers are safe. The other monitors rode out the storm.

Collector WASHBURNE has just received the following from Halifax:

REV. HENRY WARD BEECHER My Dear Sir: In your addresses to the people of England you have spoken of Slavery in this country, as being a constitutional institution, and of our Government and nation as under a binding compact not to intertere against it. The Postmaster-General Reports, that during the last fiscal year the financial condition of his Department has been one of unusual prosperity. The revenue has nearly equaled the expenditures the latter amounting to $11,314,266 84, and the former to $11,163,789 59. There is good reason to believe that the department will be self sustaining in a brief period of time.

Gov. STANFORD delivered his annual message to the State Legislature to-day. It exhibits a state of finances more favorable than was anticipated. It represents the agricultural, mining and manufacturing interests in an improving conditton, and confidently predicts that the first fifty miles of the Pacific Railroad will be completed within the time required by the act of Congress. Allow me through the TIMES to inform the public of the prevalence of pocket-picking in this City. At churches, in and about places of amusement, at markets, in cars, and wherever people customarily crowd together, there is much danger of those having wallets about them unexpectedly finding themselves victimized.

About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a murder was committed in Worth-street, between Missionplace and Centre-street. JOHN KANE, a native of Ireland, aged about thirty years, was the victim. From the testimoney, so far as adduced, we learn that about the time named above, JOHN KANE, the deceased, met a colored man, named HARKLESS LITTLE, in Worth-street, near Cow Bay.

The Aldermen, as City canvassers, met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the ninth day of the session. It was expected that Alderman WALSH would as present to read off the returns from the Sixth Ward, which were all the returns that remained to be canvassed, but illness, which had prevented his attendance on the previous day, still kept him confined to his house.
The war in New-Zealand is a war of race against race, and both natives and colonists are straining every nerve to make adequate preparation for carrying on the deadly conflict.

The Grand Duke MAXIMILIAN, who is now at Vienna, is said by the Vienna Vorstadt Zaitung to have lately expressed himself, is conversation with his brother, the Emperor, in these words: "I will accept the crown of Mexico if I am offered the guarantees I have plainly and positively indicated in my speech to the Mexican Committee, and under the condition sine qua non that the reestablishment of the American Union becomes an impossibility."

Capt. Hill, of the Steamtug Odd Fellow, reports the ship W.F. Lindsay, Capt. Patten, from Havre, with mdse, and 300 passengers, went ashore last night on the West Bank, bilged and is full of water. Owing to the heavy sea Capt. Hill could not go alongside of her. The tug has gone to her again.

Telegrams were received here last evening from Knoxville up to yesterday morning. Gen. FOSTER had assumed the command of the troops lately under Gen. BURNSIDE, and the latter had departed from that City for Cincinnati. All was then quiet in the vicinity of Knoxville.

The Constitution for Nevada, which the people are to vote for or against on the 17th of January next, is published. It declares that every citizen owes paramount allegiance to the Federal Government. Neither the Legislature nor the people are permitted.

At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a mandamus by Justice LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, was presented, requiring the Board to show cause why the bill of District Attorney HALL, presented to the Board in May last, amounting to over $18,000, should not be paid.

The Court opened at 10 o'clock, FREDERICK MUNTER, heretofore indicted for murder in killing his mistress, plead guilty to manslaughter in the first degree, and the District-Attorney accepted the plea. He was remanded for sentence.

Col. MISENER reports from Columbia, that the rebel deserters and citizens are flocking to that post in great numbers, asking to be allowed to take oath under the President's Proclamation. Col. MISENEE says in regard to the numbers arriving, that he has never seen the like.

The Malden Bank was entered shortly before noon to-day. The son of the President was the only person in the bank at the time. He was murdered, and the bank robbed of about all its contents.

LONGSTREET'S action in his retreat from Knoxville has upset all the anticipations that could reasonably have been formed of what he would do. It was natural to suppose that, having withdrawn, foiled, from before Knoxville, he would make post haste into Virginia. Morever, when we reflect that he is cut off from all base of supplies, and is without any line of communications, it is difficult to see what other course was open to him.
Senor Romero, the Mexican Minister, left the Brevoort House yesterday for Washington.

The financial delusion which has brought the Confederacy into its present unhappy plight is one which is well worthy of our attention, inasmuch as it is one in which a large number of people at the North also are rather prone to indulge. It consists in the belief that a nation can pledge its whole property for the payment of a large debt, and that such a pledge is a good and substantial security.

We could hardly lay before the readers of the TIMES, more interesting matter than the alterations of the Excise Law, recommended by Commissioner LEWIS, of the Internal Revenue Bureau. The views of this able and accomplished official upon all subjects connected with his department have so great authority, that it is altogether probable that his recommendations will become law at an early period of this session of Congress.

EDITORS: In the present excited state of the public mind regarding the recent capture of the steamer Chesapeake, a few simple facts may correct the erroneous statements circulated by interested parties to embitter the minds of those who have leaned in their sympathies to the Southern cause. On Christmas Eve the counterfeiters were very numerous and very active among the shopkeepers throughout this City and Brooklyn. The performance of "Faust," last evening, was in many respects, one of the best ever given, of any opera, in the Academy of Music. The result of a few performances in Philadelphia was perceptible in the steadiness and certainty of all the artists.

The past week has been one of an unusually belligerent character. London and England have been in a state of great excitement, caused by three distinct battles, on three widely different fields of contest the battles and victories of Gen. GRANT on the Chickamauga, the great fight between HEENAN and KING, in which the champion of America was most unexpectedly beaten, and the pending battle between Mr. COBDEN and the Times newspaper.

Our soldiers have fared badly at times, owing to circumstances with which all are acquainted. The Yankees, last Spring and Summer, sent bands of marauders into the country lying between the Potomac and James Rivers.

Major-Gen. BUTLER returned this morning from Point Lookout, where he has made a thorough inspection of the prisons and hospitals. He also examined into the probabilities of a revolt among the rebel prisoners, and took important testimony in regard to rations and the condition of rebel subjects there, which testimony was satisfactorily correct.

The holidays are bare of news of a belligerent character. All the armies are quiet. The Army of the Potomac is paying more attention to sutler's supplies, fresh oysters, milk, , than to the enemy. Gen. GRANT'S army is building bridges and railroads. Gen. FOSTER is quiet at Knoxville. From all quarters, there is scarce a ripple to disturb the serene enjoyment of the holidays.

Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE and Staff left Knoxville on the 12th, and arrived in this city yesterday about noon. They had a severe journey through the mountains but made good time. The General received a salute upon landing at the Covington depot from a squad of artillery detailed from Newport barracks.
The British steamship Corsica, from Havana 19th, and Nassau 21st, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon.

It being the design of the General Commanding the department to occupy Chattanooga exclusively for military purposes, no encouragement will be given to traders or army followers who have left their homes to avoid enrollment and the draft, and to speculate on the soldiers' pay, and this class of persons will not be tolerated at this post.

FIRE. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in an unoccupied house in Sixteenth-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, owned by Mr. SAMUEL WARBELTON. The flames enreloped the entire structure, and the whole was consumed. Loss about $300. No insurance.

By the arrival of the steamships George Washington and Mississippi, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to the 19th inst. There was no stirring news, but affairs in Texas were very encouraging.

The steamship Atlantic, MAURY, from Aspinwall, Dec. 16, arrived at this port last evening. She brings a large amount of freight and His Excellency Ex-President BARRIOS and lady, of San Salvador, as passengers. She brings no treasure. The steamship North Star would sail for New-York, Dec. 17.

THE GREAT NORTHWESTERN FAIR. The footings of the great Northwestern Fair, as first published, and as still going the rounds of the Eastern press, were much too modest. Since the close many donations have reached here which were delayed, and the articles left on hand have been mostly sold.

The long-expected crisis in the public affairs of Prussia has not yet arrived, although the original differences between the King and the people have not diminished during the last few months, and some new provocations on his part have strongly tended to widen the breach between them.

At the meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, a resolution, by Mr. BLUNT, was adopted, making the Sunday Dispatch an official county paper the same as the Leader is that is, to publish papers passed by the Board and approved by the Mayor, or passed over his veto.

Company A, Second United States Regulars, (colored,) arrived in this City on Saturday evening, in the Daniel Webster, from Folly Island, Charleston Harbor. They are now quartered at the Park Barracks, where they will remain until the sailing of the next steamer for New-Orleans, whither they are going to join their regiments.

The Sub-Committee of three of the Ways and Means, charged with the duly of revising the Internal Revenue Bill during the recess of Congress, and preparing suggestions for its alteration, have as yet heldno meeting whatever, nor determined upon any recommendation of taxation of any article in the schedule.

A report of the removal of J.W. HOWES, Esq., from the office of Vice-Consul at Montreal, which impugned Mr. HOWES' loyalty, proves to be utterly groundless. Mr. HOWES resigned his office some time time ago, while he commanded, as he does still, the perfect, confidence of Consul-General GIDDINGS both as to his capacity and loyalty.

Christmas was quietly spent in camp. No important event marked the day.

THE FULTON MONUMENT.--It seems to be decided that the FULTON Monument be erected in Trinity Church Yard, but this is meeting, though it may be uselessly, with decided opposition. No more unsuitable place could have been selected, if the design is to keep the memory of the great inventor before the people.

Senators M.S. Wilkinson, Minnesota, and S.C. Pomeroy, Kansas; Jos. L. Johnson and John M. Hawley, United States Navy; Surgeon T.C. Wallace, Sixty-first New-York Volunteers; J.T. Champlin and wife, Maine; Thos. Cottman, New Orleans, and H.H. Joy, Albany, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

Kentucky is reported to have 119,577 enrolled militia, and to have sent to the U.S. Army 49,768; 38 counties, with an enrolled militia of 41,086, sent 28,741. Monroe, on the south border, with 704 enrolled, furnished 613 three years' and 188 one year volunteers. Kentucky's quota (about 12,000) is being raised from the 72 delinquent counties.

An accident occurred last night at Bristow Station. A train of ten cars, from Brandy Station for Alexandria, owing to the switch being placed the wrong way, ran on to the side track, and on reaching the end of it, the locomotive and four cars were thrown down an embankment a distance of eight feet. Two men on the top of a car, and another inside were killed, and six or seven persons were wounded.

The steamship Atlantic, MAURY, from Aspinwall, Dec. 16, arrived at this port on Saturday. She brings a large amount of freight and His Excellency Ex-President BARRIOS and lady, of San Salvador, as passengers. She brings no treasure. The steamship North Star would sail for New-York, Dec. 17.

The weather was propitious for Mr. MARETZEK'S matinee on Saturday, and the house was handsomely filled with a surging and ever-shifting sea of crinoline, bonnets and feathers. MOZART'S opera of "Don Giovanni" was played, and several persons-- mostly from the country--listened to it. The cast was unexceptionable, especially of the female roles. Mr. MARETZEK presided in the, orchestra, and everything under that gentleman's able direction passed off to the complete satisfaction of the audience.

The Russian admiral and seven Captains of his fleet waited upon Maj.-Gen. BUTLER to-day. They were received at the wharf by Capt. A.F. PUFFER, of the General's Staff, and escorted to the General's residence, where they were formally received by himself and staff.

The colored regiment which is being raised in this City, under the auspices of the Union League Club, has already over 500 men in camp at Riker's Island. This regiment is to belong to the regular army, and is numbered the Twentieth. It is the first colored regiment raised in this State, and the colored recruits enlisting in any part are to be assigned to it.

THE MISSING DEPUTY COLLECTOR.--Mr. WM. RUNCIE, Deputy Collector of Taxes and Assessments, Brooklyn, Eastern District, who has been mysteriously missing for the past two weeks, has turned up in New-Jersey. A letter was received by his wife on Saturday stating that he was very sick. It was feared that he had been foully dealt with.

Winter in Tennessee is supposed to be greatly milder than it is in New-York. It certainly should be so, when the geographical position is considered. But had a dweller beside the Northern lakes dropped suddenly into this sunny region, on Sabbath last, or the day or two preceding it, he would not have been conscious of any particularly abrupt transition.

The steamship Atlantic, from Aspinwall Dec. 16, arrived at this port Saturday. She brings the important intelligence that actual hostilities had broken out between the Republics of Ecuador and the United States of Colombia.

The recruiting headquarters at Lafayette Hall, which is said to be conducted in the interest of Gen. SPINCLA, has commenced a system of filling up the ranks that goes a little ahead of the bounty brokers.

We notice, in our latest intelligence from New-Orleans, that a free State Convention has recently been held in Louisiana, at which a delegation of colored men were admitted to seats. Who called this Convention, and who composed it, we are not aware; nor have we any distinct statement of the precise object of its deliberations.
Hon. OWEN LOVEJOY, M.C., last night opened a course of lectures here for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. He is to be followed by the ablest speakers of the country.

A great deal of the public criticism, of what is sometimes sneeringly called "Washington strategy," and which has lately been reopened with fresh energy on the occasion of the publication of the report of the General-in-Chief, appears to receive a false direction from mistaken notions as to the true functions of the central military authorities.
Maj. WM. VAN WAGNEN, One Hundred and Fiftieth New-York, Volunteers, to date July 1, 1863, for conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman, in making a false statement under oath.

THE CONTRACTS FOR CLEANING THE STREETS.-- The Brooklyn Board of Contracts last week awarded contracts for cleaning the streets of the Fourth and Fifth Wards, at more than double the rates paid last year, thereby proving that the city cannot be kept in even a passably decent condition for the sums heretofore paid for doing the work.

Gen. BUTLER has already put a new phase upon the matter of the exchange of prisoners. He has already succeeded in rescuing five hundred of our men from filth and starvation in Richmond.

At a meet ing held last evening, the Railroad Committee to whom was referred the matter of regulating the various railroad companies, submitted an ordinance in regard to the same, a former ordinance upon the same subject having been vetoed by the Mayor.

Steamship Olympus, McRa e, Liverpool 15th inst., and Queenstown 16th, with 405 steerage passengers and a general cargo to E. Cunard. Had strong westerly gales to the Banks, from thence winds from north and northeast. Passed a great many ships inward bound about 100 miles E. of Sandy Hook.

The Overland Mail and reached England with the following dates: Calcutta, November 9; Hong Kong, October 31, and Melbourne, October 24. The news generally has been anticipated by later telegrams. The report of the cotton crop in the northwest provinces of India is gloomy.

DAMAGE OVER $15,000. Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening a fire occurred in the three-story brick building situated on the northwest corner of Marketstreet and Water-street. Before the flames could be extinguished the entire buliding and contents were destroyed.
The mails for Europe by the Australasian will close on Wednesday at 8 A.M. The mails for Hamburg and the German States by the Bavaria will close on Wednesday at 10 A.M.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday received and referred to a Special Committee a communication from the Commissioners of Health, stating that there has been a great increase of malignant fevers in certain localities of the City, and recommending that an ordinance be passed compeling some more efficient system of ventilation in tenement houses.

Tallow was in limited request. A moderate inquiry prevailed for Hay, Hops, Hides, Wool, Petroleum and Tobacco. Freights were dull.

Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, of the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, offers a novel attraction to-night, and one to which we can refer with pleasure, inasmuch as it is fully as interesting to New-Yorkers as to Brooklynites. This very energetic manager has organized an English opera company, and to-night introduces the same in BALFE'S popular opera of the "Bohemian Girl."

By the arrival of the steamship Ariatic at this port yesterday, we have London files to the 21st ult., inclusive. They contain the following interesting items, which were not telegraphed from Cape Race:

The following has been published as an exact analysis of the fresh circular upon the Congress, issued by M. DROUYN DE LHUYS, on the 8th inst. The circular commences by mentioning that several sovereigns have accepted, without reserve, the invitation to the Congress, and that others have asked for a programme:

His Grace Archbishop HUGHES expired at his residence in Madison-avenue, last evening, at 7 o'clock, after a lingering illness, in which he suffered much, but endured with fortitude. He has been failing in body for more than a year past. During the past Summer he has been continually under the care of his physicians, Drs. CLARKS and WOOD.
COTTON Sales Monday and Tuesday, 7,000 bales, including 2,500 to speculators and exporters, market closing quiet and unchanged.

A Vienna dispatch of the 20th says that the Oesterreichische Zeitung of to-day denies the statement of the Presse, that Count DEGENFELD, the Minister of War, had tendered his resignation that Count CORONINI had been appointed his successor. Count DEGENFELD is only about to visit Cairo upon leave of absence, and will be provisionally replaced by Baron MERTENS.

EFFECTS OF THE COLD WEATHER. On Friday night the Susquehanna froze up so tightly that the railroad ferry-boat, with three hundred passengers on board, was locked up in the middle of the river, immovably tight. From that day to this not a mail has arrived in Washington; not a traveller has come to one of the hotels.

With a great majority of the Army of the Potomac, these are truly holidays. While there is no relaxation in discipline, the details of camp life are not so rigidly enforced as usual, and this relaxation makes all the soldiers buoyant in spirits and contented in mind.

The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 23d, via Queenstown on the 24th of December, passed this point en route to New-York, at one o'clock this (Saturday) morning. She was boarded by the news-boat of the Associated Press, and a summary, of her news obtained.

NON-ARRIVAL OF THE FORTIETH NEW-YORK This gallant regiment, which unanimously reenlisted for the war, is now en route from the Army of the Potomac to this City. Since Saturday afternoon the arrival of the regiment, via Philadelphia, has been hourly expected. The pleasing duty of receiving the veterans was assigned to the Seventy-first NewYork, Col. TRAFFORD.

By the arrival of the steamship Evening Star, from New-Orleans, we have advices to the 27th. There was nothing of special importance transpiring in the Department of the Gulf. Our forces in Texas, were making very encouraging progress, and meeting with very little resistance. Gen.

Seals have been affixed by the police to all warehouses in the town of Bialystock, and most minute searches have been made in each.

Many rumors continue to circulate in regard to rebel movements; but up to this time there is not the least evidence that the enemy intends to attack any of the points along the railroad line. Some say that the rebel movements are made for the purpose of hunting up conseripts and pressing every able availble man found into the rebel service.

Two days' later news from Europe reaches us via Cape Race, by the arrival there Saturday morning of the steamship City of Baltimore. We learn from the brief abstract of her news furnished by the telegraph, that the American ship Living Age, from Akyab for London, had been captured by the rebel pirate Tuscaloosa, and released on giving bonds for $160,000.

One of the most important Government cases ever worked up in this City, which was given in brief detail in yesterday's TIMES, was completed at a late hour on Saturday night, and has resulted in the seizure of about $6,000,000 in Confederate bonds, $1,000,000 in Confederate Treasury notes, and a large quantity of dies, printing presses, lathes, and other machinery for doing fine bank note engraving.

Gov. SEYMOUR has shown more than Falstaff's "alacrity at sinking." We did not suppose it possible for him, after the July riots, to add anything which should lower the public estimate of his personal independence or his official courage.

The Committees in Congress which have in charge the business of elaborating plans for the restoration of loyal government in the South, when military force has done its work, we trust will be in no hurry to report. Whatever their ability or diligence, they cannot at present discreetly settle upon any particular method.
The new City Governments of Boston, Roxbury, Cambridge, Newburyport and other cities were inaugurated to-day.

The Board of Aldermen for the year 1864 was organized last evening. There was a large attendance in the audience part of the chamber, anxiously awaiting the election of a President and minor officers, while inside the railing were a number of favored politicians, to see that everything went right.

The absence of Senator WHITE, now a prisoner at Richmond, leaves the Senate a tie vote. It will be claimed that in this case the existing officers of the Senate are entitled to retain their positions until successors are elected. If the Democrats concede this (which is not probable) the Senate will organize immediately. If not the contest will be prolonged.

A breif account of the movements of the forces under Gen. SHERMAN for the relief of Knoxville, will serve to show your readers what share of honor is due to the men who, after aiding in the reduction of Vicksburgh, and the evacuation of Jackson, in July last, moved from the Big Black to Memphis, and from thence, by long continued marching, to aid in driving BRAGG from his strong position in front of Chattanooga.

The State Legislature meets at Albany, to-day. The caucuses of the Union party and the Democrats were held last evening. Hon. THOS. G. ALVORD is the Union nominee for Speaker; Jos. B. CUSHMAN, of Oneida, for Clerk; CHARLES E. YOUNG, of Oswego, for Sergeant-at-Arms. The Democratic nominee for Speaker is JACOB L. SMITH, of New-York; JOHN C. JACOBS, of Kings, for Clerk; GILES VAN HORN, of Montgomery, for Sergeant-at-Arms.
Senator SPRAGUE arrived in this City, yesterday afternoon, and proceeded to Washington by the night train. He remained at the Astor House during his brief stay.
The Court opened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. The panel of jurors was called, and a fine of $25 each enforced upon over a hundred of them, for non-attendance.

The Navy Department has received official information in relation to the attack upon the gunboat Marblehead, in Stono Inlet on Christmas morning, by which Robert Brown, Lorenzo D. Shaw and Joseph Philips were killed, and Charles Morn, Alexander Henderson, John Hackett and Charles Semmes were wounded.

Yesterday, Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT sailed from the Navy-yard in the flagship Hartford, to assume command of the East Gulf Squadron. The Hartford, as stated some time since, has recently been renovated and completely overhauled in every way. The Navy Department has received official advices of the attack upon the gunboat Marblehead in Stono Riyer, S.C. The engagement between the vessels and rebel battery was quite severe. The Marblehead, Pawnse and C.P. Williams were engaged. The rebels were finally driven from their battery, leaving two guns, which were captured by an expedition from the vessels. The Marblehead was considerably injured, being struck five times. Our loss was 3 killed and 4 wounded.

The funeral of Archbishop HUGHES will take place on Thursday morning, at 10 o'clock, from St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street. His remains will be exposes at the cathedral to-day and to-morrow, from 9 o'clock in the morning until 9 at night, so that all who wish may behold them. Great preparations are making to have the ceremonies as solemn and imposing as possible.

Our Government will not permit Gen. BUTLER to be outlawed by JUDAH P. BENJAMIN. The exchange of prisoners, committed solely to him, will be continued in his hands. Secretary STANTON determined to-day to enlarge his powers and confirm his agency, by putting all the rebel prisoners in the United States under his care. There will be thirty thousand of them at Point Lookout within three weeks.

In the Union Senatorial caucus this evening, JAMES TERWILLIGER, of Onondaga, was nominated for Clerk by acclamation; also, AZEL, B. HULL, of Alleghany, Sergeant-at-Arms; SANDERS WILSON, of St. Lawrence, Assistant Sergeant-at-Arms; LAWRENCE VAN DUZEN, of Seneca, Doorkeeper; CASPAR WALTER, of Monroe, Assistant Doorkeeper , EDWARD TRAVEE, Second Assistant Doorkeeper; A.W. JOHNSON, Third Assistant Doorkeeper, and Messrs. COOX, AMES and MUNGER, were appointed a Committee to call future caucuses. The caucus then adjourned.

THE DISLOYAL OFFICERS. A communication from the Secretary of the Navy, in reply to a resolution of the Senate, giving the names of officers who have left the naval service since Dec. 1, 1860, and entered the Confederate service, was referred, and ordered to be printed.
Mr. SMITH, of Kentucky, (Union,) introduced a bill, which was referred; providing for the pay of the bounty and pensions for soldiers called out in the Departments of Ohio and Kentucky.

We published, yesterday, an abstract of Gen. McCLELLAN'S report of his operations while Commander of the Army of the Potomac. The original document will, probably, never meet the eyes of one of a thousand of

AMENDMENTS TO THE CONSCRIPTION LAW. No less than twenty-five different propositions to amend the Conscription Law were submitted in the Senate to-day. The bill before its Military Committee has the approval of the Secretary of War and Provost-Marshal-General. It will retain the three hundred commutation clause, and among other things borrowed from the French system, such as the requirement that the conscript shall be responsible for his substitute's service and fitness.

During the past year the people of NewYork have had reason to be thankful to Almighty God for the blessings of health and abundance Our mechanics have been actively employed, our farmers have been rewarded with generous returns for their labor. The benefactions of our State have been liberal to those suffering from want or infirmities.

Both Houses reassembled yesterday. The remains of Archbishop HUGHES were laid in state yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. During the entire day, from 5 in the morning until the doors were closed at 8 o'clock in the evening, the streets and avenues leading to the Cathedral were thronged with pilgrims to the shrine of His Grace, the late Archbishop of New-York.

The one hundred and third anniversary of Independent Royal Arch Lodge was held at Dodworth Hall last evening, upon which occasion a large number of invited guests, ladies and gentlemen, were present to witness the impressive ceremonial of an installation of officers.
We have received the Annual Report of Hon. LUOIUS ROBINSON, Comptroller of the State of NewYork. It is a very interesting document, but we have room only for an abstract of its principal features.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The performance of "Faust" last evening by the German artists attracted another overflowing audience, proving once more that the non-production of this work at the commencement of the season was a grave and unfortunate blunder. However, it is never too late to mend. A few such houses as that of last night will place the enterprise on a firm footing.

Nobody is so foolish that he does not now and then say a sensible thing, and Gov. SEYMOUR is no exception to the rule. His remarks, in his Message, touching the necessity for keeping up the State militia, are peculiarly sound, just and forcible. They would have been so even if made in time of peace, and they are doubly so now in time of war.

ENGLISH OPERA. Mr. HARRISON'S operatic experiment was made on Monday night, with success. Considering that Brooklyn is a cool place, and that learned divines there make a point of preaching down amusements, we might even say with tremendous success.
The annual message of Gov. ANDREW was delivered to-day. It is a very lengthy and comprehensive document.

The letter which we published yesterday from our Pekin correspondent, announcing the acceptance by China of the code of International Law, and of WHEATON'S great work as the exponent of that code, signalizes one of the most remarkable developments of these remarkable times.

JAMES BEST, who pleaded guilty to the charge of assulting a negro in Worth-street, during the riot week, was sentenced yesterday to two years in the State Prison.

THE RATE OF PAY TO OFFICERS. The Senate bill reducing the pay of officers when not in the field though on duty or under orders, gives Brigadier-Generals, $3,200; Colonels, $2,800; Lieut.-Colonels, $2,250; Majors, $1,875; Captains, $1,500; Lieutenants, $1,200. When absent on leave Brigadier-Generals, $2,500; Colonels, $2,100; Lieut.-Colonels, $1,680; Majors, $1,500; Captains, $1,200; Lieutenants, $900. The pay of Major-Generals has been reduced to $4,000 when on duty, and $3,000 when on leave.

A bill has been introduced into the State Legislature to amend the Present Police Law so as to remove the Metropolitan Police Department, as far as possible, from the control of party politics. It has come from all quarters; from NewYork to the 19th, direct; from Europe up to the 5th, 7th and 8th instant, and from the West up to the 21st instant. It puzzled the quid nunes which end to take hold of first.

The monthly report of the Department of Agriculture, for November, will soon be issued. Hereafter it will appear every two months only, as experience shows that a monthly report does not give time enough to correspondents to properly gather the information asked of them by the monthly circulars, nor does it allow mature consideration of the statistical matters embodied in the returns of these correspondents.

The troops are building cabins and preparing quarters for the Winter, and it is hoped that all of them will be housed in a short time and protected from the wretched weather which now prevails. Thomas D. Fletcher vs. The Steamer Cubana. This libel is filed to recover damages alleged to have been inflicted on the schooner Minerva, at sea, on the morning of June 19, 1860, in a collision with the Spanish steamer Cubana. The schooner is an English vessel, belonging to Nova Scotia. The accident occured about 4 or 4 o'clock in the morning, in lat. 25 48' N. lon. 62 18' W.

The quietude of this city was violently disturbed on Monday by a "murder most foul," in open daylight, in front of the principal "hotel," in the main street; SAMUEL BUNTON, of Oregon, and recently from Idaho, being the victim, and JASON LUCE the assassin.

Maj. COLE, in command of a battalion of Maryland cavalry, encamped in Loudon County, was attacked at four A.M. to-day by the guerrilla MOSBY, the latter's force being near four hundred strong.

MR. LINCOLN AND THE PENNSYLVANIA LEGISLATURE. The Republicans of the two Houses of the Pennsylvania Legislature have, on joint ballot, nominated ABRAHAM LINCOLN for the next Presidency. Their resolutions, with the preamble engrossed on parchment, have been committed to SIMON CAMERON to bring to Washington and present to the President. The Union League in Philadelphia will nominate Mr. LINCOLN on Monday night.

The German Opera has enjoyed the comparative success of one good house out of two. On Wednesday the attendance was excellent, sufficient to encourage visions of a bright and prosperous future. These were dispelled on the following night, (Friday,) when the lieges, for reasons best known to themselves, were anything but loyal.

The steamship Columbia, Capt. BARTON, from New-Orleans, Dec. 3 via Havana, arrived at this port yesterday. She was detained at New-Orleans one day beyond her regular time of leaving, by order of Major-Gen. BANKS.

News from Mexico via Havana, mentions the occupation of Guanajuato by the French forces and their probable advance on Guadalajara. The report that DOBLADO had declared in favor of the intervention was denied. The indication that he would do so was simply a ruse to gain time. His troops were concentrating at Leon. The guerrillas are reported to have entirely disappeared from the high road between Orizaba and Vera Cruz.

THACKERAY is dead. This startling announcement seemes to add an intenser chill to the inclemency of the season, as it strikes at the heart of so much that has delighted and refined the men of this generation, in a thousand sketches of life and character vivified by the pen of a man of consummate genius.
The aggregate business of the Week has been large, particularly as regards alcohol, sugar and syrup. General markets since New-Year's day are firmer, with considerable animation.

Shortly after 11 o'clock last night,the police of the Second Precinct discovered smoke issuing from the basement of No. 55 Beekman-street. The alarm was at once given, but before the water could be got on the fire it was discovered that the flame and smoke were so great on the Ann-street side of the block, that it was with difficulty the hose could be brought to bear upon it.

In the Senate yesterday, but little business was done. The bill providing for the payment of bounties to March 1, was passed. In connection with this subject, Mr. FESSENDEN presented a letter from the secretary of the Treasury, stating that he would be unable to meet the heavy drafts required by this action within so short a time, and recommending increased taxation.
