The Military Committees of both Houses met today to confer upon the Conscription Bill. The House Committee unanimously rocommended commutation. So did Senator WILSON. The other members of the Senate opposed it.

An imprompra serenade and welcome was given to Gen. MEADE, the hero of Gettysburgh, last evening, at the residence of Mr. BENJAMIN GERHARD, No. 226 South Fourth-street. The participants were the convalescent soldiers of the Broad and Cherry Hospital, accompanied by their band.

PRESENTATION TO EX-ALDERMAN PETER MITGHELL. Last evening the friends of Ex-Alderman PETER MITCHELL of the Eighth District, met at Lindhelm's Hotel, No. 415 Grand-street, for the purpose of presenting Mr. MITCHELL with a token of their kind regard for him as a citizen and as a friend.
The Inquirer has the following special dispatch:

The carpenters' work on the Dunderberg, inside and out is finished that is, comparatively little remains to be done; odd jobs here and there not being taken into account. The engine kelsons are all laid, and massive ones they are too; the coal bunker and bulkhead surrounding the boiler compartment are also in place; and so far as the carpenters are concerned, we presume the vessel might be launched in a week.

The Park Barracks are in a most wretched condition; they are filthy in the extreme and utterly unfit for the habitation of any human being. Coals and wood are strewn upon the floor, which looks as though it had not been washed since the erection of the barracks, and the dining tables are equally innocent of soap and water.
At a meeting of the Board of Education held last evening, on motion of Mr. JAMES L. MILLER, Mr. JAMES M. TUTHILL took the chair.

The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

There have been frequent complaints made against the proceedings of our prize Courts, both here and in Europe. The complaints on this side of the water have been mainly directed to the practical working of the Courts and the officials, and in these we have sometimes been compelled to join.

The Maryland Senate yesterday passed the modified order presented by Mr. EYCHELBERGER, of Frederick, as a substitute for that relating to negro enlistments, proposing the appointment of a Joint Committee to have an interview with the President of the United States in reference to questions which at this moment engage the attention and so deeply concern the interests of the people of Maryland.

A dispatch to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated at Chattanooga on Tuesday, says that a severe cavalry fight occurred on Sunday last, at a place called Strawberry Plains, 35 miles northeast of Knoxville, in which the enemy suffered severely.

Last evening Mr. FREDERICK DOUGLASS addressed a very large and brilliant assemblage in the hall of the Cooper Institute, on the "Mission of the War." The lecture was in behalf of the Woman's Loyal League. Mr. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT.

The steamer Belle, from Memphis, has arrived, with 260 bales of cotton.
BOUNDARY LINES. Mr. RAMSEY, of Minnesota, (Union,) presented a petition from citizens of Wisconsin and Minnesota, asking for an extension of their boundary line. Referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Adelphic Lodge, No. 348, held last evening at Dodworth's Hall, No. 806 Broadway, a lodge of sorrow to the memory of their late Past Master J.B. YATES SOMMERS, also late Deputy Grand Master of the State of New-York.

Yesterday at noon Mr. THACKERAY was buried in the cemetary of Kensal-green. The day was so fine that, notwithstanding the distance from town, a vast concourse of his friends were enabled to surround his grave, and to pay him the last honor. Many hundreds must have been present of almost every rank and class. Only a very few of Mr. THACKERAY's most intimate friends were expressly invited to the funeral.

As the proposition to extend the term of the extra Government bounties ($400 to veterans and $300 to recruits) to the 1st of March has been approved by both Houses of Congress, it is probable that this action will postpone the draft during this period at least, and confide the business of recruiting our forces exclusively to the instrumentality of volunteering.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday directed the Street Committee to report some plan for the improvement of the pavement on Broadway. The Comptroller sent in his estimates of City expenses for 1864. The budget foots up $8,013,263 86, or $778,313 82 more than the total appropriations of 1863.

A dispatch from the Army of the Potomac says that no danger is apprehended from the reported movement of the rebel STUART and his cavalry, as it is not believed that he has sufficient force to accomplish much damage.

--We had occasion some time since to call attention to the position of the law as to claims for dam- ages by the owners of vessels wrongfully captured as prizes. Senator BUSH, and other prominet legislators, advocate the Senatorial election's postponement till etter the Presidential election. The Unionists of Graves, headed by Hon. R.K. WILLIAMS, of the Court of Appeals, resolved, on the 1st.

Stephen T. Clark vs. James and Eraslus Brooks. This case came up again in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday. Mr. Smythe, one of the counsel for the defendants, said that this was a motion to obtain a stay of proceedings in this matter on the part of the defendants pending an appeal from the order of Judge Hilton.
Money easy. Atlantic currency exchange is at 45@48 cent. premium for gold in New-York. Legal tenders, 65@66.

Last week the country members of the Utah Legislature began to assemble at the seat of Government for the session, and on Monday the Legislature met in the Council House, the several members taking the oath prescribed. After organization, both houses adjourned till the next day, DANIEL H. WELLS having been elected President of the Council, and JOHN TAYLOR Speakers of the House.

There are at present two bills before the State Legislature incorporating companies to run street railroads one of them down Lexington-avenue and through Gramercy Park, and the other across the City near the City Hall. This description, of course, gives no idea of their tortuous wanderings.
There are as yet no signs of the steamship Canada, now fully due at this port, with Liverpool dates of the 9th and Queenstown of the l0th inst, Wind north; weather beautiful.

The public press has given very general notice of the arrest of DANIEL W. WHITNEY Esq., contractor with the Government on the charge of willful neglect of duty, characterized by the press generally as "an attempt to defraud."
The Board met pursuant to adjournment, in-their Chamber, No. 16 City Hall.
The United States Hospital transport steamer Cosmopolitan, Capt. A.C. CROOKER, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, bringing 222 sick and wounded soldiers from the Department of the South.
The Inman steamship Etna, Capt. McGuigan, which left Liverpool at 3 P.M. on the 6th and Queenstown on the 7th of January, arrived at this port yesterday.

There are many who still doubt the possibility of a restoration to union and quiet, even after the rebellion is subdued. A "subjugated" people; they say, can never be relied on. A glance at our revolutionary history may be the best thing to reassure us, though, in fact, all history abounds with instances of great disaffection turning to order, and the spirit of rebellion forever vanishing, underthe reign of just law.

One of the One Hundred and Seventeenth New-York Volunteers, having straggled away from the line of march during Gen. SMITH'S late expedition in West Tennessee, was hung up by the heels and had his throat cut.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: One of the most annoying difficulties connected with the Hair and its diseases is Dandruff, in its various phases. Its philosophy being very little understood, I will give my views on the subject for the benefit of those afflicted.

DEAR SIR: The letter referred by you to me from "H. BARNS, Colonel First Michigan Colored regiment," requesting Your aid to "Capt. W.A. McCLEVELAND" in his recruiting mission to Kentucky for the "First Michigan Colored regiment," is before me.
We have captured a rebel mail. The secrets of the mail bag are curious, interesting, and, in one or two instances, highly important.
A letter from Knoxville says: "On the 7th inst., our pickets stationed beyond Rains Cross-Roads, upon the Rutledge Pike, discovered a small mounted party approaching with a flag of truce.

Assistant Secretary of the Navy G.V. Fox, made a flying visit to this City yesterday, from Washington, returning the night train. His business here was in connection with the preliminary arrangements pertinent to the race between the Kin Kiang and one of the vessels in the Navy.

The news from Tennessee seems to indicate that a desperate attempt is about to be made by the rebels, during the coming month, to take advantage of the supposed reduction of our forces, by the furloughs granted to the veteran regiments reenlisting, and to regain some of their lost ground in Tennessee.

We published yesterday an order issued by Gov. BRAMLETTE, of Kentucky, forbidding the recruiting of colored troops within that State. We find in the Louisville Journal the following explanatory letter from him on that subject:
Mr. RICHARDSON appeared to-day for the first time.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is pub- lished THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
Operations commenced to-day toward raising the ship Aquilla.
FELLOW-CITIZENS: The President's recent message manifests his continued solicitude for your interests. He says:
The Aldermanic Street Committee met again yesterday to consider the subject of improving the pavement on Broadway, Alderman CHIPP presiding.
The steamer Forsyth, with the Tenth Illinois Volunteers, who have re nlleted, and who muster 600 strong, has arrived here.
Maj.-Gen. BUTLER returned to Fortress Monree this morning.
The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 9th inst., at 9:30 A. M., vid Queenstown P. M. of the 10th, arrived here at 5 P. M. to-day.
A special dispatch to the Commercial from Chattanooga, dated 21st inst., says:
Mr. STRONG reported a bill to incorporate the Brooklyn Yatch Club.

The Richmond Inquirer of Jan. 19 says: Mr. HIDELL, Secretary to the Vice-President, received a dispatch yesterday, from Augusta, announcing the sudden and serious illness of Mr. STEPHENS. He was attacked on Sunday morning. This attack, with the well-known state of his health during the Winter, creates serious apprehensions in regard to him.

GERMAN OPERA. The last performance of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's troupe, at the Academy of Music, takes place to-night, when NICOLAI'S famous opera of the "Merry Wives of Windsor," will be given for the first and only time this season. The cast includes some of the best artists of Mr. ANSOHUTZ'S company and Mr. HEBRMANNS in particular is said to be remarkable in the role of Falstaff.
A large portion of the harbor was cleared of ice to-day. The ferry-boats have resumed their trips.
The Board met pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, No. 16 City Hall.

The U.S. steam transport Merrimac, SAMPSON, from New-Orleans, 17th inst., at 9 A.M., arrived at Key West on the 19th, where she put in for coal, and sailed again on the 22d at 2 A.M. She brings a cargo of cotton and sugar to the U.S. Assistant Quartermaster.

Prominent Germans who arrived here from the West to-day, indicate a new element in the Anti-Slavery politics, with reference to the next Presidency. They represent that the citizens of their nationality have determined to put in the field a candidate irrevocably committed to the destruction of Slavery, if the National Convention of the supporters of the war does not supply them with one.

The United States steam transport Fulton, Capt. WOTTON, from Port Royal, S.C., 23d, and Stono Inlet. 24th inst., at 1 A.M., with passengers to United States Quartermaster, arrived here yesterday morning, having made the trip in 52 hours. She brings no news of importance. The improvements on the various forts and batteries were progressing. The troops are all in good health.
The steamer Mars has arrived from Carleton. She reports the Ohio River gorged about 40 miles above that point.

Gen. BUTLER reports from his department the details of an expedition sent to the Peninsula. Three armed transports and a force under Gen. GRAHAM, went to Brandon Farms, a few miles below Fort Powhatan, and captured 20 prisoners, brought away 99 negroes, destroyed quantities of pork, oats and corn, and seized a sloop and schooner with 240 boxes of tobacco destined to run the blockade, returning without having lost a man.
At noon, yesterday, the new Board of Police Commissioners held a meeting at their headqarters, No. 61 William-street. After some little discussion, the following resolutions were adopted:
The One Hundred and Second Regiment Veteran Volunteers reached here on Sunday afternoon from Cnattanooga, where they led the advance in the storming of Lookout Mountain and Ringgold.

Gen. ROSSEAU lately received information that a brigade of rebel cavalry under Gen. FORREST, with a battery of artillery, were about to cross the Tennessee River at Florence, Alabama, for the purpose of a raid through Middle Tennessee.

GERMAN OPERA. Mr. ANSCHUTZ'S return to his position as chief of the German forces was hailed last night with much favor by an attendance crowded from parquet to dome. The gentleman has been very seriously indisposed, and is still feeble in everything save his baton arm, which is as nervvous and imperious as ever.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
The Petersburgh Express of Jan. 22 says: Seven hospital buildings at Camp Winder, near Richmond, were burned yesterday. A large quantity of commissary stores and clothing were destroyed.
We continue up to the 20th inst. statements of the cases argued in the Supreme Court of the United states.
For a State bounty of three hundred dollars under the last call.

The Steamer Belle of Memphis, with 292 bales of cotton, and Memphis dates of the 25th, has arrived. She also brought 450 reenlisted men of the Kansas cavalry, with about the same number of furloughed men from various other regiments, all en route home.

According to the Baltimore American, spies and rebel mail carriers pass through our military lines with alarming frequency and impunity The oath of allegiance is taken and violated without compunction, and passes beyond our pickets are given to every one desiring them who subscribes to the oath. Our military authorities almost seem to connive at these proceedings, so frequent have they become.

We notice by late English papers that the Sheffield manufacturers are alive to the importance of manufacturing iron of such superior quality as to stand the severe tests of late applied by the English Admiralty before they consent to its use in the armor-plates which are now being prepared for the enormous vessels they are constructing.

We have authority for saying that the statement published in several Northern journals that Gen. BUTLER had succeeded in effecting an exchange of all our paroled prisoners captured previous to Sept. 1, 1863, is incorrect. No such arrangements have been made, nor has Gen. BUTLER prematurely authorized any statement that he has had any such success. That will come in time.
Brig.-Gen. BARNES took his departure from Norfolk last evening. Brig.-Gen. WILD is now in command at Norfolk in his place.

Messrs. JOYCE and RICHARDSON, formerly editors of the Baltimore Republican, who were sent beyond our lines in the beginning of the year'62, for writing traitorous articles against the Republic, were again arrested, yesterday, in this City, having returned by way of Nassau. They were at once sent to Gen. LOCKWOOD, now commanding at Baltimore.
New-Orleans papers of the 17th and 18th inst. are to hand by the Empire City.

Nothing of particular importance has reached this city in the way of news, either from Mexico or St. Domingo, since my last communications. Troops and warlike materials continue to be sent unceasingly to the last-named place, showing evidently that the loss of life on the part of the Spaniards has been immense. In the shape of news, however, as I have mentioned above, little or nothing it allowed to be published.

NAVIGATION OF THE OHIO. Mr. VAN WINKLE, of Western Virginia, (Union,) presented a joint resolution of the West Virginia Legislature praying Congress to institute legislation relative to the navigation of the Ohio River, Referred.

The Richmond Examiner of Jan. 25 contains the following: CHARLESTON, Saturday, Jan. 23. The firing on the city has almost entirely ceased. Only nine shots nave been fired since 9 o'clock last evening. The position and number of the fleet are about as usual.

Coloner NAUMANN yesterday held an inquest at the Second Precinct Station-house on the body of PAUL HOFFMAN, who was killed on Tuesday evening last, at the time of the explosion and fire in the establishment of Messrs. STROSSBURGER NURN, corner of Maiden-Lane and William-street. The deceased, it may be recollected, was a salesman for the firm, and was instantly killed.

The only arrival from the coast since the sailing of the last steamer is the Talca, from Ecuador, with later dates from the seat of war. MOSQUERA had been successful in an engagement, and was marching on Quito, where he has probably arrived. It was said that the President of Ecuador had been taken prisoner.

THE ALEXANDRA CASE A NEW TRIAL DENIED. The Court of Exchequer had refused to grant a new trial in the case of the gunboat Alexandra, and owing to the judges being equally divided upon the question the Crown would appeal from the decision. The Attorney-General had intimated his intention to appeal. The London Times publishes in extense the opinions delivered by the four judges, extending over eleven closely-printed columns, and remarks:
A special dispatch from Chattanooga to the Commercial says JOHNSTON'S army has fallen back from Dalton.
The Inman steamer City of New-York, Capt KENNEDY, which left Liverpool at noon on the 13th, and Queenstown on the 14th of January, arrived at this port last evening.
A large quantity of ice floated past the city this afternoon, sinking the steamer Moderator, at the levee, to the cabin. Although she is badly careened, it is thought she can be raised.
It is reported that JOHN MORGAN, with seven regiments, will make a raid into Kentucky through the gaps in the eastern part of the State.

THE NEW-YORK CUSTOM-HOUSE INVESTIGATION The committee having in charge the investigation into the affairs of the New-York Custom-house will be divided soon, and, for the sake of convenience in taking testitmony, a portion of it will go to New-York and there thoroughly sift,the testimony, thus far ex parte and accusatory. The inquiry will have a new aspect after the evidence of the volunteer witnesses is closed.
The Lower House of the Legislature has adopted an amendment making St. Joseph the eastern terminus of the Pacific Railroad.

The liquor merchants are much excited at the prospect of another tax being levied by Congress upon their stocks of liquors. They say they have already paid one excise tax on the liquors which have gone into their private stores, and they cannot see with what justice they can be called upon to pay another.

A dispatch received late last evening brings advices from Knoxville down to the 22d. At that time our forces were reported to be retiring to the defences of the city, and the prospect of the inauguration of a second siege was imminent. LONGSTREET has a strongly fortified position at Bull's Gap, from which he can throw forces into the Tennessee valley, against Knoxville, with great facility.
The Cunard mail steamer Australasian, Capt ANDERSON, which sailed from Liverpool at 12:30, on the afternoon of the 16th, and from Queenstown on the 17th January, arrived yesterday morning.
The camps are quiet. The execution of the eight deserters fixed for to day has been suspended for the present.

Mr. EDWARD N. DICKERSON, in a pamphlet entitled "Navy of the United States," , has stated in a note on page 59, "That in consequence of my reports respecting the performance of some vessels of the Navy I have had the honor to command, that I am under the displeasure of the Department on shore duty."
At an anniversary meeting last night, a spirited debate occurred between Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS and WM. LLOYD GARRISON upon the course of the Administration.

Gen. ROSECRANS arrived at 11 o'clock this morning. He was welcomed on the other side of the river by a committee representing the City Government, the Merchants' Exchange, the Sanitary Committee, and other organizations. On arriving on this side of the river a salute was fired, and the General was escorted to the hotel by a large committee of citizens and soldiers.

The judgment pronounced by the Court of Exchequer in the Alexandra case, refusing a new trial, has the force of reaffirming the previous verdict in favor of the defendants a verdict which makes it not unlawful for British merchants to build, fit out and sell to the rebels war-vessels, provided they are not armed and equipped; but it is far from settling the question.

THE PROPOSED NAVAL RACE NOT TO TAKE PLACE. The largeness of the sum required by the Oly phants as the condition of the race between the Kin Kiang and the Eutaw, and the difficulty of raising it by subscription, will probably defeat the proposed trial of speed.

TAX ON GOLD OPERATIONS. Mr. VOORHEES of Indiana, (Dem.,) by unani mous consent, intrroduced a bill taxing all transactions in gold two per centum, and providing that the present law upon that subject shall not be evaded by persons engaged in gold speculations,
At the northwest corner of the City Hall Park has been erected and is now in use, the new building in which is to be consolidated all the recruiting offices for this City.

VIRGINIA. Richmond papers of yesterday contain nothing of importance.

The Alexandra case has been decided in a full bench of the Court of Exchequer, against the Government. Two of the Judges were in favor of a new trial. The case will now be carried to the House of Lords. Earl RUSSELL, is trying very hard to keep the peace.
The President has issued the subjoined important instructions to Gen. STEELE, which are satisfactory to the Arkansas Delegation, who are to take them to Little Rock.

The case of ALFRED GOULDING, vs. BICKFORD and LOMBARD, the trial of which was commenced on Tuesday last, before the United States Circuit Court in this city, was brought to a term nation to-day by a verdict for the plaintiff for $2,100 damages.

CONFEDERATE BONDS. Eight Cent. bonds coupon, due 1876 to 1881. $112@$118.50. The highest price bid yesterday was for bonds falling due in 1877. A bond for $1,000, maturing in 1881, brought only $117, while bonds of this date brought on Wednesday $119.50.

THE ELECTION. The work for the election goes bravely on. Nothing else is now talked of in New-Orleans but who shall be our next Governor, and all the wirepullers are hard at work from morning till night, club meetings being held every evening in a dozen places at the same time, and by day informal caucus gatherings in every bar-room and at every street corner.

The motion was agreed to, and the bill taken up.

ROBBERY. The store of Mr. JOHN GERGEN, corner of South-first and First-streets, Brooklyn, E.D., was entered on Wednesday night and robbed of a quantity of hams and pork. The robbers were discovered yesterday morning, about 2 o'clock, by Sergeant DOUGHTY, of the forty-fifth Precient Police, and one of them, named GEO. MULRONY was secured with two large bags of the stolen articles. Justice COLOHAN sent him to the Grand Jury. The other thief escaped.

Matter of W.H. Fowler This was an application on the part of Mr. Fowler to be discharged from his debts as an insolvent under the Two thirds Act. The application was opposed by the creditors on the ground, first, that the petition was not signed by the insolvent debtor, as required by section 2 of the statute: and, second, that the proof the debtor's residence was not sufficient.
From time to time we hear of, a movement, in the Common Council respecting the pavement in Broadway.

GRNERAL ORDERS, NO.--.--1. Regulations will be established on the the last of February proximo, for the government of persons employed in plantation labor during the present year. All parties interested therein will have an opportunity to present their views upon this subject to the Commission of Enrollment, the object being to secure a reliable, economical and just system of compensated labor.

STEPHEN C. FOSTER, the composer, died in this City on the 13th inst., and his funeral took place at Pittsburgh on Thursday, Jan. 21. He was born on the 4th of July, 1826. His father, W.B. FOSTER, Sen., was a native of Virginia, and settled in Pittsburgh in the year 1796.

GREENE C. BRONSON, formerly Chief Judge of this Court, departed this life on the third day of September, 1863, at Saratoga Springs. His public career is closely interwoven with the judicial history of the State. Among the official positions filled by him, those of Attorney General, from 1829 to 1835, of Justice of the Supreme Court, from 1836 to 1847, and of Judge of the Court of Appeals, from 1847 to April, 1851, are prominent.

We are pained to announce that Mr. HIDELL, Secretary to Vice-President STEPHENS, yesterday,received a telegram from Augusta, announcing the sudden and serious illness of Mr. STEPHENS, at his home at Crawfordville, Ga. He was attacked on Monday morning, and sent on that day to Augusta for a physician. This attack, with the known state of his health during the Winter, has created serious apprehensions in the minds of his friends.

A remarkable tusk of a mastodon has just been added to the cabinet of the Rochester University. It is a genuine fragment of the Mastoden Giganteus, the old king of the North American plains. The tusk is six inches in diame er at the larger end, and about two and a half inches at the smaller. Its length is about four feet, which is perhaps not more than one-half the original.

Mr. A.C. ARMSTRONG has lately become a partner in the esteemed publishing house of SCRIBNER Co. Mr. ARMSTRONG has since boyhood been in the employ of this firm in subordinate capacities, and his rise is a pleasing evidence of the rewards attending the faithful discharge of duty. The new partner has long been known to the book trade for his eminent business qualities and his agreeable and gentlemanly manners.

Possessed of considerable powers of oratory, and great logical acumen, he is also remarkable for the boldness with which he grapples with the most intricate and momentous questions, and the directness with which he proceeds to his point, and inculcates the most extreme meas- ures as the only satisfactory and complete policy. * *

What we call States never were such in the strict sense of the term. There never was a moment in history in which they were independent, sovereign Powers, that is according to Mr. LINCOLN'S most true and terse definition "having no human power above them." Take the largest of them, or the most historical among them; neither New-York nor Massachusetts were ever sovereign States, like Britain, France, Spain, or even Portugal.

Last evening the Academy of Music was crowded to its utmost extent with one of the most brilliant assemblages ever gathered within its walls, to celebrate the Annual Ball of the celebrated Arion Society, so called from the great original "Arion," who being shipwrecked, so charmed the fish by his sweet music, that a dolphin took him on his back and carried him safely to the shore.

The accured was arrested, and an investigation was made by Coroner NORRIS, but there was no evidence whatever to show that he was guilty of such an offence.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 25. One of Gen. LEE's orderlies, private TAYLOR, of the Fourth Virginia Cavalry, came into our lines yesterday, and arrived here to-day. He has been in the rebel army about fifteen months, and the last three months has been on duty at Gen. LEE'S headquarters' as orderly to Gen. LEE, whose Winterquarters are upon the road from Orange Courthouse to Verdiersville, about two miles from the former place.

We have obtained the following particulars respecting the insurance upon the property destroyed by the fire in Gloucester: T.J. KNOWLES, No. 77 Front-street, stock damaged about $250 by water; insured; $2,000 at North American, $2,000 at Eliot, and $1,500 at People's at Worcester.

We are informed that the late Government sale of burned vessels at the Gosport Navy-Yard, in Virginia, was well attended, and that the bidding was lively. Wrought scrap iron sold for 2 cents per lb., anchors, 10 cents; chains, 10 cents; boiler plate iron, 8 cents. This was sold to the Government.

The Etna reached Liverpool about 4 o'clock on the afternoon of the 12th. The Damascus arrived off Londonderry on the afternoon of the 12th.
The reports of stragglers that Gen. SMITH'S expedition had been cut up prove false. That General arrives here at 4 o'clock last night.

LIVERPOOL, Saturday, Feb. 13--Evening. Preliminary proceedings in the case of the sus pected steamer Pampero, seized on the Clyde, commenced in the Exchequer Court at Edinburgh on the 11th. The indictments are similiar to those in the Alexandra case. The defendants put in a general dental and appeal to a jury.

Private letters from Hilton Head lay the whole blame of the recent disaster in Florida upon Gen. SEYMOUR, who disobeyed orders in advancing beyond a certain point, which he was ordered by Gen. GILLMORE to hold, and to await the attack of the enemy. Our losses are stated to be larger than at first supposed.

We have information of a formidable offensive movement by a large force from the Army of the Potomac, which was initiated on Saturday night, and may possibly be heard from to-day. The demonstration is a very bold one, but is in brave hands, and will be supported by a powerful force.

LIVERPOOL, Saturday, Feb. 13--A.M. COTTON--The Brokers' Circular says: The uncertain ty of the issue of continental politics caused holders to offer their stocks pretty freely toward the end of last week; since which time, however, a more active trade demand has enabled them to obtain the extreme rates of last Thursday, and in some instances a slight advance.

In the Matter of the Petition of Anna Thompson for the Custody of Eliza Lyons, an Infant. Petition granted.

The symptoms of weakness on the part of the Ministry in England are increasing every day; and it is quite evident that nothing but the want of leaders and want of policy on the part of the Opposition prevents a crisis that would result in the ousting of the PalmerstonRussell Cabinet.

There was a numerous and very respectable meet ing at Cooper Institute last evening, to do honor to and hear the remarks of Hon GEO. THOMPSON, the champion of Emancipation in England.
We print this morning our correspondence from the Department of the South, received via Fortress Monroe, detailing the recent lamentable reverse to our arms in Florida.
Cleared.
The entire column, numbering a little less than 5,000 men, left Barber's at 7 o'clock Saturday morning, and proceeded on the main road toward Lake City.

CHANGES IN THE ENROLLMENT LAW. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, (Union,) presented a joint resountion of the Legislature of Michigan, asking changes in the enrollment law. Referred to the Military Committee.

HOMESTEADS FOR SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. Mr. JULIAN, of Indiana, (Union,) introduced a bill to secure to persons in the military and naval service homesteads in confiscated and forfeited estates within insurrectionary districts.

The diary of an officer attached to Gen. GRIEESON'S column, of Gen. SMITH'S cavalry expedition, furnishes little information of importance beyond what has been previously reported. Our loss in the attack on the enemy at West Point was forty killed and wounded. We drove the rebels and destroyed a number of cars and culverts, the depot, several miles of railroad track, and a large amount of corn and cotton.

Within the past few days a number of brilliant little affairs have occurred in the department, which, were it not for the blight caused by the disaster in Florida, would be look upon with no slight degree of interest.
Provost-Marshal-General Fry has sent the following dispatch to Albany:

We have somewhere read a French story running somewhat in this wise : Monsieur Feuillet was traveling in a steamboat, when an explosion took place. He was transfixed by an iron spit seven feet long. The spit went in at the abdomen and passed out at the back, so that there were three feet of the spit before and three feet behind.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. To the habitues of the opera there was last night a disappointment and a surprise. Miss KELLOGG was indisposed and unable to sing; hence "Faust," which had been announced, was impossible, and the management had to go through the prosy and painful operation of transferring many tickets to the next performance of GOUNOD'S work, or of refunding the money paid for the same. This was the disappointment.

We see that the Congressional Committee, appointed to investigate the charges and rumors of corruption and improper conduct on the part of Government officials, has taken rooms in Wall-street, and is about to commence its labors.

In the Senate, this evening, a message was received from the Governor. Informing the Senate that when he called the attention of the Secretary of War to the inequalities of the draft as detrimental to the State of New-York, that official appointed WILLIAM F. ALLEN, of this State...
RECONSTRUCTION. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, (Union,) presented a petition from the German Political Club of Cleveland, Ohio, in reference to the policy of reconstruction. Referred to the Judiciary Committee.

A telegram from Sonderburg of Feb. 12, says: " All is quiet at the outposts. At Tonning, Tondern, and other places unoccupied by the Germans, the revolutionary party rose against the Danish Government and expelled its officials. At Eckernforde the Prussians have allowed the proclamation of the Prince of Augustenburg."

In the House of Lords on Feb. 15, Earl RUSSELL said: "The noble Earl (the Earl of Derby) put some questions to me the other evening to which I was not at the time prepared to give an answer. He referred to several dispatches and notes of Mr. ADAMS, and expressed a wish to know how far the conduct of Her Majesty's Government had been influenced by those communications.

Credit is due the Legislature for the promptness with which business is resumed after the recess. Both Houses had a quorum, and accomplished about the usual amount of business on reassembling last evening.
The notorious guerrilla, Col. RICHARDSON, was captured on Sunday, south of the Cumberland River, below Burkville, by a detachment of Col. WEATHERFORD'S Cavalry. Another rebel was taken with him.
The General Appropriation bill has been under consideration all day. The appropriation to the State Idiot Asylum was increased all day.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 92 bbls. Ashes, 9,528 bbls. Flour, 2,437 bbls, and 1.078 bags Corn Meal, 415 bushels Wheat, 22,330 bushels Corn. 7,187 bushels Oats, 2,085 bushels Malt, 3,825 pkgs. Provisions, 415 bushels Rye, and 1.158 bbls, Whisky.

A serious evil is being committed by numerous towns and counties about New-York, in offering great inducements to bounty brokers, and little or no inducement to recruits. It is done in this way. A town meeting is held, at which the tax-payers raise a certain amount to pay each recruit $300.

Since our last the Ambassadors of the Prince of Saisuma have paid the 25,000 demanded by the English Charge d'Affaires, as indemnity for the murder of Mr. RICHARDSON, and wounding of others of his party. It was accompanied by the usual delays of Japanese diplomacy, as the time pledged for its payment had passed several days before the money was forthcoming.

The Board of Aldermen met specially yesterday, their first meeting in over a week. A resolution was adopted requesting the Comptroller to report to the board why he refuses to perfect the purchase of the Fort Gansevoort property.

Oo Monday morning about 11 o'clock, Gen. LEDLIE'S Brigade arrived in this City and quartered in the Park Barracks. They came from Fortress Monroe on the steamers Prometheus, Combria and New-Jersy, and are a fine, hardy looking set of men. They were with Gen. McCLELLAN on the Peninsula, and have been in nearly all the battles of the Army of the Potomac.

The undersigned have been appointed a committee, by the Union Central Committee, with instructions to call the attention of the loyal electors of New-York to the election to be held on the 8th day of March, to determine whether the Constitution of the State shall be so amended as to allow such of our citizens as may hereafter be absent in the military or naval service of the country, the right to vote!
The following telegrams are from the second edition of the London Times of Feb. 17:

The arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Bremen, from Southampton Feb. 17, puts us in possession of four days' later news from Europe. The discussion of the American question was continued in the British Parliament.
The mails for Europe by the Africa, via Boston, will close to-day at 5:30 P.M.

The news from the Army of the Potomac is up to 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time Gen. CUSTER'S Cavalry were sharply engaged with the enemy beyond Madison Court-house, in the direction of Stannardsville, on LEE's left flank. Madison Court-house was in our possession. Our dispatch states that KILPATRICK had been heard from, and that reports were favorable.

Baseless though we have found such of Gen. McCLELLAN'S excuses for his inactivity as we have thus far had occasion to subject to analysis, it cannot be denied that they belong to an order of facts that are grave, weighty and deserving of full consideration; and, if well grounded, they would go far to justify that delay.
The steamship Damascus, Capt. BROWN, which left Liverpool, at 2.30 o'clock, on the afternoon of the 18th, and Londonderry 19th ult., arrived at Portland of 10.50 o'clock this morning.

Nothing is officially known of the whereabouts of Gen. KILPATRICK. It is said in well-informed circles, that on Monday he was in Spottsylvania Courthouse, whlch, according to the Gazette, is fifty-six miles from Richmond.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 53 bbls. Ashes, 6,401 bbls. Flour, 131 bbls. and 868 bags Corn Meal, 1,710 bushels Wheat, 1,067 bushels Corn, 11,889 bushels Oats, 2,660 bushels Malt, 2,935 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,012 bbls. Whisky.
Col. D.T. Jenkins, of the United States Army; Hon. L. Underwood, J.S. Eldridge and wife, and G. W. Bond, of Boston, are stopping at the Fifth-avenue Hotel.

The debate in the English House of Commons in reference to the doings of our navy and our Prize Courts, was one of great interest to us. It covered a great deal of ground. Mr. FITZGERALD began it by moving for the papers in relation to the cases of four vessels ...

Gen. CUSTER started with a force of cavalry, on Sunday, to make a reconnoissance toward Gordonsville, the Sixth Corps, under Gen. SEDGWICK, following in support. He passed through Madison Court-house on Monday morning, and reaching Wolfton, a few miles beyond, encountered a rebel picket, which he captured.
Capt. Ross and twelve of his men, deserters from Gen. FRICE'S army, have arrived at Van Buren. He brings no confirmation of the news that Parox had left the rebel army.
A special dispatch to the Daily Chronicle, from Culpepper to-day, says: "Gen. CUSTAR, with 1,500 picked men, in light marching order, left Culpepper Court-house about 2 o'clock on Sunday afternoon.
The Inman steamer Etna, Capt. McGUIGAN, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 17th, and Queenstown on the 18th February, arrived here last evening.

By last night's mails we received files of Richmond papers up to Feb. 29, inclusive. They contain the usual variety of interesting intelligence. From the multitude of dispatches, statements and guesses concerning Gen. SHERMAN's movements in Mississippi, we gather that he withdrew from Meridian about the 22d, and is now on his way back to Vicksburgh.

Major-Gen. BURNSIDE reached the Produce Exchange yesterday before the close of business. He was in citizen's dress, but was very speedily recognized, and introduced to several representative merchants by the President of the Commercial Association, Mr. ARCHIBALD BAXTER.

The Board of Supervisors have allowed "The Association for the Benefit of Colored Orphans " the sum of $73,089 26 for the loss of their buildings, comprising the well-known Institution of the Colored Orphan Asylum, which will ever figure in history as having been heartlessly destroyed by the mob on the first day of riot rule in this City last July.

The Assembly disposed of the item in the Appropriation Bill giving two hundred thousand dollars to maintain the National Guard last evening, after protracted debate. A motion was finally made to strike out the appropriation, and debate was out off by ordering the previous question.

The Star of this afternoon says: "We have late interesting information from the front, to the effect that Gen. KILPATRICK, with a force of picked cavalry men, has arrived at the White House and formed a junction with a force sent up by Gen. BUTLER from the Peninsula.

SOUTH AMERICAN STEAMSHIP COMPANY. Mr. SPRAGUE, of Rhode Island, (Union,) pre sented a memorial of merchants and others from Rhode Island, in behalf of the South American Steamship Company. Referred to the Committee on Commerce.

Gen. KILPATRICK crossed the Rapidan at Ely's Ford, on Sunday morning at 4 o'clock. He surprised and captured the rebel pickets, a Captain, Lieutenant and fifteen men on the south bank of the stream, and moved in the direction of Spottsylvania Courthouse, stopping for a half hour at Chancellorsville. The last official intelligence from him was a dispatch dated 11 o'clock on Sunday morning, from the former place. The dispatch was substantially as follows:

The Congressional session has not yet lasted two full months, but it has already completely exposed the disgraceful charlatanry by which the Congressional elections were carried, to so large an extent, by the agitators against the Administration. The main issues on which these demagogues went before the people were the following:

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SPRAGUE presented the memorial of merchants of Rhode Island in behalf of the South American Steamship Company. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, presented a joint resolution of the Legislature of Kansas, praying for the removal of all Indians from that State to the Indian Territory. Mr. WILSON called up the House bill extending bounties to April 1, and he read a letter from the Secretary of War recommending its immediate passage.

The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing European advices to the 21st, an interesting telegraphic summary of which has been forwarded. On the 15th inst., after nightfall, the pirate Georgia stealthily vacated her rendezvous in the harbor of Cherbourg, and we may soon expect to hear of her further depredations upon our commerce. Several United States vessels arrived in the roadstead on the night of the Georgia's escape.

The discussion of the Governor's Message was continued in the Assembly last evening. Mr. PLATT, of Suffolk, spoke in defence of the message. This speech was noticeable as being the second of the session on this subject from the Democratic side of the House. It was in itself, also, a creditable effort, aside from the principles advocated.

COTTON The accounts from New-York, and further receipts, have so completely unsettled the market that quotations are nominal, and the demand has been restricted to one or two parties, whose operations were confined to 6 bales strict good ordinary at 71c., and 170 bales, classification not stated, embracing 138 bales at 71c., and 32 at 75c.

The steamship Yazoo, from New-Orleans on the 25th ultimo, arrived last night, bringing us our special correspondence and files of New-Orleans papers, by which we have details of the signal victory of the Free State party in the late election.
The long-dreaded draft is not likely to take place in this City. From figures procured yesterday, it seems more than probable that the number of men needed will be furnished before the 10th inst.:

MUNICIPAL REFORM. A most salutary reform is proposed in the mode of conducting City elections, by the Citizens' Association, a newly-organized body of influential citizens. It is that meetings of the people should be called in each ward, and a President and officers elected for a Ward Association. The President will then appoint from the several ward election districts one hundred persons as an Executive Committee, who will apportion themselves into District Committees.

DONIZETTI'S opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" will be given here to-night, with Mme. MEDORI, Mlle. SULZER, Signor MAZZOLENI and Signor BIACHI in the principal roles, and the other leading artists of the company in the grand finale to the first act.

Rosalie A. Hardenbrook vs. Wm. A. Hardenbrook. This is a veteran case returned again to the courts for the settlement of disputes, arising even after both parties have married a second time. The present and the former husband of the lady were both in court.
The Clerk of the steamer Pringle makes the following statement;
PARSON BROWNLOW arrived here to-night on the Nashville train. He has been very sick, but is convalescent.
The Secretary of War has telegraphed Gov. SEYMOUR that the payment of bounties will be continued for the present in this State. The draft, therefore, is indefinitely postponed.

A rumor comes from Vicksburgh by the steamer Mississippi, from New-Orleans, that Gen. SHERMAN, having returned from Meridian, had gone in the direction, and was within 40 miles of, Mobile. No dates are given, and the report cannot be traced to a reliable source.
A number of bills were advanced to a third reading, including one limiting the terms of office of Notaries Public. Recess.

MOND. We hardly think any one need be made unhappy by the announcement which comes to us from Washington, that LONGSTREET'S forces have arrived at Richmond. The President has received a dispatch from Gen. BUTLER, stating that Gen. KILPATRICK arrived yesterday within our lines with a loss of something less than one hundred and fifty men, having had skirmishes on the way. Among the missing are Cols. DAHLGREN, COOK and LITCHFIELD. DAHLGREN and COOK are supposed to be prisoners.

CONCERNING THE NINTH MINNESOTA REGIMENT. The Vice-President presented a report from the Secretary of War, communicating, in answer to a Senate resolution of Jan. 11, 1864, information relating to the arrest and imprisonment of soldiers of the Ninth Minnesota Regiment by the Missouri authorities. The report states that the soldiers were immediately discharged. The report was laid on the table and ordered to be printed.

At a late hour on Thursday evening, Officer KEARNEY, of the Twentyfirst Precinct, while patroling his beat in Third-avenue, near Fortieth-street, was suddenly attacked by a gang of young men, whom the police represent as thieves. The boisterous northeaster which visited this city yesterday week, was a portion of a blast which swept with much greater violence through the settlements immediately north of the city. In the city itself, little damage was done, a house or two unroofed was the extent of the loss, though many imaginative but weak-nerved persons of both sexes passed a shivery night in thinking of and dreading the possibilities within reach of blustering Boreas.

The work of repairing the railroad destroyed by the enemy is progressing rapidly. Three miles of track and three bridges were destroyed on the Southern road; ten miles of track on the Selma road and thirty-five miles of track on the Mobile and Ohio road were destroyed.

The Washington Chronicle of Saturday, announces that on Friday it became necessary to amputate a leg of Senator HICKS as a last expedienti for saving his life. His disease was erysipelas, from which mortification was about to ensue.

The enormous prices of merchandise of every description which have prevailed in the Confederate States for months past are attributable to two primary causes: 1. The excessive and constantly increasing redundancy of the currency; 2. The insufficiency of transportation. The effect of the superabundant currency was to produce an artificial scarcity.

The Manchester weather-prophet is immortalized. His predictions of intense cold, for England, in January and February, have been accomplished. The farmers and gardeners have stopped their work, and we have snow and frost.

The season at the Academy of Music came to a close on Saturday, when a somewhat abbreviated edition of "Faust" was given at the matinee, to an exceedingly charming audience. Mr. MARETZEK, and the leading artists of his admirable troupe, took their departure by the afternoon train for Boston, where they appear to-night, returning to the Metropolis in a fortnight, and opening at the Academy of Music on Easter Monday.

Gen. BURBRIDGE has ordered the arrest of Col. FRANK WOLFORD for disloyal sentiments rendered in a speech at a sword presentation to him at Lexington on Thursday.

The steamship Morning Star from New-Orleans, Feb. 6, arrived yesterday. She brings intelligence of the arrival at that city of Maj. Gen. W. T. SHERMAN and Staff, from Vicksburgh, thus effectually disposing of any doubts respecting the return of that General from his great raid through Mississippi and Alabama, which might have been engendered by last week's vague telegrams from the West.

We published a letter on Sunday, complaining bitterly of the enormous prices demanded for rooms in the up-town hotels, added to extortion on the part of waiters, porters and chambermaids; and the conclusion the writer seems to have come to is, that we need " twenty more good hotels " in the upper part of the City, and that the organization of hotel companies ought to be facilitated by a general act of the Legislature.

The Copperhead journals are doing their utmost to make the Florida reverse tell against the Administration. It strikes us that it is their own policy which has been most damaged by that event. Gen. SEYMOUR, it is now admitted, made a fatal mistake in indiscriminately trusting the loyal professions of the inhabitants along his line of march.

We publish to-day a highly important military order dated on Saturday last, at the War Department. The main provision of the order, and the only one which is of national scope and importance, is that which relieves Gen. HALLECK from the position of General-in-Chief of the Army, and assigns Lieut.-Gen. GRANT to the "command of the armies of the United States."

The work of reorganizing the Army of the Po tomac is proceeding this week. The number of corps will be reduced to three the First and Third being absorbed into the Second, Fifth and Sixth to be commanded respectively by Maj.-Gens. HANCOCK, WARREN and SEDGWICK. This will make three very strong corps.

A RAILROAD IN UTAH. Mr. McBRIDE, of Oregon, (Union,) introduced a bill granting lands to aid in the construction of a railroad, from Salt Lake City to the head waters of the Oregon, and secure the use of the same for postal and military purposes.

NIAGARA FALLS SHIP CANAL. Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, (Union,) presented a memorial of the Board of Trade of Chicago, asking for a ship canal on the American side around Niagara Falls. Referred to the Committee on Commerce.

Gen. FISKE, the Commander of the district of St. Louis, has just returned from a tour of inspection in Southeast Missouri. He reports that numerous bands of guerrillas have been committing depredations in that section and Northeastern Arkansas, and that some bands are preparing for extensive operations in the Spring. Stringent measures will be immediately taken to drive out or destroy all such bands, and establish law and order throughout the department.

The question of legalizing the action of taxpayers who have voted money to aid drafted men in procuring substitutes, or paying commutation, has from time to time during the present session, excited earnest debate in the Assembly. It appears from the bills introduced that not a few localities in the State have voted to raise money upon this basis. The question of legalizing such action is a delicate one, because of its relations to patriotism.
Military operations in Schleswig continued suspended. The English Ministers escaped defeat last night on mere party division in the House of Commons by a majority of one only.
The funds on the 2d showed increased dullness. There was a full demand for discount at the Bank, but no actual premium.

An accident occurred to the mail train on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad this evening, a few miles north of Brandy Station, caused by the giving way of a brake on a freight car, which threw the car from the track, completely demolishing one and badly damaging the others.

All the engineers on the Western railroads centering in Chicago have issued a circular to the different railroad companies that unless certain demands made by them are acceded to, reinstating the strikers on the Galena Railroad, they will suspend operations at noon to-morrow. It is believed that arrangements for running the trains on the Eastern roads will not be materially affected by the strike.

The gunboat Bombshell arrived at Plymouth, N.C., on Saturday last from the Chowan River. She reports that a crowd of negroes awaited her coming down the river, and that the rebels opened on her from their batteries on the banks, rendering it impossible for her to proceed. Her commander sent to Plymouth for assistance.

Some particulars of the late expedition up the Ouchita River have been received. The gunboats Ouchita, Osage, Conestoga, Lexington, Fort Hinman, and Crockett composed the expedition. Trinity was strongly fortified.

The excitement in regard to the strike still continues yet, in rather a subdued form. As was stated in our issue of yesterday, it has been found necessary to obtain military assistance. On Saturday afternoon a force of a hundred and twenty men, under the command of Capt. COGSDEN, arrived in Cold Spring from Governor's Island.

The excitement here continues, and a second attack by the rebels is looked for daily. In the meantime, Gen. PECK is adding new works and strengthening the old ones along the entire line from the Neuse to the Trent Rivers, under the direction of Col. A.H. DUTTON, his very efficient Chief of Staff. The rivers are effectually blockaded, and it will be impossible for the famous iron-clads to reach here.

The future student of history, as he ponders upon the events of this remarkable revolution, will be especially struck with the singular ebb and flow, at almost regular intervals, of the popular feeling. At one time we are on the heights of confidence and hope, having no doubt of the speedy close of the rebellion, and seeing everything in the most rose-colored hues.

The President yesterday issued another call for two hundred thousand troops, in addition to all former calls. Voluntary enlistments may be made up to April 15, when a draft is ordered in all districts deficient in their quotas. The draft will proceed as soon after that date as practicable. Present bounties will be paid to April 1, after which time only one hundred dollars regular bounty will be paid by the Government.
The House took up the Senate bill, providing that the franking privilege of the President and VicePresident shall extend to and cover all mail matter sent to or from either of them.

The British mail steamer from Valparaiso and intermediate ports arrived at Panama yesterday. Her news, which is up to the 16th of February from Valparaiso, and the 27th from Lima and Caliao, is unimportant. From Guavaquil we have dates, via Paita, to 27th February. The Republic was perfectly quiet. Most of the soldiers raised to fight against MOSQUERA'S army had returned to their homes, and planting and trade have resumed their usual course.

Gen. HURLBUT and staff arrived from Vicksburgh last night. The General has taken possession of his old quarters and expects to remain some time. The larger part of his corps is connected with another expedition, which left Vicksburgh some days since.

We have dates from Bogota, the capital, to the 12th of February. The extra session of Congress was merged into the regular annual one on the 1st of February. The Senate elected as its President Senor FRANCISCO JAVIER SALDUA; Vice-President, Senor JUAN A. DE LA ESPRIELLA; Secretary, Senor CARLOS BENEDETI, Senor ANTONIO DEL REAL was made President of the House of Representatives, and Senor ANDRES CERON Vice-President.

The Harlem Broadway Railroad Bill was argued at length before the Senate Railroad Committee this evening. HORACE T. CLARKE, for the bill, contended that a railroad in Broadway was an imperious public necessity, and that the terms on which the Harlem Railroad Company would build it would yield revenue to the City.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 100. In order to supply the force required to be drafted for the navy, and to provide an adequate reserve force for all contingencies, in addition to the five hundred thousand men called for Feb. 1, 1864, the call is hereby made and a draft ordered for two hundred thousand men for the military service, army, navy and marine corps, of the United States.

A propely written history of the world's mercantile operations would gradually work more and more into a history of the insurance system. It is profitable then to turn to the record of a single successful corporation, and note the increasing favor it yearly commands. And for such a company we point to the Washington Insurance Company.

The R.M. steamship Arabia, from Liverpool March 5, via Queenstown 6th, arrived at this port, en route to Boston, this evening. Her advices are two days later than per steamship Jura at Portland.

We publish this morning the statement of a Captain of the Second North Carolina Regiment of Union Volunteers, reaffirming the reported recent execution of twenty-four captured members of that regiment, by the rebel Gen. PICKETT. No new details are given, and we confess that we are not yet prepared to consider the horrid report as a fully substantiated fact.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. Mr. MARK SMITH, a popular and deserved favorite at this house, will take his benefit to-night. The play is the excellent one called "Speed the Plough."

In the State Senate yesterday, the most important business transacted was the passage of a bill to prohibit the sale of spirtuous and vinous liquors on Sunday. The Brooklyn Arsenal Bill was reported favorably by the majority of the Committee. Among the bills noticed was one to ...
The bill amending the charter of the Home Insurance Company was reported by the majority of the committee and subsequently referred back.

The quota of New-York City, under the late call for 500,000 men, was completed yesterday, and the Supervisors' Volunteer Committee rested temporarily from their protracted and patriotic labors. They have paid out in bounties and for other necessary purposes nearly four millions of dollars, and have secured 15,979 men. The magnitude of their work and its labor these figures will give an ides of.

Tuesday evening, Lieut.-Col.DOEBKE, Forty-fifth Regiment, New-York State Volunteers, was the recipient of an exceedingly handsome compilment from the merchant citizens of the Third Ward. He was formerly attached to the police of that precinct, was attacked with patriotic and military ardor, raised a company, and, as Captain, went out with the Regiment; has been a participant in twelve fierce battles, and comes back with the straps of a Lieutenant-Colonel upon him.

The French Government, tired of the annoyances caused by the presence of Confederate ships in French ports, has announced, as its law of action, the same regulations as those published two or three months ago by the English Government. These new regulations are more stringent than the original neutrality proclamation, and tend to diminish and simplify the contestations between the two Governments.

Gen. GRANT formally assumed the command of the armies of the United States to-day. The following is his order on the subject:

A mass meeting of those favorable to the election of Gen. GEORGE B. McCLELLAN to the Presidency was held at Cooper Institute last evening. The large hall was crowded, and there was also a gathering outside which was promiscuously addressed. Great enthusiasm was manifested, and Gen. McCLELLAN was considered as fairly placed upon the course as a candidate for the Presidency.
The United States vs. The Bark Saxon, her Tackle, , and Cargo. The following decree was this day entered in this cause:

Gen. GRANT issued at Nashville, yesterday, his official order, assuming command of the armies of the United States. Headquarters are to be in the field, and for the present, with the Army of the Potomac, for which Gen. GRANT will leave Nashville on Saturday. Gen. SHERMAN has assumed command of the Military Division of the Mississippi; headquarters at Nashville.
An adjourned meeting of the Chamber was held yesterday afternoon, A.A. Low, Esq., presiding.
The Speaker presented the report of the Trustees of the Brooklyn Institute.

The United States vs. Charles Goldey. The accused here was indicted under the Act of March 3, 1823, which provides punishment for falsely making a writing with intent to obtain a sum of money from the United States.

There is some excitement in military circles, tonight, about the reported raid by STUART. He crossed at Fredericksburgh last night, with a force estimated at five thousand men. KILPATRICK and MERRITT are on his track.

The Third Corps was reviewed yesterday by Gen. FRENCH. It is the largest corps in the army. It presented a fine spectacle. Gens. SEDGEWICK, CARR, ROBINSON and others were present, beside a large number of spectators from all departments, and ladies on horseback and in ambulances.
The Richmond papers last received contain the following interesting matter in addition to that already published:

The steamer Continental, from New Orleans, the 10th inst., has arrived with the Twelfth Wisconsin and the Eleventh and Fifteenth Iowa veteran volunteers. The Twelfth Wisconsin Regiment disembarked here, the others go on to St. Louis.

Mobile papers of the 9th of March say the Union forces attempted to land on Dauphin Island, thinking it unoccupied, but happening to catch sight of the Confederate soldiers, concealed and waiting to receive them, they hastily retired, afterward furiously shelling the woods. They also any the Union picket-boats reconnoitre with impunity to the foot of Fort Gaines' wharf.

There is a measure before the British House of Commons, just now, for the creation of a tribunal to hear and pass upon all applications for franchises, such as railroads which affect private or corporate rights, instead of leaving them, as now, to be disposed of by "private bills," after a hearing before a committee.

Mr. JULIAN, of Indiana, (Union,) introduced a substitute for the bill heretofore reported by him, from the Committee on Public Lands, extending the principles of the Homestead Law to persons in the naval and military service, on confiscated and forfeited lands.

There is an impression abroad among the people, which we have already commented upon, that, as greenbacks are so plenty, and every one is feeling so prosperous, it is perfectly right and proper for every one to spend as freely as he likes. There is no sort of conscientious feeling in regard to the duty of economy.

We had noticed with some surprise, that throughout the recent debates in the English Parliament upon our Prize Courts, the speakers, in all their complaints of illegality, had not a word to say of the case of the steamer Peterhoff. We were surprised at this, because we Could not but remember the indignation which was loudly expressed in England when the Peterhoff was captured.

The news from the front to-day indicates that the two armies which have been quietly looking at each other across the Rapidan for several months are likely to collide at any moment. The Army of the Potomac is certainly not unprepared for such a result, and it is presumed that the rebel army under LEE is in as good condition as it is possible for it to be under the circumstances.

The Unittd States vs. the Steamer Peterhoff and her Cargo. This vessel was captured by the Vanderbilt on the 25th of February, 1863, just outside the harbor of St. Thomas. She had been previously stopped by the Alabama, another of our vessels, but not seized.

FOREIGN MAIL SERVICE. Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, (Union,) called up the House bill to provide for carrying the mails to foreign parts and for other purposes, as reported from the Senate committee with amendments, which was passed.
Several men were arrested a few days since below Hickman, Ky., for having, among others, organized themselves into companies for the avowed purpose of entering the rebel service.

THE WILKES COURT-MARTIAL. In the Wilkes Court-martial to-day, the cross-examination of Commodore BALDWIN was concluded. The testimony went to show that he often applied to accused to release the Vanderbilt and let him (BALDWIN) execute the orders of the Navy Department; that the accused replied that he acted according to his best judgment for the interests of the Government and of the service; that he (accused) must bear the responsibility, not the witness.

The indications of a heavy emigration to the mines of Idaho during the coming season, across the plains and by the Missouri River, seem to render it proper for the General commanding this department to publish some information and suggestions which emigrants will find it judiclous to consider carefully.

A year ago we laid before our readers a summary, derived from official sources, of the numbers, equipment and general resources of the local military force of Canada. --For some time past a disgusting exhibition has been made in some of the low houses of the principal towns in the south of Devon. For a few days past an embargo has been laid upon the business of Chicago by a general strike among the railroad engineers. There was trouble on the 1st of January, but the roads acceded to the principal demands of the engineers, and harmony was restored. Recently, however, the Chicago, Union, and Galena Road promulgated some new arrangement which was not satisfactory, and their employes immediately refused to work.

About 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, a serious affray occurred in a 22,000 at No.86 Chathain street, during which Mr. MICHEAL MULLEN, a resident of Baltimore, was shot with a revolver in the abdomen. The wound will, doubtless, prove fatal, A man names THOMAS DORAN was the perpetrator. He was immediately arrested and is held to await the result. MULLEN was taken to the New-York Hospital, where Coroner RANNEY, yesterday, took his ante-mortem examination.

Last evening the anniversary meeting in New- York for the American Sunday-School Union, was held in the Presbyterian Brick Church, Rev. Dr. SPRING, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventh- street. The church was well filled with an excel lent and intelligent congregation.

The United States vs. Henry C. Sorrenson, William Smith and Evan Edwards.--These three men were put on trial, charged with the murder of Charles Courletta, mate of the bark Lone Star, on board which they were seamen.
Memphis dates to the 17th have been received. Brig.-Gen. BRAYMAN arrived to-day and assumed command of the District of Cairo, vice Brig.-Gen. REID, relieved.

Arkansas has given a larger vote for the Union than even Louisiana, and is also ahead of her in the adoption of a Free State Con stitution. Though the latest reduced "Con- federate" State, it is yet the first of any to reconstitute itself on a Free State basis. It has been admirably prompt both in deciding and executing.

Since my last the results of the elections in the various counties of Tennessee have become known, and may be declared a triumphant victory of the Anti-Slavery sentiment of the State. As to those gentlemen who have been placed in power in our immediate midst, they are high-toned, loyal Southerners--every one of them. The meeting which nominated them was made up of the loyal citizens of Nashville, from the Mayor down to the humblest.

The members of the State Legislature who ar rived in the City yesterday morning from Albany, per steamer St. John, are stopping at the Astor House, Metropolitan and St. Nicholas Hotels. They are expected to remain in the City until Tues- day evening.

Officers from the front represent everything quiet there this morning. The officers and men of the army are delighted at the prospect of having a general from the West to command, It will have the effect of wiping out all old grievances and contentions.

Mr. EBEN MERRIM, well known as a sta tistician and meteorologist, died at his resi- dence, No. 47 Orange-street, (Brooklyn Heights,) on Saturday afternoon, of dropsy of the liver. Thus has passed away one who devoted alife- time to the scientific and pecuniary benefit of his fellow-men. Mr, MERIAM was born in Concord, Massachusetts, June 17, 1794. and consequently was in the 70th year of his age.

At the close of the Patent Office Fair on Friday night, President LINCOLN, in answer to loud and continuous calls, made the following remarks:

C.W. McN. SHIPMAN, agent of the United States Sanitary Commission, acknowledges the receipt from Gen. REID, recent commandant at this post, of nearly $15,000, for aid of the white refugees arriving here. Of this sum, $12,500 have already been disbursed.

The English people have been a good deal stirred up on the subject of capital punishment lately, in consequence of the execution, at once, of five seamen for murder. We narrowly escaped, on Saturday last, a similar horror, in the case of the crew of the Lone Star. They were three all young men.
The steamer Fanny was sunk on the 16th inst., near Egg Point, fifteen miles above Grand Lake. No lives were lost, and most of her cargo was saved.

The adjourned meeting of the Union caucus of last week met to-night, but owing to the slim attendance no definite action was had upon any of the matters under discussion. The chairman was authorized to call them together whenever it was deemed expedient. The principle subject under consideration was the duty of Union members generally to stand by the action of committees on all important measures, which was fully acquiesced in by all those present.

Nobody who read the speech of Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, which we published on Saturday, can help seeing that whatever the feelings of the people at the South may be, the leaders are bitterly and terribly in earnest. He makes much of the desire of his audience either to return to the Union or remain neutral.
Gen. GRANT arrived this morning, and is now at the Continental Hotel.

Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, (Union,) presented a remonstrance of 117 members of the New-York Legislature, against the extension of the Goodyear patent; also one from ERASTUS CORNING and others to the same effect. Referred to the Committee on Patents.

The Assembly have taken very questionable action to-day. It has for some time been apparent that special effort must be made in order to dispose of the bills which have accumulated upon the files. There has been a strong desire to avoid the discredit of a grinding committee.

Newbern, N.C., advices to the 19th inst., mention that a great commotion was caused among the rebel troops in that region when Richmond was menaced by Gen. KILPATRICK. PICKETT, the rebel General, sent off several of his regiments in great haste to defend the city, and stopped pending military operations within his command. These regiments are now reported to be coming back.

At the meeting of the Commissioners of Health, yesterday, a communication was received from the City Inspector, in regard to the prevalence of ship fever in certain localities of the City, which is attributed to an unusual amount of emigration, and large numbers of emigrants taking lodgings in the narrow by-streets.
The Seventeenth New-York Infantry arrived from below, to-day, en route home.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their chamber, number sixteen City Hall.

It is said that a committee is about to report favorably on the bill admitting the heads of the various departments to seats in the House, and giving each the right of speaking on any subject connected with their branch of the public service. Such a measure would remedy a great defect in our national system of legislation.

Last evening the Purim Association gave their third Grand Fancy Dress Ball, at the Academy of Music. The Association was formed in 1862 by nine young men of the Jewish faith, its first ball was given at Irving Hall in 1862, its second at the Academy of Music in 1863, and its third at the same hall last evening.

Whereas, the day known as Good-Friday is widely observed throughout the Christian world, in solemn remembrance of the crucifixion of our Lord Jesus Christ for us men and our salvation, the undersigned hereby respectfully propose to their Christian brethren of this City a general agreement in that observance, on the coming 25th of the present month, being the day on which Good-Friday this year occurs.

Mr. A.X. PARKER moved to suspend the rules so that local bills and bills not conveying franchises or making appropriations from the Treasury, may be referred to committees, with power to report complete.
The Assembly resolutions, to send to the Metropolitan Fair for exhibition sundry curiosities from the State Cabinet of Natural History, was adopted.

Mr. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, (Union,) from the Committee on Commerce, reported a bill, which was passed, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to stipulate for the release from attachment or other process property claimed by the United States; in other words, to enable the Government to make arrangements to use the property it wants without waiting for legal process.

The recent raid on Richmond caused the rebel Gen. PICKETT to send several of his regiments from this State to Virginia, just as he was ready to commence operations in this direction. These regiments are returning, however, evidently with a view of carrying out their original intentions.

In the Senate to day a unanimous report was made by the committee against the BroadwayHarlem Railroad Bill. Subsequently a motion wass made to lay the report on the table, which was carried by a vote of twenty-two yeas to one nay. Several of the Senators who voted for the motion stated that their vote would not bind them to support the bill, as they were opposed to it.

Everything is quiet at Jacksonville. Col. GUY V. HENRY'S Light Brigade continues to hold its position in front of the intrenchments. Palatka is still occupied by troops under the command of Col. BALTON. The rebel pickets are near Three Mile Run, while the main force is at Baldwin.
The Austrians are advancing large forces upon Fredericia.

The proposed review of the army of the Potomac, to-morrow, will not take place. Gen. GRANT, who arrived here this morning, proceeds at once to the front. The reorganization of the army will be quietly and speedily consummated.
The steamship Germania, on the 9th March from Southampton, also arrived last evening.

The Legislature is just now having its annual spasm over the appointment of a "Grinding Committee." Toward the close of every Session the same debate is had on the subject the same struggle is renewed between apprehensive virtue and impatience to secure the passage of bills, and the same result is reached: the committee is appointed and the work goes on.
The Royal Mail steamer China, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 11:30 on the morning of the 12th, and Queenstown on the afternoon of the 13th March, arrived here at a late hour last night.
The steamer Pauline Carveil, from New-Orleans, has arrived here with a cargo of sugar andd molasses for St. Louis. She brings no news of general interest from New-Orleans.

The House of Representatives was yesterday the scene of another of those terrible rows between the Missouri members, which have so frequently disgraced the present session of Congress. This time it was BLAIR vs. McCLURG, and the language and epithets they applied to each other were of a nature that must astound respectable people.
Advices from Vicksburgh, of March 15, give the following intelligence:

It seems that poor old Gen. PRICE, who has not been heard of since he was so badly whipped by our negro troops at Helena, last Summer, gain threatens to take the field. He has issued an address to his men, promising soon to lead them against their "cowardly and boasting foes," and prophecying that he and they will retrieve past reverses, reoccupy lost territory, Gen. PRICE should not talk in this style.
The Democratic State Convention met here today, and organized by the election of GEORGE REX as President, after considerable confusion and squabbling by Vallandigham men.
The following is the report of the brig Howard, arrived yesterday, which H.B.M, gunboat Styx, arrived at Halifax, repored hadispoken the Italian frigate Re Galantuemo:
The extra Cunard screw steamer Olympus, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th March, arrived here at 6 o'clock last evening.
The hearing of the appeal to the House of Lords, to the case of the gunboat Alexandra, was fixed for the 11th of March.

The Court of Appeals has been occupied nearly the entire day in hearing an argument by Judge STUART for the prisoner, and S.D. MORRIS, DistrictAttorney, in the Ignatz-Radtzky diamond-merchant murder case. The case attracts much attention.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. MAEWTZEK'S Boston season will close on Saturday next, and on the following Monday the impresario opens at our Academy. The opera selected for the occasion is "Faust." Subscribers can procure their seats, , to-day the ticket office opening for that purpose. On Friday the regular sale of tickets commences.
