Mr. WILSON of Massachusetts, (Union,) from the Committee on the Military, reported on the House bill establishing a Bureau of Military Justice, with an amendment changing the head officer of the Bureau from Major to Colonel.
Gov. Evans has issued a proclamation calling a Constitutional Convention for the the first Monday in May.

East and West! We look alternately across the North Sea and the Atlantic. In our quiet nook in this peaceful land of non-intervention, where ironclad ships and Armstrong guns are only experimental playthings we can look out on two wars with that kind of enjoyment that people are said to have, who, safe on the shore, behold ships and sailors tossing on a stormy sea.
The friends of Gov, JOHNSON here confidentially expect his nomination by the Republican Convention as Vice-President on the ticket with President LISCOLN.
On March 13 an adjourned meeting of the citizens of Madison County, Ala., was held at Huntsville. Hon. JERE CLEMENS, Ex-United States Senator, stated the object of the meeting as follows:
By Mr. ANGELL The West Shore and North Shore Railroad bills. Against the Harlem-Broadway Railroad bill a unanimous report.
The severest storm of the season commenced here yesterday morning, continuing throughout the day and night, accompanied by a heavy fall of snow.
The following order has been issued by the War Department:
Yesterday the United States iron-clad Onondaga was put formally in commission at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. She will go to sea this week. We published a list of her officers a few days ago.
The Democratic State Convention met to-day, and organized by the election of WILLIAM H. WITTE as permanent President, and ROBERT J. HEMPHILL as Secretary.
Sailed, steamer Constitution, for Panama, with 150 passengers and $800,000 in treasure for England, and $206,000 for New-York.
GENERAL ORDERS No. 10 1. The Following order has been received from the War Department:
The following letter was written by Gen. GRANT, in acknowledgement of the gift of a sword by the people of Jo Daviess County, Ill.:
BILLS REPORTED. To amend the charter of the Home Insurance Company.

The Board of Commissioners of the New-York Fire Department have disbanded Engine Company No. 47, on complaint of Hose Company No. 19, for running them into the sidewalk. The case was a very important one; the board examined over sixty witnesses, and did not adjourn until 2 o'clock in the morning. Ex-Judge PHILLIPS appeared on behalf of Engine Company No. 47.
FORREST is reported at Bolivar, Tenn., with 7,000 men, stopping men moving North. GRIEBSON'S cavalry is looking out after the rebels.
A dispatch from Cairo says: "We have good news from the Red River expedition, which comes from undoubted authority.

Subsequent to the arrival of the steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool, on last Saturday, the 19th inst., JOHN HARVEY, a third-class passenger, who had been ill during the voyage, died just previous to the landing of the passengers at Castle Garden.

The second regiment of colored troops, raised under the auspices of the Union League Club of this City, known as the Twenty-sixth United States Colored Troops, will receive their stand of colors from the ladies and parade through the City previous to embarking for the seat of war, to-morrow.

On motion of Mr. BLAINE, of Maine, (Union,) the Committee on the Judiciary was instructed to inquire into the expediency of proposing an amendment to the Constitution, by striking out the article which forbids the laying a tax on articles imported from any State.
Thomas Murphy plead guilty of petit larceny, and was remanded for sentence.

WINTER GARDEN. Mr. and Mrs. W.J. FLORENCE who have so long gratified the public with their admirable performances will take their last benefit here to-night, when the "Ticket-of-LeaveMan" will be played for the one hundred and second time. The piece will be withdrawn after tomorrow night, and on Monday Mme. METHUA-SOHELLER will appear in a new piece by Mr. DALY, called "Lorlie's Wedding."
The flag-of-truce steamer New-York arrived at Annapolis to-day with the released Union prisoners, numbering 63 officers and 920 soldiers. Five hundred of the number were sick.

THE PROVOST-MARSHAL-GENERAL TO HAVE INCREASED RANK AND PAY. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, (Union,) from the Military Committee, reported favorably on the bill to increase the rank, pay and emoluments of the Provost-Marshal-General, proposing to give that officer the rank and emoluments of a Brigadier-General.

March played this year a scurvy trick on the milliners, coaxing them with false looks and deceitful smiles to the belief that Spring had really come, setting people wild after new Spring bonnets and plaid cloaks, and then turning literally a cold shoulder upon its friends, and pouring, literally also, cold water upon the hopes it had fostered into existence.
A flag of truce for the exchange of rebel for Union citizens, went to the front to-day.

The weather for the past four or five days has been decidedly cold and disagreeable. Business, however, and travel, all the time increase. Immediately in our midst, outside of the military, nothing is transpiring of moment. For the past few days there has been a considerable buzz around headquarters. and yesterday Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, Maj.-Gens. ROUSSEAU, DODGE, SHERMAN, and SHERRIDAN, and Brig.- ...
Maj.-Gen. Ambrose E. Burnside passed through this City yesterday, en route to his residence in Providence, Rhode Island.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President submitted a communication from the President, inclosing a report from the Secretary of State, in relation to the establishment of a monarchical Government in Central and South America. Referred, and ordered to be printed. Mr. TRUMBULL introduced a bill to construct a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River.

One of the most successful expeditions ever recorded of our operations in this vicinity, was that sent out on the 1st of last month, commanded by Col. JAMES II. COATES, of the Eleventh Illinois infantry. The force consisted of the Eleventh Illinois infantry, Eighth Louisiana infantry, and First Mississippi cavalry the two latter being colored troops.

FIRE AND EXPLOSION ONE MAN KILLED Loss $15,000. An explosion in the Kerosene Oil Re finery of the New-York Coal Oil Company, whose office is at No. 104 Maiden-lane, occurred about halfpast 8 o'clock on Thursday evening, at Hunter's Point, L.I. One of the night watchmen named JAMES NOONEN entered the room where the oil is refined, with a lighted lamp, when instantly an explosion occurred, and the building was set on fire.

At the present time there is an unusual excitement in the billiard circles in the vicinity, which extends even to the far West, occasioned by the near approach of the time set for the trial for the American Championship, between KAVANAGH of this City, the present holder of the champion cue, and TIEMAN, of Cincinnnati, who desires to dispute the NewYorker's right of possession.

The pressure on our space of other matter has prevented us from recurring to the serious and important topic of "Miscegenation." We regret very much, however, having allowed our attention to be even temporarily diverted from it, as we find from the earnest discussion which it is receiving at the hands of our cotemporaries, that it has lost none of its importance.

W.T. SHERMAN'S late report of his operations oflast Winter furnishes a satisfactory explanation of a portion of his conduct, that was at the time and has continued to be made the subject of considerable censure. We refer to his failure to pursue LONGSTREET, after that General had given up the siege of Knoxville in December last.

We have had a pretty strong attack of the war, fever since my last. The sleepy old House of Lords, that generally meets at 5 P.M. and adjourns in 20 minutes or half an hour, on Tuesday night waked itself up and "pitched into" Earl RUSSELL. Four Earls, DERBY, ELLENBOROUGH, GREY and SHAFTSBURY of whom the Music Hall chorus says:

The bill of which we spoke the other day, authorizing the construction of an Underground Railroad from Central Park to the Battery, has been introduced into the Legislature. In addition to the main line, it is proposed also to construct branches, connecting it with the Harlem, New-Haven and Hudson River Railroads.

The Constitutionnel of this morning, a paper which speaks more correctly for the Government than any of the semi-official papers, declares that the new Holy Alliance is a phantom, and the loud cries of the English journals so many false alarms. The conditions of such an alliance, according to this journal, no longer exist.
The Floral Committee of the Metropolitan Fair appeal to the public through the columns of the TIMES, hoping thus to gain the attention of some whom their circulars have not reached.
The Secretary of State transmitted the official canvas of the election on the 8th instant to amend the Constitution relative to soldiers voting. The whole number of votes cast was 307,435.

At a meeting of the Young Men's Union Central Committe, held at Headquarters, corner of Twentythird-street and Broadway, on Thursday evening, March 17, 1864, the following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted:

In the Senate, yesterday, the result of the official canvass of the election on the 8th inst., relative to soldiers voting, was announced, showing that of 305,435 ballots cast, 48,079 were against the amendment. A petition was presented for a railroad in Fifty-ninth-street, New-York, and also from the Staten Island Ferry Company for a new ferry slip.

Gen. GANDARA has been appointed CaptainGeneral of the Spanish part of St. Domingo, and also promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-General in the Spanish armies. His rise has been very rapid, having been only a few years ago a Brigadier-General.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your recent article upon extravagance interested us in the country exceedingly, expressing our sentiments exactly. Now, we live in the land of steady habits, where, during this war, the price of cotton has so appalled us, that we actually mend up, and "top over" articles of wearing apparel in a way that I suppose would be perfectly shocking to the taste of your city ladies.

Editor of the New-York Times: In connection with your remarks in Saturday's issue in regard to the recent accident on this road, permit me to add some experience of my own on this delectable route to Philadelphia.

Secretary CHASE is understood to be making arrangements for the issue of gold notes, receivable for duties, which he proposes to pay for the interest falling due on April 1, May 1, July 1, August 19, October 1, November 1, 1864, and January 1, 1865, without rebate on interest due on and before July 1, and with rebate at the rate of 3 per cent, per annum on interest due after that date.

The meeting of the Historical Society Monday evening was unusually interesting. The Chiefs of the six tribes were present. Mr. FREDERIO DE PEYSTER presided. Dr. OSGOOD in a short speech stated the object of the meeting. Mr. DE PEYSTER delivered the welcome address to the chiefs, which was interpreted by Mr. PIERCE of the Senecas.

We are enabled this morning to lay before our readers direct and reliable news from the Idaho gold mines. Dr. E.D. RALPH, an old and well-known citizen of this city, went to Bannock last year with a stock of goods, and has just returned. We have had a conversation with him, and gather the following interesting particulars:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Perhaps no one act of Mr. LINCOLN'S administration has been so widely discussed, so vehemently condemned on the one hand, and so joyously hailed on the other, as that one which called into the field as soldiers the black men, both free and slave, of America.

Private William Vongster, One Hundred and Seventy-eighth New-York Volunteers, sentenced to be shot for falling asleep on his post as a guard of the Forest Hall Prison, in Georgetown, has been pardoned by the President firstly, because the kindhearted President can't help pardoning soldiers, and secondly, because it was proved that Vongster was the best soldier in his company, and was tired when unexpectedly placed on duty.

Sailed, ship William Chamberlain, for Callao. The Union State Convention organized at Sacra mento, yesterday, by the election of WILLIAM H. SEARS, Chairman, by 45 majority over W.H. PARKS, (Anti-Conness candidate.) The whole vote cast amounted to 257.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the many towns doing nobly for our soldiers, Flushing, L.I., takes a high rank. Here is the record, so far, this year: When the Metropolitan Fair was proposed, Flushing immediately made up in cash $2,000. Next the ladies united with other Long Island towns, and sent $1,700, in salable articles, hospital stores and money, to the Brooklyn Fair.

CHILDREN'S DEPARTMENT OF THE METROPOLITAN FAIR.--The children's department will occupy the easterly wing of the buildings on Union-square, and will be contained in a hall ninety feet square, arranged with booths on the sides and a stage for performances.

Dispatches from Gen. SIBLEY'S scouts at the head of the Coteau de Prairie, northwest from Lake Traverse, indicate that buffaloes are coming down the valleys of the James and Cheyenne Rivers, and that the half-starved Indians are following them.
The truly Irish demonstration of Irish brotherhood at the Dublin Rotunda has been followed by another, and less lawless, indication of the discord which prevails in the "National" party.
The examination of John E. Cook, first mate of the ship Victory, was continued yesterday morning.

We have at last news of active work in this department. On the 15th instant a portion of the fleet appeared opposite Alexandria and demanded its surrender. The demand was complied with without, so far as we can learn, any show of opposition.

It is generally known that the Navy Department is constructing a fleet of immense screw propellers, designed especially for speed and power. At this station three of these vessels--the Wampanoag, Mattawasca and Idaho--are in progress.

There can be no doubt that an immense goldseeking immigration will come to or pass through this Territory during the ensuing Summer, when the mountains and valleys and canons of the Territory will be thoroughly prospected, and the vexed question as to the mineral capabilities of Utah be settled.

A telegram from Turin of March 13, says, M. PIEDO, the new Swiss Envoy, presented his credentials to-day.

Major WM. P. MORRIS, paymaster in the army, a citizen of Philadelphia, died here on the 22d.

RETURN OF GEN. GRANT FROM THE ARMY. Gen. GRANT came up from the army this even ing and was closeted several hours with the Secretary of War. He says the reorganization of the army is progressing rapidly, and when completed it will be the finest army on the Continent. He will return to the front to-morrow.

The Memorial Diplomatique says: The draft of a treaty was agreed upon at the Tuileries, to be ratified as soon as the Emperor MAXIMILIAN I. shall have ascended the Mexican throne and announced his accession to the Court of the Tuileries.

Danish coinage has been abolished in Schleswig, and German introduced instead.

The murmurings that come over the water from England, have an ominous and threatening sound, not certainly foretelling the shock of arms, but, as before the Crimean "drifting" into war, they betoken the uneasiness and the slow up-working of the popular feeling on a question which may at any moment plunge the nation into a tremendous struggle.

Reports were circulated here this morning that the rebels, under FORREST, attacked Paducah, Ky., 50 miles above here, yesterday, and burned part of the town; but as telegraphic communication is cut off, no authentic information could be obtained.

It will certainly be a source of satisfaction to the country to know that though apparently idle the Army of the Potomac is not asleep, as was fully illustrated in the recent attempted raid by STUART.

The last of this series of papers brought the review of Gen. McCLELLAN's Report down to the safe and secret evacuation of Yorktown by the enemy an act which Gen. McCLELLAN attributes to the siege preparations which he had occupied a whole month in making, but which there is now little doubt was much more powerfully prompted by the menacing position of McDOWELL's corps at Fredericksburgh.

Among the kaleidoscopic changes which Mexico is now constantly exhibiting, one of the strangest is the sudden emergence of SANTA ANA from his obscurity of the last nine years, his flitting a moment as a flaming partisan of the new Empire, and then his equally sudden projection back into the shades.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.

THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT. The Division Court of Inquiry, instituted on the 17th of February last to inquire whether the Sixty-ninth volunteered into the service of the United States, and whether the Sixty-ninth became a part of the Corcoran Legion, have adjourned.

SUBSCRIPTIONS TO THE TEN-FORTY LOAN. The First National Bank of Washington has re ceived authority to receive subscriptions to the tenforty loan.

Your old Kansas correspondent finds time to write some brief notes. He is on duty at this place. Gen. BLUNT arrived on Wednesday last, and assumed command, yesterday, of the District and Army of the Frontier. It appears that in the recent changes of department lines, a portion of Gen. BLUNT's old district and army found themselves in the Department of Arkansas.
THE PROHIBITION OF SLAVERY. Mr. NORTON, of Illinois, (Union,) introduced a joint resolution, proposing an amendment to the Constitution, prohibiting Slavery in the States and Territories.

JOHN RANDOLPH, of Roanoke, was a remarkably eccentric man; yet in some respects had very strong sense, and especially in affairs of business. He had a great estate, with many negroes, and managed it well.

Before Judge Shipman. Henry C. Sorrenson and Evan Edwards, seamen on board the bark Lone Star, convicted of manslaughter in killing the mate of the vessel, Charles Courletta, by beating him on the head with a belaying pin and throwing him overboard, were brough up this morning for sentence. Edwards handed to the Judge the following letter:

Three men employed on Government vessels here, report that on their way from Biddeford to this city they saw two vessels on fire, between 4 and 5 o'clock this morning. One about four miles distant, near Wood Island, burnt to near the water's edge; she was heading toward the island; the other from eight to ten miles distant.
JAMES S. THOMAS was unanimously nominated by the Radicals, to-day, for Mayor, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Mr. FILLEY. The election takes place on the first Monday in April.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 53 bbls. Ashes, 13,223 bbls. Flour, 640 bbls, and 857 bags Corn Meal, 15,275 bushels Wheat, 39,840 bushels Corn, 10,657 bushels Malt, 30,876 bushels Oats, 4,017 pkgs. Provisions, 1,686 bbls, Whisky.

In the changes lately made in the Corps Commanders of the Army of the Potomac, though Gen. PLEASONTON was relieved from the command of the Cavalry Corps, no officer was nominated to fill the vacant place. We take it this arose from the fact that the military authorities were not immediately able to pitch upon the proper man for this important and peculiar command.

The Common Council, yesterday, passed over the Mayor's veto, the resolution granting to the Third-avenue Railroad Company permission to extend their tracks through certain streets. It is now a law. Resolutions were adopted relative to the death of MATTHIAS GOODERSON, Superintendent of Markets. It was resolved to close all the public offices, and to attend the funeral in a body, to-day.
The steamship North Star, Capt. LEFEVRE, arrived at this port last evening from a cruise in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, which vessel was spoken at sea in a sinking condition.

The United States transport steamer Daniel Webster, Capt. DEARING, arrived here this morning from Washington, D.C., with a load of mules. She leaves for New-York, via Fortress Monroe, at five o'clock this morning.

On the 9th instant an expedition left Jacksonville for this place, arriving the following morning. No enemy was found here. Our forces are now intrenched, and hold the town, waiting patiently for the enemy to come and see us.

The venerable Rev. JOHN PIERPONT, in November, 1861, began, and in March, 1864, finished, a Di gest of the Decisions and Instructions of the Treasury Department to Collectors of Customs, contained in fifty-four folio volumes, which he has reduced to one. The Secretary of the Treasury has sent him the following complimentary letter:

SIR: Referring to my communication addressed to you on the 7th of January last, and in view of the amendment which has been offered by you, at the instance of the Committee on Finance, to restore the provisions of law which formerly authorized, as an important part of the Consular system.

In pursuance of directions from Gen. SCHOFIELD and in accordance with Gen. GRANT'S orders, Kentucky has been divided into two districts. The Western District comprises all between the Nashville Railroad and the Cumberland River, under Gen. EWING, with headquarters on the railroad.

FORREST, with a force estimated at 7,000, was reported within eight miles of Columbus, Ky., last night. They cut the telegraph lines between that place and Cairo yesterday.

REPORTS. Against the Brooklyn Fire Department Bill. Recommitted. Against the New-York Aldermanic Tax-Levy Bill. Agreed to. Against the petition of the Staten Island Ferry Company for a new ferry slip. Recommitted.
BILLS PASSED. To legalize certain acts of the New-York Common Council. To amend the charter of the Sixth-avenue Savings Bank.

The bill providing the way in which soldiers may vote under the amendment of the Constitution of this State, came up in Assembly this morning as special order. It was expected that a good deal of opposition would be manifested by the Democratic part of the House to the provisions of this bill.
The City of Manchester, For Liverpool, March 16, and Queenstown March 17, arrived yesterday morning, bringing one day's later telegraphic intelligence than that received by the America.

Our forces, under Col. HICKS, at Paducah, comprised the First Battalion of the Sixteenth Illinois, numbering 300 raw recruits, under Maj. BARNES, three companies of the One Hundred and Twenty-second Illinois, 120 strong, under Maj. CHAPMAN, and 250 of the First Kentucky Heavy Artillery, (colored,) under Lieut. CUNNINGHAM.

Lieut.-Gen, GRANT, accompanied by Maj.-Gen. MEADE, yesterday reviewed the First Corps of the Army of the Potomac, now a part of the Fifth Corps. Everywhere along the lines, on his way to the review ground, the General-in-Chief was enthusiastically received by the troops.

A special dispatch to the Democrat, from Charleston, Coles County, says the Copperheads came into that town to attend court yesterday, with guns concealed in their wagons and armed with pistols. Some soldiers in the Conrt-house yard were drawn into an affray, and a general fight occurred.
A special dispatch to the Tribune, dated Mattoon, Ill., last night, says:

Hon. JAMES H. LANE, United States Senator from Kansas, addressed the Central Union Lincoln Campaign Club last evening, at the Cooper Institute. The meeting was large and exceedingly enthusiastic. On a table in front of the platform facing the audience, was a marble bust of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, and on either side the American flag was suspended.
Consols, after official hours, yesterday, closed at 91 @91 7/8.
Memphis papers of the evening of the 28th contain no news.

KIRBY SMITH, of the rebel army in the Department of the Mississippi, had been negotiating with certain parties in the United States, with the knowledge and consent of the rebel Government at Richmond, to exchange cotton for provisions, army clothing and other articles of which the rebel troops were in most pressing need.

A heavy rain storm set in last night, accompanied with hail. The weather is moderating this forenoon, with some prospect of its clearing up.

Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday completed the sale of five-year leases of market cellars and other Corporation property, the leases for which had expired or will expire by May 1. The sale was a very successful one.
The steamer David Tatum, which reached Cairo last night, reports a part of FORREST'S forces crossing the Cumberland River at Eddyville. A gunboat has been sent up the river to look after the matter.
A late Berlin dispatch says that five Prussian batteries are ready to open fire across the Weninberg. The Danish iron-clad Golf Drake has been repulsed.

We have the report from East Tennessee that the Yankees, who had advanced as far east as Morristown, have again taken the back track, and retired to Strawberry Plains, only some fifteen or twenty miles from Knoxville. This retreat of the enemy has dissipated, for the present at least, all prospects of a fight.

During yesterday the wind was from east northeast and blew heavily with rain througdout the day. From pilots come in from sea we learn the gale was severe outside. The pilot-boat M.E. Fish, No. 4, when off the Highlands, picked up three barrels of kerosene marked No. 2, from a lot of about twenty barrels; saw no other wrecked stuff.

By instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury, dated March 26, 1864, this Bank will receive subscriptions for the National 10-40 Five Per Cent. Loan, in coupon bonds or registered certificates, redeemable after ten, and payable forty years from date, in coin, and will allow to banks, bankers and brokers the usual commission of one-eighth of one per cent.

The Enquirer publishes an appeal to the benevolent in behalf of soldiers' families and other poor of the city, which says: "The poor have not been able to procure supplies at the shops established by the city councils, even at the reduced prices charged by the committee." The appeal states that pressing necessity exists for immediate aid to prevent absolute suffering.
A chapter will be written by some future historian on the horrors of the "Libby Prison," which will almost equal in fearful interest the records of the Bastile.

JOHN REYNOLDS, convicted of manslaughter, was sentenced to two years' confinement in the State Prison. Prisoner was convicted of killing PAT. MATTHEWS, and was tried over a year ago, his case having been removed to the Supreme Court on a writ of error.

Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, (Union,) presented the, memorial of the Cincinnati Horticultural Society, declaring that important and beneficial results from the establishment of the Department of Agriculture had already become apparent, taking away all apology for further timid legislation regarding it, and therefore praying Congress to sustain it with liberal appropritions from the public treasury. Referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
The rebel Gen. FORREST is again on the rampage through Western Kentucky and Tennessee, plundering, burning, killing and doing whatever other damage he can to the rebel cause.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their chamber, number sixteen City Hall.

In the Senate, yesterday, the House Bill providing for a territorial government for Montana, was passed, with an amendment striking out the word " white" in the section which prescribes the qualifications and officeholders in the Territory. The joint resolution for an Anti-Slavery amendment to the Constitution came up, and was opposed by Messrs. SAULSBURY and DAVIS, and advocated by Mr. CLARK. The Senate then adjourned.

The monopoly of Camden and Amboy propose to succeed by foul means, if they cannot succeed otherwise. Much indignation was caused at Trenton yesterday, among those who are not carried in the pockets of the monopoly, at the introduction of a bill by Mr. BENSON, of Hudson, to repeal the charter of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Company.

The Provost Marshal-General has ordered the seizure of POLLARD'S Southern History of the War, the Confederate Official Reports, the Life of STONE WALL JACKSON, MORGAN and his men, and all publications based upon rebel information circulating of for sale in this department.
The special dispatch of the Democrat, from Cairo, says:

The United States steamer Commodore Barney, with fifty-six picked men from the Minnesota, all in charge of Capt. J.M. WILLIAMS, left this point yesterday afternoon, proceeded up the Chuckatuck Creek, and landed the men in small boats at the head of the Creek.
The steamer Golden Age arrived last night from Panama.
Santa Fe papers of the 19th say that on the night of the 14th, one wing of the Capitol buildings was destroyed by fire. Valuable papers in very important law cases were destroyed.
Mr. SHANNON, of California, (Union,) from the Committee on Indian Affairs, reported the Senate bill for the better organization of the Department of Indian Affairs in California.
As the time for the inauguration of the Metropolitan Fair lessens the contributions increase. The work devolving upon the different committees keeps them busy during the day and into the night.

The steamer Fulton, which arrived from Port Royal yesterday, when about 65 miles from Cape Henry, on the night of March 29, spoke a two-masted propeller firing signal guns. A heavy gale and the high sea prevented any effectual efforts to relieve her, although the Fulton spoke her and endeavored to lay by her through the night. On the next morning the propeller was not in sight.
About sixty rebel deserters have come into our lines during the past week, making a total of over 1,100 for the past three months.
The United States steam transport Fulton, WOTTON, Commander, from Port Royal, March 27, at 3 o'clock P.M., with mails and passengers to Major STEWART VAN VLIET, Quartermaster.

In a speech just delivered in Portland, Gen. NEAL Dow, who for nine months has been a prisoner at Richmond and other points, detailing his personal observations, made the statement that "at present the rebels are looking anxiously at movements at the North in relation to the next Presidential election, and their hope is that some other man than Mr. LINCOLN may be nominated and elected."
About one hundred of the rebel force under Gen. FORREST crossed the Cumberland River at Eddyville yesterday.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. "Faust" was given here last evening to a tremendous house and with the usual success. There is nothing more to say.

The ship Staffordshire, from Kennebunk for St. John, N.B., which anchored in the bay several days and then disappeared, was to-day seen off this place with her masts all gone; probably cut away. A vessel has gone out to her.

About 10,000 effective troops have gone South from this district. The whole number in the department, under Gen. STEELS, now moving southward, is from 30,000 to 35,000, sufficient to overpower any rebel force opposed to them.
On the receipt of the news of the riot at Charleston, Ill., two hundred and fifty men of the Fifty-fourth Illinois Regiment, rendezvousing here, went to Charleston.

Ashes, 10.054 bbls, Flour, 388 bbls. and 557 bags Corn Meal, 22,045 bushels Wheat, 1,002 bushels Corn, 80 bushels Rye, 6,500 bushels Barley, 60,350 bushels Oats, 657 bushels Mait, 5,277 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,668 bbls. Whisky.

It has been my misfortune during the past few months to ride several times by railway, between New-York and Washington. At one time, in common with four hundred others, I was disembarked at Havre-de-Grace in the middle of the night, and after a tedious passage over the river on the ferry-boat, passed nearly two hours on the further side, waiting for the down train from New-York, which was to take us on our journey.

The Canadian Ministry has been formed. Sir E.B. TACHE is Premier, Receiver-General and Minister of Milltia; Mr. CARTIER, Attorney-General for Canada East; Mr. GALT, Finance Minister; Mr. CHAPAIS, Commissioner of Public Works; Mr. McGEE, Minister of Agriculture; Mr. LANGEVIN, Solicitor-General for Canada East; JOHN A. McDONALD, Attorney-General for Canada West; WM. CAMPBELL, Crown Lands; Mr. FOLEY, Postmaster-Generl; Mr. SIMPSON, Provincial Secretary; Mr. COCKBURN, Solicitor-General for Canada West.
The enemy in our front are guarding their lines with unusual care, in order to cut off all information from us as to their strength.

Capt. J.H. WILLIAMS, PROVOST-Marshal of the District of Cairo, was arrested last night and taken to Memphis to answer before Gen. HURLBUT, for offences not yet made public. The brother of WILLIAMS, Lieut. THROOP and Mr. BUELL, a criminal attorney, were also arrested and confined at Columbus, charged with being connected with WILLIAMS in the offences which caused his arrest.
A letter from the Army of the Potomac says the rebels for the past two days have been busily engaged in digging rifle pits along the south side of the Rapidan, in the vicinity of Raccoon Ford.

The Tax Levy Bill which has been forwarded to Albany is exciting the strongest opposition from citizens. As we have stated, it estimates the expenses of the year at $15,000,000. The dissection which will be given it will reveal startling facts and the most profligate designs for the expenditure of the public monies.

In the absence of any books of very remarkable character, the recent issues of the publishers evince considerable activity in catering for the tastes of the reading world, and testify to the existence of a lively general demand for books.

NEW-YORK, Friday, April 1, 1864 6 P.M. The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 29 bbls, Ashes, 6,684 bbls. Flour, 387 bags Corn Meal, 1,463 bushels Wheat, 4,522 bushels Oats, 660 bushels Malt, 5,233 pkgs, Provisions, and 1.351 bbls, Whisky.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. MEYERBEER'S grand opera "Robert le Diabie," was produced here last evening, with a degree of success which will insure its repetition on many occasions during the present season. It is pleasant to know that there is one opera at least that "Faust" has not staled.

On Thursday the Inman steamer the City of Baltimore, Capt. MIREHOUSE, arrived in the harbor at an early hour. The Baltimore on this occasion was employed as an extra boat, in addition to the ordinary weekly sailing. She brought from Liverpool 400 passengers, and took in here something over one hundred, leaving for Thursday's steamer no less than 400 more, of whom it is probable not more than half will be able to find room.

Strange phenomena does the cunning brain of man develop, Coal and wood are about to lose their prestige, and Water, with which we have all along fought fire, will, to a great extent, take their place, for it has been practically found that it will burn.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their chamber, No. 16, City Hall.

An allegorical figure of New-York, just at this period, if true to the life at all, would be a man or a woman either would do-inflicting wounds with one hand, and salving them over with the other. We are to open a Sanitary Fair, at Palace Garden, on Monday, to heal up the hurts of our soldiers, while at home we are all the while doing the best we can to multiply those hurts.

The most material change is in the manner of appointing and removing the teachers employed in the Ward Schools. The total number of these teachcrs is about two thousand.

The articles on "Conscription," the "Raid upon Richmond."

SUICIDE OF A WEALTHY CITIZEN. Justice AVERY, of Hoboken, held an inquest this week upon the body of CORNELIUS BOGERT, a wealthy and respect able gentleman, 63 years of age, residing at No. 234 Washington-street, Hoboken, who committed suicide by cutting his throat.

England hopes for peace. The Government has put so much pressure upon poor Denmark that it is now expected she will consent to a conference on any terms. It is not sure, but ardently hoped by the Government, which must avoid a war, because it cannot fight with Germany, and does not know what may come from America.
The steamer Sultana, with New-Orleans dates of the 25th of March, arrived here yesterday with a cargo of sugar for St. Louis, and the Sixth Indiana Veterans en route home.

The United States vs. J.S. Miller. The accused was indicted under the 24th section of the act to call out the national forces, for inducing a soldier to desert.

King LOUIS II., of Bavaria, has notified to his subjects his accession to the throne by a proclamation dated the 11th March, and countersigned by his Ministers. In this document the young king takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia. He orders that all the functionaries of the kingdom should continue their functions until he may decide otherwise.

Under date of March 16, he writes: "A very cozy house on Pine-street was found to be occupied by a widow lady, three daughters, and seven handsome little pigs. The compatibility of feeling between the families was surprisingly good.

We find the following in the Richmond Examiner: So far from Vicksburgh having been surrendered on account of a scarcity of supplies, it now appears officially that PEMBERTON had, at the time of the surrender, about 40,000 pounds of pork and bacon, which had been reserved for the subsistence of his troops in the event of his attempting to cut his way out of the city.
You are well aware that the inhabitants of this city do seriously cherish the gorgeous assurance of being, and remaining evermore, the Capital of the great Northwest.

The rebel Gen. McCULLOUGH is reported to be en route North with 2,500 men to reinforce Gen. FORREST.

A very significant meeting was held in Danville, on Monday, the 21st inst., in which two of the most distinguished men in Kentucky participated conspicuously, Dr. ROBERT J. BRECKINRIDGE and Hon. JOSHUA F. BELL. The assembly (it being County Court day) was large, and really represented the aggregate sentiments of Kentucky. Judge MITCHEL, a large slaveholder and most worthy citizen, presided.

The "Treasury Regulations" in North Carolina, which have been carried into practical execution by Hon. DAVID HEATON, have attained a success and perfection which challenge the admiration of all.

The correspondence between the Messrs. LAIRD BROTHERS and Her Majesty's Government has just been published in a pamphlet. Apparently, now, there is nothing more to be desired, in the way of curiosity, than the result of the pending trial, for the main facts have been frequently repeated.

In this document the young King takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia.

Secretary SEWARD'S letter to the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, on our Consular system, and the necessity for "Consular pupils," appointed by the Government, and trained to their duties, suggests some considerations with regard to the whole public service that are well worthy of attention.

GEN. MEADE AND THE BATTLE OF GETTYSBURGH. Gen. MEADE has submitted a written statement to the War Committee, giving a detailed account of the pattle of Gettysburgh, together with an explanation of his conduct on that occasion. His statements are corroborated by the testimony of Gens, HANCOCK, WARREN, GIBBONS and others, and triumphantly vindicate him from the accusations made before the committee by his enemies.

We have called attention before to the clear and conclusive arguments of a distinguished publicist of Boston, Hon. C.G. LORING, on questions at issue between England and America. Nothing more able in the recent discussions upon international law has appeared, in our judgment, on this side of the Atlantic.
Nothing of importance has transpired since the sailing of the Yazoo, two days ago.

Steamship Columbia, Barton, New Orleans March 26, and Havana 29th, with mdse. and passengers to Spofford, Tileston Co. Has had heavy N.E. gales. March 26, towing up the Mississippi River, bark Martha's Vineyard, of New-York, and schr. Electric. At anchor on the Bar, bark Ellingwood, of New-York.

We hear from Washington that a tremendous "pressure" is brought to bear upon the Union National Committee, to induce them to postpone the National Convention for nominating a Union Presidential candidate.

The building erected at the north end of Unionsquare rapidly approaches completion. Carpenters, painters, gilders, decorators, masons, plumbers, ar tisans of all sorts, work like beavers from 3 in the morning until 12 at night; but the heavy rains have interfered so much with the progress of the work, that this department of the great fair will not be opened until Tuesday morning.

The past week was one of almost unexampled prosperity at the Academy of Music, and if the weather had not been unpropitious in the early part of it, Mr. MARETZEK would certainly be able to show the largest returns ever known at his prices in the Fourteenth-street establishment.

The steamers Matanzas, from New-Orleans March 25, and the Columbia, from same port, March 26, arrived at this port yesterday. There was little additional news. The army was still advancing, but more slowly than it had been, because it was getting farther away from its supplies.

Money is tightening; rate firm at 2 per cent. per month. Atlantic currency exchange at the rate of 50@55 premium for gold in New-York. Coin bills, 5@6 premium. Telegraphic transfers, 7 premium. Sterling unchanged.

The two candidates of the democracy at the supplementary elections in the two vacant districts of Paris literally walked over the track. A few years ago the election of Messrs. CARNOT and GARNIER-PAGES by such majorities would have produced a terrible fluttering in the money market.
The Democrat's Leavenworth special dispatch says:

The funds on the 22d were steady throughout the day, but closed at a slight relapse. Consols 91 @5/8. The discount demand at the Bank was comparatively moderate. There was a revival in the demand for gold for the continent. Silver also was in increased demand for India.

Any new book of Mr. SMILES as scarcely needs critical recommendation to insure its meeting with thousands of readers. The happy discernment that led him to select a class of subjects strangely neglected until his day, is only equaled by the felicitous treatment that makes the annals of mechanical inventions, and the struggles and sufferings of their originators, in his hands, hardly second in interest to the exciting scenes of fictitious romance.

Gen. GRANT returned here to-day from Fortress Monroe. He at once called upon the President and Secretary of War, and held a protracted interview with them. While at Fortress Monroe, the preliminaries for the exchange of prisoners, upon a basis entirely satisfactory to the Government authorities, were concluded and heartily approved by him. He leaves for the front to-morrow.

We have reason to believe that on accepting the Crown of Mexico, the Emperor MAXIMILIAN Will address from Miramar, a formal notification of his accession to the throne to all the Provinces and Powers with which he desires to establish diplomatic relations. Among the number are the United States of America, Mr. DAYTON, the American Minister in Paris, having already intimated the readiness of his Government to accredit a Representative in Mexico.

We spoke some time ago about the case of the Tuscaloosa and her discharge from arrest at the Cape of Good Hope, conjecturing that this release might have followed from the British Government's noticing the bearing of her arrest upon our claims in the Alabama matter.

The Southern press is quite jubilant over the result of the late rebel financial operation, by which all holders of Government notes, over a certain value, have been compelled to convert them into four per cent. bonds, on pain of forfeiting a third of its value, on the 1st of April, and the entire value on the 1st of January, 1865.

By instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury, dated March 26, 1864, this Bank will receive subscriptions for the National 10-40 Five Per Cent. Loan, in coupon bonds or registered certificates, redeemable after ten, and payable forty years from date, in coin and will allow to banks, bankers and brokers the usual commission of one-eighth of one per cent.

The steamer Fairhaven, Capt. BLUNT, from NewYork, bound to Alexandria, was wrecked on the beach north of Cape Henry, in the gale on the night of the first of April. Though she had four hundred troops on board no lives were lost.
The indications now are that BUCKINGHAM is elected by 10,000 majority. The gains are very large over last year.

Taking the facts as they actually lie before us, and the people have already renominated Mr. LINCOLN. Since the fall of Vicksburgh and the reopening of the navigation of the Mississippi, this has been a very probable event. To reopen the great river of the West was, in the understanding of the Western people, an event in importance scarcely less than the entire subjugation of the rebels.
By order of Gov. MORTON, the entire Indiana Legion has been ordered to hold itself in readiness to take the field at any moment, to repel invasion.

The extra Cunard screw steamer Hecla, which left Liverpool at 8 P.M. on the 22d, and Queenstown on the 23d of March, arrived here at an early hour yesterday morning. She reports that the steamship Asia arrived at Queenstown at 10 A.M. on the 21st of March, and that the Louisiana arrived at Queenstown the same day.

The United States steam frigate Niagara returned on Sunday, having left this port March 18, to go in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, and has therefore been absent fifteen days. The Niagara has experienced very severe weather the whole time. On Wednesday, 23d, in latitude 40 45' north, longitude 33 27' west, her situation was appalling.

Mayor THOMAS' majority is over 2,500. The new Council will stand thirteen Radicals to seven Conservatives. The aggregate vote is about 10,000, or about one-third lees than at the election last Spring, when the Democrats ran a candidate.

Gen. J. Farnsworth, Cheshire; W.H. Phelps, Connecticut; C.S. Howe, Philadelphia; C.H. Wolfe. Pittsburgh; Cal. H.D. Booth, Chicago; W. Hellemv, Chicago; E.S. Goodrich, St. Paul and E.P. Fenion, Syracuse, are at the Metropolitan Hotel.

REVERDY JOHNSON ON SLAVERY. In a remarkably brilliant speech in the Senate today, REVERDY JOHNSON cut loose from all Pro-Slavery associations by a bold declaration of strongest AntiSlavery sentiments. He spoke in favor of immediate and universal emancipation, and advocated the proposed amendment to the Constitution forever prohibiting Slavery in the United States. Union Senators crowded around him with hearty congratulations when he closed, while Copperheads only scowled.

The Connecticut election bas resulted in a magnificent triumph for the Union cause and the Administration. It is a clear, distinct verdict in favor of the general course which has been pursued in putting down the rebellion. Less effort was put forth on both sides than for many years past.

A meeting of Commissioners of the International Bridge Company for a bridge between this point and Canada over the Niagara River, was held here yesterday afternoon. Over three millions was subscribed. The estimated cost of the bridge is only one million. The speedy construction is looked upon ascertain.

The schooner Berger, from Baltimore, bound to New-Haven, was run into by the propeller Virginia, in Chesapeake Bay, yesterday, and had her bowsprit carried away and bows stove in. She arrived here to-day. What damage the propeller received is not known.

The unanimous declaration of the popular branch of Congress that the United States will not assent to any monarchical Government in Mexico, erected under the auspices of any European Power, is but the expression of the universal feeling of the people.
Complete returns show the election of R. RENWICK, the Radical candidate for Mayor, by two votes. The Council stands seven Radicals and three Conservatives.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: How does it happen that among the princely contributions from every branch of trade and the professions, to the great Sanitary Fair, the hotel proprietors are unrepresented?

His Honor, Mayor GUNTHER, has addressed the following communication to the Legislature, relative to the Tax Levy. It deserves their serious attention, for three millions of dollars, which it proposes to save, to a sum too stupendous for them to saddle upon our citizens unnecessarily. Mayor GUNTHER'S proposition is a frank one, based on the knowledge that it can be sustained, and on facts which the Legislature, are doubtless ere this made fully aware of.

The completion of the buildings on Unionsquare complete the Metropolitan Fair, and when the visitor from the rural districts has exhausted all his adjectives while wandering through the mazes of beauty offered in Fourteenth-street, he will hear with astonishment that on Union-square there is another building almost as extensive, quite as elegant, and containing some features of novelty, splendor and variety, which render it the rival of its sister edifice.

Mr. HARRIS, of Kentucky, (Union,) reported from the Judiciary Committee a bill for the collection of taxes in the insurrectionary districts, with amendments striking out the provision authorizing grants of forty acre lots to soldiers, and that empowering the Tax Commissioner to set aside sales deemed to be unfairly made.

Advices from Alexandria to the 27th ult. say that the main body of Gen. FRANKLIN'S army arrived there the day before, meeting no opposition. The country through which it passed was deserted by whites and male blacks, they having gone to Texas. The indications are that Gen. BANKS' army will remain there some time.

News from the armies in Louisiana is received to the 27th of March. At that date Gen. FRANKLIN's column of Gen. BANKS' army had reached Alexandria, and Gen. SMITH'S army was just leaving it on their advance to Shreveport, which, it was believed, would be taken without resistance from the enemy.

Mr. GEORGE W. SNOW, Clerk of the steamer Saxon, from Philadelphia for Boston, which met with a disaster on Nantucket Shoals, reached this City tonight. He reports, at 2 P.M. Sunday last, fell in with the ship C. Grinnell, Capt. SPENCER, from Liverpool for New-York, with 150 passengers, showing a signal of distress. She was at anchor inside of Five Fathom Bank, having thumped over the shoal.
A large boiler at MERRICK SONS, "Southwark Foundry," exploded this morning, causing much loss of life and a great destruction of property.
Baltimore City gives 9,021 for a convention and 41 against.

Another order for the consolidation of army corps has been issued. The Eleventh and Twelfth Corps are consolidated, and Maj.-Gen. HOOKER assigned to the command. The corps will hereafter be known as the Twentieth. Maj.Gen. HOWARD, formerly of the Eleventh Corps, takes command of the Fourth, relieving Gen. GORDON GRANGER, who reports to the Adjutant-General of the Army. Gen. SLOCUM reports to Gen. SHERMAN.

Miss EMMA WEBB, who will, perhaps, be better recognized as one of the Webb Sisters, of east-side theatre celebrity, delivered a lecture last evening at Cooper Institute, in answer to Miss ANNA E. DICKINSON'S "Lessons of the Hour." The audience was small, numbering not over four hundred. Promptly at 8 o'clock, however, Miss WEBB was introduced by Mr. THEO MARHINE, and commenced her lecture.

Our courts have hitherto been but little troubled with questions arising under the confiscation laws. Those questions would naturally be more frequent in the Border States, where there were more men who had left their property within reach of the process of the United States Courts, while they themselves had gone to take an active part in the rebellion.

Yesterday was the fourth day of the Metropolitan Fair, and and the first day that people were admitted for fifty cents. The building was crowded day and night to overflowing; the number of visitors was thirty thousand two hundred and forty-four. The price of admission to-day and until further notice will be $1.

Yesterday, the fourth day of the great fair was of the most pleasant days we have had this season, and as a natural consequence the crowd was immence. The fact that the price of admission was reduced to fifty cents, helped largely to swell its numbers, and long before the hour for opening the doors, Fourteenth-street was filled with a huge crowd, waiting impatiently for admission.

IMPORTANT IF TRUE. A party of refugees, just arrived, bring late intelligence from Richmond. They report daily augmentations to LEE'S army by large numbers of conscripts from various portions of the Confederacy, rebels are increasing their armies very quietly, but effectively and rapidly; and they expect to start LRE out on the Spring campaign, with not less than eighty or ninety thousand men, without weakening other armies in the field.

The Committee of Ways and Means of the House of Representatives is at present engaged in perfecting bills for the revision of our Tax and Tariff Laws. But notwithstanding the fact that they are so engaged, there is a feeling prevalent that they will not come up to the needs of the hour, and unsparingly apply taxes where they are needed.

Yesterday was Good Friday, and as much of a holy day as English know how to make. All works were stopped, all business traffic withdrawn from the streets, shops and public houses all closed as on Sunday, and more strictly, and the theatres and places of amusement closed.

That fierce and untamea ble tribe of redskins, the Navajoes, whom we have been fighting for the last eighteen years, are reported to have lately surrendered to our forces in New-Mexico; and on the heels of this news, we have the announcement from Washington that an appropropriation of one hundred thousand dollars is asked from Congress for the subsistence of the tribe.
The movements of the enemy in this neighborhood during the last few days have been such as to attract the careful attention of the Generals commanding and their subordinates.

Since my last we have had our promised review by Gen. HOOKER. Among others, the States of Pennsylvania and New-Jersey are now represented by regiments in the Eleventh Corps, and the Kentucky Gen. WARD'S veterans are a late accession to our strength.

MORRIS ISLAND, S., C., Saturday, March 26, 1864. The guns on the northern portion of the island continue to send shells at intervals into Charleston. As an item of curiosity, I will state that one 30-pound Parrott discharged 4,615 rounds of shell at Charleston before it became incapacitated.
The steamer Molly Able arrived here to-night with Memphis dates of last evening and 480 bales of cotton for St. Louis.

The Soldiers Voting Bill was taken up and amended by providing that the ballot may be sent by the soldier to any elector instead to the Inspectors of Election exclusively; also, that where the particular election district of the soldier cannot be ascertained, his ballot may be deposited in town, ward or city in which he is a voter.
The imperative demand for high speed in shipsof-war is leading some of our builders and engineers to make exertions to accomplish in this respect all that can be desired.

One of them says that FORREST, on the 26th, marched between Mayfield and Paducah, disbanded the Third, Seventh and Eighth Kentucky rebel Cavalry, and permitted members thereof to go home.

The election of yesterday, for members of Constitutional Convention, resulted in a complete triumph of the Free-State Party. With few exceptions the regular Free-State ticket was elected in this parish; and in these exceptional cases the successful candidates are in favor of a Free Constitution.

--An elevator is to be soon erected at Milwaukee, which will eclipse in size and capacity any grain warehouse in the world. Its length to to be 280 feet; width, 88 feet; height, 132 feet; height to lower eaves, 78 feet.

The American brig Wandering Wave, LINNELL, Master, left Hong Kong for Hangchow Nov. 23, and on Dec. 17 anchored at a place called ScheSnan, where she was attacked by pirates and all the crew murdered, except the Captain and second mate, the vessel plundered and subsequently fired. The Captain and second mate concealed themseves, and subsequently reached the shore.

A few days ago, ISAAC JOHNSON, a sailor residing at No. 92 Baxter-street, appeared before Justice HOGAN at the Tombs Police Court, and entered a complaint against THOMAS HADDEN and PATRICK WADDLETON, charging them with kidnapping and robbing him.

Vicksburgh advices of the 3d instant say that the rebels attacked Rooch's Plantation at 2 o'clock on Friday morning. The plantation is situated seven miles above Snyder'S Bluff, on the Yazoo River, and is one of the largest in the State. It had extensive cotton works and splendid buildings, all of which were destroyed.

This volume takes its name from the first article of its contents, an oration delivered before the Ph Beta Kappa Society of Harvard University in 1848. A letter from the Army of the Potomac says: "Major-Gen. MEADE'S headquarters is no longer headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, at least so far as news of the army is concerned. By instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury, dated March 26, 1864, this Bank will receive subscriptions for the National 10-40 Five Per Cent. The debate in the House of Representatives on the expulsion of Mr. LONG, of Ohio, was continued, yesterday, and occupied the greater part of the day and the evening till midnight. The debate was earnest, somewhat stormy, and occasionally foul, and it was participated in by a large number of members.

Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday. Both boards adopted an ordinance providing that all disputed questins of elections in fire companies shall be referred to the Commissioners of the Fire Department, who shall examine and decide them, and whose decision shall be final. The middle of this month will witness in Europe another of those grand events which, like the President's Proclamation of Emancipation in America, are to make these years forever illustrious in history. At 4 o'clock on the morning of Friday, the 1st inst., the army steam-transport Maple Leaf, while passing down the St. John's River, from Pilatka to Jacksonville, Fla., ran against a torpedo, moored in the stream twelve miles above the latter place, which exploded and sent the vessel to the bottom.

Robert L. Taylor et al. vs. Benjamin H. Hutton et al. PECKHAM, J. This is substantially an application for the continuance of an injunction to prevent the alleged illegal removal of the President of the Fourth National Bank, threatened by two-thirds of the directors, defendants herein. It is charged in the complaint that the defendants entered into a combination shortly after the election of the President.

No one but a traitor most vile could conceive or execute a deed so base as the one which was attempted this morning upon the Minnesota, the flagship of the blockading squadron, stationed at the mouth of James River. It was about two o'clock, when an object upon the water was discovered approaching by the deck officer of the Minnesota. Moving noiselessly forward, nearer and nearer, it was hailed, but no reply was elicited.

With unaffected sorrow we record the death of Mr. TICKNOR, of the well-known firm of TICKNOR FIELDS, publishers, Boston. It occurred, yesterday morning, at the Continental Hotel, in this city. Mr. Ticknor arrived here on Tuesday, accompanying his friend, NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE, Esq., the author, whose health demanded change of scene and air.

On Monday morning, March 14, at five o'clock, Gen. LEE left Franklin with as fine a body of cavalry, probably, as now exits in any of our departments accompanied by three fine batteries NIME,' RALL'S, and one other and on Saturday afternoon he reached Alexandria, on the Red River, which had already been occupied by Gen.
