The steamer Ariel has arrived from Aspinwall with the California mails of March 23.

GEN. GRANT'S MOVEMENTS. Lieut.-Gen. GRANT has been engaged most of to day in the War Department. He will leave to-morrow morning for the front. He seems highly pleased with the Army of the Potomac. It never was in better condition, and is eager for the conflict.
We find the following choice morsel in the closing paragraph of the minority report of the Committee of the State Legislature on Banks:

THE FLORIDA EXPEDITION. Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, (Union,) moved the printing of 5,000 copies of the report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the late Florida Expedition. Adopted.

By the arrival of the steamship Creole, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to April 6th, though the news has been mostly anticipated via Cairo. Admiral FARRAGUT was in the city. The Era stated that the Liberals, under CORTINAS, had defeated VIDUARRI at Monterey, Mexico. French war-vessels were taking soundings at the mouth of the Rio Grande. CORTINAS had returned to Matamoras, and expressed his determination to defend it to the last extremity.
The R.M. steamship Asia, Capt. MOODIE, which left Liverpool at 3 P.M. of the 2d, and Queenstown 3d, arrived at Halifax at 10 o'clock this forenoon.
The Raleigh Confederate says: "Gen. MORGAN is about to undertake one of the boldest expeditions he has ever yet made, which, if successful, will be productive of great good to our cause."
The following dispatch per steamer Olive Branch failed to reach your correspondent's hands till today:

Yesterday, the tenth day of the great fair, was one of the most successful since its opening. From morning till night the buildings were crowded to their utmost, and many were turned away, unable to gain admission. More than 30,000 people visited the fair during the day and evening.

A detachment of the First Colorado cavalry had a fight with a party of Chevennes on the north side of Platte River, near Fremont's Orchard, 85 miles east of here, on the State Road, on the 12th inst. Two soldiers were killed and four wounded. Several of the Indians were killed.
The Canal Commissioners have resolved to allow boats on the Erie and Oswego Canals to draw six feet of water after the 1st of June.

The Greenville Convention of 1861 reassembled yesterday at the Court-house. About 160 delegates reported in person, representing 22 counties. The President T.A.R. NELSON, on opening the convention, made an explanatory speech and resigned the chair. WILLIAM HESSKET was chosen President.

Well, Mr. COLFAX has withdrawn his expelling resolution, and accepted a milder one as a substitute. His original attempt completely miscarried. We trust its fate will be a warning for all time against any other such effort in an American Congress.

This is the day on which the draft was appointed to take place throughout the country, under the President's March call for troops. It is postponed as usual we suppose on account of the weather. It will now positively take place on the first of May very positively. That being "moving day," it will furnish an excellent opportunity to catch recusant conscripts when they are out of doors.
The steamer New-York returned from City Point this morning, bringing neither news nor prisoners, the water being so high in the James River as to prevent communication with Richmond.

One of the vessels built at Bordeaux by M. AR MAN Deputy in the Corps Legislatif, for the Confederate Government, was launched on Thursday last, and shows herself on the water to be a most beautiful specimen of naval architecture. An English vessel is lying in the same port with all the necessary equipments on board for the new vessel, the articles having been put on board the English vessel at Havre.
The steamer Creole, from New-Orleans 6th, has arrived. Her news is mostly anticipated via Cairo.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: The determination of the stage-owners to extort a dime per ride from the public is as unjustifiable as it is absurd.

NIGHT SESSIONS. Mr. WILSON, of Iowa, (Union,) asked leave to offer a resolution that, until otherwise ordered, the House will each day take a recess from 4 till 7 o'clock, for the purpose of holding night sessions for the transaction of business. Objection was made from the Opposition side.

Our dispatches from Cairo bring us a story almost too horrible in its details for human belief, but which comes with such directness as to leave no doubt of its truth. The attack on Fort Pillow by the rebels under FORREST, which was announced yesterday, was followed up by frequent demands for its surrender, which were refused...

This elegant volume is a continuation of the series undertaken by Messrs. TICKNOR FIELDS, with the object of placing the best works of RICHTER within the means and knowledge of English readers. It forms the fifth volume of the set, commencing with Mr. BROOKS'S version of "Titan;" and will be followed by a new translation of "Hesperus," so there is ground to suppose. JEAN PAUL does not lack readers and...

The canvass for the elections to Congress is progressing actively and spiritedly. It is calculated the Government will be supported by two-thirds of the new Deputies, while the balance will be divided between the ultra-liberals and ultra-conservatives.

In the Court of Sessions, yesterday, DANIEL BROOKS, who was convicted of manslaughter in the third degree, was brought up for sentence. His Honor said that the facts of the case showed that BROOKS might have avoided the affray with SMITH. There were no mitigating circumstances, and the sentence of the court would be as heavy as the limitation of the law allowed. He was sent to the State Prison for four years.
Advices from Texas state that Gen. DANA had been relieved from the command of the troops at Pass Cavallo, and succeeded by Gen. WARREN, Gen. HERRON is sick at Brownsville with the small-pox.

HAWLEY D. CLAPP, recognized as the head and front here of bounty brokers, was arrested and sent to Fort Lafayette, where he yet remains. He addressed sometime since an appeal to the Legislature for relief. The matter was referred to the Judiciary Committee, who applied to Gen. DIX, who caused the arrest, for information on the subject. The following is the General's reply:

Pensacola advices report a fight between Capt. SCHMIDT, Company M, Fourteenth New-York Cavalry, and fifty rebels, under Maj. RANDOLPH, of the Sixth Alabama Cavalry, near that place. After a ten minutes' hand-to-hand fight the rebels fled. Their loss was fifteen killed and wounded and eleven prisoners. Our loss was three slightly wounded, including Lieut. VON LUGERECKE.

Congress met nineteen weeks ago. Gold, which is the only real barometer of national credit and public confidence, then sold fiftytwo per cent. over the money of the Government. It now sells at seventy-four per cent. over. What has been the cause of this weakening of the national credit? Not disaster in...
To provide an armory for the Eighth Regiment National Guard.

Up to this evening no account whatever had been received at the War Department of the reported massacre at Fort Pillow. The report is not generally credited in military circles. In spite of the fact that the Government don't know anything about it, there is every reason to believe it to be entirely true. ED. TIMES.]

The gunboat Chenango, while outward bound, and off Fort Lafayette, this afternoon, burst her boiler. Forty men on deck were scalded some of them are dead. The engine-rooms of the vessel have not been reached yet. The revenue cutter Bronx has come ashore for medical assistance.

By instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury, dated March 26, 1864, this Bank will receive subscriptions for the National 10-40 Five Per Cent. Loan, in coupon bonds or registered certificates, redeemable after ten, and payable forty years from date, in coin and will allow to banks, bankers and brokers the usual commission of one-eighth of one per cent.

At the close of last year, a resolution passed both Houses of Congress, calling upon the Secretary of the Navy to communicate all official reports and dispatches and papers in the Navy Department, relating to actions in which any of the armored vessels have been engaged. Under date of the 11th inst., Secretary WELLES responds to this call in a letter accompanied by documents, embracing reports from Admiral DUPONT, Rear-Admiral PORTER,...
Yesterday was one of the greatest days since the opening of the fair, there was no cessation, no rest. The crowd was as usual, a perfect jam, and the receipts were very satisfactory.
To amend the charter of the Harlem and Hudson River Canal Company, Complete.

The British Steamship Company's two beautiful ships Quito and Peru arrived at Panama, the first from Callao, on the 2d, and the last from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, yesterday. Dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chili are to the 17th, and Callao and Lima to the 28th of March. The Peru brings $365,100 specie for Southampton, a good list of passengers, and the following freight:

The news from Gen. BANKS is cheering, and everything is progressing finely, so far as the movements of the army are concerned. His command is above Natchitoches, and up to this time there has been no battle between us and the rebel forces, printed rumors and "authentic details " to the contrary notwithstanding. There is constant skirmishing, ...
Advices from Gen. STEELE to the 7th inst. are received.

The State Constitutional Convention met in New-Orleans on March 6. Judge DURRELL was elected to preside, and delivered an appropriate address upon taking the chair. Only preliminary business was transacted the first and second days' sessions.

Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan, (Union,) introduced a bill to amend the statutes in force in the District of Columbia; repealing the saving clause in favor of pension beyond lives in the old Maryland laws; for the limitation of certain actions for avoiding suits at law; the administration of justice in testamentary affairs,

On Tuesday morning the rebel Gen. FORREST attacked Fort Pillow. Soon after the attack FORREST sent a flag of truce demanding the surrender of the fort and garrison, meanwhile disposing of his force so as to gain the advantage. Our forces were under command of Major BOOTH, of the Thirteenth Tennessee (U.S.) Heavy Artillery, formerly of the First Alabama Cavalry.
Col. PRATT, commanding at Paducah, telegraphs that he is informed that Paducah has been attacked, and the town is full of rebels.
Mr. WILSON, of Iowa, (Union,) again asked, but failed to obtain, consent to offer a resolution providing for night sessions for the transaction of business.

The bank question has again been sharply debated in the Assembly to-day. Four thousand copies of the minority report were ordered printed, and upon this Mr. ANDRUS desired to call up the majority report. The House permitted him to do so, and the proceeded to read a carefully prepared and temperate speech, setting forth the reasons which governed the majority of the committee in making their report. His remarks were complimented ...
Head quarters are advised of a dispatch from Col. GALLUP, received at Lexington, that the rebels are in full retreat from East Kentucky.

French justice can only find its parallel in French freedom. As gagging the press, coercing electors, and prohibiting political meetings, are deemed quite consistent with the one, so disregarding the evidence of witnesses, reversing arbitrarily the verdicts of juries, and imposing penalties by mere caprice, are held to be equally compatible with the other. But it is easier to illustrate the anomalies of French criminal procedure than to describe them.

There is a prospect at last of the rebels being treated to some of their own internal machines. The recent loss of the Maple Leaf in the St. John's River, Florida, has added another disaster to the record of their efforts to destroy our transports and gunboats with torpedoes.
Mobile papers of March 25 have come to hand via New-Orleans. They publish the following important telegram from Georgia:

Our opinion has been asked by certain shareholders of the Fourth National Bank of New-York, who have united in the call for a meeting of the shareholders on the 14th day of April, instant, as to the legality of the meeting thus called, and the powers of the shareholders when assembled.
Capt. AINSWORTH returned from the search after the steamer Scott, on the steamer Winants. The steamer S.O. Pierce has also returned.

Shortly after the guerrilla FORREST had entered Kentucky, we suggested that, if necessary for his capture, it would be cheap to send against him all the infantry, cavalry, artillery, gunboats, horse-marines and negro soldiers in West Tennessee; and if all these were not sufficient for the work of catching him, that our army at Chattanooga should be ordered to send ten or twenty or thirty thousand additional reinforcements to help them.
The rebels have appeared in large force upon the Chowan River, apparently for the protection of the shad and herring fisheries.

The Morning Star, of Monterey, of March 11, says that it is rumored MEJIA is surely marching on Saltillo; that the President(JUAREZ) contemplates leaving for Durango, as to which the Star ejaculates quien sabe?

On exhibition in the rubber department will be found that great promoter of domestic comfort, the universal clothes wringer, the proprietors of which munificently donated five hundred of these machines, with the proviso that they should be sold at neither more nor less than the regular price, $7 each.

On Friday a body of rebel cavalry made an attack on our pickets at Bristow Station, killing one man and wounding two others of the Thirteenth Pennsylvania Regiment. They were driven off after a few shots had been exchanged, but carried their wounded with them. Lieut.Gen. GRANT had passed the spot in the car only a few moments before the attack, and the supposition is that the rebels designed to make him prisoner.

L. MONTGOMERY BOND, Esq. Dear Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 6th instant, enclosing circulars of the "Committee on Labor, incomes and Revenues" of the Great Central Fair for the United States Sanitary Commission. I feel very much flattered and complimented at the honor conferred on me, by placing my name as one of the honorary members of this important committee.

In your to-day's report of yesterday's proceedings of Congress, I saw, with astonishment, some words reported of Mr. ORTH, of Indiana, in his speech upon HARRIS, to the effect that it JACKSON were now in power, the traitor, (HARRIS,) instead of being merely censured, would be in the Old Capitol Prison.

I heartily agree with "P.I.L.," in yesterday's TIMES, that there should be at least one "cheap day." at the fair, when those who can afford but twenty-five cents, should have the pleasure of giving that sum for the triple purpose of aiding the enterprise, of enjoying the sights, and of cultivating their patriotic impulses. I would even have one "shilling day," to draw in and enlist the sympathies of the poorest sewing girls and laborers.
Will you permit me to ask Mr. B. B. WILLS0N for some explanations that he has omitted in his letter in the Times of the 7th instant?

The London Times has lately discovered a method more Machiavelic than any of its previous ones in aid of the rebel cause. Outside of Paris, scarcely any of the continental journals publish anything more than the telegraphic reports which are are sent over the wires on the arrival of the steamers, and even in Paris only a few persons read more of American affairs than is found in these first telegraphic reports.

You will have received intelligence, ere this, of the close of our Illinois civil war. It is now proposed to turn over the Cole County prisoners some twenty-five in number to the civil authorities for trial on a charge of murder and riot the position of affairs not being deemed such as to justify the holding them under the United States laws, either for treason, or resistance to the Federal authorities.
The expedition under Gen. STEELE was at Arkadelphia on the 28th, where Gen, THAYER, with a strong force from Fort Smith, was to join it.

The explosion on board the Chenango has resulted in nineteen deaths. Of the fifteen injured, lying at the Naval Hospital, but four are expected to recover. A detailed account will be found in another column.

The following letter from a respectable citizen of Charleston, S.C., a Union man, to a gentleman of Philadelphia, gives a faithful account of the city, as it was Feb. 28 1864. The statement can be depended upon as accurate and impartial. We publish it literally as written, omitting only names and private matters:

Yesterday afternoon, about 5 o'clock, dispatches were received here from Gen. SHERMAN, confirming the surrender of Fort Pillow, and the brutal conduct of the rebels immediately afterward, which bids fair to be amply retaliated in that quarter in due time.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Would you have the kindness to tell your readers something about Gen. "Baldy" SMITH, so they may know the difference between him and all the rest of the SMITHS (Generals.)

Rev. B.F. MORRIS, a most excellent gentleman, has recently published a work to show the influence of Christianity on American institutions. I was recently turning over the correspondence of some of our statesmen, and could not help thinking that he could make a still more interesting work by tracing out the irreligion of most public men, and the great improvement which has taken place in that respect since the period of the Revolution.
At the opening of the Sanitary Fair in St. Louis, a few days since, Gen. ROSECRANS made a speech, in the course of which he said:

We have conversed with two or three highly intelligent gentlemen just returned from Cairo and Columbus, and are in possession of some facts and surmises that may, as far as they are sustained, throw some light on the situation in that region, now be coming of most exciting interest.
Yesterday, Judge ATOCHA had seven negroes, named Fowler Willis, Stephen Johnson, Jordan

In the Senate yesterday, sundry petitions were presented asking for increased pay to the Metropolitan Police Force, in view of the high prices of the necessaries of life. Bills were reported relative to the Excelsior Fire Insurance Company of Kings County; authorizing the Supervisors of Kings County to provide relief for the families of volunteers; incorporating the International Land Company, for the consideration of the Senate.
The following the concluding portion of the Washington dispatch relative to the Tax Bill, which appeared in our Saturday morning's edition:

Jehial J. Post vs. Henry Martens and Robert Cross. This action was brought to recover balance due for rent of premises No. 9 First-street, under a lease dated Nov. 28, 1859, to commence May 1, the ensuing, for three years at $300 per annum, and croton water tax, and keep premises in repair. The lease was signed by James H. Thorne, as agent for plaintiff. The defendants answered separately ...

In the United States Court at Wheeling, on Thursday last, judgments were rendered against ALBERT G. JENKINS, the celebrated guerrilla General one for $5,525, and the other for $100,000. Capt. W. C. THROPE testified that he was robbed by JENKINS in Jackson County, on the 3d of September last, of $5,525. The Captain exhibited the following receipt for the money which he received at the time:

In noting the pro gress made in raising the Comanche monitor, the San Francisco Bulletin says:
Special dispatches from Indianapolis represent that military matters there are very active. Large numbers of recruits leave for the front daily.
The United States ship Mohican, commanded by Capt. O.S. GLISSON, arrived in our port last evening from the coast of Brazil, via St. Thomas.

Gen. HAYS has received orders from Washington ordering him to prepare for a draft on Monday, but none ordering him to commence the draft. This City is short 3,912 men. It is thought, however, that these can easily be raised, and thus save a draft.

A "Georgian" writes from Nashville to the Louisville Journal: "As you pass through the country since the recent conscription, you cannot but notice the lack of males at some of the railroad station villages there is not a vigorous man to be seen. Women, children, a maimed soldier, or a few very old men, constitute the population.
The Knoxville-Greenville Convention met again on Wednesday, pursuant to adjournment. Much talking was done, with no result.

The People vs. MARK TOPLITZ. It will be remembered that the accused, MARK TOPLITZ, was fully committed for trial by Judge MANSFIELD for arson, in setting fire to his premises, (a hat and cap store,) No. 386 Grand-street.

The Italian journals stated some months since that revolutionary movements were brewing in Hungary. About the middle of March on the anniversary of Hungary's deliverance from Austrian rule a formidable riot occurred in Pesth, of which the Vienna papers were careful to say very little. The crowd shouted "Effin Kossuth!" and even attacked the police. Arms, it is said, had been introduced from Poland and Galicia; and there was great popular ferment.
I cannot let the day pass without presenting my respects to the TIMES for its noble article this morning on the duties of Congress and the freedom of debate.

Saturday night brought the close of the second week of the Fair. The departments on Unionsquare have added largely to the total receipts, and contributed their full share to the success of the enterprise. After some drawbacks and disappointments at first, they have now become the favorite resorts of the habitues of the fair, who have seen the whole and know which to choose as the best parts.
All is quiet at the front, and there is no change in the situation of the rebel lines. A rebel Lieutenant and 52 non-commissioned officers and privates came into our lines last night.

Two weeks of continued and uninterrupted success have passed, and to-day commences the third and last week at the great fair. There is no statement of the interest the people take in it; the first few days of last week were very rainy and disagreeable; it did not, however, affect the crowds in the least, the buildings were just as full and the greenbacks just as plenty as on the clear and smiling days.

On Friday a body of rebel cavalry made an attack on our pickets at Bristow Station, killing one man and wounding two others of the Thirteenth Pennsylvania Regiment. They were driven off after a few shots had been exchanged, but carried their wounded with them. Lieut. Gen. GRANT had passed the spot in the car only a few moments before the attack, and the supposition is that the rebels designed to make him prisoner.

It is ascertained that the schooner Patter, which sailed in ballast for the Colorado River, on Sunday, clangestinely took as cargo, after clearing from the Custom-house, three thousand kegs of blasting powder. It is believed that this powder is destined for Northern Mexico for mining purposes. The authorities having prohibited such shipments, the mines of Sonora must be closed unless means are devised to introduce powder clandestinely.

According to the popular superstition, when a man makes a false start he had better abandon his voyage entirely, for he is sure not to attain his object. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN falls exactly within this case. He has made a false start, and crowds of people are predicting for him all sorts of bad luck in his undertaking.

The Senate discussed, yesterday afternoon, at considerable length, a bill empowering the authorities of New-York to convey certain premises on Ward's Island, to the society for the protection of destitute Roman Catholic children. Senator COZANS made an earnest effort in behalf of this bill, which was opposed by several Senators. The bill was ordered to a third reading.

The explosion on board the Chenango has resulted in nineteen deaths. Of the fifteen injured, lying at the Naval Hospital, but four are expected to recover. A detailed account will be found in another column.

A Port Royal paper of the 14th, reports the capture of the side-wheel blockade-runner Alliance on the 12th, near Dafuskie Island, in the Savannah River, where she run aground. All but six of her crew were taken prisoners.

Dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac state that yesterday about noon a party of rebel cavalry made an attack on the pickets at Bristoe Station, but were driven off after a brisk skirmish. One man was killed and two wounded, belonging to the Thirteenth Pennsylvania. Several of the rebels were wounded, but were carried off by their comrades.
The rebels have appeared in large force upon the Chowan River, apparently for the protection of the shad and herring fisheries.

Mr. MARETZEK'S season at the Academy of Music will end with the present week, and to-night GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" will be played for the thirty-first and last time. These two facts should go a long way toward securing crowded houses for the short term that remains. But there is yet another circumstance worth placing on record for the benefit of those whose purses are not plethoric.

Vive la Reine ! The long and dreary mourning is over. Queen VICTORIA once more takes her place at the head of her Court and Kingdom. The skies brighten at the announcement. Joy irradlaten London, and its gleam penetrates the most distant provinces. The Queen herself will hold a drawingroom reception next Wednesday. Court balls, con certs, and receptions are to follow. The world of fashion and the world of trade, are alike delighted.

The reports in a New-York Sunday paper of the perilous condition of the President's health, are fortunately without foundation at this writing. Mr. LINCOLN and Speaker COLFAX will probably visit Baltimore to-morrow evening, by invitation, to assist at the opening of the Maryland Sanitary Fair.

[ELEVENTH ARTICLE.] The last article of this series left Gen. McCLELLAN established with what remained of his shattered army on the banks of the James, at Harrison's Landing. If the army had sustained itself nobly throughout the sad campaign on the Peninsula, it cannot be denied that so much fruitless toil and so much disaster had impaired its morale, while the losses in battle and the epidemics of the region had frightfully thinned its ranks.

Yesterday afternoon, about 5 o'clock, dispatches were received here from Gen. SHERMAN, confirming the surrender of Fort Pillow, and the brutal conduct of the rebels immediately afterward, which bids fair to be amply retaliated in that quarter in due time.

An expedition under command of Gen. GRAHAM, consisting of the army gunboats, the Ninth New-Jersey, Twenty-third and Twenty-fifth Massachusetts, and the One Hundred and Eighteenth New-York Regiments, and two sections of artillery, under Capt. EASTERLY, left here on Wednesday night last, and landed at different points.

The steamer Glendale from Memphis, morning of 15th, has arrived. She past Fort Pillow last evening. There was no appearance of the enemy, and the river is all clear. Nothing remains of the fort but ruins.

NEW-YORK CITIZENS' ASSOCIATION. We understand delegations, composed of our most influential citizens, will continue to visit Albany all the week, for the purpose of securing such a reduction in the tax-levy as can be made, not only without an injury to the efficient working of any of the departments but with great benefit to the community.

Our opinion has been asked by certain shareholders of the Fourth National Bank of New-York, who have united in the call for a meeting of the shareholders on the 14th day of April, instant, as to the legality of the meeting thus called, and the powers of the shareholders when assembled.

THE REPORTED REBEL MASSACRE. -- Both the Senate and House passed a resolution, on Saturday, calling for immediate inquiry into the circumstances of the Fort Pillow Massacre. Even before this action, the Secretary of War had appointed officers to make investigation into the matter. It is essential that this should be done, and it is well it should be done very promptly.
The official Staatzanzerger, of to-day, gives the following account of the engagement in the trenches before Duppel on the 28th inst.:

'The $973,100 worth of stock of the Soldiers' Bounty Fund, awarded by the Comptroller on Saturday, and noticed in the TIMES yesterday, was all at premium rates above 2 cent., and the premiums net $30,607.75, or a fraction over 3 p cent. The 2 p cent. premium bids were excluded from acceptance.
Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, (Union,) reported back a report of the Secretary of the Interior, in reference to the Idaho Indians. Ordered to be printed.

A telegram from Hamburg, of April 2, says: "It is said that the Austro-Prussian troops intended to turn the position of Duppel by crossing over to the Island of Alsen very shortly, by means of Austrian pontoons. Everything is said to be prepared for an important action."

yesterday, the thirteenth day of the Fair. was a clear, bright day, and the buildings though very well filled, were not quite as crowded as was expected. The attendance, however, was good, and the receipts for sales satisfactory.

The Metropolitan Police Salary Bill. Incorporating the Fire Island Hotel Company. Relative to the Board of Commissioners of Appeal of the New-York Fire Department. Conferring additional powers upon Marshals of Courts in New-York.
Mr. KESSON, of Iowa, (Union,) introduced a bill extending the western boundary of that State to the Missouri River. All the above were appropriately referred.

The inauguration exrcises of the great fair, at the American Institute, to-night, were very imposing The display was exceedingly fine. The immense building was thronged. President Lincoln made a speech.
The steamer Mina was fired into on Tuesday night near Fort Pillow by fifty rebels in Federal uniform, supposed to have been the rear guard of the enemy, who are withdrawing in a northern direction.

On Thursday, Col. GALLUP, while falling back to get an advantageous position, attacked 1,000 rebels, killing and wounding 25, including a rebel Colonel, and capturing 50 rebels, 100 horses, ahd 200 saddles.

That any insurance corporation should possess a capital of One Million Dollars is in itself an aston hing fact, so greatly does this sum exceed the capital ordinarily employed. But when such a corporation increases its capital at one bound from one to TWO MILLIONS, it simply astonishes the observer, and makes him more than ever inclined to inquire into the grounds and the methods of such prosperity. The funeral of the unclaimed victims by the disaster on board the United States gunboat Chenango, took place at the Marine Hospital yesterday, In presence of a large concourse, principally members of the Masonic fraternity, some of the friends of deceased, and the officers and crew of tee ill-fated vessel.

'Steamships City of Limerick, (Br.,) Jones, Liverpool, John G. Dale; United States, Gates. New-Orleans. steamers Locust Point. Willetts, Portland, Cromwell Co., Fanny Cadwallader, Pierson, Baltimore, Wm. Dalzell.

An adjourned meeting of the Shareholders of the Fourth National Bank was held yesterday afternoon in the main room of the banking-house. The attendance was large, and the business transacted of considerable importance. At the last meeting of the shareholders, held on the l4th instant, it was resolved that the Directors be requested to resign. Yesterday
The transport Fulton arrived at Hampton Roads April 16, having left Port Royal April 14. The following communication from her obliging Purser, Mr. THOMAS McMANUS, gives interesting details of news:

It is reported that Maj.-Gen. Q.A. GILLMORE Will be immediately recalled from duty in front of Charleston, and ordered an service elsewhere. It is not unlikely, notwithstanding this change, that our iron-clads will be alongside Charleston wharf before the incoming Summer has gone out. Gen. HATCH is mentioned as the successor of Gen. GILLMORE in the Department of the South.

Gen. LEE has issued a General Order directing the observance of to-morrow as a day of fasting, humiliation and prayer; directing the due preparation of all the departments to anticipate the wants of the several commanders. All military duties, unless absolutely necessary are to be suspended, and the chaplains are desired to hold divine service in their regiments and brigades. Officers and men are requested to attend.

-The Legislature of 1857 appointed a commission, consisting of Messrs. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES and ALEXANDER W. BRADFORD, to prepare, in conformity to the direction of the Constitution, a complete code of the law of this State, other than that relating to the mere procedure of the courts.

Elijah W. Carpenter vs. The Steamboat Island City, This was a case of collision. The libel ant was the owner of the schooner Peri, which was sunk on Sept. 27, 1862, by a collision with the steamboat in Hell Gate. The schooner was going east and the steamboat was bound to New-York. The tide was flood. There was great controversy as to the amount of wind, and whether there was enough ...

Before leaving Memphis Tuesday afternoon, we heard a report that Fort Pillow was captured, and at 5 P.M. we proceeded up the river in the Platte Valley, loaded down with passengers, and with the gunboat Silver Cloud, No. 27, under Acting Master FERGUSON, in tow. We designedly proceeded slowly, and arrived near the fort at 8 A.M., where the gunboat cast off, and steamed up toward the fort.

Yesterday, the fourteenth day of the great fair, was one of the most beautiful since its opening, yet it was not fully attended. During the afternoon and evening, however, the crowd increased, and by eight o'clock the hall was crowded and as full as usual.

The President, in his speech at Baltimore on Monday, made an allusion to the alleged massacre at Fort Pillow, and his remarks at once illustrated some of his most prominent mental characteristics, and set forth the policy the Government would pursue in the matter of retaliation.

Letters to the Chicago Journal, published in that paper yesterday, give an account of a serious encounter between a part of our forces in Louisiana, at Pleasant Hili, near Grand Ecore, consisting of cavalry and two divisions of infantry, and a largely superior force of rebels, in which our forces were defeated with a loss of two thousand men and a battery of artillery.

Commissioner OSBORN yesterday decided to discharge JOHN E. COOK, first mate of the ship Victory, who was charged with the homicide of a steerage passenger on a voyage from Liverpool to this port. The evidence for the Government in this case showed that the accused, at most, was only guilty of manslaughter, and he was released on bail several weeks ago.

The large hall of the Cooper Institute was nearly filled with a most attentive audience last evening, convened to hear Miss ANNA DICKINSON'S speech on the management of public affairs. At the appointed time, Mr. THEODORE TILTON, of the Independent, came forward and introduced the fair speaker, who was received with cheers.
We find the following curious dispatch in late Soutnern papers, which may or may not be connected with the above affair:

-The Legislature of 1857 appointed a commission, consisting of Messrs. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES and ALEXANDER W. BRADFORD, to prepare, in conformity to the direction of the Constitution, a complete code of the law of this State, other than that relating to the mere procedure of the courts.

The House concurred in the Senate amendment to the House resolution, so as to read that the Committee on the Conduct of the War inquire into the truth of the rumors attending the recent attack on Fort Pillow, and whether that fort could not hare been sufficiently reinforced, and report the facts as soon as possible.
The Democrat has several dispatches from the Red River, containing nothing, however, of special importance. Little had occurred except skirmishing.

ITALIAN OPERA. Sig. BELLINI, the favorite baritone, takes his benefit this evening, on which occasion the ever welcome opera of "Faust" will be produced, with KELLOGG, SULZER, MAZZOLENI, BELLINI and HEEMANNS in the cast. To-morrow (Thursday) "La Traviata" will be given, together with the second act of "Un Ballo in Maschera," for the benefit of Mme. ORTOLANI BRIGNOLI.

Gen. LEE has issued a General Order directing the observance of to-morrow as a day of fasting, humiliation and prayer; directing the due preparation of all the departments to anticipate the wants of the several commanders. All military duties, unless absolutely necessary are to be suspended, and the chaplains are desired to hold divine service in their regiments and brigades. Officers and men are requested to attend.

Elijah W. Carpenter vs. The Steamboat Island City, This was a case of collision. The libel ant was the owner of the schooner Peri, which was sunk on Sept. 27, 1862, by a collision with the steamboat in Hell Gate. The schooner was going east and the steamboat was bound to New-York. The tide was flood. There was great controversy as to the amount of wind, and whether there was enough ...

OFFICERS AND SOLDIERS OF THE FOURTH CORPS: Paragraph II, General Orders No.5, dated Headquarters Military Division of the Mississippi, April 5, 1864, relieves me from command of the Fourth Army Corps, and from duty with the Army of the Cumberland.

The court-room was crowded yesterday by members of the Bar, reporters and spectators, anxious to learn the issue of the Horace Greeley contempt case, the citation in which was returnable yesterday morning. The arrival of Mr. GREELEY was looked for with interest, but he did not appear personally, being represented in court by J.T. WILLIAMS, Esq., his counsel.

In the Democrat of yesterday morning we made brief mention of an attack being made upon the camp of Col. GALLUP, at Paintsville, Johnson County, Ky. Since then we have learned the following additional particulars: The attack was made about 10 o'clock on Wednesday morning by over 1,000 rebel infantry, who were supposed to have been under command of Gen. JONES, who was reported to be in Owsley County a few days since.

The Boston Traveller of Monday evening, says: "Mr. GREEN, the murderer of young CONVERSE, was arraigned at Lowell, this morning, and pleaded guilty to murder in the second degree. He was informed that this plea was not possible under the indictment. After consultation with Messrs. SWEETSER and GRIFFIN, he pleaded guilty in the first degree. Judge HOAR postponed sentence till Monday next. The accused manifested no unusual emotion. The court-room was crowded with spectators."
The funds on the 8th were steadily maintained. Consols closed at 91 1/8@5/8 for Money.
The steamer Liberty arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing New-Orleans papers of the 13th inst.

The investigation in the case of the boiler explosion on the United States steamer Chenango, was continued before Coroner NORRIS and jury, yesterday afternoon, commencing at 3 o'clock. The following evidence was elicited:

Positive information has been received at headquarters that the main body of LONGSTREET'S veterans have succeeded in effecting a junction with LEE. LONGSTREET carried to East Tennessee 18,000 men, but returned with less than 12,000. Scouts just returned from within the enemy's lines report that troops from JOE JOHNSTON'S army and from Charleston are arriving at Gordonsville. Rebel conscripts are coming in at the rate of a thousand a day.

Rev. CALVIN FAIRBANKS, who was implicated with DELIA WEDSTER in enticing slaves from Kentucky, several years since, and who had served twelve of a sentence of fifteen years in the Frankfort Penitentiary, was pardoned by Lieut.-Gov. JACOBS, while performing executive duties during the Gov. BRAMLETTE'S absence from the State.

The recent vote in Tennessee for county and district officials is an encouraging omen of the growing Union feeling that is steadily pervading the population. From 48,000 to 50,000 votes were cast, about one-third of the whole vote of the State just previous to the breaking out of the rebellion.
The House immediately went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, Mr. WASHBURNS, of Illinois, (Union,) in the Chair, and resumed the consideration of the Internel Revenue Bill.
The Royal mail steamer Australasian, which left Liverpool at 10:30 on the morning of the 9th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 10th of April, arrived here at 9 o'clock last evening.

Last evening's Journal publishes extracts from private letters from members of the Chicago Mercantile Battery, dated April 12, to the effect that on the day of the recent disaster to the Thirteenth Army Corps, Gen. A.J. SMITH, with the Nineteenth Army Corps, engaged the enemy and defeated them, capturing 2,000 prisoners and 20 cannon.
